ADOPTING ORDINANCE
 
TITLE 1: ADMINISTRATION
CHAPTER 1: PRINCETON CITY CODE
Section
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Code Alterations
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon adoption by the city council, this city code is hereby declared to be and
shall hereafter constitute the official city code of Princeton. This city code
of ordinances shall be known and cited as the PRINCETON CITY CODE and is hereby
published by authority of the city council and shall be supplemented to
incorporate the most recent legislation of the city as provided in section
1-1-3 of this chapter. Any reference to the number of any section contained
herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same number, its
appropriate chapter and title headings, and to the general penalty clause
relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to
this city code by title in any legal documents.
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
The city code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in all administrative tribunals of the
state as the ordinances of the city of general and permanent effect, except the
excluded ordinances enumerated in section
1-2-1 of this title.
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
   A.   Amendments to any of the provisions of this city code may be made by
amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this
code in substantially the following language: “That section      of the city
code of the city of Princeton is hereby amended to read as follows.”. The new
provisions shall then be set out in full as desired.
   B.   If a new section not heretofore existing in this city code is to be
added, the following language may be used: “That the city code of the city of
Princeton is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered
               , which section reads as follows.”. The new section shall then
be set out in full as desired.
(1989 Code § 1-8)
   C.   All such amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately
forwarded to the codifier, and the said ordinance material shall be prepared
for insertion in its proper place in each copy of this city code. Each such
replacement page shall be properly identified and shall be inserted in each
individual copy of the city code.
1-1-4: CODE ALTERATIONS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface
in any way any section or any page of this city code in such a manner that the
meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Replacement pages may
be inserted according to the official instructions when so authorized by the
city council. The city clerk shall see that the replacement pages are properly
inserted in the official copies maintained in the office of the clerk.
   B.   Any person having in his or her custody an official copy of this city
code shall make every effort to maintain it in an up to date and efficient
manner. He or she shall see to the immediate insertion of new or replacement
pages when such are delivered to him or her or made available to him or her
through the office of the city clerk. Such code books, while in actual
possession of officials and other interested persons, shall be and remain the
property of the city and shall be returned to the office of the clerk when
directed so to do by order of the city.
(1989 Code § 1-12)
CHAPTER 2: SAVINGS CLAUSE
Section
1-2-1: Repeal Of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Court Proceedings
1-2-3: Severability Clause
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
   A.   All general ordinances of the city passed prior to the adoption of this
city code are hereby repealed, except such as are included in this city code or
are by necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to the saving
clauses contained in the following sections), and excluding the following
ordinances which are not hereby repealed:
      1.   Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the
city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of
the city’s indebtedness; any contract or obligation assumed by the city; or the
issuance of warrants.
      2.   Any ordinance not included in this code fixing salaries of officers
or employees of the city, or any ordinance consistent with this code that fixes
fees.
      3.   Any appropriation ordinance.
      4.   Any right or franchise granted by the city council to any person.
      5.   Any public utility ordinance relating to railroads or railroad
crossings with streets and other public ways, or relating to the conduct,
duties, service or rates of public utilities, to the extent that it is
consistent with this code.
      6.   Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating,
relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street, public way
or other public place in the city, or acquiring or vacating any easement in the
city.
      7.   Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any
street in the city.
      8.   Any ordinance providing for local improvements or assessing taxes
therefor, or levying any other taxes that are not superseded by this code.
      9.   Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the
city.
      10.   Any ordinance annexing property to the city, describing the city
boundary or setting out the location or boundary of any city park.
      11.   Any ordinance relating to specific elections.
      12.   Any ordinance relating to the transfer or acceptance of property.
      13.   Any temporary ordinance.
      14.   Any special ordinance.
   B.   All such ordinances, as now or hereafter amended, are recognized as
continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length
in this code.
(1989 Code § 1-10)
1-2-2: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
   A.   Prior Acts: No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a
former ordinance, whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not,
as to any offense committed against such former ordinance or as to any act
done, any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued
or claim arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect
any such offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or
punishment so incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new
ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform
to the ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as
practicable. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment is mitigated by any
provision of a new ordinance, such provision may be, by the consent of the
party affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes
effect.
   B.   Extend To All Repeals: This section shall extend to all repeals, either
by express words or implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making
any new provisions upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
   C.   Current Pending Actions: Nothing contained in this chapter shall be
construed as abating any action pending under or by virtue of any general
ordinance of the city herein repealed, and the provisions of all general
ordinances contained in this code shall be deemed to be continuing provisions
and not a new enactment of the same provision; nor shall this chapter be deemed
as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to
accrue, or as affecting the liability of any person, or as waiving any right of
the city under any ordinance or provision thereof in force at the time of the
adoption of this code.
(1989 Code § 1-11)
1-2-3: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this city
code, or any codes or portions of codes adopted herein by reference, is for any
reason held to be unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any court of
competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or
effectiveness of the remaining portions of this code, or any codes or portions
of codes adopted herein by reference. The city council hereby declares that it
would have passed each section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or
phrase thereof irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections,
subsections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses or phrases be declared
unconstitutional, invalid or ineffective.
CHAPTER 3: DEFINITIONS; INTERPRETATION
Section
1-3-1: Rules Of Interpretation
1-3-2: General Definitions
1-3-3: Catchlines
1-3-1: RULES OF INTERPRETATION:
   A.   Liberal Construction: All general provisions, terms, phrases and
expressions contained in this code shall be liberally construed in order that
the true intent and meaning of the mayor and city council may be fully carried
out.
   B.   Minimum Requirements: In the interpretation and application of any
provision of this code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirement adopted
for the promotion of the public health, safety and general welfare.
   C.   Delegation Of Authority: Whenever a provision appears requiring the
head of a department or some other city officer to do some act or perform some
duty, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department or other
officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the
required act or perform the duty unless the terms of the provision or section
specify otherwise.
   D.   Gender: The use of any gender based pronoun should not be construed to
be gender biased, but is only used for grammatical simplicity.
   E.   May; Shall: The word “may” is permissive; the word “shall” is
mandatory.
   F.   Nontechnical And Technical Words: Words and phrases shall be construed
according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words
and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate
meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning.
   G.   Number: A word importing the singular number only may extend and be
applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing.
   H.   Officers And Employees Generally: Whenever any officer or employee is
referred to by title only, such reference shall be construed as if followed by
the words “of the city of Princeton”.
   I.   Tense: Words used in the past or present tense include the future as
well as the past and present.
   J.   Intent To Defraud: Whenever an intent to defraud is required in order
to constitute an offense, it shall be sufficient if an intent appears to
defraud any person.
   K.   Ordinance: The word “ordinance” contained in the ordinances of the city
has been changed in the content of this city code to “title”, “chapter”,
“section” and/or “subsection” or words of like import for organizational and
clarification purposes only. Such change to city ordinances is not meant to
amend passage and effective dates of such original ordinances.
(1989 Code § 1-4)
1-3-2: GENERAL DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this code, they shall have
the meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
CITY: The city of Princeton, in the county of Bureau and the state of Illinois.
CODE: This city code.
COUNTY: The county of Bureau in the state of Illinois.
FISCAL YEAR: The period beginning May 1 of each year and ending April 30 of the
next succeeding year.
ILLINOIS COMPILED STATUTES (ILCS): The Illinois Compiled Statutes, the latest
publication thereof.
MUNICIPAL YEAR: The period beginning May 1 of each year and ending April 30 of
the next succeeding year.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, corporation, joint stock association or
the state or any subdivision thereof, and includes any trustee, receiver,
assignee or personal representative thereof.
STATE: The state of Illinois.
(1989 Code §§ 1-2, 1-4)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of the city code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify or
in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any
section hereof, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when
any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted.
CHAPTER 4: GENERAL PENALTY
Section
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-2: Application Of Provisions
1-4-3: Non-Liability Of Officers And Employees
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
   A.   General Penalty Imposed:
      1.   Fine; Imprisonment: Unless specifically provided elsewhere in this
code, any person found to have been in violation of any of the terms and
provisions of this code shall be fined in an amount not less than fifty dollars
($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the first
offense, and not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for a second or subsequent offense. No
imprisonment for failure to pay such fine, penalty or cost shall exceed six (6)
months for each offense. Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed to
be a separate offense.
      2.   Additional Penalties: In addition to the fine described in
subsection Al of this section, the circuit court may impose a period of
“conditional discharge”, as defined in 730 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-1-4,
or “court supervision”, as defined in 730 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-1-21,
for a period of up to six (6) months, an order of restitution, an order to
perform community service, an order to complete an education program and/or any
other appropriate penalties or conditions authorized in any section of this
code or stand alone ordinance or any conditions for conditional discharge set
forth in 730 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-6-3 or for court supervision in 730
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-6-3.1, as the foregoing are amended from time to
time.
      3.   Costs And Fees: Any person violating the terms or provisions of this
code shall be subject, in addition to the penalties set out in this subsection,
to the payment of court costs and reasonable attorney fees.
      4.   Default In Payment: A default in the payment of a fine or any
installment of a fine may be collected by any means authorized for the
collection of monetary judgments. The city attorney may retain attorneys and
private collection agents for the purpose of collecting any default in payment
of any fine or installment of that fine. Any fees or costs incurred by the city
with respect to attorneys or private collection agents retained by the city
attorney under this subsection A4 shall be charged to the offender.
   B.   Acts Consistent With Criminal Laws Of State: If, by the terms of this
code or any ordinance, an act that would be consistent with the criminal laws
of the state is declared to be a misdemeanor, the penalty therefor shall be for
a period of incarceration in a penal institution other than a penitentiary not
to exceed six (6) months, and the matter shall be prosecuted under the rules of
criminal procedure of the state, and the city shall be required to establish
guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. This subsection shall not apply to city code
provisions adopted pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-5-1, 5/11-5-
2, 5/11-5-3, 5/11-5-4, 5/11-5-5, 5/11-5-6, 5/11-40-1, 5/11-40-2, 5/11-40-2a, 5/
11-40-3, 5/11-80-9 and 5/11-80-16.
   C.   Limitation; Compliance With Statute: The provisions of subsection A of
this section notwithstanding, no penalty shall be greater than that established
by state statute for the same offense.
(2017 Code)
1-4-2: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   Application Of Penalty: The penalty provided in this chapter shall be
applicable to every section of this city code the same as though it were a part
of each and every separate section unless otherwise indicated. Any person
convicted of a violation of any section of this city code where a duty is
prescribed or obligation imposed, or where any action which is of a continuing
nature is forbidden or is declared to be unlawful, shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day such
duty or obligation remains unperformed or such act continues, unless otherwise
specifically provided in this city code.
   B.   Acts Punishable Under Different Sections: In all cases where the same
offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of
this city code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed, but
not more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same
offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or permit shall not be
considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced.
   C.   Breach Of Provisions: Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to
do any act constitutes a breach of any section or provision of this city code
and there shall be no fine or penalty specifically declared for such breach,
the provisions of this chapter shall apply.
(2017 Code)
1-4-3: NON-LIABILITY OF OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES:
No provision of this city code designating the duties of any officer or
employee shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for
any fine or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the
intent of the city council to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the
duty.
(2017 Code)
ARTICLE 4A: ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION SYSTEM
Section
1-4A-1: Department Created; Purpose
1-4A-2: State Regulations Adopted
1-4A-3: Administrative Hearings Supervisor
1-4A-4: Administrative Hearing Officers
1-4A-5: Charging Document Procedure
1-4A-6: Hearings
1-4A-7: Representation At Hearings
1-4A-8: Defaults
1-4A-9: Payment Of Fines
1-4A-10: Enforcement Of Orders
1-4A-11: Prepayment In Lieu Of Appearance
1-4A-12: Procedures Not Exclusive
1-4A-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED; PURPOSE:
There is created a separate and independent department of the city to be known
as the code hearing department. The code hearing department shall have as its
purpose to provide for the equitable and efficient enforcement of the city
code, through an administrative adjudication proceeding before an
administrative hearing officer.
(Ord. O-16-003, 4-18-2016)
1-4A-2: STATE REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
   A.   The city of Princeton hereby adopts in its entirety division 2.2 of
article 1 of the Illinois municipal code, being 65 ILCS 5/1-2.2-1 et seq. The
code hearing department shall have the power and authority under this
subsection A and division 2.2 of article 1 of the Illinois municipal code to
enforce any municipal ordinance by an administrative adjudication proceeding,
except for:
      1.   Building code violations that must be adjudicated pursuant to
division 31.1 of article 11 of the Illinois municipal code and section
1-4A-2B of this article;
      2.   Any offense under the Illinois vehicle code or a similar offense
that is a traffic regulation governing the movement of vehicles; or
      3.   Any reportable offense under section 6-204 of the Illinois vehicle
code.
   B.   The city of Princeton hereby adopts in its entirety division 31.1 of
article 11 of the Illinois municipal code, being 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1 et seq..
The code hearing department shall have the power and authority under this
subsection B and division 31.1 of the article 11 of the Illinois municipal code
to enforce any municipal ordinance, law, housing or building code or zoning
ordinance that establishes construction, plumbing, heating, electrical, fire
prevention, sanitation or other health and safety standards that are applicable
to structures in a municipality or any municipal ordinance that requires, after
notice, the cutting of weeds, the removal of garbage and debris, the removal of
inoperable motor vehicles, or the abatement of nuisances from private property.
(Ord. O-16-003, 4-18-2016)
1-4A-3: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS SUPERVISOR:
   A.   The code hearing department shall be directed by an administrative
hearings supervisor, who shall be appointed by the city manager, or his or her
designee. The administrative hearings supervisor’s function is to manage and
oversee the prosecution and/or correction of code violations subject to the
jurisdiction of the code hearing department in the manner provided in this
article. The administrative hearings supervisor’s duties shall include:
      1.   Reviewing the qualifications of potential administrative hearing
officers and making recommendations to the mayor regarding appointments;
      2.   Reviewing and distributing notices and charging documents as may be
required under this chapter;
      3.   Establishing such rules and regulations as may be necessary for the
effective operation of the code hearing department;
      4.   Carrying out such other duties as may be reasonably necessary for
the proper and efficient administration of this article.
   B.   The administrative hearings supervisor may also appoint other persons
to serve in the code hearing department.
   C.   The administrative hearings supervisor, or his or her designee, shall
also act as the traffic compliance administrator and perform those duties
required by 625 ILCS 5/11-208.3, as amended, in regard to violations for the
standing, parking or condition of motor vehicles.
(Ord. O-16-003, 4-18-2016)
1-4A-4: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING OFFICERS:
   A.   Appointment: The mayor shall have the authority to appoint
administrative hearing officers, with the advice and consent of the city
council, to preside over administrative hearings in the city, including,
without limitation, hearings regarding vehicle impoundments under title 5,
chapter 9 of this code.
   B.   Qualifications:
      1.   Prior to conducting administrative adjudication proceedings under
this article, the administrative hearing officer shall have successfully
completed a formal training program that includes the following:
         a.   Instruction on the rules of procedure of the administrative
hearings over which the administrative hearing officers shall preside;
         b.   Orientation to each subject area of the code violations they will
adjudicate;
         c.   Observation of administrative hearings; and
         d.   Participation in hypothetical cases, including ruling on evidence
and issuing final orders.
      2.   In addition, the administrative hearing officer must be an attorney
licensed to practice law in the state of Illinois for at least three (3) years,
and be in good standing with the attorney registration and disciplinary
commission of the supreme court of Illinois.
   C.   Scope Of Authority: The authority of an administrative hearing officer
shall encompass all acts necessary to conduct fair and impartial adjudicatory
hearings, including, but not limited to:
      1.   Hearing testimony and accepting evidence that is relevant to the
existence of the code violation.
      2.   Administering oaths and affirmations to witnesses.
      3.   At the request of any party or on the administrative hearing
officer’s own motion, issuing subpoenas for the attendance of relevant
witnesses.
      4.   Asking questions of the parties and witnesses, as necessary to
ensure the clarity and completeness of the testimony and the record.
      5.   Preserving the record of the hearing, including all exhibits and
evidence admitted into the record at the hearing.
      6.   Issuing a signed, written finding, decision and order following the
conclusion of an administrative hearing, stating whether a city code violation
exists.
      7.   Upon finding a respondent liable for violating one or more charged
code provisions, imposing penalties, sanctions, costs of the hearing
(including, but not limited to, the administrative hearing officer’s fee), or
other relief consistent with applicable city code provisions.
      8.   Regulating the course of the hearing in accordance with this
article, the rules adopted by the administrative hearings supervisor for the
conduct of administrative hearings, and other applicable law.
(Ord. O-16-003, 4-18-2016)
1-4A-5: CHARGING DOCUMENT PROCEDURE:
   A.   All matters to be adjudicated by the administrative hearing officer
shall be commenced against the party alleged to have violated one or more code
provisions by issuing and serving upon that party a charging document in
accordance with the requirements of this section. The charging document shall
be issued by a city officer or employee authorized to exercise code enforcement
authority and served as provided for in subsection D of this section.
   B.   Any charging document issued pursuant to this section shall contain, at
a minimum, the following information:
      1.   The name, city department, position and identification number, if
applicable, of the person issuing the charging document.
      2.   The name and address of the person or entity being charged with one
or more code violations (“respondent”).
      3.   The section(s) of the code alleged to have been violated.
      4.   The date, time and place of the alleged violation(s), and, if
applicable, the address of the structure where the violation was observed.
      5.   A description of the activity, conduct or circumstances giving rise
to the allegations set forth in the charging document.
      6.   The complainant’s name if the complainant is not the issuing city
officer or employee, and the names of witnesses to the violation(s).
      7.   The signature of the city officer or employee issuing the charging
document.
   C.   The charging document shall be forwarded to the code hearing department
where a docket number shall be stamped on all copies of the report and a
hearing date shall be noted in the blank spaces provided for that purpose on
the form.
   D.   The respondent named in a charging document shall be served with a copy
of the charging document, along with a summons commanding the respondent to
appear at the hearing. Service may be given in any of the following ways:
      1.   By first class mail; or
      2.   By personal service; or
      3.   By any other means permitted by law for service of civil summons; or
      4.   In the case of violations adjudicated pursuant to section
1-4A-2B, if the name of the owner of the structure where the alleged violation
is observed cannot be ascertained or service on the owner cannot be made by one
of the methods listed above, service may be made on the owner by posting a copy
of the charging document and summons on the front door of the structure where
the violation is found, not less than 20 days before the hearing is scheduled.
   E.   The charging document must be a multi-copy violation notice.
1-4A-6: HEARINGS:
   A.   All hearings conducted pursuant to this chapter shall be open to the
public and shall be presided over by a duly appointed administrative hearing
officer who is charged with providing the parties a full and fair opportunity
to be heard.
   B.   All hearings shall be conducted on the date set for hearing. In rare
instances and for good cause shown, a continuance may be granted at the
discretion of the administrative hearing officer. Lack of preparation shall not
be grounds for a continuance.
   C.   Parties to an administrative hearing may be represented by an attorney,
present witnesses and cross examine opposing witnesses. All testimony shall be
given under oath. Parties may request the administrative hearing officer to
issue subpoenas according to the authority granted in this article.
   D.   The formal rules of evidence applicable to judicial proceedings shall
not apply to hearings authorized by this article. The hearing officer shall
accept any evidence relevant to the existence or non-existence of a violation.
   E.   No violation may be established except upon proof by a preponderance of
the evidence.
   F.   No action for eviction, abatement of a nuisance, forcible entry and
detainer or other similar proceeding shall be threatened or instituted against
an occupant of a dwelling or other structure in the city solely because such
occupant agrees to testify or testifies at an administrative hearing.
   G.   It shall be a defense to a code violation charged under section
1-4A-2.B of this article if the property owner, his or her attorney or any
other agent or representative proves, to the hearing officer’s satisfaction,
that:
      1.   The code violation alleged in the notice does not in fact exist, or
at the time of the hearing, the violation has been remedied or removed;
      2.   The code violation has been caused by the current property occupants
and that in spite of reasonable attempts by the property owner to maintain the
dwelling free of such violations, the current occupants continue to cause the
violations;
      3.   An occupant or resident of the dwelling has refused entry to the
property owner or his or her agent to all or a part of the dwelling for the
purpose of correcting the code violation.
   H.   The administrative hearings supervisor shall determine the manner in
which the record shall be preserved. Such preservation may be made by tape
recording or other appropriate means. Recording by any means by any member of
the public is prohibited unless expressly authorized by the administrative
hearings supervisor. The record of all hearings before an administrative
hearing officer shall include a copy of the findings, decision and order of the
administrative hearing officer’s final determination.
   I.   1.   At the conclusion of a hearing, the administrative hearing officer
shall issue a written determination of whether or not a code violation exists.
The determination shall be designated as findings, decision and order, and
shall include:
         a.   The hearing officer’s findings of fact;
         b.   A decision whether or not a code violation exists; and
         c.   An order stating the sanction imposed, or dismissing the case if
the violation is found not to be proven.
      2.   A copy of the findings, decision and order will be served on the
respondent within five (5) days after it is issued, in the same manner as
provided for service of the summons and charging document under section
1-4A-5D of this article.
   J.   If the administrative hearing officer issues a written determination of
liability, he or she may impose fines, costs of the hearing (including, but not
limited to, any fee charged by the administrative hearing officer), and other
sanctions as provided by subsection
1-4A-4C7 of this article, and as are consistent with the specific code
provision(s) found to have been violated.
   K.   A written determination issued pursuant to this section shall
constitute a final determination for purposes of judicial review and is subject
to review under the Illinois administrative review law.
(Ord. O-16-003, 4-18-2016)
1-4A-7: REPRESENTATION AT HEARINGS:
   A.   The case for the city may be presented by a city employee or by an
attorney designated by the mayor but not by an employee or other representative
of the code hearing department.
   B.   The case for the respondent may be presented by the respondent or by an
attorney or agent of the respondent. An attorney or agent appearing at an
adjudicatory hearing on behalf of a respondent shall present the administrative
hearing officer with a signed entry of appearance form.
(Ord. O-16-003, 4-18-2016)
1-4A-8: DEFAULTS:
   A.   If, at the time set for hearing, the respondent, or his or her attorney
or agent of record, fails to appear, the administrative hearing officer may
find the respondent in default and proceed with the hearing and accept evidence
relevant to the existence of a code violation. A copy of the default finding,
decision and order shall be served in any manner permitted by this article. The
order shall advise the respondent of the procedure for setting aside the
default judgment.
   B.   A respondent against whom a default judgment has been entered may file
a motion with the code hearing department to set aside the default judgment and
request a new hearing. A motion to set aside a default judgment may be filed at
any time if the respondent alleges lack of subject matter or personal
jurisdiction. In all other cases, the motion must be filed within twenty one
(21) days of entry of the default judgment. A motion to set aside a default
judgment shall set forth the reason(s) the respondent failed to appear on the
original hearing date. The administrative hearing officer shall hear and rule
on the motion. If the administrative hearing officer grants the motion, a
hearing will be held immediately on the alleged code violation(s) set forth in
the charging document unless the respondent requests another hearing date and
presents good cause for continuing the hearing.
   C.   If any default judgment is set aside pursuant to this section, the
administrative hearing officer shall have authority to enter an order
extinguishing any lien which has been recorded for any debt due and owing the
city as a result of the vacated default judgment.
(Ord. O-16-003, 4-18-2016)
1-4A-9: PAYMENT OF FINES:
   A.   All fines and other payments imposed pursuant to this article must be
made within thirty (30) calendar days.
   B.   Any fine or portion of a fine that is not paid in accordance with this
section may be collected by the city by any means authorized by applicable law.
1-4A-10: ENFORCEMENT OF ORDERS:
   A.   Any fine, sanction or costs imposed by an administrative hearing
officer’s order that remain unpaid after the exhaustion of, or the failure to
exhaust, judicial review procedures, unless stayed by a court of competent
jurisdiction, shall be a debt due and owing the city and may be collected in
accordance with applicable law.
   B.   After the expiration of the period for which judicial review may be
sought, unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, the determination
of liability of an administrative hearing officer, other than for code
violations adjudicated pursuant to subsection
1-4A-2B of this article, may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment
entered by a court of competent jurisdiction.
   C.   In any case in which a respondent fails to comply with an
administrative hearing officer’s order to correct a code violation, any
expenses incurred by the city to enforce the administrative hearing officer’s
order including, but not limited to, attorney fees, court costs and costs
related to property demolition or foreclosure shall be a debt due and owing the
city. Prior to any expenses being fixed by an administrative hearing officer
pursuant to this subsection, the respondent shall be provided with notice that
directs the respondent to appear at a hearing before an administrative hearing
officer to determine whether the respondent has failed to comply with the
administrative hearing officer’s order. The notice shall set the place and the
time for the hearing, which shall not be less than seven (7) days from the date
the notice is served. Notice may be served by any manner set forth in
subsection
1-4A-5D of this article.
   D.   Nothing in this section shall prevent the city from enforcing or
seeking to enforce any order of an administrative hearing officer in any manner
provided by law.
(Ord. O-16-003, 4-18-2016)
1-4A-11: PREPAYMENT IN LIEU OF APPEARANCE:
   A.   Respondents charged under this article with the offenses listed in this
section shall be eligible for prepayment of a fine, in such amount listed below
in lieu of appearing at an adjudicatory hearing. Where applicable, the charging
document shall notify the respondent of the amount that may be prepaid in lieu
of appearing at the adjudicatory hearing.
      1.   Violations relating to building, zoning and property maintenance and
abandoned or inoperable vehicle violations, the prepayment fine is one hundred
dollars ($100.00).
      2.   Curfew violations, the prepayment fine is seventy five dollars
($75.00).
      3.   Soliciting without a permit violation, the prepayment fine is
seventy five dollars ($75.00).
      4.   Violations relating to open burning, the prepayment fine is seventy
five dollars ($75.00).
      5.   Animal related violations, the prepayment fine is seventy five
dollars ($75.00).
      6.   Violations relating to the operation of motor vehicles, the
prepayment fine is one hundred dollars ($100.00); except, that seat belt
violations shall be fifty dollars ($50.00).
      7.   Violations of the city noise ordinance, including animal and vehicle
noises, the prepayment fine is seventy five dollars ($75.00).
      8.   Violations relating to the possession or use of tobacco products,
the prepayment fine is fifty dollars ($50.00).
      9.   Littering violations, the prepayment fine is fifty dollars ($50.00).
      10.   Parking violations regarding persons with disabilities, the
prepayment fine is the statutorily required minimum fine as established, and as
may be amended from time to time, by the Illinois general assembly.
      11.   Snow route parking violations, the prepayment fine is twenty five
dollars ($25.00).
      12.   For all other parking violations not referenced in this section,
the prepayment fine is twenty dollars ($20.00). If a parking violation
continues for longer than 24 hours, the fine increases to twenty-five dollars
($25.00), and if the violation continues longer than 72 hours, the fine
increases to fifty dollars ($50.00).
   B.   The prepayment of a fine under this section shall constitute an
admission of guilt by the person charged.
   C.   Persons charged with an offense not listed in this section and non-
first time offenders shall be required to appear at an adjudicatory hearing.
For the purpose of this section, a “first time offender” shall be defined as a
person who has never, at any time, been found guilty of violating any of the
offenses subject to this article.
   D.   Persons under the age of eighteen (18) shall not be eligible for the
prepayment option under this section unless agreed to, in writing, by their
parent or legal guardian.
   E.   The chief of police or his or her designee is authorized to establish
the procedures for exercising the prepayment option under this section. Said
procedures shall be recited on the charging document served under this article.
(Ord. O-16-003, 4-18-2016)
1-4A-12: PROCEDURES NOT EXCLUSIVE:
The adoption of this article does not preclude the city from using other lawful
methods to enforce the provisions of this code.
(Ord. O-16-003, 4-18-2016)
CHAPTER 5: FORM OF GOVERNMENT
Section
1-5-1: Managerial Form Of Government
1-5-1: MANAGERIAL FORM OF GOVERNMENT:
The government of the city shall be the managerial form of municipal
government.
(1989 Code § 2-181)
CHAPTER 6: MAYOR
Section
1-6-1: Oath Of Office
1-6-2: Powers And Duties
1-6-1: OATH OF OFFICE:
The mayor, before entering upon the duties of his or her office, shall take and
subscribe the following oath or affirmation:
I do solemnly swear (affirm) that I will support the constitution of the United
States and the constitution of the state of Illinois and ordinances of the city
of Princeton, and that I will faithfully discharge the duties of the office of
mayor of the city of Princeton, Illinois, to the best of my ability.
which oath or affirmation, so subscribed, shall be filed in the office of the
city clerk.
1-6-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Generally:
      1.   The mayor shall have and exercise all the powers and perform all the
duties provided or prescribed by the provisions of this code, and not in
conflict with the provisions of this title, or with the provisions contained in
the law governing the managerial form of municipal government, and shall have
and exercise all the powers and perform all the duties provided or prescribed
by law.
(1989 Code § 2-51; amd. 2017 Code)
      2.   The mayor shall devote so much time to the duties of his or her
office as a faithful and efficient discharge thereof may require, or as may be
required by statute. He or she shall see that all provisions of this code are
duly enforced. He or she shall preside over and preserve order and decorum at
all meetings of the city council and shall generally do and perform all acts
and things which are enjoined upon him or her by the laws of the state and the
provisions of this code.
(1989 Code § 2-56)
   B.   Appointments: The mayor shall appoint members to all boards and
commissions of the city, unless otherwise provided by statute or this code. All
appointments made by the Mayor pursuant to this code shall be subject to
approval by the city council.
   C.   Voting: The Mayor shall have the right to vote on all questions coming
before the council, but the mayor shall have no power to veto.
   D.   Inspect Books And Records: The mayor shall at all times have the power
to examine and inspect the books, records and papers of any agent, employee or
officer of the city.
   E.   Interpret Ordinances: The mayor shall settle all disputes in regard to
the interpretation of ordinances. He or she shall give his or her decision
after consultation with the city attorney.
(1989 Code § 2-56)
   F.   Ceremonial Duties: The mayor shall preside over all ceremonial
occasions of the city.
CHAPTER 7: CITY COUNCIL
Section
1-7-1: Composition; Term Of Office
1-7-2: Oath Of Office
1-7-3: Meetings
1-7-4: Rules Of Order
1-7-5: Powers; Duties
1-7-6: Ordinances And Resolutions
1-7-1: COMPOSITION; TERM OF OFFICE:
The city council shall consist of the mayor and four (4) commissioners. At the
first meeting in May, the council shall assign the various commissioners to
their departments, one to each, for a four (4) year term; except, that the
mayor shall be the commissioner of public affairs.
(1989 Code § 2-26)
1-7-2: OATH OF OFFICE:
All council members shall take the oath of office as nearly as may be in the
form prescribed in this title for the mayor.
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
1-6-1A of this title
1-7-3: MEETINGS:
   A.   Regular Meetings: The regular meetings of the city council shall be
held in the council chamber in the city hall on the first and third Mondays of
each month at six o’clock (6:00) p.m., except when such days shall be legal
holidays, in which case, the council shall meet at the same hour on the next
day following.
   B.   Adjourned Meetings: Adjourned meetings of the council may be held for
the purpose of completing any unfinished business of a regular meeting at such
time or times as may be determined by the council.
(1989 Code § 2-28; amd. Ord. O-23-009, 7-3-2023)
   C.   Special Meetings: The mayor or any two (2) council members may call a
special meeting of the city council on forty eight (48) hours’ notice; but if
all the members of the council are present at any special meeting, the failure
to give such notice or the failure to have the meeting called in this manner
shall not affect the validity of the meeting. The city clerk shall serve or
have served notices of a special meeting if requested to do so by the mayor or
any council member.
(1989 Code § 2-29)
   D.   Presiding Officer: The mayor shall preside over the meetings of the
council when he or she is present. In the absence of the mayor, council members
may choose a presiding officer.
(1989 Code § 2-30)
   E.   Quorum: Any three (3) members of the council shall constitute a quorum,
and the affirmative vote of three (3) members shall be required for the passage
of any motion, resolution or ordinance, as is required by statute.
(1989 Code § 2-31)
   F.   Voting: Every member of the city council shall vote on all questions in
which he or she is not directly and personally interested which may be brought
before the council for its action in such manner as to require a vote to be
taken thereon.
(1989 Code § 2-33)
   G.   Public Participation Policy:
      1.   At each regular meeting and special meeting of the Princeton city
council, and at the meetings of all city of Princeton standing committees, the
citizens of Princeton and employees of the city of Princeton may express
comments or concerns with regard to city business or issues that affect the
city of Princeton at the appropriate time.
      2.   Those persons wishing to make public comment, when allowed to do so
by the mayor, shall abide by the following public participation rules:
         a.   The speaker shall identify himself or herself by name and may
publicly address the city council when recognized to do so by the mayor or
presiding officer.
         b.   The speaker may have up to three (3) minutes to address the city
council. By request from the speaker, more time may be permitted at the
discretion of the mayor or presiding officer.
         c.   The speaker shall not talk above the voice of the mayor or
presiding officer, nor shall the speaker talk over other people or interrupt
other speakers.
         d.   The speaker shall stop talking when requested to do so by the
mayor or presiding officer.
         e.   The Mayor and City Council shall not be subjected to abusive,
harassing or violent language or behavior by the speaker. Those wishing to make
comment shall do so with respect and civility and they shall not use obscene or
vulgar language, fighting words or defamatory comments. Such comments are
disruptive to an orderly meeting.
         f.   The cumulative elapsed time for a public participation period
shall not exceed twenty (20) minutes. If a large number of those wishing to
make comment are present and the public participation period may not be timely
completed, the mayor or presiding officer may reduce the amount of time each
individual gets to make their comments. In unusual circumstances, the mayor or
presiding officer may extend the maximum elapsed time limit.
         g.   Speakers shall know that neither the mayor nor city council
members are obligated to respond to any questions or comments made by the
speaker during public participation.
         h.   Any speaker failing to comply with the foregoing rules may be
removed from the meeting.
(Ord. O-21-013, 5-3-2021)
1-7-4: RULES OF ORDER:
The following rules shall govern the procedure of the council:
Rule 1: No vote of the city council shall be reconsidered or rescinded at a
special meeting unless, at such special meeting, there are present as large a
number of members as were present when such vote was taken.
Rule 2: Any report of a committee of the city council shall be deferred for
final action thereon to the next regular meeting of the council, after the
report is made, upon the request of any member present.
Rule 3: All special committees shall be appointed by the mayor and shall
consist of three (3) members each, unless some other number is specified, and
the first person named shall be the chair.
Rule 4: On the acceptance of a final report from a special committee, the
committee shall be considered discharged without a vote, unless otherwise
ordered.
Rule 5: The order of business shall be as provided on the agenda published for
the meeting. Before any petition, communication or memorial address of the city
council shall be received and read at the table, whether the same shall be
introduced by the chair or a member, a brief statement of the contents of the
petition or memorial shall verbally be made by the introducer.
Rule 6: No member shall speak to another or otherwise interrupt the business or
read in any newspaper while the journals or public papers are being read or
when any member is speaking in debate.
Rule 7: When a member shall be called to order by the chair or another member,
he or she shall sit down, and every question of order shall be decided by the
chair without debate, subject to the appeal of the council. Upon such appeal,
the ayes and nays shall be taken and the chair may call for the sense of the
council on any question of order.
Rule 8: If the member is called to order by a member for words spoken, the
exceptional words shall be immediately taken down in writing, so that the chair
may be better able to judge the matter.
Rule 9: No motion shall be debated until seconded.
Rule 10: When a motion shall be made and seconded, it shall be reduced in
writing, delivered at the table and read before the same shall debated.
Rule 11: When a test question is under debate, the only motion and order shall
be:
   1.   To adjourn;
   2.   The previous question;
   3.   To lay on the table;
   4.   To postpone indefinitely;
   5.   To postpone to a certain day;
   6.   To refer; and
   7.   To amend, and such motions shall have precedence in the order arranged
in this rule, the first three (3) to be decided without debate.
Rule 12: A motion to adjourn the council shall always be in order; except:
   1.   When a member is in possession of the floor;
   2.   While the ayes and nays are being called;
   3.   When the members are voting;
   4.   When adjournment was the last preceding motion; and
   5.   When it has been decided that the previous question shall be taken.
Rule 13: When a question has been once made and carried in the affirmative or
negative, it shall be in order for any member of the majority to move for the
reconsideration thereof, but no motion for reconsideration shall be in order
unless made at the same or next succeeding meeting on which the vote was taken.
Rule 14: No person, other than a member, shall be permitted to introduce any
business personally before the council, except by permission.
Rule 15: New rules may be made, or all or any of the present rules may be
annulled, changed or suspended, at any regular meeting of the council on the
vote of three (3) members, such vote to be taken by ayes and nays and entered
upon the journal of the proceedings.
Rule 16: “Robert’s Rules Of Order” shall govern the proceedings of the city
council, except when in conflict with this section.
(1989 Code § 2-34)
1-7-5: POWERS; DUTIES:
The powers of the city council shall be purely legislative except as may be
otherwise provided by applicable law. The city council shall approve for
payment all expenses and liabilities of the city.
1-7-6: ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS:
   A.   The mayor shall have no power to veto, but shall have the right to vote
on any question before the council. Every resolution, ordinance or warrant
passed or ordered by the city council shall be signed by the mayor, and all
ordinances and resolutions shall be filed for record before they shall be in
force.
(1989 Code § 2-35)
   B.   No ordinance may be adopted by the city council at the same meeting at
which it is offered for consideration, but each ordinance shall pass to a
second reading at the next regularly scheduled city council meeting after the
meeting at which said ordinance’s consideration was offered; provided, however,
that if a motion to suspend the operation of this rule is adopted by a four-
fifths (4/5) vote of all the members of the city council elected, then said
ordinance may be adopted upon proper motion at said meeting without a second
reading.
(1989 Code § 2-36)
CHAPTER 8: CITY OFFICERS AND PERSONNEL
Section
1-8-1: Qualifications Of Officers
1-8-2: Prospective Employees
1-8-3: Travel Expenses Policy
1-8-4: Whistleblower Protection Policy
1-8-5: City Purchasing Manual
1-8-6: Sexual Harassment Policy
1-8-7: City Credit Card User Policy
1-8-1: QUALIFICATIONS OF OFFICERS:
No person shall be eligible to any elected or appointed city office unless he
or she is a qualified elector of the city and has resided therein at least one
year next preceding his or her election or appointment. However, these
requirements shall not apply to city employees. Nor shall these requirements
apply to city attorneys. However, no person shall be eligible to any city
office who is a defaulter to the city.
(1989 Code § 2-156; amd. 2017 Code)
1-8-2: PROSPECTIVE EMPLOYEES:
   A.   Physical Examination: Every prospective employee of the city shall
obtain a physical examination prior to being hired by the city. Each department
head shall be responsible for ensuring that a completed physical examination
form is on file in the human resource manager’s prior to hiring any city
employee. The physical examination form shall request only that information
which is reasonably related to the determination of the individual’s physical
condition. The physical examination form shall be completed and signed by the
licensed physician conducting the physical examination of the prospective
employee. The city shall specify a licensed physician to conduct the physical
examination and shall pay for the cost of the examination.
   B.   Motor Vehicle Record Check: A motor vehicle record check shall be
conducted for each prospective employee who may be required to operate a motor
vehicle in the course of his or her employment with the city. The chief of
police shall cause an inquiry to be directed to the secretary of state
requesting any information pertinent to the prospective applicant’s driving
record. A written copy of any such information shall be forwarded to the human
resource manager.
(1989 Code § 2-157; amd. 2017 Code)
1-8-3: TRAVEL EXPENSES POLICY:
   A.   City Policy: The city’s policy is to establish controls based upon the
official city travel procedures administered by the city manager for city
employees and appointed and elected officials traveling on official city
business.
   B.   General Provisions:
      1.   City Objective: The city, to advance the training and
professionalism of its personnel, may authorize, if funds are available,
attendance at training sessions and conferences requiring employees to travel.
The city’s objective is to allow travel arrangements that minimize travel
expenditures.
      2.   Reimbursable Expenses: Reimbursable expenses include: per diems for
meals, air fares, lodging, rental cars, city vehicles, private vehicles, and
other ground transportation.
      3.   Other Conditions And Restrictions: Other conditions and restrictions
on travel include: family or other members accompanying the traveler, cash
advances for travel, entertainment, alcoholic beverages, elected officials, and
the city manager.
      4.   All travel requests must be preapproved and submitted to the city
manager in a timely manner. No other submittal form will be accepted.
         a.   Travel approval requests are to be submitted at least two (2)
weeks prior to the date of travel and/or registration deadline.
         b.   Exceptions may be considered with the employee’s department
director’s recommendation and details supporting why the late request should be
considered.
         c.   Reimbursement requests received beyond the sixty (60) day window
of acceptance will not be honored, and employees will be responsible for any
payments and invoices resulting from their business related travel.
         d.   Employees are responsible for any traffic tickets/violations
during their travel.
   C.   Reimbursable Travel Expenses:
      1.   Receipts Reimbursed for Meals:
         a.   The employee will be compensated for food for their time away.
Receipts must be provided to be reimbursed.
         b.   Reimbursement for meal expenses will not be allowed when a
training session or conference has any meals included in the cost of the event.
         c.   Reimbursements for meals will not be allowed when the site of the
travel event is within fifteen (15) miles of the employee’s assigned work
location, unless otherwise specified by a collective bargaining agreement.
      2.   Registration Fees: Registration fees must be preapproved after which
they may be prepaid via a city credit card. Registration is not a reimbursable
expense.
      3.   Air Fares:
         a.   Air fares must be preapproved after which they may be prepaid via
a city credit card or, in some circumstances, with a personal credit card in
order to secure frequent flyer miles or other mileage credits for the employee
traveler’s benefit.
         b.   Any request for a reimbursement of air fares must be submitted
for approval to the city manager or designee with a written explanation and
with receipts attached.
         c.   Air fares shall be limited to the fare of the lowest jet class
reasonably available. Advance purchase rates contain restrictions regarding
length of stay or other limitations. In this instance, a comparison of the
total additional expenses for an extended stay versus the next lowest round
trip fare would be required and approval received prior to reservations being
made.
      4.   Lodging/Accommodations:
         a.   Lodging must be preapproved, after which it may be prepaid.
However, lodging, or a portion of the traveler’s lodging expenses, will most
likely be paid by the traveler and will be reimbursable under the following
conditions:
            (1)   Lodging expenses shall only cover the minimum number of
evenings required by the event;
            (2)   Lodging expenses shall be reasonable in accommodations and
expense; and
            (3)   Lodging expenses must be supported by the original machine
printed receipt furnished by the hotel or motel.
         b.   Extra lodging expenses such as dry cleaning, laundry, room
service surcharges, valet or concierge service, video/movie/gaming, and
equipment rental are not reimbursable expenses.
         c.   The city manager’s approval is required for any exception.
         d.   An employee who is required to remain in one location for an
extended period of time is expected to find lodging at a weekly and/or monthly
rate. When attending a school or training session, which covers more than one
week, an employee may return home on the weekends, but will not be reimbursed
for the expense.
         e.   If an employee’s family member shares lodging, reimbursement
shall be limited to the single room rate for that room.
      5.   Internet Access: Business related internet use by the traveler to
send or respond to city e-mails or to check other city business websites, is
reimbursable when submitted with valid receipts.
      6.   Rental Cars:
         a.   The city favors ground transportation such as airport shuttle
service and taxicabs. Conditions may exist where a rental car may be approved
for use and may be eligible for a full or partial reimbursement. Prior approval
for the use of a rental car is required.
         b.   Paying for the rental car using the traveler’s own personal
credit card is also a requirement. The necessity for a rental car must be
supported with a written explanation, submitted during the travel preapproval
process. The level of reimbursement will be equal to the least expensive ground
transportation from the airport to the site of the conference/meeting/purpose
of the trip, regardless of the actual cost of the rental car.
         c.   Expenses as a consequence of renting a car, such as parking,
fuel, and tolls are not reimbursable expenses beyond the level of reimbursement
equal to the least expensive ground transportation.
         d.   Reimbursement requires the original machine receipt printed by
the car rental agency.
         e.   An insurance rider for collision coverage on the rental vehicle
should be included, and this expense will be reimbursed by the city. Personal
liability coverage should not be included as this coverage is already covered
elsewhere by the city for city business travelers and will, therefore, not be a
reimbursable expense.
      7.   City Vehicles:
         a.   City vehicles may be used to travel in situations where air
travel is uneconomical, for example, short distances generally less than six
hundred (600) miles roundtrip.
         b.   Special approval for longer trips may be granted by the city
manager if there will be more than one employee making the trip. Receipts for
fuel purchased are required for reimbursement.
      8.   Private Vehicles:
         a.   Private vehicles may be used to travel in situations where air
travel is uneconomical, for example, short distances generally less than six
hundred (600) miles roundtrip.
         b.   Reimbursement for the use of a private vehicle while on city
business will be made at the current mileage rate established by the internal
revenue service.
         c.   Mileage should be calculated upon the shortest practical route to
the destination from the employee’s base of operations and return to the same.
Employees may utilize Map Quest or Google Maps to determine the route.
         d.   An exception to the shortest practical route would be if the
employee’s actual point of departure is closer to the final destination. In
such a case, the mileage would be calculated at this lesser distance.
         e.   Travel to and from municipal facilities or locations within the
city to attend training, drills, meetings or other similar activities is not
reimbursable.
         f.   Parking fees and toll charges will be reimbursed when submitted
with valid receipts.
         g.   Primary insurance coverage follows the vehicle, not necessarily
the driver of the vehicle or the city. This means the insurance coverage
provided by the owner of the vehicle is the coverage that will be applied,
should an accident involving a private vehicle occur. It is, therefore,
essential to the city and to the owners of the private vehicles that the proper
levels of personal liability and property coverage are in place for protection
from financial loss. Employees driving private vehicles will be required to
submit evidence of insurance coverage to the city upon request. It is required
that employees on official city business, driving personal automobiles, be
adequately covered by auto insurance, including personal liability and property
coverage.
      9.   Other Ground Transportation:
         a.   Reimbursement for other ground transportation, such as public
transportation and taxis, will be made when supported with valid receipts.
         b.   The need for such transportation must be business related, not
just coincidental to a business trip.
         c.   The traveler is to choose the most reasonable mode of ground
transportation considering factors such as time constraints, convenience,
costs, and safety.
         d.   Travel to and from airports should use the most economical means
available.
   D.   Conditions And Restrictions On Travel:
      1.   The least expensive mode of transportation must be taken when
traveling on city business.
      2.   Any exception to anything stated in this protocol will need the
approval of the city manager or designees. Any expense or action not
specifically covered in these regulations will be judged for appropriateness by
the city manager or designees.
      3.   Family/other members may accompany the traveler when traveling on
official city business. However, no expenses attributable to any family/other
member will be a reimbursable expense. All expenses will be calculated as if
the traveler was traveling alone, using the minimum costs to the city for
lodging and transportation.
      4.   No advancement of cash will be made for travel.
      5.   The city discourages partial reimbursement of expenses due to the
inefficiency of processing reimbursements more than once. Reimbursement for
travel should be organized and submitted at one time. Exceptions for hardship
may be submitted to the city manager or designee for consideration. No partial
reimbursements will be made for less than fifty dollars ($50.00).
      6.   Entertainment and alcoholic beverage charges are not reimbursable
expenses.
(Ord. O-16-019, eff. 1-1-2017)
1-8-4: WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION POLICY:
   A.   Purpose: The city of Princeton provides whistleblower protections in
two important areas: confidentiality and against retaliation. The
confidentiality of a whistleblower will be maintained to the extent allowable
by law, however, an identity may have to be disclosed to conduct a thorough
investigation, to comply with the law and to provide accused individuals their
legal rights of defense. A whistleblower may also waive confidentiality in
writing. The city of Princeton will not retaliate against a whistleblower. This
includes, but is not limited to, protection from retaliation in the form of an
adverse employment action such as termination, compensation decreases or poor
work assignments and threats of physical harm. Any whistleblowcrs who believe
they are being retaliated against must submit a written report to the auditing
official within sixty (60) days of gaining knowledge of the retaliatory action.
The right of a whistleblower for protection against retaliation does not
include immunity for any personal wrongdoing that is alleged and investigated.
   B.   Definitions:
AUDITING OFFICIAL: Any elected, appointed or employed individual, by whatever
name, in the city of Princeton whose duties may include: receiving, registering
and investigating complaints and information concerning misconduct,
inefficiency and waste within the city of Princeton; investigating the
performance of officers, employees, functions and programs; and, promoting
economy, efficiency, effectiveness and integrity in the administration of the
programs and operations of the city of Princeton. If the city of Princeton does
not designate an auditing official, the auditing official defaults to the
state’s attorney of Bureau County, Illinois.
EMPLOYEE: Anyone employed by the city of Princeton, whether in a permanent or
temporary position, including full-time, part-time and intermittent workers.
“Employee “also includes members of appointed boards or commissions, whether
paid or unpaid. “Employee” also includes persons who have been terminated
because of any report or complaint submitted under 50 ILCS I 05/4.1.
IMPROPER GOVERNMENTAL ACTION:
      1.   Any action by an employee of the city of Princeton; an appointed
member of a board, commission or committee; or, an elected official of the city
of Princeton that is undertaken in violation of a federal or state law or local
ordinance; is an abuse of authority; violates the public’s trust or expectation
of their conduct; is of substantial and specific danger to the public’s health
or safety; or, is a gross waste of public funds. The action need not be within
the scope of the employee’s, elected official’s, board member’s, commission
member’s or committee member’s official duties to be subject to a claim of
“improper governmental action”.
      2.   “Improper governmental action” does not include the city of
Princeton’s personnel actions, including, but not limited to employee
grievances, complaints, appointments, promotions, transfers, assignments,
reassignments, reinstatements, restorations, reemployment, performance
evaluations, reductions in pay, dismissals, suspensions, demotions, reprimands
or violations of collective bargaining agreements, except to the extent that
the action amounts to retaliation.
RETALIATE, RETALIATION OR RETALIATORY ACTION: Any adverse change in an
employee’s employment status or the terms and conditions of employment that
results from an employee’s protected activity under 50 ILCS 105/4.1.
“Retaliatory action” includes, but is not limited to, denial of adequate staff
to perform duties; frequent staff changes; frequent and undesirable office
changes; refusal to assign meaningful work; unsubstantiated letters of
reprimand or unsatisfactory performance evaluations; demotion; reduction in
pay; denial of promotion; transfer or reassignment; suspension or dismissal;
or, other disciplinary action made because of an employee’s protected activity
under 50 ILCS 105/4.1.
WHISTLEBLOWER: An employee, as defined in this subsection B of this policy, of
the city of Princeton who:
      1.   Reports an improper governmental action as defined under 50 ILCS
105/4.1;
      2.   Cooperates with an investigation by an auditing official related to
a report of improper governmental action; or
      3.   Testifies in a proceeding or prosecution arising out of an improper
governmental action.
   C.   Duties Of An Auditing Official:
      1.   Each auditing official shall establish written processes and
procedures consistent with the terms of this policy and best practices for
investigations for managing complaints filed under 50 ILCS 105/4.1. each
auditing official shall investigate and dispose of reports of improper
governmental action in accordance with these processes and procedures, and all
other provisions of 50 ILCS 105/4.1.
      2.   The auditing official must provide each employee a written summary
or a complete copy of 50 ILCS 105/4.1 upon commencement of employment and at
least once each year of employment. At the same time, the employee shall also
receive a copy of the written processes and procedures for reporting improper
governmental actions from the applicable auditing official.
      3.   Auditing officials may reinstate, reimburse for lost wages or
expenses incurred, promote or provide some other form of restitution.
      4.   In instances where an auditing official determines that restitution
will not suffice, the auditing official may make their investigation findings
available for the purposes of aiding in that employee’s, or the employee’s
attorney’s, effort to make the employee whole.
      5.   Auditing officials are responsible for reading the full context of
50 ILCS 105/4.1 and complying with all requirements.
      6.   If no auditing official is designated, the state’s attorney of
Bureau County, Illinois will be the default auditing official.
   D.   Duties Of An Employee:
      1.   All reports of illegal and dishonest activities will be promptly
submitted to the auditing official who is responsible for investigating and
coordinating corrective action.
      2.   If an employee has knowledge of, or a concern of, improper
governmental action, the employee shall make a written report of the activity
to the auditing official. The employee must exercise sound judgment to avoid
baseless allegations. An employee who intentionally files a false report of
wrongdoing will be subject to discipline up to and including termination.
      3.   The whistleblower is not responsible for investigating the activity
or for determining fault or corrective measures; a designated auditing official
is charged with these responsibilities.
   E.   Defend Trade Secrets Act Compliance: Immunity from liability for
confidential disclosure of a trade secret to the government or in a court
filing:
      1.   Immunity: An individual shall not be held criminally or civilly
liable under any federal or state trade secret law for the disclosure of a
trade secret that
         a.   Is made (i) in confidence to a federal, state or local government
official, either directly or indirectly, or to an attorney; and (ii) solely for
the purpose of reporting or investigating a suspected violation of law; or
         b.   Is made in a complaint or other document filed in a lawsuit or
other proceeding, if such filing is made under seal.
      2.   Use of Trade Secret Information in Anti-Retaliation Lawsuit: An
individual who files a lawsuit for retaliation by an employer for reporting a
suspected violation of law may disclose the trade secret to the attorney of the
individual and use the trade secret information in the court proceeding, if the
individual:
         a.   Files any document containing the trade secret under seal; and
         b.   Does not disclose the trade secret, except pursuant to court
order (18 U.S.C. § 1833).
   F.   Employee Acknowledgment: Employees are required to sign a written
acknowledgment that they have received, read and understand this policy, and to
submit that acknowledgment to the auditing official or other designated
official of the city of Princeton.
(Ord. O-21-027, 1-3-2022)
1-8-5: CITY PURCHASING MANUAL:
   A.   Introduction/Statement of Policy:
      1.   The city of Princeton is governed by both state laws and local
ordinances with regards to purchasing policies and procedures. Many of these
laws and ordinances have been enacted to conserve tax dollars and to protect
the public from fraudulent practices. While laws and ordinances can help to
achieve these goals, a higher public purchasing standard must be implemented to
protect the public trust. The purchasing policies and procedures of the city of
Princeton have been developed with this standard as the highest priority.
      2.   The city of Princeton has adopted the provision of Illinois statutes
commonly called the “budget officer act” whereby an annual budget is adopted in
lieu of an appropriation ordinance. The annual budget includes all city
operating units and is made up of line items for each object of expenditure.
When adopted by the mayor and city council members, the budget becomes the
legal authorization to expend resources for providing city services.
Accordingly, all city expenditures must be authorized in the approved budget or
in a subsequent amendment.
      3.   The goal of the city’s purchasing program is to obtain quality goods
and services at the lowest possible price. The purpose of this manual is to
establish guidelines to achieve this goal within the philosophy stated above.
Therefore, the procedures contained in this manual will assist the city manager
and department heads in procuring necessary goods and materials in a manner
that is consistent with the highest standards of public service.
      4.   This purchasing manual provides guidelines and directions for the
procurement of goods and services. When used with good judgment and common
sense, the policies and procedures conveyed within this manual will allow the
city to procure required supplies and services efficiently and economically.
All purchasing by the city will be in accordance with the municipal code, city
policy and Illinois law. City employees are expected to conduct themselves in a
manner which will lead to public confidence in the integrity of the city’s
procurement procedures.
      5.   The city utilizes a decentralized purchasing process. Purchasing
activities (specification preparation, bid reviews, telephone quotation
solicitation and requisition preparation) are the responsibility of each
department and must be conducted within procedures established by this policy.
      6.   The city will make every effort to purchase services, commodities or
materials from vendors located in and around Princeton if these vendors are
competitive in price and quality.
      7.   The city encourages the use of environmentally friendly products.
Priority shall be given to these products provided the products are competitive
in price and quality.
      8   It shall be the policy of the city to participate in a joint
purchasing cooperatives such as the state of Illinois joint purchasing program
to the extent such programs provide an economic advantage to the city.
      9.   This manual is designed to be a fluid document and will be amended
from time to time to conform to changes in legislation, technology and actual
practice. Employees who need assistance with specific purchasing situations not
covered by the purchasing manual should contact the city manager.
   B.   Code Of Ethics:
      1.   All city personnel engaged in purchasing and related activities
shall conduct business matters with the highest level of integrity.
Transactions relating to expenditure of public funds require the highest degree
of public trust to protect the interests of residents and business owners of
the community. City employees are expected to conduct themselves in the
following manner:
         a.   Ensure that public money is spent efficiently and effectively and
in accordance with statutes, regulations and city policies.
         b.   Never accept gifts or favors from current or potential suppliers,
which might compromise the integrity of their purchasing function. (5 ILCS 430/
10 et seq.)
         c.   Specify generic descriptions of goods whenever possible in lieu
of brand names when compiling specifications.
         d.   Never allow purchases for similar or like goods or services to be
split into smaller orders to avoid required approval or in any manner that
would circumvent this policy or applicable law.
         e.   Purchase without favor or prejudice.
         f.   Ensure that potential suppliers are provided with adequate and
identical information upon which to base their proposal or quotation and that
any subsequent information is made available to all bidders in an equitable and
timely manner.
         g.   Establish and maintain procedures to ensure that fair and equal
consideration is given to each proposal or quotation received and selection is
based upon the lowest total cost compliant bid.
         h.   Provide a prompt and courteous response to all inquiries from
potential or existing suppliers.
      2.   It shall be the responsibility of the city manager or his or her
designee to determine if a violation of this code of ethics has occurred and if
any disciplinary action is necessary.
   C.   Conflict of Interest Policy:
      1.   It shall be a breach of ethical standards for any employee or
elected official to participate directly or indirectly in the purchasing
process when:
         a.   The employee or elected official is an owner of, is
contemporaneously employed by, is an independent contractor by/of, or serves on
a board of directors of a bidder, vendor or contractor involved in the
procurement transaction;
         b.   The employee or elected official, the employee’s or elected
official’s spouse or domestic partner, or any member of the employee’s or
elected official’s immediate family holds a position, including as an
independent contractor, with a bidder, proposer or contractor such as an
officer, director, trustee, partner or the like, or is employed in a capacity
involving personal and substantial participation in the procurement
transaction, or owns or controls an interest in the company;
         c.   The employee or elected official, the employee’s or elected
official’s spouse or domestic partner, or any member of the employee’s or
elected official’s immediate family has a financial interest arising from the
procurement transaction; or
         d.   The employee or elected official, the employee’s or elected
official’s spouse or domestic partner, or any member of the employee’s or
elected official’s immediate family is negotiating or is retained as an
independent contractor, or has an arrangement concerning, prospective
employment with a bidder, vendor or contractor.
      2.   An employee or elected official is obligated to and must disclose
immediately to his or her supervisor and the city manager or his or her
designee if a company providing services to the city or which is making a
quote, proposal, or bid to the city employs, is owned (directly or indirectly)
by, or substantial influence is exerted by a spouse, domestic partner or
immediate family member of the current employee(s) or elected official(s).
      3.   Where any party serving as an independent contractor for the city of
Princeton has any economic interest in another company, contractor or
subcontractor who is proposed or contracted to provide services to the city on
a project in which the party is involved, or in which that party has any role
in recommending selection of subcontractors, the party shall disclose such
interest to the city in writing, based upon the same standards utilized for
city staff and elected officials as outlined above.
      4.   The employee’s or elected official’s immediate family shall be
defined as a spouse, children (including but not limited to foster children,
adopted children, children for which the employee or elected official is a
guardian), parents, brothers, sisters, and any other person living in the same
household as the employee.
      5.   It shall be the responsibility of the city manager or his or her
