4-3-7: PENALTIES; INJUNCTIONS:
   A.   Penalties:
      1.   A person, corporation, partnership, association or other entity who
violates section
4-3-2 of this chapter shall be fined pursuant to this section. Each day that a
violation occurs is a separate violation.
      2.   A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited under
section
4-3-2 of this chapter shall be fined an amount not less than one hundred
dollars ($100.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). A
person who owns, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of
employment that violates section
4-3-2 of this chapter shall be fined:
         a.   Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the first violation;
         b.   Five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the second violation within
one year after the first violation; and
         c.   Seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each additional
violation within one year after the first violation.
(1989 Code § 9-207)
   B.   Injunctions: The city police department, or any individual personally
affected by repeated violations, may institute, in a circuit court, an action
to enjoin violations of this chapter.
(1989 Code § 9-208) (Ord. O-3-09-2-17, 2-17-2009)
4-3-8: DISCRIMINATION PROHIBITED:
No individual may be discriminated against in any manner because of the
exercise of any rights afforded by this chapter.
(1989 Code § 9-209) (Ord. O-3-09-2-17, 2-17-2009)
CHAPTER 4: GROUNDWATER AS POTABLE WATER SUPPLY
Section
4-4-1: Definitions
4-4-2: Use Prohibited; Exceptions
4-4-3: Memorandum Of Understanding
4-4-4: Penalty
4-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, limited
liability company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust,
estate, political subdivision except the city of Princeton, or any other legal
entity, or their representatives, agents or assigns.
POTABLE WATER: Any water used for human or domestic consumption, including, but
not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming, washing dishes or
preparing foods, watering lawns or gardens in which produce intended for human
consumption is grown.
(1989 Code § 13-85) (Ord. O-17-22, 11-6-2017)
4-4-2: USE PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS:
Except for such uses or methods in existence before November 6, 2017, the use
of or attempted use of groundwater from within the corporate limits of the city
of Princeton, as a potable water supply, by the installation or drilling of
wells or by any other method, is hereby prohibited. This prohibition expressly
includes the city of Princeton.
(1989 Code § 13-85) (Ord. O-17-22, 11-6-2017)
4-4-3: MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING:
The mayor is hereby authorized and directed to enter into a memorandum of
understanding with the Illinois environmental protection agency in which the
city assumes responsibility for tracking all sites that have received no
further remediation determinations from the Illinois EPA, notifying the
Illinois EPA of changes to this chapter, and taking certain precautions when
siting public potable water supply wells.
(1989 Code § 13-85)
4-4-4: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this section will be subject to a fine
of up to seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) per day for each violation.
(1989 Code § 13-85) (Ord. O-17-22, 11-6-2017)
CHAPTER 5: HAZARDOUS MATERIAL REMOVAL AND ABATEMENT
Section
4-5-1: Definitions
4-5-2: Authority To Remove Or Abate
4-5-3: Liability For Costs Of removal Or Remedial Action
4-5-4: Supervision Or Verification By Fire Chief
4-5-5: Costs
4-5-6: Nonexclusive Remedies
4-5-7: Burden Of Liability
4-5-8: State Reimbursement
4-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
HAZARDOUS MATERIAL: A substance or material in a quantity and form determined
by the United States department of transportation to be capable of posing an
unreasonable risk to health and safety or property when transported in commerce
and hazardous substance or waste as defined by the environmental protection
act.
HAZARDOUS MATERIAL INCIDENT: Any emergency or nonemergency circumstance
involving the sudden release or threatened or potential release of hazardous
material which, in the judgment of an appropriate governmental agency,
threatens imminent and irreparable harm to the environment or the health,
safety or welfare of any individual other than individuals exposed to the risk
associated with hazardous material in the normal course of their employment.
RELEASE: Any actual or threatened spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring,
emitting, emptying, discharging, injecting, escaping, leaching, dumping or
disposing into the environment.
REMEDIAL ACTION: Actions consistent with permanent remedy taken instead of or
in addition to removal actions in the event of a release or threatened release
of a hazardous substance into the environment, to prevent or minimize the
release of hazardous substances so that they do not migrate to cause
substantial danger to present or future public health or welfare or the
environment.
REMOVAL: The cleanup or removal of released hazardous material or improperly
stored hazardous material from the environment; such actions as may be
necessary to be taken in the event of the threat of release of hazardous
material into the environment; such actions may be necessary to monitor, assess
and evaluate the release or threat of release of hazardous material; the
disposal of removed material; or the taking of such other actions as may be
necessary to prevent, minimize or mitigate to the public health or welfare or
environment which may otherwise result from a release or threat of a release.
(1989 Code § 10-163)
Statutory reference:
   Environmental protection act, see 415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.
4-5-2: AUTHORITY TO REMOVE AND ABATE:
The fire chief or his or her authorized representative is authorized to
response to any actual or threatened release, discharge or deposit upon or onto
property or facilities within the city, or in any location under the
jurisdiction of or serviced by the fire department of the city, including, but
not limited to, removal and/or remedial action.
4-5-3: LIABILITY FOR COSTS OF REMOVAL OR REMEDIAL ACTION:
   A.   The following described persons shall be jointly and severally liable
to the city for the payment of all costs incurred by the city as a result of
such removal or remedial action, subject only to the defenses set forth in
subsection B of this section:
      1.   The owner and operator of a facility or vessel from which there is a
release or substantial threat of release of hazardous materials.
      2.   Any person who at the time of disposal, transport, storage or
treatment of a hazardous material owned or operated the facility or vessel used
for such disposal, transport, treatment or storage from which there was a
release or substantial threat of a release of any such hazardous material.
      3.   Any person who by contract, agreement or otherwise has arranged with
another party or entity for transport, storage, disposal or treatment of
hazardous materials owned, controlled or possessed by such person at a facility
owned or operated by another party or entity from which facility there is a
release or substantial threat of a release of such hazardous materials.
      4.   Any person who accepts or accepted any hazardous material for
transport to disposal, storage or treatment facilities or sites from which
there is a release or a substantial threat of a release of a hazardous
material.
(1989 Code § 10-163)
   B.   There shall be no liability under this section
4-5-3 for a person otherwise liable who can establish by a preponderance of
evidence that the release or substantial threat of release of hazardous
material and any resulting damages occurred under one of the permitted defenses
set forth in 415 ILCS 5/22.2(j).
4-5-4: SUPERVISION OR VERIFICATION BY FIRE CHIEF:
In the event that any person undertakes, either voluntarily or upon the order
of the fire chief or other city official, to remove or abate the effects of any
actual or threatened release of hazardous material upon or onto any property or
facility within the city, the fire chief may take such action as is necessary
to supervise or verify the adequacy of the removal or abatement. The persons
described in section
4-5-2 of this chapter shall be liable to the city for all costs incurred as a
result of such supervision or verification.
(1989 Code § 10-163)
4-5-5: COSTS:
Costs incurred by the city and recoverable under this chapter shall include,
but not necessarily be limited to, the following: actual labor costs of city
personnel, including benefits and administrative overhead; cost of equipment
operation; cost of materials obtained directly by the city and cost of
consultants whose expertise is required to remove or remediate the hazardous
material incident or to assess the nature and extent of the damage done; cost
of equipment operation; replacement cost of vehicles or equipment which, in the
determination of the fire chief, is contaminated beyond reuse or repair;
laboratory costs; cost of materials or equipment obtained directly by the city;
cost of any contract or mutual aid labor and materials; and attorney fees
incurred in collecting monies owed the city by liable parties.
(1989 Code § 10-163)
4-5-6: NONEXCLUSIVE REMEDIES:
The remedies provided in this chapter shall be in addition to any other
remedies or penalties provided by law.
(1989 Code § 10-163)
4-5-7: BURDEN OF LIABILITY:
This chapter shall be liberally construed to give effect to its purpose which
is to shift the burden of liability for the aforesaid removal or abatement
costs from the citizens of the city to those responsible for the incident.
(1989 Code § 10-163)
4-5-8: STATE REIMBURSEMENT:
In the event that the city is not reimbursed by the responsible party as
required herein, if applicable, the fire chief shall make application to the
emergency response reimbursement fund of the state of Illinois pursuant to the
hazardous material emergency response reimbursement act.
(1989 Code § 10-163)
Statutory reference:
   Hazardous material emergency response reimbursement act, see 430 ILCS 55/
1 et seq.
CHAPTER 6: NOISE CONTROL
Section
4-6-1: Purpose
4-6-2: Scope
4-6-3: Definitions
4-6-4: Noises Prohibited
4-6-5: Noise Level Tests
4-6-6: Noise Levels Between Properties
4-6-7: Motor Vehicle Noise
4-6-8: Exemptions From Noise Level Restrictions
4-6-9: Enforcement
4-6-10: Violations; Penalty
4-6-1: PURPOSE:
   A.   This chapter is enacted to protect, preserve and promote the health,
safety, welfare, peace and quiet of the citizens of the city through the
reduction, control and prevention of any noise that unreasonably disturbs,
injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of reasonable
persons of ordinary sensitivity. Nothing in this article shall be construed as
preventing the lawful exercise of the right of free speech protected by the
Constitutions of the United States or the state of Illinois. The city has the
authority to regulate noise as set forth in sections 11-5-2 and 11-60-2 of the
Illinois Municipal Code.
   B.   The city council finds that:
      1.   Excessive noise degrades the environment of the city to a degree
which:
         a.   Is harmful and detrimental to the health, welfare and safety of
its inhabitants;
         b.   Interferes with the comfortable enjoyment of life, property and
recreation and with the conduct and operation of business and industry; and
         c.   Causes nuisances.
      2.   No one has any right to create excessive noise.
      3.   Effective control and elimination of excessive noise is essential to
the furtherance of the health and welfare of the city’s inhabitants and to the
conduct of the normal pursuits of life, recreation, commerce and industrial
activity.
(Ord. O-17-010, 5-4-2017)
4-6-2: SCOPE:
This chapter applies to the control of all sound originating within the
jurisdictional limits of the city.
(Ord. O-17-010, 5-4-2017)
4-6-3: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. All technical
definitions are in accordance with American National Standards Institute:
“A” BAND LEVEL: The total sound level of all noise as measured with a sound
level meter using the “A” weighting network. The unit of measurement is the dB
(A).
AMBIENT NOISE: The all-encompassing noise associated with a given environment,
being usually a composite of sounds from many sources, near and far.
BEL: A unit of level which the base of logarithm is ten (10). Use of BEL is
restricted to levels of quantities proportional to power.
CYCLE: The complete sequence of values of a periodic quantity that occur during
a period.
DECIBEL: One-tenth (0.1) of a BEL and is a unit of level when the base of the
logarithm is the tenth root of ten (10) and the quantities concerned are
proportional to power.
EMERGENCY WORK: Work made necessary to restore property to a safe condition
following a public calamity, or work required to protect persons or property
from an imminent exposure to danger.
PERIOD OF A PERIODIC QUANTITY: The smallest increment of time for which the
function repeats itself.
PERIODIC QUANTITY: An oscillating quantity, the values of which recur for equal
increments of time.
PERSON: Any person, person’s firm, association, copartnership, joint venture,
corporation or any entity public or private in nature.
SOUND ANALYZER: A device for measuring the band pressure level or pressure
spectrum level of a sound as a function of frequency.
SOUND LEVEL METER: An instrument including a microphone, an amplifier, an
output meter and frequency weighting networks for the measurement of noise and
sound levels in a specified manner.
SOUND PRESSURE LEVEL IN DECIBELS OF SOUND: Twenty (20) times the logarithm to
the base- 10 of the ratio of the pressure of this sound to be the reference
pressure, which reference pressure must be explicitly stated.
(Ord. O-17-010, 5-4-2017)
4-6-4: NOISES PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue, or cause to be made or
continued any excessive, unnecessary or unusually loud noise which either
annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or
safety of others within the corporate limits of the city.
(Ord. O-17-010, 5-4-2017)
4-6-5: NOISE LEVEL TESTS:
The standards which shall be considered in determining whether a violation of
section
4-6-4 of this chapter exists shall include the following:
   A.   The volume of the noise.
   B.   The intensity of the noise.
   C.   Whether the nature of the noise is usual or unusual.
   D.   Whether the origin of the noise is natural or unnatural.
   E.   The volume and intensity of the background noise, if any.
   F.   The nature and zoning of the area within which the noise emanates.
   G.   The density of inhabitation of the area within which the noise
emanates.
   H.   The time of the day or night the noise occurs.
   I.   The duration of the noise.
   J.   Whether the noise is recurrent, intermittent or constant.
   K.   Whether the noise is produced by a commercial or noncommercial
activity.
(Ord. O-17-010, 5-4-2017)
4-6-6: NOISE LEVELS BETWEEN PROPERTIES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to project a sound or noise, excluding noise
emanating from cars, trucks or motorcycles, from one property into another,
which exceeds the limiting noise spectra set forth in this subsection, with the
classification of land being by zoned district. Sound or noise projecting from
one zoned district into another zoned district with a different noise level
limit shall not exceed the limits of the district into which the noise is
projected.
 
Noise Levels for Use Districts
Maximum permissible sound pressure level (dB) of sound emitted to any of the
following zoned districts:
Hours                            Residential Commercial Industrial
Between 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. 60          70         85
Between 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 55          65         80
 
      1.   Residential: All single-family and multi-family dwelling units under
R1, R2, R3, RIA, RE and A zoning districts.
      2.   Commercial: All business and commercial uses under B1, B2, B3 and B4
and all nonresidential special uses.
      3.   Industrial: All industrial uses including uses under M1 and M2.
   B.   The measurement of such sound or noise shall be made with a sound level
meter and octave band analyzer meeting the standards prescribed by the American
National Standards Institute, or its successor. The instruments shall be
maintained in calibration and good working order. Octave band corrections may
be employed in meeting the response specification. A calibration check shall be
made of the system prior to the time of any noise measurement and thereafter.
Measurements recorded shall be taken so as to provide a proper representation
of the noise source. The microphone during measurement shall be positioned so
as not to create any unnatural enhancement or diminution of the measured noise.
A windscreen for the microphone shall be used when required. Traffic, aircraft
and other transportation noise sources and other background noises shall not be
considered in taking measurements except where such background noise interferes
with the primary noise being measured.
   C.   The slow meter response of the sound level meter shall be used in order
to best determine that the average amplitude does not exceed the limiting noise
spectra set forth in subsection A of this section.
   D.   The measurement shall be made at the property line of the property on
which such noise is received, five feet (5') aboveground, but such measurement
shall not be made closer than twenty five feet (25') from such noise source.
   E.   In the case of an elevated or directional sound or noise source,
compliance with the noise limits is to be maintained at any elevation at the
boundary, but not closer than twenty five feet (25') from said noise source.
   F.   Occasional outdoor activities exempted. The provisions of this section
shall not apply to occasional outdoor gatherings, shows and sporting and
entertainment events; provided the events are not conducted on a regular basis
and have the appropriate approval from the city (if applicable; i.e. special
event policy).
(Ord. O-17-010, 5-4-2017)
4-6-7: MOTOR VEHICLE NOISE:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to operate a motorized vehicle within the city
limits which creates a noise or sound which exceeds the noise level limits set
out below:
Noise Levels for Motor Vehicles
Types of Vehicles Maximum Allowable Limits
Noise Levels for Motor Vehicles
Types of Vehicles              Maximum Allowable Limits
Trucks and buses:               
   Over 10,000 pounds       87 dB(A) measured at 50 feet
                              93 dB(A) measured at 25 feet
   Under 10,000 pounds      80 dB(A) measured at 50 feet
                              86 dB(A) measured at 25 feet
Passenger cars                 78 dB(A) measured at 50 feet
                              84 dB(A) measured at 25 feet
Motorcycles and other vehicles 87 dB(A) measured at 50 feet
                              93 dB(A) measured at 25 feet
 
   B.   The measurement of sound or noise shall be made with a sound level
meter and octave band analyzer meeting the standards prescribed by the American
National Standards Institute. The instruments shall be maintained in
calibration and good working order. Octave band corrections may be employed in
meeting the response specifications. A calibration check shall be made of the
system prior to the time of any noise measurement and thereafter. Measurements
recorded shall be taken so as to provide a proper representation of the noise
source. The microphone during measurement shall be positioned so as not to
create any unnatural enhancement or diminution of the measured noise. A
windscreen for the microphone shall be used when required. Traffic, aircraft
and other transportation noise sources and other background noises shall not be
considered in taking measurements except where such background noise interferes
with the primary noise being measured.
(Ord. O-17-010, 5-4-2017)
4-6-8: EXEMPTIONS FROM NOISE LEVEL RESTRICTIONS:
The following uses and activities shall be exempt from noise level regulations:
   A.   Noises or safety signals, warning devices and emergency pressure relief
valves installed.
   B.   Noises resulting from any authorized emergency vehicle, when responding
to an emergency call or acting in time of emergency.
   C.   Noises resulting from “emergency work”, as defined in section
4-6-3 of this chapter.
   D.   Noises resulting from work performed by governmental agencies or their
agents (road, street, water, sewer repairs or construction) to promote the
public health, welfare and safety.
   E.   Noises resulting from work performed by public utilities.
   F.   Noises resulting from community events including, but not limited to,
parades, festivals, July 4th celebrations, sponsored in whole or part by local
governments, schools, charitable or service organizations.
   G.   Noises in the course of business controlled or within the jurisdiction
of another governmental agency including, but not limited to, FAA, airplanes
and the like.
   H.   Any organized amateur or professional sporting activity.
(Ord. O-17-010, 5-4-2017)
4-6-9: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Violations of this chapter shall be prosecuted in the same manner as
other violations of this city code.
   B.   As an additional remedy, the operation or maintenance of any device,
instrument, vehicle or machinery in violation of any provision hereof which
causes discomfort or annoyance to reasonable persons of normal sensitiveness or
which endangers the comfort, repose, health or peace of residents in the area
shall be deemed, and is declared to be a public nuisance and may be subject to
abatement summarily by a restraining order or injunction issued by a court of
competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. O-17-010, 5-4-2017)
4-6-10: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY:
   A.   Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter
shall be deemed guilty of a petty offense. Upon conviction of such offense a
person shall be fined in an amount listed below, and each day such violation is
committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and
shall be deemed punishable as such hereunder. Any person violating section
4-6-6 of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a petty offense and upon
conviction thereof shall be fined as follows:
 
First violation                          $50
Second violation within 72 hours of a    $100
first violation

first violation

first violation
Subsequent violations within 72 hours of Subject to a complaint for a permanent
the first violation                      injunction
 
   B.   All fines shall be paid within ten (10) days of the time such alleged
violation or offense was committed, or the alleged violator must appear at the
scheduled administrative hearing date.
(Ord. O-17-010, 5-4-2017)
TITLE 5: POLICE, FIRE AND PUBLIC SAFETY
CHAPTER 1: POLICE DEPARTMENT
Section
5-1-1: Composition
5-1-2: Chief Of Police
5-1-3: Auxiliary Police
5-1-1: COMPOSITION:
The police department shall consist of its chief of police, who shall have
supervision over the department, and such other officers and members as may be
provided by ordinance.
(1989 Code § 10-51)
5-1-2: CHIEF OF POLICE:
   A.   Office Created; Appointment: There is hereby created the office of
chief of police. The chief shall be the chief officer of the police department
and shall be appointed by the city manager.
(1989 Code § 10-52)
   B.   Oath Of Office: The chief of police, before entering upon the duties of
his or her office, shall take the oath as nearly as may be in the form provided
in this code for the mayor.
(1989 Code § 10-53)
   C.   Powers And Duties: The chief of police shall:
      1.   Possess all of the statutory powers of a city marshal and shall
possess the power and authority of a constable at common law.
      2.   Devote his or her entire time and energy to the discharge of the
duties of his or her office and shall see that the laws and ordinances are
enforced and that all offenders are properly reported to some proper tribunal
for punishment.
      3.   Be the commanding officer of the entire police force of the city,
subject to the rules and regulations prescribed by the city council. He or she
shall assign to all police officers under him or her their different beats or
districts and their respective hours of service and shall see that each officer
performs his or her whole duty according to law and the provisions of this
code. The chief of police in no case shall absent himself or herself from the
city without consent.
      4.   Properly suspend any member of the police department who may be
guilty of impairment, neglect of duty, disobedience of orders or violation of
the standing rules and regulations of the department, and shall immediately
report such suspension. Such officer shall remain in suspension without pay
until such time as he or she may be reinstated by the city council. If not at
once reinstated by the mayor, the mayor shall report such suspension to the
city council as in other cases.
      5.   Attend, either in person or by his or her assistant, all meetings of
the city council and execute all its orders and all warrants or other legal
process required to be executed by him or her under any provision of this code.
      6.   Keep books or records of the police department and of all persons
arrested or committed by the police, showing the time and place of each arrest,
by whom the arrest was made, the offense charged, the proper officer before
whom such person was tried, the disposition of each case, the amount of fine
imposed, if any, and the amount collected, the amount of city officer costs for
serving papers collected, if any, and, in addition, shall record a list of all
monies and valuables taken from each prisoner at the time of his or her
commitment and the disposition thereof.
      7.   Present a monthly written report showing the number of arrests made
by the police force during the preceding month, the name of each person
arrested, the offense charged, the officer making the arrest, the proper
officer before whom tried, the disposition of the case, the fine imposed, if
any, and the amount of such fine. In such report, he or she shall give a list
of all dogs killed and buried, if any, during the preceding month, the name of
the owner, if known, the officer by whom killed and the reason therefor.
      8.   Have the care, custody and control of all books, records, equipment
and all property belonging to the police department and of all stolen goods
seized and retained by police authority. Such books at all times shall be open
to public inspection, except as may be otherwise provided by law.
      9.   Appoint a deputy chief pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
10-2.1-4.
(1989 Code § 10-54)
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
1-6-1 of this code
5-1-3: AUXILIARY POLICE:
Auxiliary police may be appointed as follows:
   A.   Appointment: Auxiliary police officers may be appointed to assist the
police department from time to time upon authorization of the city council.
   B.   Auxiliary police shall not be members of the regular police department
and shall possess those powers set forth in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
3.1-15-25.
   C.   Duties: Auxiliary police officers will serve and act at the direction
and control of the chief of police and may perform such duties as authorized in
65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-30-20.
   D.   Firearms:
      1.   Auxiliary police officers may carry firearms while in uniform and on
duty only when authorized by the chief of police.
      2.   Auxiliary police officers, before entering upon any of their duties,
shall receive a course of training in the use of weapons and other police
procedures appropriate for the exercise of the powers conferred upon them under
this code. The training and course of study shall be determined and provided by
the corporate authorities of each municipality employing auxiliary police
officers. Before being permitted to carry a firearm, however, an auxiliary
police officer must have the same course of training as required of peace
officers under section 2 of the peace officer and probation officer firearm
training act. The municipal authorities may require that all auxiliary police
officers be residents of the municipality served by them. Before the
appointment of an auxiliary police officer, the person’s fingerprints shall be
taken, and no person shall be appointed as an auxiliary police officer if that
person has been convicted of a felony or other crime involving moral turpitude.
(65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-20(b))
   E.   Compensation: Auxiliary police officers shall receive no compensation
for services rendered.
   F.   Uniforms And Identification: Auxiliary policy officers may wear
uniforms as specified by the chief of police; however, said uniforms and
identification symbols worn by auxiliary police officers must be different and
distinct from those worn by regular police officers.
(1989 Code § 10-56)
CHAPTER 2: FIRE DEPARTMENT
Section
5-2-1: Statute Authority
5-2-2: Department Created; Composition
5-2-3: Adoption Of Constitution, Bylaws And Regulations
5-2-4: Duties Of Department
5-2-5: Chief And Deputy Chief
5-2-6: Regulations And Authority At Fires
5-2-7: Mutual Aid Agreements; Service Fee
5-2-8: Firefighters’ Pension Fund
5-2-9: Penalty
5-2-1: STATUTE AUTHORITY:
This chapter is promulgated pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-6-1.
(1989 Code § 10-143)
5-2-2: DEPARTMENT CREATED; COMPOSITION:
There is hereby created a fire department in and for the city, which shall
provide fire and emergency services, and shall be designated as the “Princeton
Fire Department”.
(1989 Code §§ 10-144, 10-147)
5-2-3: ADOPTION OF CONSTITUTION, BYLAWS AND REGULATIONS:
The department may adopt and enforce such constitution, bylaws and regulations
for its government and operation which are not inconsistent with law or the
provisions of this code and which shall be approved by the city council.
(1989 Code § 10-147)
5-2-4: DUTIES OF DEPARTMENT:
It shall be the function and duty of the fire department to:
   A.   Respond to all fire alarms, extinguish any accidental or destructive
fires, prevent the occurrence or spread of such fires within the city and
throughout the jurisdiction of the fire department, and to remain at the scene
of a fire until it has been extinguished.
   B.   Operate the city ambulance service, as provided in chapter 2A of this
title.
   C.   Undertake all other fire and emergency services as may be directed from
time to time by the city manager or the city council.
(1989 Code § 10-145)
5-2-5: CHIEF AND DEPUTY CHIEF:
   A.   Offices Created; Appointment: There are hereby created the offices of
fire chief and deputy fire chief, each of whom shall be appointed by the city
manager.
   B.   Oath And Term: Upon his or her appointment, each officer shall qualify
by taking such oath as may be prescribed by the city council. Each officer
shall serve until his or her removal or until his or her successor shall have
been appointed and qualifies.
   C.   Duties:
      1.   The fire chief shall have control, subject to the order and
direction of the city manager, of the fire department and other emergency
apparatus belonging to the city. Whenever any such apparatus needs repairing,
the fire chief shall cause the same to be done without delay.
      2.   The deputy fire chief shall assist the fire chief in the performance
of his or her duties and shall obey his or her orders with regard to the same.
During the temporary absence or disability of the fire chief, the deputy chief
shall perform all duties of the fire chief as set forth in this chapter.
(1989 Code § 10-149)
5-2-6: REGULATIONS AND AUTHORITY AT FIRES:
   A.   Firefighter Disobedience Of Orders: No member of the fire department,
when on duty as a firefighter, shall disobey any lawful order of the officer
then in command. Any member who shall violate the provisions of this subsection
shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for such offense.
(1989 Code § 10-152)
   B.   Limitation Of Action: At any fire occurring within the corporate limits
of the city, the management and control of all means employed for the
extinguishment of the same shall entirely devolve upon the officer or officers
in command, as in this chapter provided, and only such person or persons as
shall be so directed or ordered by such officers shall enter any burning
building or structure or approach the same within any limits or bounds
established by such officer or officers, and the care, protection and
preservation of all property endangered by any fire shall also devolve upon
such officer or officers and shall only be removed under his, her or their
direction or orders.
(1989 Code § 10-155)
   C.   Removal Of Obstructions: The officer in command may, during the
progress of any fire within the corporate limits of the city, as may be
necessary for the protection of other property or to prevent the fire from
spreading, direct or order that any fence or fences, building or buildings, or
any other obstruction or obstructions be torn down and removed.
(1989 Code § 10-156)
5-2-7: MUTUAL AID AGREEMENTS; SERVICE FEE:
   A.   Mutual Aid Agreements: Pursuant to law, the city council may enter into
contracts or agreements with other municipalities and fire protection districts
for mutual aid consisting of furnishing equipment and manpower from and to such
other municipalities and fire protection districts.
(1989 Code § 10-153)
   B.   Firefighting Service Fee For Nonresidents: There is hereby fixed a fee
for all firefighting services rendered by the city fire department against
persons, businesses and other entities who are not residents of the city or
municipalities that have entered into intergovernmental cooperation agreements
with the city for ambulance service. The charge for such services shall be as
established by the fire chief from time to time, with the approval of the city
manager.
(1989 Code § 10-161; amd. 2017 Code)
   C.   An invoice for any service fee provided for under this section shall be
prepared and mailed to the responsible party promptly after such service has
been rendered, and payment shall be made to the city within thirty (30) days
after the mailing of such invoice. The city attorney is hereby authorized and
directed to take legal action as may be authorized by law or this code to
collect charges which remain unpaid thirty (30) days after the date a bill was
mailed to the responsible party.
5-2-8: FIREFIGHTERS’ PENSION FUND:
   A.   Statute Authority: This section is promulgated pursuant to 40 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/4-101 et seq., as amended.
   B.   Fund Created: There is hereby created a firefighters’ pension fund for
the benefit of city “firefighters” as defined in 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/4-106.
(1989 Code § 10-201)
   C.   Administration Of Fund: The firefighters’ pension fund of the city
shall be operated and administered by the firefighters’ pension fund board of
trustees as established in section
2-2-1 of this code.
(1989 Code § 10-202)
Cross-reference:
   See section
2-2-1 of this code for firefighters’ pension fund board of trustees
5-2-9: PENALTY:
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, any person who shall violate any
provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(1989 Code § 10-142)
ARTICLE 2A: AMBULANCE SERVICE
Section
5-2A-1: Statute Authority
5-2A-2: Definitions
5-2A-3: Ambulance Service Established; Private Service Prohibited
5-2A-4: Duties
5-2A-5: Service Charges
5-2A-1: STATUTE AUTHORITY:
This article is promulgated pursuant to the authority established by 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-5-7, as amended.
(1989 Code § 10-177)
5-2A-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
EMERGENCY AMBULANCE SERVICE: Applied when the person operating an ambulance is
either responding to a bona fide emergency call or is specifically directed by
a licensed physician to disregard traffic laws in operating the ambulance and
for the purpose of the specific trip or journey that is involved.
TRANSFER SERVICE: Applies when a patient or other person is being transported
from one place to another within or without the city in other than an
emergency.
(1989 Code § 10-176)
5-2A-3: AMBULANCE SERVICE ESTABLISHED; PRIVATE SERVICE PROHIBITED:
   A.   There is hereby established the Princeton fire department ambulance
service. Such ambulance service shall be operated by the fire department under
the supervision of the fire chief.
(1989 Code § 10-178)
   B.   No private ambulance service shall be established within the city, and
no such service shall be operated within the city on a continuing basis.
(1989 Code § 10-181)
5-2A-4: DUTIES:
The ambulance service shall provide emergency ambulance service and transfer
service within or without the city when called upon as required in this
article.
(1989 Code § 10-179)
5-2A-5: SERVICE CHARGES:
   A.   Charges for ambulance service shall be at rates established from time
to time by the fire chief with the approval of the city manager.
(1989 Code § 10-180)
   B.   Bills For Service; Payment: Charges for ambulance service shall be
billed by the city to the recipient of such service, and payment shall be made
to the city within thirty (30) days after the mailing of a statement of charges
to such person. The city attorney is hereby authorized and directed to take
legal action as may be authorized by law or this code to collect charges which
remain unpaid thirty (30) days after the date a bill was mailed to the
responsible party. Nothing herein shall be construed to limit the city’s
remedies for collection of delinquent charges under this chapter. The city
shall have the authority to pursue any remedy available at law or under this
code, including but not limited to administrative proceedings pursuant to title
1 chapter 4 article A of this code.
(1989 Code § 10-180)
CHAPTER 3: ANIMAL CONTROL
Section
5-3-1: Definitions
5-3-2: Interpretation; Breed Specific Prohibited
5-3-3: Number Of Dogs And Cats
5-3-4: Cat Neutering/Spaying Required
5-3-5: Running At Large Restrictions And Prohibitions
5-3-6: Nuisance Animals
5-3-7: Impoundment, Redemption And Disposal Provisions
5-3-8: Keeping Of Vicious Dogs
5-3-9: Duty To Report
5-3-10: Rabies Control
5-3-11: Treatment Of Animals
5-3-12: Trapping, Hunting Animals
5-3-13: Riding, Racing Animals Creating A Dangerous Condition
5-3-14: Excrement Removal Required; Exceptions
5-3-15: Indecent Exhibition Of Animals
5-3-16: Penalty
5-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
ABANDONED DOG OR CAT: Running at large, wearing no collar, tag, or evidence of
ownership, the ownership of which the animal control officer shall be unable to
ascertain after diligent inquiry about the immediate neighborhood in which the
dog or cat was found or located.
ANIMAL: Every living creature, other than man, which may be affected by rabies.
ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER: A person appointed by the city manager to enforce the
provisions of this chapter.
AT LARGE: Any dog or cat shall be deemed to be at large when it is off the
premises of its owner’s real property and not restrained by a competent person.
BUSINESS DAY: Any day that the animal control facility is open to the public
for animal reclaims or regular business. (Does not include city holidays or
weekends.)
CAT: All members of the family Felidae, male or female, four (4) months of age
or older.
COMPETENT PERSON: A human being that is capable of controlling and governing
the dog or cat in question, or other animal, and to whose commands the dog or
cat is obedient.
CONFINED STRUCTURE: A securely locked pen, kennel or structure at least six
feet (6') in height designed and constructed for the keeping of a vicious dog
and designed, constructed and maintained in accordance with the standards set
forth in this chapter. Such pen, kennel or structure must have secure sides and
a secure top attached to the sides, as well as be suitable to prevent the entry
of young children. All structures used to confine vicious dogs must be locked
with a key or combination lock when such animals are within the structure and
left unattended. Such structures must have a secure bottom or floor attached to
the sides of the pen, or the sides of the pen must be embedded in the ground
not less than two feet (2'). All structures erected to house vicious dogs must
comply with all zoning and building regulations of the city. All such
structures must be adequately lighted, ventilated and kept in a clean and
sanitary condition.
CONSTRAINED: Contained within a fenced enclosure, or within the garage or home
on the owner’s premises, such enclosure to be such where other animals and dogs
would not have access to the animal or dog so constrained.
CRUELTY TO ANIMALS: The intentional or criminally negligent mistreatment of any
animal by any act or omission whereby unjustifiable physical pain, suffering,
or death is caused to or permitted upon such animal.
DANGEROUS DOG:
   A.   Any individual dog anywhere other than upon the property of the owner
or custodian of the dog and unmuzzled, unleashed or unattended by its owner or
custodian that behaves in a manner that a reasonable person would believe poses
a serious and unjustified imminent threat of serious physical injury or death
to a person or a companion animal; or
   B.   A dog that, without justification, bites a person and does not cause
serious physical injury.
DEPARTMENT: The department of agriculture of the state of Illinois.
DOG: All members of the canine family, male or female, four (4) months of age
or older.
DOMESTIC CAT: Those cats owned by an individual, a household, a business or
corporation. These cats needs are supplied by their owner(s).
IMPOUNDED: Taken into custody of the public animal control facility in the
city, town or county where the animal is found or located.
MICROCHIP: The implanting of a device for identification purposes that can be
detected by an electronic scanner.
NEUTERED OR SPAYED: To cause the animal to no longer be capable of reproducing.
OWNER: Any person, firm, association or corporation owning, keeping or
harboring a dog or cat.
RESTRAINT: A dog off the premises of its owner’s real property is under
restraint within the meaning of this chapter, If it is controlled by a line or
leash not more than six feet (6') in length when the line is held by a
competent person;
   A.   When at “heel” of a competent person;
   B.   When within a vehicle being driven, parked or stopped; or
   C.   When not more than fifty feet (50') from a competent person, if such
dog is not annoying or worrying any human or domestic animal or trespassing on
private property or in a public area where dogs or cats are forbidden.
VACCINATION AGAINST RABIES: The injection, subcutaneously or otherwise, as
approved by the state department of agriculture, of antirabic vaccine approved
by the department.
VICIOUS DOG: A dog that, without justification, attacks a person and causes
serious physical injury or death, or any individual dog that has been found to
be a “dangerous dog” on three (3) separate occasions. No dog shall be deemed
vicious if it bites, attacks or menaces a trespasser on the property of its
owner or harms or menaces anyone who has tormented or abused it or is a
professionally trained dog for law enforcement or guard duties. Vicious dogs
shall not be classified in a manner that is breed specific.
(1989 Code § 10-271)
5-3-2: INTERPRETATION; BREED SPECIFIC PROHIBITED:
No regulation or ordinance of the city shall be specific to breed.
(1989 Code § 10-286)
5-3-3: NUMBER OF DOGS AND CATS:
There shall be no limitations on the number of dogs or cats per dwelling.
Provided, however, that upon determining that any animal or animals pose a
threat to the health and safety of the residents of any such dwelling, or the
neighbors thereof, any animal control officer or police officer of the city can
remove or have removed any dogs or cats, or any other animal(s), until the
identified threat is eliminated.
(1989 Code § 10-282)
5-3-4: CAT NEUTERING/SPAYING REQUIRED:
The owners of all domestic cats within the city who allow such cats outside of
their residence shall have their cats neutered or spayed, and said cats shall
wear a tag or collar indicating compliance with this requirement.
(1989 Code § 10-282)
5-3-5: RUNNING AT LARGE RESTRICTIONS AND PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   General Prohibition: It shall be unlawful for any person owning,
keeping or possessing any animal, bird or fowl within the city to own, keep or
possess such an animal which is running at large. It shall not be a defense
that the owner or possessor of such an animal did not allow or permit such
animal to run at large. Any animal running at large is hereby declared to be a
nuisance, and may be taken up and impounded by the city animal control officer
or any city police officer, and may be redeemed only by paying the appropriate
fees as provided in section
5-3-7 of this chapter.
   B.   Dogs: Notwithstanding subsection A of this section, any dog which is
properly licensed and vaccinated as set forth in this chapter, other than dogs
determined to be vicious dogs subject to the provisions of section
5-3-8, may be allowed outside of an enclosure if under a secure leash and
accompanied by its owner or keeper, but is not to be allowed to trespass on any
private property.
   C.   Cats: Notwithstanding subsection A of this section, any cat which is
privately owned, has been spayed or neutered, and is properly tagged with an
identification tag provided by the owner or police department, which must
clearly indicate the owner’s name, current address and telephone number, may be
allowed outside of an enclosure. However, if said cat is declared a nuisance or
the city receives a complaint, then said cat will be found to be at large and
impounded if deemed necessary by the animal control officer or police.
(1989 Code § 10-274)
   C.   Poultry Running at Large: Raising, harboring or keeping chickens
(poultry) within the city limits of Princeton is permitted only in agriculture-
zoned districts and residential-zoned districts. Keeping of chickens in
agriculture-zoned districts is unrestricted. Keeping of chickens in
residential-zoned districts is restricted as follows:
      1.   Only the owners of chickens prior to the adoption of this chapter
who reside on lots zoned for single family residential use are eligible for
permitting. Those owners must obtain a permit from the city of Princeton within
sixty (60) days after adoption of this chapter. The permit shall be free of
charge. A renewal permit shall be required on May 1 of each year thereafter,
with no additional fees required. No new chicken permits will be issued after
the sixty (60) day registration period expires. Non-permitted uses will be
subject to enforcement action.
      2.   Roosters are prohibited.
      3.   No more than six (6) chicken hens shall be permitted on lots zoned
and occupied for single family residential use.
      4.   At all times, chicken hens shall be kept within a covered enclosure/
structure (henhouse) with an adjacent outdoor fenced-in area that is no less
than thirty two (32) square feet. Proper fencing material includes clean chain
link, aluminum, wood, manufactured PVC or iron, to prevent poultry from being
at-large on the owner’s property or on neighboring properties. Chicken wire is
not an approved fencing material.
      5.   An outdoor area of a minimum of six (6) square feet per chicken hen
shall be required, and a maximum of one hundred (100) square feet shall be
permitted for both the covered enclosure/structure and outdoor area.
      6.   All enclosures/structures shall be located no closer than ten (10)
feet from all property lot lines.
      7.   Electric service to a hen house shall not be provided by electrical
cord or extension cords.
      8.   All chicken hen enclosures/structures shall be located in the rear
yard.
      9.   All areas where chicken hens are kept shall be clean and well
maintained with little to no accumulation of waste and shall not produce or
cause odors that are detectable on adjacent properties. All areas shall be kept
clean, sanitary and rodent free.
      10.   All feed shall be contained in containers with tightly fitted lids.
      11.   Owner shall ensure that chickens hens do not produce excessive and/
or unreasonable noise.
      12.   Inspection of the premises by city representatives shall be a
condition of permitting.
      13.   No butchering of chickens shall be allowed anywhere on the
property.
      14.   All other poultry, including but not limited to, ducks, geese,
turkeys, and peacocks are prohibited.
      15.   If it is found that a non-eligible chicken occupation exists, or
other noncompliances are evident, and correction has not been made within the
time frame given by city authorities, fines will be levied as follows:
 
First offense                                                 $200
Second offense within any 12-month period                     $500
Third offense, or each thereafter, within any 12-month period $750
 
      16.   If there have been three (3) documented violations of any portion
of these guidelines, within any twelve (12) month period, there will be a
revocation of the permit to keep poultry on the property. Keeping poultry on
the property after license revocation will result in a seven hundred fifty
dollar ($750.00) fine per day, and for every day the violation exists. The
eligibility for that lot to raise chickens will be permanently revoked.
      17.   All other poultry, including but not limited to, ducks, geese and
turkeys, are prohibited in residential-zoned districts.
      18.   An initial building permit shall be required for all enclosures/
structures associated with the keeping of chickens. Building permit fees apply.
      19.   Chickens or other fowl shall be prohibited if expressly enumerated
in subdivision protective covenants.
      20.   Chicken uses allowed by permit runs with the land and not the
owner. Owners who move to another residential lot shall be bound by the
circumstances imposed by the new location prior to any allowance or
transference of chickens. If an eligible lot is not inhabited by chickens for
one year or more, then the eligibility for chickens is permanently revoked.
(Ord. O-21-023, 9-20-2021)
5-3-6: NUISANCE ANIMALS:
   A.   No keeper or owner of any animal shall fail to exercise proper care and
control of the animal to prevent the animal from becoming a public nuisance.
Any animal doing any of the following is declared a nuisance:
      1.   Excessive, continuous or untimely barking;
      2.   Molesting passersby;
      3.   Biting or attacking any person without provocation on one or more
occasion;
      4.   Chasing vehicles including bicycles;
      5.   Attacking other domestic animals;
      6.   Trespassing upon school grounds or trespassing upon private property
in such manner as to damage property.
   B.   Other nuisances are:
      1.   Foul odors;
      2.   The keeping of unclean or filthy surroundings where an animal is
maintained;
      3.   Any animal matter that is putrid, foul or offensive;
      4.   Animal noises that disturb the public peace; or
      5.   Any animal that is in public that may alarm or disturb the general
public, such as snakes, spiders, lizards etc.
(1989 Code § 10-281)
5-3-7: IMPOUNDMENT, REDEMPTION AND DISPOSAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   Authority To Impound; Record Information: It shall be the duty of every
police officer and the animal control officer of the city to apprehend any
animal found running at large contrary to the provisions of section
5-3-5 of this chapter and to impound such animal in the city pound or other
suitable place. The animal control officer or some other designated official,
upon receiving any animal, shall make a complete registry, entering the type,
breed (if possible), color and sex of such animal and the location the animal
was found or located. All animals will be scanned for the presence of a
microchip.
(1989 Code § 10-275)
   B.   Notice Of Impoundment: Not later than three (3) days after the
impounding of any animal, an attempt will be made to notify the owner and any
appropriate agencies and/or any not for profit animal organizations, or if the
owner of the animal is unknown, notice shall be broadcast daily for five (5)
days on any radio station broadcasting within the city describing the animal
and the place and time of taking of such animal.
(1989 Code § 10-276)
   C.   Redemption Provisions; Costs: The owner of any animal so impounded may
reclaim such animal upon payment of all costs and charges incurred by the city
for impounding and maintenance of the animal. The charges for the following are
as provided in the city fee schedule and shall be paid to the city: impounding
any animal; keeping any animal; and giving notice. In cases of neutering,
spaying, microchipping and any or all vaccinations, the owner or adopter will
be responsible for these costs before release of the animal.
(1989 Code § 10-276)
   D.   Disposition Of Unclaimed Or Diseased Animals:
      1.   The animal control officer shall keep animals impounded for a period
of seven (7) days after broadcast of notice if the owner of the dog or cat is
unknown, and for ten (10) days from the date of notice to the owner if the
owner is known. If, at the expiration of notice by broadcast or to the owner,
such dog or cat shall not be redeemed, it may be destroyed.
      2.   Any dog or cat which appears to be infected or suffering from rabies
or other infectious or dangerous disease, as determined by a licensed
veterinarian, shall not be released but may be immediately destroyed.
(1989 Code § 10-277)
5-3-8: KEEPING OF VICIOUS DOGS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, harbor, own, or in any way possess
within the corporate limits of the city a vicious dog, subject to the following
exceptions and standards:
   A.   Identification of Vicious Dogs:
      1.   a.   Any police officer or animal control officer of the city who
suspects that a dog may be vicious within the meaning of this chapter may
conduct an investigation to determine whether or not the dog has committed any
act or displays any characteristics which qualify it as a vicious dog. If upon
the completion of such investigation the officer concludes that the dog is a
vicious dog, such officer shall issue a written notice of determination which
includes at least the following:
            (1)   A description of the dog;
            (2)   Information available concerning the ownership of the dog;
            (3)   A statement or conclusion that the dog is a vicious dog
within the meaning of this chapter;
            (4)   A description of the investigation conducted by the officer
and what acts or characteristics discovered during the investigation led the
officer to conclude that the dog is a vicious dog;
            (5)   Notice to the owner that the vicious dog must be licensed and
housed in accordance with the requirements of this chapter;
            (6)   Notice that the owner may appeal the determination of the
officer to the mayor or his or her designee within seven (7) business days
after the determination is served upon the owner.
         b.   The officer shall serve the notice of determination on the owner
by certified mail or hand delivery to the last known address of the owner.
      2.   The owner may appeal any determination that the owner’s dog is a
vicious dog. An appeal must be directed to the city manager and must be filed
by the owner in the office of the city clerk within seven (7) business days
after receipt of the notice of determination which identifies the dog as a
vicious dog. Should the owner fail to appeal the determination within seven (7)
business days, the determination of the investigating officer that the dog is a
vicious dog shall become final. Upon receipt of an appeal, the city manager
shall convene a hearing for the purpose of determining whether the dog in
question is a vicious dog.
      3.   The hearing of an owner’s appeal shall be held within sixty (60)
days of the date on which the appeal is filed. The city manager shall serve a
notice of the time, date and location of the hearing upon the owner of the
allegedly vicious dog at least five (5) business days before the hearing. The
hearing shall be conducted before the city administrative hearing officer
pursuant to the procedures set forth in title 1, chapter 4A of this code,
unless different procedures are set forth in this section. At the hearing, the
owner shall have the opportunity to present evidence to explain why the dog
should not be declared a vicious dog. The owner shall have the right to be
represented by legal counsel at the owner’s expense. The officer who made the
initial determination that the dog is vicious, and any other persons having
knowledge of the facts and circumstances, may be heard by the administrative
hearing officer and shall be subject to cross examination by the owner or the
owner’s attorney. The administrative hearing officer shall decide all issues
for or against the owner of the dog regardless of whether the owner appears at
the hearing.
      4.   Within five (5) business days after the conclusion of the hearing,
the administrative hearing officer shall determine whether or not the dog is a
vicious dog within the meaning of this chapter, and shall notify the owner in
writing of its determination. The decision of the administrative hearing
officer shall be final.
      5.   If any officer of the city determines that the public safety
requires the immediate impoundment of a dog as authorized by this chapter, the
officer shall within a reasonable time notify the owner of the facts and
circumstances relating to the impoundment. Upon receipt of such notification,
the owner may appeal the determination of the officer to the city manager in
accordance with the procedures established hereinabove for the identification
of vicious dogs.
   B.   Licensing of Vicious Dogs:
      1.   No person shall possess any vicious dog for a period of more than
fifteen (15) days after the dog’s designation as vicious is final without
having first obtained an annual vicious dog license therefor from the city.
      2.   An application for a license to possess a vicious dog shall be filed
with the city on a form prescribed and provided by the city and shall be
accompanied by all of the following:
         a.   Verification of the identity of the owner and current address by
providing a photostatic copy of the owner’s driver’s license.
         b.   Proof of ownership of the vicious dog.
         c.   A copy of the current immunization and health record of the
vicious dog prepared by a veterinarian licensed to practice in the State of
Illinois.
         d.   Proof that the vicious dog has been spayed or neutered.
         e.   A certificate of insurance evidencing coverage in an amount not
less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00), insuring said person
against any claim, loss, damage or injury to persons, domestic animals, or
property resulting from the acts, whether intentional or unintentional, of the
vicious dog.
         f.   Two (2) photographs of the vicious dog to be licensed taken not
less than one (1) month before the date of the application. One (1) photograph
shall provide a front view of the vicious dog and shall clearly show the face
and ears of the vicious dog. One (1) photograph shall show a side view of the
vicious dog.
         g.   A license fee of seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00).
         h.   Such other information as may be required by the city clerk.
      3.   Upon receipt of an application, the city clerk shall forward such
application to the city’s animal control officer, who shall cause an inspection
of the premises on which the vicious dog shall be kept to determine that all
provisions of this section relating to confinement and posting of signs have
been complied with by the applicant. Upon completion of the inspection, the
code enforcement officer shall notify the city clerk in writing of the results
of its inspection.
      4.   Upon receipt of the results of the inspection, the city clerk shall
notify the applicant of the approval or denial of the license. In the event
that the license is denied, the notification shall be provided in writing and
the reasons for such denial shall be stated. Upon denial, the owner or keeper
of the vicious dog shall remedy the reasons for denial, if possible, and
immediately reapply within forty-eight (48) hours, or remove the vicious dog
from the municipality within forty-eight (48) hours. Upon approval, the clerk
shall issue a license to the applicant.
      5.   A vicious dog license expires annually. No one shall own, possess,
keep or maintain a vicious dog without applying annually for a new vicious dog
license as provided for in this section to avoid owning, possessing or
maintaining a vicious dog for which the license has expired.
   C.   Confinement of Vicious Dogs: No person shall possess any vicious dog
unless the vicious dog is confined in accordance with this section. Any owner
who has appealed a determination that a dog is vicious shall temporarily
confine such dog in accordance with this section until a final determination
regarding such appeal is issued.
      1.   Confinement Indoors: No vicious dog may be kept on a porch, patio or
in any part of a house or structure that would allow the vicious dog to exit
the structure on its own volition. No vicious dog shall be kept in a house or
structure when the windows are open or when screen windows or screen doors are
the only obstacle preventing the vicious dog from exiting the structure.
      2.   Confinement in an Exterior Yard: No person shall confine a vicious
dog in an exterior area unless such vicious dog is confined in a confinement
structure constructed and maintained in accordance with this section, except
that a vicious dog may be confined outside of a confinement structure in a
manner set forth in subsection C3 hereof. Such a confinement structure must be
located in an area enclosed and screened by an opaque privacy fence of six (6)
feet in height and composed of wood, metal, vinyl or some other material
designed to completely block the view from both within and without the fenced
area to the other side of the fenced area.
      3.   Confinement on Leash and Run Line:
         a.   No person shall permit a vicious dog to go outside a confinement
structure, house or other structure unless the vicious dog is securely
restrained with a leash no longer than three (3) feet in length and fitted with
a muzzle or securely restrained on a run line no longer than ten (10) feet in
length and fitted with a muzzle. No person shall permit a vicious dog to be
kept on a leash unless a person is in actual physical control of the leash. Any
such leash or run line must be enclosed and screened by an opaque privacy fence
of six (6) feet in height and composed of wood, metal, vinyl, or some other
material designed to completely block the view from both within and without the
fenced area to the other side of the fenced area.
         b.   The only time that a vicious dog may be allowed out of the
enclosure or off the run line are when the dog is in a carrier, crate or other
enclosure designed to and capable of safely confining the dog for
transportation: if it is necessary for the owner or keeper to obtain veterinary
care for the vicious dog; or to sell or give away the vicious dog; or to comply
with the order of a court of competent jurisdiction. The owner or keeper may
also allow the dog out of the enclosure or off the run line to walk the vicious
dog; provided that said vicious dog is securely muzzled and restrained with a
leash having a minimum tensile strength of at least three hundred (300) pounds
and not exceeding three (3) feet in length, and shall be at all times under the
direct physical control and supervision of the owner or keeper of the vicious
dog.
   D.   Impoundment of vicious dogs.
      1.   Any vicious dog which is not properly confined shall be impounded by
a police officer or animal control officer of the city; provided, however, that
if the police officer or animal control officer reasonably believes that such
dog poses an immediate threat of severe injury to any person, such officials
are authorized to kill such dog. Any vicious dog found to be running at large
by any member of the city police department shall be presumed to be in
violation of this section and shall be subject to impoundment.
      2.   If the incident giving rise to the impoundment has resulted in an
injury to a person, upon impoundment by the police department, the chief of
police or his or her designee shall notify the rabies control administrator of
the county pursuant to 510 ILCS 5/12, and shall transfer control of the vicious
dog to the administrator in accordance with 510 ILCS 5/13.
      3.   Any vicious dog that has previously been impounded for not properly
being confined or for running at large in violation of subsection C1, C2 or C3
hereof, or which has previously bitten or attacked a human being or other
domestic animal without provocation, shall be ordered destroyed in an
expeditious and humane manner upon any subsequent violations of those
subsections or upon any subsequent unprovoked attack or bite.
   E.   Redemption of Impounded Vicious Dog: An owner of a vicious dog holding
a license pursuant to this section, may redeem an impounded vicious dog if: the
vicious dog has been impounded pursuant to subsection D. of this section; and
the vicious dog has not caused severe injury to a person, subject to the
following conditions:
      1.   Proof of a valid license issued by the city under subsection B of
this section; and
      2.   Payment of the cost of keeping the vicious dog during the period of
impoundment; and
      3.   Approval by the city code enforcement officer, or Bureau County
animal control of the enclosure in which the vicious dog will be kept.
   F.   Sale or Transfer of Ownership or Location Prohibited: No person shall
sell, barter, offer to breed or in any other way dispose of a vicious dog or
its offspring to any person within the city without approval from a court of
competent jurisdiction, or the city manager, unless the recipient resides
permanently in the same household and on the same premises as the registered
owner of such vicious dog or the recipient is a persons who does not reside
within the city, provided they give written notice to the person who will be
receiving the vicious dog that such dog has been deemed a vicious dog under
this section. An owner or keeper of a vicious dog shall notify the city manager
when he or she moves the vicious dog to a different residence from where he or
she formerly lived, regardless of whether it is in or outside of the city.
   G.   Reporting Requirements of License:
      1.   Any person holding a license pursuant to subsection B of this
section shall report the incidence of any of the following events:
         a.   The sale, barter, exchange, gift or death of any vicious dog
shall be reported within forty-eight (48) hours.
         b.   The escape from confinement of any vicious dog shall be reported
upon discovery of the escape.
         c.   The biting or nipping of any person or animal by a vicious dog
shall be reported immediately upon occurrence.
         d.   The permanent removal of any vicious dog from the territorial
limits of the city shall be reported within forty-eight (48) hours of such
removal by surrender of the license of the owner to the city clerk.
      2.   Except as otherwise provided in this section, the report of any
incident required to be reported under this subsection shall be made to the
city police department.
   H.   Sign Required: All persons possessing a vicious dog shall display in a
prominent place on the premises where a vicious dog is to be kept a sign which
is readable by the public from a distance of not less than one hundred feet
(100') using the words “Beware of Dog.” A similar sign shall be posted on any
confinement structure.
   I.   Revocation of License: A license granted pursuant to this section shall
be automatically revoked upon the second violation by the licensee of any
provision of this section. In the event of a revocation of the license, the
license fee shall be retained by the city and the vicious dog must be removed
from the municipality within forty-eight (48) hours.
   J.   Spaying or Neutering of Vicious Dog: Within ten (10) days of the
determination that a dog is vicious becomes final, the owner of the vicious dog
shall have it spayed or neutered.
   K.   Exceptions: This section shall not apply to any K-9 patrol dogs or
police dogs as defined in this chapter.
   L.   Penalties: Any person found to have violated this section shall be
fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day a violation continues shall
constitute a separate offense. Additionally, any person found to have violated
this section shall pay all expenses, including shelter, food, veterinary
expenses and other expenses necessitated by the seizure of the dog for the
protection of the public, and such other expenses as may be required for the
destruction of any such dog.
   M.   Failure to Comply: It shall be unlawful for the owner, keeper or
harborer of a vicious dog registered with the city to fail to comply with the
requirements and conditions set forth in this section. Any vicious dog found to
be the subject of a violation of this section is subject to immediate seizure
and impoundment. In addition, failure to comply may result in the revocation of
the license of such animal resulting in the immediate removal of the animal
from the city.
   N.   Severability: If any subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this
section is, for any reason, held to be unconstitutional or invalid by a
decision of any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect
the validity of the remaining portions of this section.
(1989 Code § 10-278)
5-3-9: DUTY TO REPORT:
All dog owners, whether or not their dog is licensed as a vicious dog pursuant
to section 5-4-8 of this chapter, receiving notice or having knowledge that
their dog has bitten or attacked a human being or domestic animal without
provocation shall immediately notify the police department of said incident.
5-3-10: RABIES CONTROL:
   A.   Rabies Crisis:
      1.   Whenever it becomes necessary to safeguard the public from the
dangers of rabies, the mayor, if he or she deems it necessary, shall issue a
proclamation ordering every person owning or keeping a dog to confine it
securely on his or her premises, and each such dog shall have a muzzle of
sufficient strength to prevent its biting any person.
      2.   Any dog running at large during the time of the proclamation shall
be seized and impounded unless noticeably infected with rabies and displaying
vicious propensities. If the dog is noticeably infected with rabies, it shall
be killed by a police officer or the animal control officer without notice to
the owner.
(1989 Code § 10-279)
      3.   Dogs impounded during the first two (2) days of such proclamation
shall, if claimed within five (5) days, be released to the owner, unless
infected with rabies, upon payment of the impounding charges provided in the
city fee schedule. If unclaimed after that period, the dog may be summarily
destroyed.
(1989 Code § 10-279)
   B.   Rabies Suspects:
      1.   If a dog is believed to have rabies or has been bitten by a dog
suspected of having rabies, the dog shall be confined by a leash or chain on
the owner’s premises and shall be placed under observation of a veterinarian at
the expense of the owner for a period of two (2) weeks. The owner shall notify
the animal control officer of the fact that his or her dog has been exposed to
rabies, and at his or her discretion, the animal control officer is empowered
to have such dog removed from the owner’s premises to a veterinary clinic and
there placed under observation for a period of two (2) weeks at the expense of
the owner.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person knowing or suspecting that a dog
has rabies to allow such dog to be taken off his or her premises or beyond the
limits of the city, except to a veterinary hospital within the county, without
the written permission of the animal control officer. Every owner, or other
person, upon ascertaining a dog is rabid shall immediately notify the animal
control officer or a police officer, who shall either remove the dog to the
pound or summarily destroy it.
(1989 Code § 10-280)
   C.   Vaccination Requirements: Any owner, possessor or maintainer of a dog
shall ensure that it is inoculated or vaccinated against rabies within the time
prescribed by law. Further, such person shall keep a certificate of a
veterinarian licensed by the state as proof of such inoculation or vaccination.
The owner of a dog shall provide the dog with a collar or harness made of
leather, metal or other substantial material to which shall be securely
fastened the tag issued by the state rabies inspector, deputy inspector or any
licensed veterinarian showing that such dog has been vaccinated against rabies
during the current or immediately preceding year. A dog found within the city
not wearing the proper collar and tags shall be impounded.
5-3-11: TREATMENT OF ANIMALS:
   A.   Cruelty To Animals: It is unlawful for any person to commit the crime
of cruelty to animals or to overdrive, overload or unnecessarily or cruelly
beat, mutilate, kill, torture or abuse, or cause or procure to be overdriven,
overloaded, cruelly beaten, mutilated, killed, tortured, or abused, any animal.
(1989 Code §§ 9-30,10-284)
   B.   Food, Drink And Shelter: No person in the city shall fail to provide
any animal in his or her charge or custody with necessary sustenance, drink,
and protection from the elements, or cause any of these acts to be done.
   C.   Abandonment: No person in the city shall abandon any animal or cause
such act to be done.
   D.   Fights: No person in the city shall maintain any place where fowl or
any animals are suffered to fight upon exhibition or for the sport upon any
wager.
   E.   Poisoning: No person in the city shall poison any dog, cat or other
domesticated animal, or distribute poison in any manner whatsoever with the
intent or for the purpose of poisoning any dog, cat or other domesticated
animal.
(1989 Code § 9-30)
   F.   Wild Birds: No person in the city shall frighten, shoot at, wound,
kill, take, capture, ensnare, net, trap or in any other manner molest or injure
any wild bird or part thereof (their nest and eggs) as defined in 520 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/2.2.
(1989 Code § 9-30)
5-3-12: TRAPPING, HUNTING ANIMALS:
   A.   Trapping Animals: It shall be unlawful for any person to trap or
attempt to trap any animal in the city limits. The animal control officer and
the person designated by the chief of police are the only authorized persons to
trap or attempt to trap animals within the city. The only exception, with prior
notification to the chief of police or his or her designee, would include not
for profit animal organizations.
(1989 Code § 10-285)
   B.   Hunting Animals: No person shall engage in the hunting or killing of
any animal within the city except as prescribed by law.
(1989 Code § 9-13)
5-3-13: RIDING, RACING ANIMALS CREATING A DANGEROUS CONDITION:
Prohibited: No person in the city shall run, ride, drive, race or trot any
horse or other animal in any public street, lane, alley or public place at a
speed or in a manner which is dangerous to any person using such street, lane,
alley or public place or the person’s property.
(1989 Code § 9-9)
5-3-14: EXCREMENT REMOVAL REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit a dog or cat to defecate
on property, public or private, not owned or possessed by such person unless
such person has in his or her immediate possession an appropriate depository
for the transmission of excrement to a receptacle located upon property owned
or possessed by the person. This section shall not apply to a person who has
visual or physical disabilities.
(1989 Code § 10-283)
5-3-15: INDECENT EXHIBITION OF ANIMALS:
Prohibited: No person in the city shall exhibit any studhorse or bull or other
animal indecently, nor shall any person let any male animal to any female
animal except in some place wholly enclosed and out of public view.
(1989 Code § 9-30)
5-3-16: PENALTY:
Unless otherwise provided herein, any person violating any provision of this
chapter may be punishable by a fine of not less than seventy five dollars
($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such
offense.
(1989 Code § 10-272)
Cross-reference:
   See chapter 1-4A of this code for prepayment fine in lieu of court
appearance
CHAPTER 4: GENERAL OFFENSES
Section
5-4-1: Short Title
5-4-2: Aid In Escape
5-4-3: Resisting, Interfering With Police Officer
5-4-4: Penalty
5-4-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter, including articles A through E, shall be known and may be cited
as the OFFENSES ORDINANCE OF THE CITY OF PRINCETON.
(1989 Code § 9-1)
5-4-2: AID IN ESCAPE:
No person in the city shall offer or endeavor to assist any person in the
custody of a police officer, a member of the police department or a person duly
empowered with police authority to escape or to attempt to escape from such
custody.
(1989 Code § 9-11)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 720 ILCS 5/31-7
5-4-3: RESISTING, INTERFERING WITH POLICE OFFICER:
No person in the city shall resist any police officer, any member of the police
department, or any person duly empowered with police authority, while in the
discharge or apparent discharge of his or her duty, or in any way interfere
with or hinder him or her in the discharge of his or her duty.
(1989 Code § 9-17)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 720 ILCS 5/31-1
5-4-4: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter, including articles
A through F, shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than seventy five
dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(1989 Code § 9-2)
ARTICLE 4A: OFFENSES RELATING TO PERSONS, HEALTH AND SAFETY
Section
5-4A-1: Assault
5-4A-2: Battery
5-4A-3: Disorderly Conduct
5-4A-4: Mob Action
5-4A-5: Loitering
5-4A-6: Disturbing Religious Worship
5-4A-7: Throwing, Discharging Stench Bombs
5-4A-1: ASSAULT:
No person in the city shall commit an assault on the person of another. A
person commits an assault when, without lawful authority, he or she engages in
