conviction, be fined not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(1989 Code § 9-2)
CHAPTER 8: CHRONIC NUISANCES PROPERTIES
Section
5-8-1: Definitions
5-8-2: Violations
5-8-3: Procedure
5-8-4: Remedies
5-8-5: Abatement Of Nuisance; Burden Of Proof
5-8-6: Emergency Closing Procedure
5-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
CHRONIC NUISANCE PROPERTY: Property upon which three (3) or more occurrences of
nuisance activity have occurred during a twelve (12) month period as a result
of any three (3) separate factual events that have been independently
investigated by any law enforcement agency.
   A.   Disorderly conduct, as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/26-
1 or this code.
   B.   Unlawful use of weapons, as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/24-1 et seq. or this code.
   C.   Mob action, as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/25-1 or this
code.
   D.   Discharge of a firearm, as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
24-1.2 and 5/24-1.5 or this code.
   E.   Gambling, as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/28-1 or this
code.
   F.   Possession, manufacture or delivery of cannabis, controlled substances,
synthetic or look-alike substances, as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 570/401 et seq. or this code.
   G.   Assault or battery, as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12
et seq. or this code.
   H.   Sexual abuse or related offense, as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-1.50 et seq. or this code.
   I.   Public indecency, as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-30
or this code.
   J.   Prostitution, as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-14 et
seq. or this code.
   K.   Criminal damage to property, as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/21-1 et seq. or this code.
   L.   Possession, cultivation, manufacture or delivery of cannabis, as
defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq. or this code.
   M.   Illegal consumption or possession of alcohol, as defined in 235
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1 et seq. or this code.
   N.   Violation of any city of Princeton code relative to garbage, junk and/
or weeds.
   O.   Violation of any city of Princeton ordinance or state of Illinois
statute controlling or regulating the sale or use of alcoholic beverages.
CONTROL: The ability to regulate, restrain, dominate, counteract or govern
conduct that occurs on that property.
OWNER: Any person, agent, firm or corporation having any legal or equitable
interest in the property. “Owner” includes, but is not limited to:
   A.   A mortgagor in possession in whom is vested:
   1.   All or part of the legal title to the property; or
   2.   All or part of the beneficial ownership and the right to the present
use and enjoyment of the premises; or
   B.   An occupant, including a tenant, who can control what occurs on the
property.
   C.   Any person acting as agent of the owner or occupant.
PERMIT: To suffer, allow, consent to, acquiesce by failure to prevent, or
expressly assent or agree to the doing of an act.
PERSON: Any natural person, association, partnership or corporation capable of
owning or using property in the city of Princeton.
PROPERTY: Any real property, including land and that which is affixed,
incidental, or pertinent to land, including, but not limited to, any premises,
room, house, building, or structure, or any separate part or portion thereof,
whether permitted or not.
(1989 Code § 9-222)
Cross-reference:
   Alcoholic beverages, see title 3, chapter 1 of this code
   Garbage, see title 8, chapter 5 of this code
5-8-2: VIOLATIONS:
   A.   It is hereby declared a nuisance and danger to public health, safety,
welfare, peace and comfort for any owner of property within the city to permit
such property to become a nuisance property as defined in this chapter.
   B.   Any owner who permits property under his or her ownership or control to
be a public nuisance property shall be in violation of this chapter and subject
to its remedies.
(1989 Code § 9-221)
   C.   The third occurrence of a nuisance activity, as defined in this
chapter, and each subsequent occurrence thereof, occurring during any twelve
(12) month period, constitutes a separate violation of this chapter.
5-8-3: PROCEDURE:
When the city chief of police receives two (2) police reports documenting the
occurrence of nuisance activity on or within a property within a twelve (12)
month period, the chief of police shall, if he or she determines, upon
investigation, that the documented nuisance activity has occurred:
   A.   Notify the owner in writing that the property is in danger of becoming
a chronic nuisance property. The notice shall contain the following
information:
      1.   The street address or a legal description sufficient for
identification of the property.
      2.   A statement that the chief of police has information that the
property may be a chronic nuisance property, with a concise description of the
nuisance activities determined to exist or have occurred, and a statement that
a third occurrence of nuisance activity may result in a determination that the
property is a chronic nuisance property.
   B.   After complying with the notification procedures described in
subsection A, upon receipt of a police report documenting the occurrence of a
third nuisance activity at or within a property within a twelve (12) month
period, if the chief of police determines the property has become a chronic
nuisance property, the chief of police shall:
      1.   Notify the owner in writing that the property has been determined to
be a chronic nuisance property. The notice shall contain the following
information:
         a.   The street address or legal description sufficient for
identification of the property.
         b.   A statement that the chief of police has determined the property
to be chronic nuisance property, with a concise description of the nuisance
activities leading to the findings.
         c.   Demand that the owner respond within ten (10) days to the chief
of police and propose a course of action that the chief of police agrees will
abate the nuisance activities giving rise to the violation.
      2.   Service shall be made either personally or by certified, postage
prepaid, return receipt requested, addressed to the owner at the address of the
property believed to be a chronic nuisance property or such place which is
likely to give the owner notice of the determination by the chief of police.
      3.   A copy of the notice shall also be posted at the property after ten
(10) days has elapsed from the service or mailing of the notice to the person
in charge, and the person in charge has not contacted the chief of police.
      4.   The failure of any person to receive notice that the property may be
a chronic nuisance property shall not invalidate or otherwise affect the
proceedings under this chapter.
      5.   If, after notice is provided as set forth herein, but prior to the
commencement of legal proceedings by the city pursuant to this chapter, an
owner in charge stipulates with the chief of police that the owner will pursue
a course of action the parties agree they will abate the nuisance activities
giving rise to the violation, the chief of police may agree to postpone legal
proceedings for a period of not less than ten (10) nor more than thirty (30)
days, except in the case of a nuisance activity under section
5-9-6 of this chapter. If the agreed course of action does not result in the
abatement of the nuisance activity or if no agreement concerning abatement is
reached within thirty (30) days, the chief of police shall request
authorization for the city council to commence legal proceeding to abate the
nuisance activity.
      6.   Concurrent with the notification procedures set forth herein, the
chief of police shall send copies of the notice, as well as any other
documentation which supports legal proceedings, to the city council.
   C.   When a owner makes a response to the chief of police as required in
subsection B of this section, any conduct or statements made in connection with
the furnishings of that response shall not constitute an admission that any
nuisance activities have or are occurring. This subsection does not require the
exclusion of any evidence which is otherwise admissible or offered for any
other purpose.
(1989 Code § 9-225)
5-8-4: REMEDIES:
   A.   In the event a court or administrative hearing officer determines
property to be a chronic nuisance property, the court or administrative hearing
officer may order that the property be closed and secured against all use and
occupancy for a period of not less than thirty (30) days, but not more than one
hundred eighty (180) days, or the court or administrative hearing officer may
employ any other remedy deemed thereby to be appropriate to abate the nuisance.
   B.   In addition to the remedy provided in subsection A of this section, the
court may impose upon the owner of the property a civil penalty in the amount
of up to one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day, payable to the city of
Princeton, for each day the owner had actual knowledge that the property was a
public nuisance property, and permitted the property to remain public nuisance
property.
   C.   In determining what remedy or remedies shall be allowed, the court may
consider evidence of other conduct which has occurred on the property
including, but not limited to:
      1.   The disturbance of neighbors.
      2.   The recurrence of loud and obnoxious noises.
      3.   Repeated consumption of alcohol in public.
      4.   The repeated sale or possession of controlled substances on the
premises.
(1989 Code § 9-223)
5-8-5: ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE; BURDEN OF PROOF:
   A.   The city attorney, at the direction of the city manager, may commence
an action to abate a public nuisance as described herein. Upon being satisfied
by affidavits or other sworn evidence that an alleged public nuisance exists,
the court may, without notice or bond, enter a temporary restraining order or a
preliminary injunction to enjoin any defendant from maintaining such nuisance
and may enter an order restraining any defendant from removing or interfering
with all property used in conjunction with the public nuisance.
(1989 Code § 9-224)
   B.   In an action seeking closure of a chronic nuisance property, the city
shall have the initial burden of showing by preponderance of the evidence that
the property is a chronic nuisance property.
   C.   It is a defense to an action seeking the closure of a chronic nuisance
property that the owner of the property at the time in question could not, in
the exercise of reasonable care or diligence, determine that the property had
become a public nuisance property, or could not, in spite of the exercise of
reasonable care and diligence, control the conduct leading to the findings that
the property is a chronic nuisance property.
   D.   In establishing the amount of any civil penalty requested, the court
may consider any of the following factors if they need be found appropriate,
and shall cite those found applicable:
      1.   The actions or lack of action taken by the owner to mitigate or
correct the problem at the property.
      2.   Whether the problem at the property was repeated or continuous.
      3.   The magnitude or gravity of the problem.
      4.   The cooperation of the owner with the city.
      5.   The cost of the city investigating and correcting or attempting to
correct the condition.
(1989 Code § 9-226)
5-8-6: EMERGENCY CLOSING PROCEDURE:
   A.   In the event that it is determined that the property is an immediate
threat to the public safety and welfare, the city may apply to the court for
such interim relief, as is deemed by the chief of police to be appropriate. In
such an event, there need not be compliance with the notification provision set
forth in section
5-8-3 of this chapter; however, the city shall make a diligent effort to notify
the person in charge prior to a court hearing.
   B.   In the event that the court finds the property constitutes a “chronic
nuisance property”, as defined in section
5-8-1 of this chapter, the court may order the remedy set out herein. In
addition, in the event that it also finds the person in charge had knowledge of
activities or conditions of the property constituting or violating this chapter
and permitted such activities to occur, the court may assess a civil fine as
provided herein.
   C.   The court may authorize the city to physically secure the property
against use or occupancy in the event the owner fails to do so within the time
specified by the court. In the event that the city is authorized to secure the
property, all costs reasonably incurred by the city to effect a closure shall
be made and assessed as a lien against said property. As used herein, “costs”
means those costs actually incurred by the city for the physical securing of
the property, as well as tenant relocation costs.
   D.   The city street department effecting the closure shall prepare a
statement of cost, and the city shall thereafter submit said statement to the
court for its review. If no objection of the statement is made within the
period described by the court, a lien in said amount may be recorded against
said property.
   E.   Any person who is assessed the cost of closure and/or a civil penalty
by the court shall be personally liable for the payment thereof to the city.
   F.   A tenant is entitled to his or her reasonable relocation costs, as
those are determined by the court, if, without actual notice, the tenant moved
into the property after either:
      1.   The owner or tenant received notice as described herein of the
police chief’s determination that the property is a chronic nuisance property.
      2.   An unknown owner or other agent received notice of an action brought
pursuant to this chapter.
(1989 Code § 9-227)
CHAPTER 9: SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES FOR CERTAIN CRIMES
Section
5-9-1: Purpose
5-9-2: Definitions
5-9-3: Public Nuisance Declared; Vehicles Subject To Seizure And Impoundment
5-9-4: Authority To Seize And Impound; Owner Removal Authorized
5-9-5: Posting Bond
5-9-6: Administrative Hearing
5-9-7: Disposition Of Impounded Vehicles
5-9-8: Appeals; Judicial Review
5-9-9: Applicability Of Other Laws; Exceptions
5-9-10: Use Of Fees
5-9-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to reduce, eliminate and curb drug activity,
illegal firearm activity, illegal driving under the influence and while license
suspended or revoked, and significant events involving driving without a valid
driver’s license in the city by providing for the seizure and impounding of
motor vehicles used in such activities and providing a civil penalty therefor,
to better maintain the public health, safety and welfare of the residents of
the city.
(Ord. O-16-004, 4-18-2016)
5-9-2: DEFINITIONS:
HEARING OFFICER: The administrative hearing officer appointed pursuant to
section
1-4A-4 of this code.
OWNER OF RECORD: The record titleholder to a motor vehicle as registered with
the secretary of state of the state of Illinois, or any other applicable
governmental agency.
(Ord. O-16-004, 4-18-2016)
Cross-reference:
   See section
1-4A-6 of this code
5-9-3: PUBLIC NUISANCE DECLARED; VEHICLES SUBJECT TO SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT:
A motor vehicle operated by or with the permission, express or implied, of the
owner of record shall be declared a public nuisance and shall be subject to
seizure and impoundment under this chapter where such motor vehicle is used in
the commission of any of the violations set forth in this section or when the
commission of any of the violations set forth in this section makes impoundment
of the motor vehicle reasonably necessary as a community caretaking function so
that the motor vehicle does not jeopardize public safety and the efficient
movement of vehicular traffic. It shall not be necessary for criminal charges
to be filed, prosecuted and/or proven in order to demonstrate that one or more
of the following violations has/have been committed:
   A.   The operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, an offense for which a motor vehicle may be seized and
forfeited pursuant to 720 ILCS 5/36-1; or
   B.   Driving under the influence of alcohol, another drug or drugs, an
intoxicating compound or compounds, or any combination thereof, in violation of
625 ILCS 5/11-501; or
   C.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, a felony or in violation of the cannabis control act (720
ILCS 550/1 et seq.); or
   D.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, an offense in violation of the Illinois controlled
substances act (720 ILCS 570/100 et seq.); or
   E.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, an offense in violation of 720 ILCS 5/24-1 (unlawful use of
weapons), 720 ILCS 5/24-1.5 (reckless discharge of a firearm), or 720 ILCS 5/
24-3.1 (unlawful possession of firearms and firearm ammunition); or
   F.   Driving while a driver’s license, permit, or privilege to operate a
motor vehicle is suspended or revoked pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/6-303; except that
vehicles shall not be subjected to seizure or impoundment if the suspension is
for an unpaid citation (parking or moving) or due to failure to comply with
emission testing; or
   G.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle while soliciting, possessing or
attempting to solicit or possess cannabis or a controlled substance, as defined
by the cannabis control act or the Illinois controlled substances act; or
   H.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle with an expired driver’s license,
in violation of 625 ILCS 5/6-101, if the period of expiration is greater than
one year; or
   I.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a
driver’s license or permit, in violation of 625 ILCS 5/6-101, or operating a
motor vehicle without ever having been issued a driver’s license or permit due
to a person’s age; or
   J.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle by a person against whom a warrant
has been issued by a circuit clerk in Illinois for failing to answer charges
that the driver violated 625 ILCS 5/6-101 (driving without a valid license or
permit), 625 ILCS 5/6-303 (driving while license, permit, or privilege to
operate a motor vehicle is suspended or revoked), or 625 ILCS 5/11-501 (driving
under the influence of alcohol, another drug or drugs, an intoxicating compound
or compounds, or any combination thereof); or
   K.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, an offense in violation of article 16 (theft and related
offenses) of the criminal code of 2012 (720 ILCS 5/16-0.1 et seq.); or
   L.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, any other misdemeanor or felony offense in violation of the
criminal code of 2012; or
   M.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in violation of 625 ILCS 5/11-503
(reckless driving):
      1.   While the vehicle is part of a funeral procession; or
      2.   In a manner that interferes with a funeral procession.
(Ord. O-16-004, 4-18-2016)
5-9-4: AUTHORITY TO SEIZE AND IMPOUND; OWNER REMOVAL AUTHORIZED:
   A.   Whenever a police officer has probable cause to believe that a motor
vehicle is subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant to this chapter, the
police officer shall cause the motor vehicle to be removed or towed to a
facility authorized by the city. When the vehicle is towed, the city shall
notify or make a reasonable attempt to notify the owner of record, lessee or
person identifying himself or herself as the owner or lessee of the vehicle, or
any person found to be in control of the vehicle at the time of the alleged
offense, of the fact of the seizure and of the owner of record’s or lessee’s
right to an administrative hearing as provided in this chapter. The city shall
also provide notice that the motor vehicle shall be and remain impounded
pending the completion of the administrative hearing provided in this chapter,
unless the owner of record or lessee of the motor vehicle, or a lienholder of
record of the motor vehicle, posts with the city a cash bond and pays all
towing and storage fees, as set forth in section
5-9-5 of this chapter.
   B.   If, in the judgment of the police officer then present, a person
authorized by the owner of record or the operator of the motor vehicle is
present and capable to provide for the lawful immediate removal of the motor
vehicle, and said motor vehicle is not required to be held as evidence in
regard to the violation, the police officer shall allow that individual to
promptly remove the motor vehicle without it being subject to seizure and
impoundment.
(Ord. O-16-004, 4-18-2016)
5-9-5: POSTING BOND:
   A.   A motor vehicle impounded pursuant to this chapter shall be released to
the owner, lessee or lienholder of record upon posting of a bond in the amount
of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) with the city, and the payment of the
towing and storage costs to the applicable towing company.
   B.   If an administrative fee is imposed pursuant to subsection
5-9-6B of this chapter, the bond shall be applied to said fee; provided, that
in the event that a violation of this chapter is not proven, the bond shall be
returned to the person posting the bond. All bond money posted pursuant to this
section shall be held by the city until a hearing officer issues a decision,
or, if there is judicial review pursuant to section
5-9-10 of this chapter, until a reviewing court issues a final decision.
(Ord. O-16-004, 4-18-2016)
5-9-6: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING:
   A.   Within ten (10) days after a motor vehicle is impounded pursuant to
this chapter, the city shall notify the owner of record, any lessee and any
lienholder of record of the date, time and location of an administrative
hearing that shall be conducted pursuant to this chapter and article 4A of
title 1 of this code. Such notice shall be personally served upon or mailed by
certified mail, return receipt requested, and first class U.S. mail to the
owner of record, any lessee and any lienholder of record as shown on the
records of the Illinois secretary of state. The administrative hearing shall be
scheduled and convened no later than 45 days after the date of the mailing or
personal service of the notice of hearing, and shall be conducted by a hearing
officer appointed pursuant to section
1-4A-6 of this code. All interested persons shall be given a reasonable
opportunity to be heard at the evidentiary hearing. At any time prior to the
administrative hearing date, the hearing officer may, at the request of either
the city, the owner of record, any lessee or lienholder of record, direct
witnesses to appear and give testimony at the administrative hearing. The
formal rules of evidence shall not apply at the administrative hearing, and
hearsay evidence shall be admissible.
   B.   At the conclusion of the administrative hearing, the hearing officer
shall issue a written decision either sustaining or overruling the vehicle
impoundment. If the owner, lessee, or lienholder of record fails to appear at
the administrative hearing, the hearing officer shall enter a default decision
sustaining the vehicle impoundment.
      1.   If the basis for the vehicle impoundment is sustained by the hearing
officer, the hearing officer shall impose an administrative fee as provided in
the city fee schedule, which shall be a debt due to the city. If a bond has
been posted pursuant to section
5-9-5 of this chapter, such bond shall be forfeited to the city and shall be
applied to the administrative fee imposed by the hearing officer. The vehicle
shall not be released to the owner, lessee or lienholder of record until all
administrative fees and towing and storage charges are paid.
      2.   If the basis for the vehicle impoundment is overruled by the hearing
officer, the hearing officer shall order the immediate return of the impounded
vehicle to the owner, lessee or lienholder of record. Any cash bond posted
pursuant to section
5-9-5 shall be returned, and the city shall be liable to the owner, lessee or
lienholder of record for the cost of storage fees and reasonable attorneys’
fees.
(Ord. O-16-004, 4-18-2016)
   C.   At the evidentiary hearing, the violation citation shall be prima facie
evidence that the violation was committed as provided in the citation, and the
burden of proof shall be upon the owner of record to prove that the violation
was not committed.
(Ord. O-16-004, 4-18-2016)
5-9-7: DISPOSITION OF IMPOUNDED VEHICLES:
   A.   If the administrative fee and other applicable fees are not paid within
thirty five (35) days after (i) the administrative hearing officer issues a
written decision, or (ii) an action seeking administrative review of the
hearing officer’s decision has been resolved in favor of the city, whichever is
applicable, the motor vehicle shall be deemed abandoned and shall be disposed
of in the manner provide by law for the disposition of unclaimed motor vehicles
pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 et seq., as amended.
   B.   Except as otherwise specifically provided by law, no owner of record,
lienholder or other person shall be legally entitled to take possession of a
motor vehicle impounded under this chapter until the administrative fee and
towing and storage costs to the applicable tow company imposed pursuant to this
chapter have been paid. However, whenever a person with a lien of record
against an impounded motor vehicle has commenced foreclosure proceedings,
possession of the motor vehicle shall be given to that person if he or she
agrees in writing to refund to the city the amount of the net proceeds of any
foreclosure sale, less any amounts required to pay all lienholders of record,
not to exceed the administrative fee plus the applicable towing and storage
costs.
   C.   Costs for towing and storage of a motor vehicle pursuant to this
chapter shall be those approved by the chief of police for all tow companies
authorized to tow for the police department.
(Ord. O-16-004, 4-18-2016)
5-9-8: APPEALS; JUDICIAL REVIEW:
Any owner of record, lessee, lienholder or other person with a legal interest
in the motor vehicle shall have the right to appeal the decision of the hearing
officer to the circuit court of Bureau County pursuant to the administrative
review law, being 735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq., as amended. Unless stayed by a
court of competent jurisdiction, any fine, penalty or administrative fee
imposed under this chapter which remains unpaid in whole or in part after the
expiration of the deadline for seeking judicial review under the administrative
review law may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment entered by a court
of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. O-16-004, 4-18-2016)
5-9-9: APPLICABILITY OF OTHER LAWS; EXCEPTIONS:
This chapter is in addition to and shall not replace or otherwise abrogate any
existing state or federal laws or any ordinance that relates to the seizure or
impoundment of motor vehicles, and any fee provided in this chapter shall be in
addition to any and all penalties that may be assessed or imposed by a court
for any criminal charges. This section shall not apply:
   A.   If the motor vehicle used in the violation was stolen at the time of
the violation and verifiable proof of the theft is provided to the city;
   B.   If the motor vehicle is operated as a common carrier as defined by
applicable law and the violation occurs without the knowledge of the person in
control of the motor vehicle; or
   C.   If the motor vehicle is subject to successful forfeiture proceedings
under 725 Illinois Compiled Statutes 150/1 et seq., as amended (drug asset
forfeiture procedure act); 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/36-1 et seq., as
amended (seizure and forfeiture of vessels, vehicles and aircraft); or other
state or federal forfeiture laws.
(Ord. O-16-004, 4-18-2016)
5-9-10: USE OF FEES:
All fees collected by the city pursuant to this chapter shall only be deposited
and used for city traffic safety and enforcement expenditures and for the
expenses of the city’s vehicular administrative adjudication system.
(Ord. O-16-004, 4-18-2016)
TITLE 6: MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
CHAPTER 1: GENERAL TRAFFIC PROVISIONS
Section
6-1-1: Illinois Vehicle Code Adopted
6-1-1: ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE ADOPTED:
The Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq. as passed, approved and
amended is hereby adopted by the city of Princeton as if fully set out herein;
the provisions shall therefore be controlling within the corporate limits of
the city of Princeton. In the event of any inconsistency between any provision
of this title and any provision of the Illinois vehicle code, the terms of this
title shall apply.
CHAPTER 2: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES
Section
6-2-1: Authority To Direct Traffic; Obedience Required
6-2-2: Penalties
6-2-1: AUTHORITY TO DIRECT TRAFFIC; OBEDIENCE REQUIRED:
   A.   Police Officers:
      1.   Members of the police department and auxiliary police assigned to
traffic duty are hereby authorized to direct all traffic in accordance with the
provisions of this title, or in emergencies as public safety or convenience may
require, and it shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to comply
with any lawful order, signal or direction of a police officer.
      2.   Except in case of emergency, it shall be unlawful for any person not
authorized by law to direct or attempt to direct traffic.
(1989 Code § 8-5)
   B.   Firefighters: The fire department officer in command, or any
firefighter designated by him or her, may exercise the powers and authority of
a police officer in directing traffic at the scene of any fire or where the
fire department has responded to an emergency call for so long as fire
department equipment is on the scene, in the absence of or in assisting the
police.
(1989 Code § 8-6)
6-2-2: PENALTIES:
Unless otherwise provided herein, any person violating any provision of this
title shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
Cross-reference:
   See chapter 1-4A of this code for prepayment fines in lieu of court
appearance
CHAPTER 3: NON-HIGHWAY VEHICLES
Section:
6-3-1: Purpose
6-3-2: Definitions
6-3-3: Operation Of Low-Speed Vehicles And Non-Highway Vehicles
6-3-4: Regulation Of Non-Highway Vehicles; General Regulations
6-3-5: Regulation Of Low-Speed Vehicles
6-3-6: Insurance Requirements
6-3-7: Seatbelts Required
6-3-8: Permit Required
6-3-9: Use Under The Influence
6-3-10: Denial, Suspension Or Revocation Of Permit; Hearing
6-3-11: Violations
6-3-1: PURPOSE:
As defined and qualified herein shall be allowed on City streets under the
conditions as stated herein. (Ord. O-23-008, 6-5-2023)
6-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following terms and phrases shall have the
meanings set forth in this section:
      LOW SPEED VEHICLE. Any four-wheeled vehicle with a maximum speed greater
than twenty (20) miles per hour but not greater than twenty-five (25) miles per
hour that conforms with the federal motor vehicle safety standards set forth in
49 C.F.R. Part 571.500.
      NON-HIGHWAY VEHICLE. Any recreational off-highway vehicle not
specifically designed to be used on a public highway. For purposes of this
article, non-highway vehicles shall not include all-terrain vehicles, off-
highway vehicles and low speed vehicles, as such terms are defined in the
Illinois Vehicle Code.
      QUALIFIED APPLICANT. Any governmental unit, governmental agency or
organization, not for profit charitable, civic or religious corporation or
organization, or fraternal organization. The city shall
be entitled to request proof of documentation, including but not limited to
tax-exempt status, from any person or entity purporting to be a qualified
applicant.
      RECREATIONAL OFF-HIGHWAY VEHICLE. Any motorized off-highway device
designed to travel primarily off-highway, sixty-four (64) inches or less in
width, having a manufacturer's dry weight of two thousand (2,000) pounds or
less for gas-powered engines or three thousand (3,000) pounds or less for
electric-powered engines, traveling on four or more non-highway tires, designed
with a non-straddle seat and a steering wheel for steering control, except
equipment such as lawnmowers. (Ord. O-23-008, 6-5-2023)
6-3-3: OPERATION OF LOW-SPEED VEHICLES AND NON-HIGHWAY VEHICLES:
   A.   The use of non-highway vehicles on the streets, roadways and alleys of
the city shall be permissible subject to the provisions of this article. Non-
highway vehicles may not be used on any toll road, interstate highway,
controlled access highway or other highway or road under the jurisdiction of
the state, except through permitted crossings as set forth in this chapter.
   B.   The use of low-speed vehicles on the streets, roadways and alleys of
the city shall be permissible if operated in accordance with the provisions set
forth in section 11-1426.2 of the Illinois Vehicle Code and such other
provisions applicable to low-speed vehicles as are set forth in this chapter.
   C.   Signs shall be posted at the point of entry of all roadways and
highways entering into the city to read as follows: "USE OF STREETS PROHIBITED
BY LOW SPEED AND NON-HIGHWAY VEHICLES WITHOUT CITY PERMIT".
   D.   When authorized by and pursuant to the provisions of this article, low-
speed and Non-highway vehicles may be operated within the city only in
compliance with all traffic rules and regulations established by the Illinois
Vehicle Code or by city ordinance, and only those vehicles that comply with the
equipment requirements of the Illinois Vehicle Code may be operated when
otherwise authorized pursuant to this article. Nothing herein shall be
interpreted or construed to permit a person who does not possess a valid
driver's license to operate a low-speed or non-highway vehicle. A valid
driver's license means a license issued in the name of the operator by the
state or a foreign jurisdiction and in force at the time of operation of the
vehicle. (Ord. O-23-008, 6-5-2023)
6-3-4: REGULATION OF NON-HIGHWAY VEHICLES; GENERAL REGULATIONS:
   A.   Low-speed and non-highway vehicles shall be permitted to operate within
the city twenty-four (24) hours a day. However, all low-speed and non-highway
vehicles must obey the hour restrictions enforced upon all Park District
property as indicated at the entrances to each park.
   B.   Non-highway vehicles shall be operated only on streets where the posted
speed limit is thirty-five (35) miles per hour or less. The foregoing provision
shall not prohibit a non-highway vehicle from crossing a road or street at an
intersection where the road or street has a posted speed limit of more than
thirty-five (35) miles per hour.
   C.   Non-highway vehicles shall not be not allowed on the City sidewalks and
City rights-of-way. Non-highway vehicles are also not allowed on private
property unless permitted by the owner of said property.
   D.   A person may not operate a non-highway vehicle upon any street,
highway, or roadway unless he or she is:
      1.   Eighteen (18) years of age or older; and
      2.   Has a valid driver's license issued in his or her name by the
Illinois Secretary of State or such other applicable foreign jurisdiction. All
passengers in the non-highway vehicle must be at least eight (8) years of age.
   E.   No person operating a non-highway vehicle shall make a direct crossing
upon or across any toll road, interstate highway, or controlled access highway.
A person may make a direct crossing of any other highway under the jurisdiction
of the state at an intersection of the highway with another public street,
road, or highway.
   F.   Non-highway vehicles shall not be allowed to be driven on Illinois
State Route 26, U.S. Route 34, Main Street, Backbone Road, Ace Road and U.S.
Route 6 in the City of Princeton. Non-highway vehicles shall be allowed to
cross a state highway or county highway if the operator of the non-highway
vehicle makes a direct crossing provided:
      1.   The crossing is made at an angle of approximately ninety (90)
degrees to the direction of the street, road or highway and at a place where no
obstruction prevents a quick and safe crossing.
      2.   The non-highway vehicle is brought to a complete stop before
attempting a crossing.
      3.   The operator of the non-highway vehicle yields to the right of way
to all pedestrian and vehicular traffic which constitutes a hazard.
      4.   That when crossing a divided highway, the crossing is made only at
an intersection of the highway with another public street, road, or highway.
   G.   A non-highway vehicle shall not be operated on any street or roadway
unless, at a minimum, it has the following:
      1.   Brakes;
      2.   A steering apparatus;
      3.   Tires;
      4.   A rearview mirror;
      5.   Amber reflectorized warning devices in the front and red reflective
warning devices in the rear;
      6.   A slow-moving emblem (as required of other vehicles in section 12-
709 of the Illinois Vehicle Code) on the rear of the non-highway vehicle;
      7.   A headlight that emits a white light visible from a distance of five
hundred feet (500') to the front;
      8.   A tail lamp that emits a red light visible from at least one hundred
feet (100') from the rear;
      9.   A horn;
      10.   Full windshield;
      11.   Seat belts for all seat positions;
      12.   Brake lights; and
      13.   Turn signals.
   H.   When operated on a roadway, a non-highway vehicle shall have its
headlight and tail lamps lighted as required by section 12-201 of the Illinois
Vehicle Code.
   I.   A person who drives or is in actual physical control of a low speed or
non-highway vehicle on a roadway while under the influence is subject to
sections 11-500 through 11-502 of the Illinois Vehicle Code and all other
applicable laws.
   J.   The operation of a low speed or non-highway vehicle upon any street,
roadway or alley is subject to the provisions of Chapter 11 of the Illinois
Vehicle Code concerning the Rules of the Road and all applicable city
ordinances, as the same may be amended from time to time.
   K.   Low speed and non-highway vehicles shall not be operated on any city
sidewalks or other surfaces other than city streets, alleys and roadways.
   L.   Non-highway vehicles are also not allowed to be driven in any cemetery
or city designated park space within the City of Princeton.
   M.   Non-highway vehicles are also not allowed to be driven on any grass or
turf surface, or walking paths on Princeton Park District property beyond the
designated parking lots. (Ord. O-23-008, 6-5-2023)
6-3-5: REGULATION OF LOW-SPEED VEHICLES:
In addition to the regulations applicable to low-speed vehicles herein, low
speed vehicles shall at all times be operated in accordance with the standards
set forth in section 11-1426.2 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. (Ord. O-23-008, 6-
5-2023)
6-3-6: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
Any person who operates a low speed or non-highway vehicle on a street,
highway, or roadway of the city shall be subject to the mandatory insurance
requirements and the minimum liability insurance set forth in article VI of
chapter 7 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. (Ord. O-23-008, 6-5-2023)
6-3-7: SEATBELTS REQUIRED:
The operator and all passengers shall wear a seatbelt at all times during the
operation of a low speed or non-highway vehicle. (Ord. O-23-008, 6-5-2023)
6-3-8: PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   No person shall operate a low speed or non-highway vehicle on the
city's streets, roadways or alleys without first obtaining an annual permit
from the city as provided herein. Permits for low-speed vehicles shall be
limited to qualified applicants only.
   B.   A permit shall be valid, unless suspended or revoked, from May 1 of the
year of issuance until April 30 of the following year.
   C.   The cost of the annual permit shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00)
for the first year and fifty dollars ($50.00) for each subsequent year, with no
prorations or refunds. Every low speed or non-highway vehicle shall be required
to have a permit and such permit shall not be transferable. Annual renewal
stickers shall be displayed in the proper location as indicated on the
registration plate. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the annual permit fee shall
be waived for any qualified applicant.
   D.   Every application for a permit shall be made on a form supplied by the
city and shall contain, at a minimum, the following information:
      1.   Name and address of applicant (including the name and type of
organization, as applicable);
      2.   Name of insurance carrier and policy number and/ or a photocopy of
applicable liability insurance coverage card issued specifically for the low
speed or non-highway vehicle to be operated pursuant to the permit;
      3.   The serial number, make, model and description of the low speed or
non-highway vehicle;
      4.   A certification from the applicant that the low speed or non-highway
vehicle satisfies the requirements of this article and the Illinois Vehicle
Code; and
      5.   Such other information as the city may require, including a release
and waiver of liability signed by applicant releasing the city and its
employees, and agreeing to indemnify and hold the city harmless, including the
costs of defense, from any and all claims, penalties, costs, judgments,
settlements or causes of action resulting or arising from the operation of
applicant's low speed or non-highway vehicle on city streets.
   E.   No application shall be approved until the chief of the police or fire
department, or a qualified designee, has conducted an investigation into the
application, and shall have caused an inspection of the vehicle or vehicles for
which permit is sought to be obtained. Following completion of the inspection
and investigation, the chief or his or her designee shall report their findings
to the mayor, and upon satisfactory inspection the mayor shall direct the city
clerk to issue the permit. The inspection conducted by the chief or his or her
designee shall be to ascertain:
      1.   That the vehicle or vehicles comply with all applicable laws and
regulations concerning equipment required to be installed under this article;
      2.   The name or names of the persons who shall be the operators of the
vehicles;
      3.   That said persons possess the required driver's license;
      4.   That the vehicle or vehicles are insured to meet or exceed the
requirements of the Illinois Vehicle Code; and
      5.   That the applicant is otherwise qualified to hold a permit
hereunder.
   F.   The city shall issue each permitted low speed or non-highway vehicle a
numbered license plate, sticker or other identifier which shall be affixed to
the rear of such vehicle. Every low speed or non-highway vehicle shall be
required to have such identifier and shall not be transferable. There shall be
a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for any replacement.
   G.   The mayor may deny issuance of a permit to any applicant if:
      1.   The inspection reveals that any equipment required by this article
does not exist;
      2.   The operators do not possess the required license;
      3.   The applicant or any of the proposed operators of the vehicles have
previously been found to be in violation of the provisions of this article or
have previously had a permit issued pursuant to this article revoked; or
      4.   The applicant would otherwise not qualify for the issuance of a
permit hereunder.
   H.   The city shall issue non-highway vehicle qualified applicants a permit
to operate within the city limits of Princeton as set forth in this chapter at
no cost. The qualified applicant will be issued a yellow registration plate
indicating and exempt status. (Ord. O-23-008, 6-5-2023)
6-3-9: USE UNDER THE INFLUENCE:
A person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle authorized
under this chapter on a roadway in the City of Princeton while under the
influence of alcohol or drugs, is subject to the provisions of sections 11-500
through 11-502 of the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
11-500 through 11-502. Further, a violation of the provisions of this section
shall be cause for the City of Princeton to revoke the peiinit of the
authorized vehicle. (Ord. O-23-008, 6-5-2023)
6-3-10: DENIAL, SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF PERMIT; HEARING:
   A.   An appeal for refusal to grant a permit must be submitted in writing to
the mayor and filed in the office of the city clerk within ten (10) days
following the issuance of the denial of the application by the mayor. Notice of
the date and time of the hearing shall be given in writing by the mayor to the
party appealing the decision at least five days prior to the hearing.
   B.   For any proposed revocation or suspension of a permit issued pursuant
to this chapter, a notice of hearing on such proposal shall be given in writing
by the mayor setting forth the grounds for the proposed revocation or
suspension, and the time and place of hearing. Such notice shall be sent by
certified mail, return receipt requested, at the address of the applicant set
forth in the application for the permit, and shall be sent at least five (5)
days prior to the date set for the hearing. If, prior to the hearing, the
appellate requests a continuance of the date of the hearing, the mayor may
impose a suspension of the permit pending the final hearing, and the final
hearing shall be rescheduled for a date not later than fourteen (14) days
following the request for continuance.
   C.   Hearings shall be conducted by the mayor. At the hearing, the city
attorney shall present the complaint on behalf of the city and shall offer
evidence sufficient to justify the revocation or suspension, as applicable. On
appeal of a denial of a permit, the appellant shall be required to produce
evidence to rebut the basis for denial. The appellant in either case shall be
allowed counsel and shall have the right to submit evidence and cross examine
witnesses. The mayor shall preside over the hearing and shall render a written
decision to the appellant within thirty (30) days following the conclusion of
the hearing.
   D.   Following the written decision of the mayor, the appellant shall have
the right to appeal to the ordinance and license committee of the city council.
Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the city clerk a request to appeal
within ten (10) days after notice of the written decision by the mayor. The
committee shall thereupon set the time and place for a hearing on such appeal,
and notice of such hearing shall be given to the appellant in the same manner
as provided in this section. The hearing shall be held at a date not earlier
than five (5) days after notice is given, and may be held at a regularly
scheduled meeting of the committee. The decision of the committee on such
appeal shall be final and shall constitute a final administrative ruling,
subject to review under the provisions of the state administrative review law
(735 ILCS 5/ 3-101 et. seq.). (Ord. O-23-008, 6-5-2023)
6-3-11: VIOLATIONS:
   A.   Any person who violated any provision of this chapter shall be guilty
of a petty offense and shall be punished by a fine of one hundred dollars
($100.00) plus court costs normally assessed by the City of Princeton Municipal
Court.
   B.   A second or subsequent offense by any person who violated any provision
of this chapter shall be guilty of a petty offense and shall be punished by a
fine of no less than two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) but not more than
seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00), plus court costs normally assessed
by the City of Princeton Municipal Court.
   C.   Any second or subsequent offense shall result in the revocation of the
permit for a period of not less than one (1) nor more than three (3) years.
   D.   To the extent that any violation of this ordinance also constitutes a
violation of a criminal statute of the State of Illinois, then the violator
shall also be subject to criminal prosecution.
   E.   Non-highway vehicles shall be subject to impoun
CHAPTER 4: DRIVING RULES
Section
6-4-1: Through, Stop And One-Way Streets
6-4-2: Speed Restrictions
6-4-3: Turning Movements
6-4-4: Miscellaneous Prohibitions
6-4-1: THROUGH, STOP AND ONE-WAY STREETS:
Signs Posted: The superintendent of streets or any other person designated by
the mayor or city council shall post or cause to be posted suitable signs for
all through streets, one-way streets or alleys and stop intersections.
(1989 Code § 8-41)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 625 ILCS 5/11-302, 625 ILCS 5/11-904, 625 ILCS 5/11-
708
6-4-2: SPEED RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Speed Limits Established:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any motor vehicle on
any street, in an urban district within the city at a speed in excess of thirty
(30) miles per hour, or in an alley at a speed in excess of fifteen (15) miles
per hour.
      2.   If the city council, by ordinance, sets other speed limits as
provided by the Illinois Vehicle Code after an engineering or traffic
investigation, then such limits shall govern the rate of speed on the streets
indicated in such ordinance. The superintendent of streets shall post
appropriate signs giving notice of such speed limits at the proper places or
along the proper part or zone of the applicable street or highway.
6-4-3: TURNING MOVEMENTS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to make a U-turn
at any place where such a turn is prohibited by ordinance.
(1989 Code § 8-77)
   B.   No Left Turn: It shall be unlawful for the operator of any motor
vehicle to turn left at any place where such a turn is prohibited by ordinance.
(1989 Code § 8-78; amd. 2017 Code)
6-4-4: MISCELLANEOUS PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   Toy Vehicles: It shall be unlawful for any person on any skates,
skateboard, coaster, sled or other toy vehicle:
      1.   To go upon any roadway other than at a crosswalk; or
      2.   To go upon sidewalks in business districts.
(1989 Code § 8-95)
   B.   Riding On Fenders Or Running Boards: It shall be unlawful for any
person to ride upon the fenders, running board or outside step of any privately
owned vehicle.
(1989 Code § 8-96)
CHAPTER 5: PARKING REGULATIONS
Section
6-5-1: General Parking Restrictions
6-5-2: Parking Trailers, Motor Homes And Nonmotorized Vehicles On Public Ways
6-5-3: Truck, Truck-Tractor, Refrigerated Truck And Bus Parking
6-5-4: Signs Posted
6-5-5: Prima Facie Proof
6-5-6: Penalties
Cross-reference:
   See chapter 1-4A of this code for prepayment fines in lieu of court
appearance
6-5-1: GENERAL PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Alleys: No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner
or under such conditions as to leave available less then ten feet (10') of the
width of the alley for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person
shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such a position as to
block the driveway entrance to any abutting property.
(1989 Code § 8-174)
   B.   Bus Loading Zones: No vehicle, other than a bus, shall be parked in a
place designated as a bus loading zone.
(1989 Code § 8-175)
   C.   Time Limit Parking: Except on Sundays or holidays, it shall be unlawful
for any person to park any vehicle in a limited parking area for a longer
consecutive period of time than that designated by an official sign between the
hours of nine o’clock (9:00) a.m. and six o’clock (6:00) p.m.
(1989 Code § 8-176)
   D.   Parking During Snow Removal: It shall be unlawful for any person to
park any vehicle on any public street, alley or city owned or leased parking
lot in the city at any time within twelve (12) hours after a snowfall of three
inches (3") or more has occurred or until the snow has been removed therefrom,
whichever shall occur sooner. Vehicles parked in violation of this subsection
may be removed at the owner’s expense.
(1989 Code § 8-177)
   E.   Vehicles For Sale; Sales Of Merchandise: It shall be unlawful for any
person to park any vehicle upon any roadway for the purpose of displaying it
for sale, or to park any vehicle upon any business street from which vehicle
merchandise is peddled.
   F.   Fire Zone: No vehicle, other than an authorized fire department
vehicle, shall be parked in a place designated as a fire zone.
   G.   No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to
avoid conflict with other traffic or in obedience to an official traffic
control device, in front of or directly across from a public or private
driveway on any street within the city when such street is thirty feet (30') or
less, measured from the exterior face of curb to the exterior face of the
opposite curb, or if no curb is present, from the edge of the pavement to the
opposite edge of the pavement.
(1989 Code § 8-171)
6-5-2: PARKING TRAILERS, MOTOR HOMES, AND NONMOTORIZED VEHICLES ON PUBLIC WAYS:
   A.   Parking Prohibitions:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to park, or permit to be parked,
any trailer, motor home, travel trailer, truck camper, golf cart, all-terrain
vehicle, or nonmotorized vehicle which is owned, operated, controlled by, or
registered to such person on any street, alley, or other public way within the
corporate limits of the city.
6-5-3: TRUCK, TRUCK-TRACTOR, REFRIGERATED TRUCK AND BUS PARKING:
   A.   Definitions: As used in this section, the following terms shall have
the following definitions:
   LARGER TRUCK: Any motor truck with a D license or larger.
   REFRIGERATED TRUCK: A truck, trailer or other moveable container which is
refrigerated by means of an internal combustion engine as its source of power.
   B.   Parking Restrictions:
      1.   No person shall park, leave or store any larger truck, truck-
tractor, bus or refrigerated truck on the streets of the city except under the
following circumstances.
         a.   When a bona fide delivery is being made for the reasonable time
required.
         b.   Where the vehicle is mechanically disabled for the reasonable
time required to remove same for repair.
      2.   No person may park, leave or store any refrigerated truck while its
refrigeration engine is operating, or any truck or truck-tractor with its
engine running, when parked in a residential zone or within five hundred feet
(500') of any residential zone, except when the truck is for institutional or
governmental use.
(Ord. O-14-11-02-51, eff. 11-3-2014)
6-5-4: SIGNS POSTED:
The superintendent of streets or any other person authorized by the mayor or
city council shall cause signs to be posted in all areas where parking is
limited or prohibited, indicating such limitations or prohibitions.
(1989 Code § 8-168)
6-5-5: PRIMA FACIE PROOF:
Whenever any vehicle is parked in violation of the provisions of this chapter,
the person in whose name such vehicle is legally registered shall be considered
prima facie proof that such person is responsible for such violation and
subject to the penalty therefor.
(1989 Code § 8-167)
6-5-6: PENALTIES:
Unless otherwise provided, any person violating the provisions of this chapter,
including article 5A, shall be assessed fines as follows:
   A.   Park in a metered stall in violation of section
6-5-2, whenever paid, fifty dollars ($50.00).
   B.   Parking in an area reserved for persons with disabilities, whenever
paid: three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00).
(1989 Code § 8-166; amd. 2017 Code)
   C.   Parking in violation of section
6-5-3 , whenever paid: fifty dollars ($50.00).
   D.   Parking in violation of any other provision of this chapter:
      1.   If paid within twenty four (24) hours: Twenty dollars ($20.00).
      2.   If paid more than twenty four (24) hours and less than seventy two
(72) hours: Twenty five dollars ($25.00).
      3.   If paid over seventy two (72) hours: Fifty dollars ($50.00).
(1989 Code § 8-166)
Cross-reference:
   See also section
6-5A-8 of this chapter
ARTICLE 5A: PARKING METERS AND ZONES
Section
6-5A-1: Definitions
6-5A-2: Parking Meter Zones
6-5A-3: Parking Rules
6-5A-4: Placement Of Meters
6-5A-5: Marking Parking Places
6-5A-6: Use Of Coins
6-5A-7: Prohibited Acts
6-5A-8: Penalty
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 625 ILCS 5/11-1307
6-5A-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
HOLIDAYS: January 1, May 30, July 4, the first Monday in September, December 25
(Christmas) and Thanksgiving Day.
6-5A-2: PARKING METER ZONES:
Parking meter zones shall be such as may from time to time be established by
ordinance.
(1989 Code § 8-198)
6-5A-3: PARKING RULES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to:
   A.   Park any vehicle, or to permit a vehicle to remain parked, in any
parking meter zone for a period longer than designated on the meter, between
the hours designated thereon, except on Sundays and holidays;
   B.   Park a vehicle in any parking meter zone without paying the fee
designated in this article; or
   C.   Permit a vehicle to remain parked longer in any such zone than for the
period for which the fee was paid;
except on Sundays and holidays, and except two (2) 3-day dollar day events
designated by the mayor at the request of the city retail merchants and except
park days and sidewalk days as designated by the mayor, on which days, the
meters shall be covered but parking shall be limited to one hour in each
parking stall.
(1989 Code § 8-199)
   D.   If for any reason the parking meter serving a space or meter zone is
malfunctioning due to the accumulation of ice or snow and it has been reported
to the local authorities as malfunctioning prior to a violation for the
standing or parking of vehicles being issued, it shall be a valid affirmative
defense to such violation until such time as the parking meter is brought back
into service.
6-5A-4: PLACEMENT OF METERS:
Parking meters shall be installed in the parking meter zones and shall be
placed upon the curb immediately adjacent to the individual parking places.
Each parking meter shall be placed or set in such a manner as to show or
display by a signal whether or not the parking space adjacent to such meter is
legally in use.
(1989 Code § 8-200)
6-5A-5: MARKING PARKING PLACES:
The superintendent of streets shall have markers painted or placed upon the
curb of the street adjacent to each parking meter for the purposes of
designating the parking space and the angle at which vehicles are parked to the
curb. Each vehicle parking within any parking meter zone shall park within the
line or markings so established. It shall be unlawful for any person to park
any vehicle across any such line or marking or to park such vehicle in such
position that the same shall not be entirely within the area designated by such
lines or markings.
(1989 Code § 8-201)
6-5A-6: USE OF COINS:
Any person desiring to park any vehicle within a parking meter space shall
deposit the proper coins for the time desired as follows:
   A.   One cent ($0.01) for each twelve (12) minutes of time desired.
   B.   Five cents ($0.05) for each hour of time desired.
   C.   Ten cents ($0.10) for two (2) hours of time desired.
(1989 Code § 8-202)
6-5A-7: PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   Tampering With, Damage To Meters: It shall be unlawful for any person
not authorized by the city council to deface, injure, tamper with, open or
wilfully break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter installed
under the provisions of this article.
   B.   Use Of Slugs: It shall be unlawful to deposit any slug, device or
metallic or other substitute for a coin in any parking meter.
(1989 Code § 8-203)
6-5A-8: PENALTY:
Any person who fails to pay the amount for the use of any parking meter within
the time specified thereon shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than five
dollars ($5.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00).
(1989 Code § 8-197)
Cross-reference:
   See also subsection
6-5-5 of this chapter
