CHAPTER 8: BICYCLES, SKATEBOARDS AND ROLLERBLADES
Section
6-8-1: Bicycles
6-8-1-1: Operation Of Bicycles
6-8-1-2: Parking Bicycles
6-8-2: Operation Of Skateboards And Rollerblades
6-8-3: Compliance With Provisions
6-8-4: Responsibility Of Parent Or Guardian
6-8-5: Penalty
6-8-1: BICYCLES:
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 625 ILCS 5/11-1501 et seq.
6-8-1-1: OPERATION OF BICYCLES:
   A.   Riding On Sidewalks:
      1.   Except in business districts and as provided in this subsection,
bicycles may be ridden on sidewalks.
(1989 Code § 8-298)
      2.   Pedestrians shall have the right of way at all times over bicycles.
A person riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk or sidewalk crossing shall either
turn off the sidewalk when meeting or passing pedestrians or shall dismount
until the pedestrians have passed.
(1989 Code § 8-300)
   B.   Riding In A Group: Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not
ride more than two (2) abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside
for the exclusive use of bicycles.
   C.   Clinging To Vehicles: No person riding upon any bicycle, coaster,
roller skates, sled or toy vehicle shall attach the same or himself or herself
to any vehicle upon a roadway.
   D.   Trick Riding; Racing: No rider of a bicycle shall remove both hands
from the handlebars, or feet from the pedals, or practice any acrobatic or
fancy riding on any street; nor shall any person operating a bicycle upon a
public highway participate in any race or speed or endurance contest with
another vehicle, except under a permit from and under the supervision of the
chief of police.
(1989 Code § 8-300)
6-8-1-2: PARKING BICYCLES:
   A.   No person shall park a bicycle upon a roadway.
   B.   Bicycles parked in an alley, in a public driveway, on a sidewalk, or on
a public path must be in such a position as not to interfere with the safety or
movement of vehicular or pedestrian traffic.
(1989 Code § 8-300)
6-8-2: OPERATION OF SKATEBOARDS AND ROLLERBLADES:
   A.   Except in business districts and as provided in this section,
skateboards and rollerblades may be ridden on sidewalks.
   B.   Pedestrians shall have the right of way at all times over skateboards
and rollerblades. A person riding a skateboard upon a sidewalk or sidewalk
crossing shall either turn off the sidewalk when meeting or passing pedestrians
or shall dismount until the pedestrians have passed. A person skating on
rollerblades upon a sidewalk or sidewalk crossing shall turn off the sidewalk
when meeting or passing pedestrians.
(1989 Code § 8-301)
Cross-reference:
   See subsections
6-4-4A and B of this title
6-8-3: COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform
any act required in this chapter.
(1989 Code § 8-297)
6-8-4: RESPONSIBILITY OF PARENT OR GUARDIAN:
The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or
knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of
this chapter.
(1989 Code § 8-297)
6-8-5: PENALTY:
Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be
punishable by a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(1989 Code § 8-296)
CHAPTER 9: UNUSED AND INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLES
Section
6-9-1: Definitions
6-9-2: Leaving, Storing Vehicles Prohibited; Nuisance Declared; Exemptions
6-9-3: Notices To Remove
6-9-4: Hearing
6-9-5: Failure To Comply; Removal By City
6-9-6: Redemption Of Impounded Vehicle
6-9-7: Disposal Of Unclaimed Vehicles; Disposition Of Proceeds
6-9-8: Remedy Not Exclusive
6-9-9: Liability
6-9-10: Penalty
6-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle from which, for a period of at
least seven (7) days, the engine, wheels or other parts have been removed, or
on which the engine, wheels or other parts have been altered, damaged or
otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its
own power. “Inoperable motor vehicle” shall not include a motor vehicle which
has been rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own power in
order to perform ordinary service or repair operations.
MOTOR VEHICLE NOT REGULARLY USED: Any motor vehicle which:
   A.   Has not been driven off the premises where it is parked or stored under
its own motor power for a period longer than three (3) months;
   B.   Is not registered, licensed or properly displaying registration plates
or stickers as required by the Illinois vehicle code; or
   C.   Exhibits damaged parts or appears to be in a state of disrepair,
including but not limited to, broken and missing windows, body panels with
holes, and fluid leaks which pose an open threat of injury or contamination for
a period longer than fourteen (14) days.
6-9-2: LEAVING, STORING VEHICLES PROHIBITED; NUISANCE DECLARED; EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   No person shall park, store or leave, or permit the parking, storing or
leaving, of any inoperable motor vehicle or motor vehicle not regularly used,
whether attended or not, upon any public or private property within the city
for a period of time in excess of seven (7) days. The presence of an inoperable
motor vehicle, motor vehicle not regularly used, or parts thereof, on private
or public property is hereby declared a public nuisance which may be abated as
such in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. This section shall not
apply to any motor vehicle that is kept within a building when not in use, to
operable historic vehicles over twenty five (25) years of age, or to a motor
vehicle on the premises of a place of business engaged in wrecking or junking
of motor vehicles.
(1989 Code § 8-230)
   B.   No person shall be deemed to cause, permit or allow such a nuisance to
exist if such person:
      1.   Has an ownership interest in or is in control of the inoperable
motor vehicle or motor vehicle not regularly used;
      2.   Causes the inoperable motor vehicle or motor vehicle not regularly
used to be deposited at the site in question;
      3.   Has an ownership interest in the real estate upon which the
inoperable motor vehicle or motor vehicle not regularly used is located;
      4.   Has an ownership interest in or operates a business which causes,
permits or allows such a nuisance to exist on the real estate upon which the
business is operated or on adjacent real estate which is under the control of
the business owner or operator; or
      5.   Has an ownership interest in real estate upon which a business is
being operated and the operator or owner of said business causes, permits or
allows such a nuisance to exist on the real estate upon which the business is
being operated or on adjacent real estate which is under the control of the
person having an ownership interest in real estate upon which said business is
being operated.
6-9-3: NOTICES TO REMOVE:
   A.   Public Property: Whenever any person causes, permits or allows a
nuisance under this chapter to exist or be stored on public property, the chief
of police shall have the authority to direct the removal of the motor vehicle
in accordance with chapter 4, article 2 of the Illinois vehicle code.
   B.   Private Property: Whenever any person causes, permits or allows a
nuisance under this chapter to exist or be stored on private property, the
chief of police shall have the power to authorize removal of the motor vehicle.
Before a motor vehicle can be removed from private property, the chief of
police or his or her designee shall serve a written notice to abate upon the
person who is causing, permitting or allowing the nuisance to exist or be
stored on private property and in accordance with the following procedure:
      1.   Notice shall be served either personally or by certified mail upon
the person who is causing, permitting or allowing the nuisance to exist or be
stored on private property. Personal service shall be by a local law
enforcement officer or any person authorized by law to make personal service.
      2.   The notice shall describe the motor vehicle to be removed and give
the person served seven (7) days from the date of service of the notice to
either abate the nuisance or request a hearing on the question of whether the
vehicle is an inoperable motor vehicle or motor vehicle not regularly used.
6-9-4: HEARING:
   A.   Opportunity For Hearing: The person who is causing, permitting or
allowing the nuisance to exist or be stored on private property shall have
seven (7) days from the date of service of the notice to submit a written
request for a hearing on the question of whether the described motor vehicle is
an inoperable motor vehicle and/or motor vehicle not regularly used within the
meaning of this chapter with the city clerk. If the recipient of the notice
does not file a written request for hearing within the seven (7) day period,
any hearing rights under this section will be deemed waived, and the city may,
at its option, cause the abatement of the nuisance in accordance with this
chapter. Hearings shall be held by an administrative hearing officer.
   B.   Scheduling Of Hearings: If a hearing is requested within the seven (7)
day period, the hearing shall be scheduled to occur within thirty (30) days
after the request for a hearing is received by the city clerk. The person
making the request for a hearing shall be provided with reasonable notice of
the hearing date and time in person or by first-class mail.
   C.   Nature Of Hearing: The hearing will not be determinative of, or
adjudicate, any nuisance citation issued to the person who is causing,
permitting or allowing the nuisance to exist or be stored on private property.
After receiving all relevant evidence, the administrative hearing officer shall
make a written decision based upon a preponderance of the evidence as to
whether the motor vehicle constitutes an inoperable motor vehicle and/or motor
vehicle not regularly used within the meaning of this chapter.
   D.   Hearing Decision: The person who requested the hearing shall be
provided a copy of the hearing decision within seven (7) days of the decision
in person or by first-class mail. If the hearing officer determines that the
motor vehicle is an inoperable motor vehicle and/or motor vehicle not regularly
used, then the notice to abate shall become effective from and after the date
such determination is served on the person who requested the hearing, and the
city may, at its option, cause the removal of the motor vehicle in accordance
with chapter 4, article 2 of the Illinois vehicle code. The person shall be
responsible for all costs related to the towing, storage, disposal, and
processing of the motor vehicle.
6-9-5: FAILURE TO COMPLY; REMOVAL BY CITY:
   A.   If the violation described in the notice has not been remedied within
the seven (7) day period of compliance, or if the notice requesting a hearing
is timely filed, a hearing is had, and the existence of the violation is
affirmed by the administrative hearing officer, the chief of police or his or
her designee shall have the right to take possession of the inoperable motor
vehicle, motor vehicle not regularly used, or part thereof, and remove it from
the premises.
   B.   In order to remove a motor vehicle under this chapter from private
property, the city must first apply to the circuit court of Bureau county and
request the court to issue a warrant for the removal of said motor vehicle.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, hinder or refuse
to allow such person or persons to enter upon private property for the purpose
of removing said inoperable motor vehicle, or part thereof, under the
provisions of this chapter.
(1989 Code § 8-235)
6-9-6: REDEMPTION OF IMPOUNDED VEHICLE:
The owner of any vehicle seized under the provisions of this chapter may redeem
or reclaim such vehicle at any time after its removal, but prior to the sale or
destruction thereof in accordance with this chapter, upon presenting proof of
ownership or proof of the right to possession to the chief of police or his or
her designee, and payment all applicable towing, storage and processing
charges.
(1989 Code § 8-237)
6-9-7: DISPOSAL OF UNCLAIMED VEHICLES; DISPOSITION OF PROCEEDS:
Following the removal of any motor vehicle as provided in this chapter, the
disposal of such unclaimed motor vehicle and the disposition of any proceeds
thereof shall be in accordance with chapter 4, article 2 of the Illinois
vehicle code.
6-9-8: REMEDY NOT EXCLUSIVE:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as imposing upon the city, a duty to
abate the nuisance as specified in this chapter. The action authorized by this
chapter shall be in addition to and without waiver of any other remedies.
6-9-9: LIABILITY:
Any police officer, the police department or a towing service owner, operator
or employee shall not be held liable for damages in any action brought by the
registered owner, former registered owner, or his or her legal representative,
lienholder or any person legally entitled to the possession of a motor vehicle
when the motor vehicle was processed and sold or disposed of as provided by
this chapter.
6-9-10: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to
a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each act in violation of any provision hereof
shall be deemed a separate offense.
(1989 Code § 8-228)
Cross-reference:
   See chapter 1-4A of this code for prepayment fine in lieu of court
appearance
TITLE 7: PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1: STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
Section
7-1-1: Sidewalk Construction
7-1-2: Obstructing Public Ways
7-1-3: Depositing Refuse Onto Public Ways
7-1-4: Connection Of Private Drains To Tile Drains
7-1-5: Awnings
7-1-1: SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   Materials And Specifications: All sidewalks hereafter constructed
within the city upon any street or alley or any part thereof, shall be
constructed of cement concrete unless the city council shall provide otherwise.
In order to construct or repair a sidewalk within the corporate limits of the
city, one must apply for and receive a permit to build or repair within the
city’s right of way. Sidewalks must be constructed or repaired according to the
specifications approved in the right of way permit.
   B.   Special Ordinance Required: The city may require a lot, block, tract or
parcel owner to construct or repair a sidewalk that touches the line of the
sidewalk by special ordinance pursuant to the requirements set forth in 65 ILCS
5/11-84 et al. The city may levy a tax against that lot, block, tract or parcel
owner in order to pay for any part or all of the construction or repair of a
required sidewalk pursuant to the requirements set forth in 65 ILCS 5/11-84 et
al.
   C.   All of the contracts shall be approved by the mayor, or in the case the
board of local improvements shall have the supervision of the construction of
any sidewalks, then such contract shall be approved by the president of the
board.
7-1-2: OBSTRUCTING PUBLIC WAYS:
   A.   Nuisance Obstructions:
      1.   Every obstruction or encumbrance of any street, alley, lane, avenue,
sidewalk, crossing or public square within the corporate limits of the city,
including but not limited to firewood, lumber, barrels, boxes, manure,
merchandise or other things, is hereby declared to be a nuisance, unless
authorized by the city. Any person who shall so obstruct or encumber any
street, alley, lane, avenue, sidewalk, crossing or public square, or who shall
cause or suffer the same to be so obstructed or encumbered, shall, upon
conviction thereof, be fined as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of in this code;
and if any such person shall then neglect or refuse immediately to remove such
nuisance, after having been notified by the city to remove the same, he or she
shall, upon conviction of such neglect or refusal, be fined as in provided in
title 1, chapter 4 of this code. Each day said nuisance shall exist, shall
constitute a separate violation and shall be subject to a fine for each day the
nuisance remains. An exception to the obstruction of a street, alley, lane,
avenue, sidewalk, crossing or public square is any person loading or unloading
merchandise or household goods at a dwelling house or at any place of business
within the city limits. Such person shall have a reasonable time, not exceeding
two (2) hours, within which to effect the same without being in violation of
this section.
      2.   When a building is to be erected, the necessary materials to
construct the same may occupy so much of the street, alley or lane in front of
the sidewalk of such building as shall not exceed one- fourth (1/4) of the
width of the street, alley or lane, for a reasonable time but not more than
sixty (60) days. The city shall be notified of such obstruction prior to the
materials being placed in said street, alley, or lane.
   B.   Erection Of Structures: No person shall erect or place any building or
fence, in whole or in part, upon any street, alley, sidewalk or other public
ground within the city limits, and any person in violation of this section
shall be subject to penalty as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this code;
provided, that any person desiring to move any house or other building from one
portion of the city to another shall be allowed a reasonable time within which
to accomplish the same after notice to and approval from the city.
   C.   Display Of Merchandise: It shall be unlawful for any person to keep,
store or display upon the space between the sidewalk and the streets of the
city any goods, wares or merchandise, in boxes or otherwise, including
machinery, vehicles or other articles for use or sale.
7-1-3: DEPOSITING REFUSE ONTO PUBLIC WAYS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sweep, throw or in any other manner
deposit any dirt, trash, scraps or pieces of paper or other materials, ashes,
cinders or any other refuse matter of any kind, from any dwelling house, store,
grocery, shop, office, hotel or other place of business or building or
premises, onto or upon any public street, public avenue, public square or
public grounds within the city limits, or onto or upon any sidewalk or
crosswalk in any such street, avenue, public square or public grounds, without
the consent of the city council. Any owner(s), lessee(s), proprietor, occupant
(s) of any dwelling house, store, grocery, shop, office, hotel or other place
of business or building or premises who shall violate any of the provisions of
this section, or cause the same to be violated, or suffer or permit the same to
be violated, by any person in his or her employ, or as his or her agent or
otherwise, shall be subject to the penalty provided in title 1, chapter 4 of
this code.
Cross-reference:
   See also subsection 8-4-8B of this code
7-1-4: CONNECTION OF PRIVATE DRAINS TO TILE DRAINS:
The connection of all private drains with the tile drains constructed by the
city shall be made under and in accordance with the direction of the
superintendent of streets. Every person who shall, without the permission in
writing of the superintendent of streets, dig any ditch or trench in or upon
any street, alley, park or public ground, or connect any drain with any of the
tile drains constructed by the city, or injure or disturb, in any manner, any
such tile drain, shall be subject to the penalty as provided in title 1,
chapter 4 of this code. Such penalty shall not apply to work done by the
employees or agents of the city at the direction of the superintendent of
streets.
7-1-5: AWNINGS:
   A.   Restrictions: It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, build or
construct any awning over, upon or across the sidewalk in, upon and along Main
Street in the city that shall rest, in whole or in part, upon the sidewalk or
in the street in front of or outside of the sidewalk, nor shall any awning or
any material attached or fastened thereto extend down to within six and one-
half feet (6-1/2') of the surface of the sidewalk in front of the building to
which the awning is attached. Awnings shall be constructed of cloth, iron,
steel or other metal, but not wood or other material. However wooden rollers or
rods may be used in connection with cloth awnings, and metal roofs or awnings
may rest upon wooden stringers.
   B.   Removal: All awnings that have been erected, built or constructed in,
upon or over the sidewalk, or in, upon or over Main Street in the city, and
resting in whole or in part upon the sidewalk or in the street in front of or
outside of the sidewalk, or are awnings as are prohibited to be constructed in
subsection A of this section shall be removed within 30 days of notice from the
city that the awning is in violation of this section of the code. Should the
awning not be removed within the 30 days of the notice, the city may remove
such awning and may bill the owner for the cost of said removal. The city shall
have all remedies at law available to it to collect said costs and fines.
ARTICLE 1A: EXCAVATIONS
Section
7-1A-1: Short Title
7-1A-2: Definitions
7-1A-3: Permit Required
7-1A-4: Application For Permit
7-1A-5: Bond Requirements
7-1A-6: Fees And Costs
7-1A-7: Issuance Or Denial Of Permit
7-1A-8: Emergency Excavations
7-1A-9: Specifications And Restrictions
7-1A-10: Supervision And Enforcement
7-1A-11: Revocation, Expiration Of Permit
7-1A-12: Exemptions From Provisions; Conflicts
7-1A-13: Penalty
7-1A-1: SHORT TITLE:
This article shall be known as the STREET OPENINGS AND CLOSINGS ORDINANCE.
7-1A-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
ENGINEER: The engineer for the city of Princeton.
FRANCHISED UTILITY: Any private or public organization operating and
maintaining equipment for the use of the public in, on or over a public right
of way under terms of a franchise granted by the city council.
SUPERINTENDENT OF STREETS: The superintendent of streets of the city or his or
her duly authorized representative.
7-1A-3: PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to tunnel under or to make any
excavation in any street, alley or public right of way in the city without
first making application for and obtaining a permit from the engineer or
superintendent of streets as provided in this article.
   B.   A permit may be issued for more than one simultaneous cut or street
opening; provided, that the work is in one contiguous area (lying in connecting
street blocks).
7-1A-4: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Applications for permits under this article shall be made in duplicate at the
office of the engineer or superintendent of streets and shall show:
(1989 Code § 11-91)
   A.   The location, extent and details of the proposed work and description
of abutting property, by means of sketch.
   B.   The name and address of the person for whom the work is being done.
   C.   The name and address of the person performing the work.
   D.   A certificate that the applicant is authorized to act on behalf of the
owner (if other than the owner applies) and has received a copy of this article
and any specifications applicable thereto and will comply with the provisions
contained therein, and will comply with all other ordinance provisions of the
city applicable to the work.
   E.   A certificate that the applicant has notified private utilities under
franchise to the city of proposed work. Franchised utilities that certify by
letter that arrangements satisfactory to other franchised utilities have been
made for adequate protection of their facilities shall not be required to
execute individual certificates.
   F.   The estimated cost of the work, when deemed necessary.
   G.   The estimated date of the commencement and completion of the work;
however, in no case shall the completion of the work be later than three (3)
months after the date the permit is issued; provided, that at the time of
application, the engineer or superintendent of streets may, for work of
considerable magnitude, authorize such three (3) month limit to be extended for
a definite period of time necessary to complete the work; provided, at any time
prior to the expiration thereof where the permittee has made application in
writing to the engineer or superintendent of streets, setting forth the
justification for such extension, the engineer or superintendent of streets may
extend the permit time limit if the engineer or superintendent of streets finds
such extension of time is justified.
   H.   If the applicant elects to construct a temporary patch in an existing
paved street to be replaced later by a permanent patch, the following procedure
on this portion of the work only shall apply:
      1.   Temporary patchwork shall be completed within the time limit as set
forth in subsection G of this section. The applicant shall inspect such patch
at regular, and not to exceed monthly, intervals, or on notification by the
city, and maintain the patch in good condition and to finished pavement grade
at all times. The applicant shall notify the engineer or superintendent of
streets upon completion of all temporary patches.
      2.   Temporary patches placed prior to October 1 of each year shall be
replaced by permanent patches within sixty (60) days, but in no case later than
the first frost of each year. Temporary patches placed after October 1 of each
year shall be replaced by permanent patches prior to April 1 of the following
year.
      3.   Exceptions to this subsection may be made by the engineer or
superintendent of streets due to weather conditions making these provisions
inoperative.
   I.   Such other information as the engineer or superintendent of streets
shall deem reasonably necessary for the determination of whether a permit
should be issued under this article.
7-1A-5: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
The following bonds or equivalent shall accompany an application for permit
under this article, and such bonds shall be in a form approved by the city
attorney:
(1989 Code § 11-94)
   A.   Maintenance And Construction Bond: The applicant shall furnish the city
a maintenance and construction bond to be filed with the application for permit
in an amount equal to the estimated cost of the work to be done and conditioned
that such work shall be done in accordance with the city’s standard
specifications and guaranteeing the same for a period of one year after the
date of completion. The applicant may substitute for the bond an amount of cash
equal to the cost of the work, which amount shall be left on deposit with the
city during the guarantee period. In lieu of individual bonds and with the
approval of the engineer or the superintendent of streets, the applicant may
file with the city a blanket bond on or before January 1 of each year in an
amount equal to the total cost of street work done by the applicant in the
preceding calendar year, conditioned as specified for individual permit bonds.
If the engineer or the superintendent of streets determines that the work in
any one year may exceed this amount, the engineer or superintendent of streets
may require an additional bond to be filed in an amount estimated to cover the
cost of the work he or she estimates will be performed during the balance of
the year. If the permittee fails to comply with the requirements of this
article or defaults, the engineer or the superintendent of streets shall order
completion or correction of the work by the city and shall recover the cost
from the permittee as required by law.
   B.   Indemnity Bond: The applicant shall file with the application for
permit an indemnity bond, conditioned to protect and save harmless the city
from all claims for damages or injury to persons or property by reason of work
performed under this article. The bond shall be in an amount of not less than
twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) and shall remain in effect during the
guarantee period; however, if a blanket indemnity insurance policy in the
amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) saving the city against
any loss or liability due to such work is secured by the applicant and filed
with the city clerk, no such bond shall be required. Such policy shall be
noncancellable for thirty (30) days after notification to the city of intent to
cancel has been made by the applicant or insurer.
(1989 Code § 11-94)
7-1A-6: FEES AND COSTS:
   A.   Fees Established: The filing (inspection) fees, which shall be
determined for each permit as provided in the city fee schedule, shall
accompany an application for a permit under this article.
   B.   Additional Costs: The applicant shall, in addition to a filing fee, pay
the actual costs of engineering and inspection when the work under the permit
is greater than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) in value, value to be
determined by the engineer. In lieu thereof, the applicant may furnish
inspection services at his or her own expense; provided, that such inspection
service is approved by the engineer or the superintendent of streets at the
time of issuance of the permit, and inspection reports are furnished the city
as may be required by the engineer.
7-1A-7: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF PERMIT:
   A.   The engineer shall forward each application for a permit under this
article to the superintendent of streets for his or her recommendation prior to
review and approval and issuance of the permit. If application under this
article is submitted to the office of the superintendent of streets, he or she
shall forward each application for permit to the engineer, along with a
recommendation as to whether the engineer should approve the application and
issue a permit.
   B.   Permits may be denied if the applicant shall have previously failed to
follow the provisions of this article or correct improper work after due
notification by the engineer or the superintendent of streets.
   C.   A notice of issuance of permit for street work shall be sent to
appropriate departments of the city as determined by the engineer and the
superintendent of streets.
   D.   No permits shall be issued by the engineer or the superintendent of
streets for cuts in resurfaced or newly paved streets for a period of three (3)
years after completion of such paving except as specifically provided as
follows:
      1.   Where hazard to health, safety or life exists and must be corrected,
the engineer shall issue a permit upon finding that such condition exists.
      2.   Where the applicant shows that he or she was unable, due to economic
or unforeseen circumstances prior to the resurfacing or paving of the street,
to accomplish the work set forth in the application for permit, and that the
denial of such permit will work hardship on him or her, the engineer or
superintendent of streets shall approve such application if the facts warrant
such action. If the application is denied, the applicant may appeal to the city
council who may authorize the issuance of the permit after review of the
application, all data and the recommendation and review of the engineer and
superintendent of streets.
7-1A-8: EMERGENCY EXCAVATIONS:
In the event of emergency work during working hours, persons shall contact the
engineer or the superintendent of streets in person or by phone, describing the
work, the location and the reason for the necessity of proceeding immediately,
and shall obtain verbal approval from the engineer. Formal application covering
such work shall be made within twenty four (24) hours thereafter. If an
emergency arises after working hours or on days when the engineer and the
superintendent of street’s offices are closed, work may be accomplished in
accordance with this article followed by formal application on the next working
day; provided, that the street department’s on-call emergency contact is
immediately notified of the emergency, in person or by telephone, by the person
performing the work.
7-1A-9: SPECIFICATIONS AND RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   All work performed under permits issued in accordance with this article
shall be done in conformity with specifications prepared by the engineer and
the superintendent of streets and copies of applicable city ordinances shall be
furnished each applicant for a permit at no cost.
   B.   In addition, the work shall meet the following requirements:
      1.   The operation shall not unreasonably interfere with vehicular and
pedestrian traffic, the demand and necessity for parking spaces, and the means
of egress to and from the property affected and adjacent properties. Where
pedestrian traffic must be detoured, temporary sidewalks shall be constructed
or provided which shall be safe for travel and convenient for users.
      2.   The health, welfare and safety of the public shall not be
unreasonably impaired.
7-1A-10: SUPERVISION AND ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   The engineer and the superintendent of streets shall enforce the
provisions of this article and shall from time to time cause inspections to be
made of work under permits to ensure that the provisions of this article and
specifications are being followed.
   B.   Notice shall be given to the engineer or the superintendent of streets
by the permittee at least twenty four (24) hours in advance of commencement of
work under a permit.
   C.   Apparent violations of this article shall be reported immediately by
police, fire, public works or other city officials or employees to the engineer
or the superintendent of streets for investigation.
7-1A-11: REVOCATION, EXPIRATION OF PERMIT:
   A.   Revocation: The engineer or superintendent of streets may revoke any
permit and stop work upon finding that work is not being done in accordance
with this article or specifications.
   B.   Expiration: Permits shall become null and void if work is not commenced
within thirty (30) days after the estimated date of commencement of work as
shown on the application for permit. In any case where no work commences under
a permit within six (6) months of the date of issuance of permit, the permit
shall become null and void and a new application shall be submitted for the
work. Lack of required notification by the permittee to the engineer or the
superintendent of streets prior to expiration dates shall be prima facie
evidence to cause nullification of the permit.
7-1A-12: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS; CONFLICTS:
   A.   The provisions of this article pertaining to the issuance of a permit
shall not apply to officers or employees of the city engaged in doing work for
the city.
   B.   Excavations in tree banks for service connections by franchised
utilities or replacement or repair of existing utility poles and appurtenances
not requiring replacement or repair of any existing street improvements shall
not require permits; provided, that all applicable provisions of this article
are observed.
   C.   The provisions of any ordinance granting a franchise to a public
utility, now or hereafter in effect, shall prevail over any conflicting
provisions of this article.
7-1A-13: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall, upon
conviction, be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
CHAPTER 2: TREES AND SHRUBS
Section
7-2-1: Short Title
7-2-2: Purpose And Intent
7-2-3: Definitions
7-2-4: Tree Commission
7-2-5: Authority Of City To Plant, Maintain And Remove
7-2-6: Location Restrictions
7-2-7: Responsibility Of Property Owners
7-2-8: Removal Of Stumps
7-2-9: Tree Topping Prohibited
7-2-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the PRINCETON TREE ORDINANCE.
7-2-2: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
   A.   Purpose: The purpose of this chapter is to promote and protect the
public health, safety and general welfare by providing for the regulation of
the planting, maintenance and removal of trees, shrubs and other plants within
the city.
   B.   Intent: It is the intent of the city council that the terms of this
chapter shall be construed to promote the following:
      1.   The planting, maintenance, restoration and survival of desirable
trees, shrubs and other plants within the city; and
      2.   The protection of the residents of the city from personal injury and
property damage, and the protection of the city from property damage caused or
threatened by the improper planting, maintenance or removal of trees, shrubs or
other plants located within the city.
7-2-3: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
CITY OWNED PROPERTY: Property located within the city limits either:
   A.   Owned by the city in fee simple; or
   B.   Impliedly or expressly dedicated to the city.
PARK TREES: Trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation in public
parks having individual names, and all areas owned by the city or to which the
public has free access as a park.
PROPERTY OWNER: The record owner or contract purchaser of any parcel of land.
STREET TREES: Trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation on land
lying within the city rights of way for all streets, avenues, alleys or ways
within the city.
TREES, SHRUBS AND OTHER PLANTS: All vegetation, woody or otherwise, except lawn
grass or flowers that are less than twenty four inches (24") in height.
7-2-4: TREE COMMISSION:
   A.   Commission Created; Composition: There is hereby created a tree
commission, which shall consist of five (5) members appointed by the mayor and
city council. Members shall be residents or property owners in the city,
including at least one member being a state certified arborist or an
established tree nursery person. Members shall serve for a term of three (3)
years, except for the inaugural terms whereby three (3) members shall serve
until 4-30-2022 and two (2) members shall serve until 4-30-2023. Thereafter,
all service shall be in full three (3) year terms. Members may be re-appointed.
(Ord. O-20-01, 11-2-2020)
   B.   Duties:
      1.   It shall be the responsibility of the commission to investigate,
counsel, update annually and administer a written plan for the care,
preservation, pruning, planting, replanting and removal or disposition of trees
and shrubs along city streets and other public places. Such plan will be
presented annually to the city council and, upon acceptance, shall constitute
the official comprehensive tree plan for the city.
      2.   The city tree commission shall determine, with the assistance of any
experts the commission wishes to consult, a list of street tree species for the
city. This list shall be used to select appropriate trees to be planted on city
rights of way and shall become part of the overall comprehensive tree plan for
the city.
7-2-5: AUTHORITY OF CITY TO PLANT, MAINTAIN AND REMOVE:
   A.   The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove
trees, plants and other shrubs within the rights of way of all streets,
avenues, alleys, lanes, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary to
ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such
public ways and grounds.
   B.   The city may remove or cause to be removed any tree or part thereof
which is in an unsafe condition or which, by reason of its nature, is injurious
to the sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines or other public
improvements, or is infected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pests
if such trees are located on city rights of way or property.
7-2-6: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   No street trees shall be planted within thirty five feet (35') of any
street corner measured from the point of the nearest intersecting curbs or curb
lines.
   B.   No street trees shall be planted within ten feet (10') of any fire
hydrant.
7-2-7: RESPONSIBILITY OF PROPERTY OWNERS:
Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right of way within the city
shall prune the branches so that such branches do not obstruct the light from
any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection so that there
is a clear space of eight feet (8') above the surface of the street or
sidewalk. Such owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees or
broken or decayed limbs which constitute a danger to the safety of the public.
The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property
when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a
streetlight or interferes with the visibility of any traffic control device or
sign.
7-2-8: REMOVAL OF STUMPS:
The city shall remove the stumps of street and park trees below the surface of
the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of
the ground.
7-2-9: TREE TOPPING PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person or company to top any street tree, park
tree or other tree on public property. “Topping” is defined as severe cutting
back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches (3") in diameter within the
tree’s crown to such a degree as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the
tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes or certain trees under
utility lines or other obstructions where other pruning practices are
impractical may be exempt from this section. The city will determine which
trees are exempt upon the request of a utility company or lot owner.
CHAPTER 2A: TREE CODE
Section
7-2A-1: Statement Of Purpose

7-2A-20: Enforcement
7-2A-21: Exceptions
7-2A-22: Appeals for Variance

7-2A-1: STATEMENT OF PURPOSE:
   A.   It is the purpose of this tree preservation ordinance to promote and
protect the public health, environment, safety and general welfare by providing
for the regulation of the planting, maintenance and removal of trees, shrubs
and other plants within the city of Princeton, Illinois, (hereinafter referred
to as “Princeton” or “city”).
   B.   It is the intent of the city council of Princeton that the terms of
this chapter shall be construed so as to:
      1.   Protect, preserve and enhance the quality of life and general
welfare of the city, its residents and its property owners; and conserve and
enhance the city’s natural, physical and aesthetic environment.
      2.   Preserve, protect and enhance the urban forest to ensure that trees
are properly planted and maintained within the city so that trees can protect,
enhance and preserve the quality of life for people within the city.
      3.   Recognize that trees are an integral part of the infrastructure of
the city and as such should be preserved, protected and cared for as other
critical city infrastructure.
         a.   Trees absorb pollution from the air;
         b.   Trees absorb and sequester carbon dioxide;
         c.   Trees absorb and filter pollution from stormwater run-off;
         d.   Trees produce oxygen;
         e.   Trees reduce flooding;
         f.   Trees stabilize soils and reduce erosion;
         g.   Trees cool the surrounding area helping to reduce impacts due to
heat islands;
         h.   Trees reduce energy consumption by shielding structures from
harsh winds and sun;
         i.   Trees provide a buffer and screen against noise, light and
pollution;
         j.   Trees improve property values;
         k.   Trees improve commercial district buyer traffic and purchasing;
         l.   Areas with trees have lower crime rates;
         m.   Areas with trees have higher levels of community interaction;
         n.   Trees provide important habitat for birds and other wildlife; and
         o.   Trees protect and enhance our quality of life.
      4.   Trees provide the city collective benefits that extend beyond
property boundaries throughout the entire city.
      5.   Recognize that larger trees provide larger benefits. When a large
tree is removed and replaced with a smaller tree the benefits and services are
reduced.
      6.   Recognize that some trees may have a condition that constitutes a
threat, danger or nuisance to the public or property within the city or may be
dangerous to the health of other trees and vegetation in the city.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-2: DEFINITIONS:
APPLICANT: An owner of a lot, parcel or tract of land for which an application
has been filed for a permit, subdivision, or any activity requiring the
issuance of a permit. A contractor is an agent, acting on behalf of the
applicant - the landowner.
ARBORIST: Any individual experienced in the profession of forestry or a related
field and is licensed or certified in forestry by an accredited forestry
industry body, e.g., International Society of Arboriculture.
BUILDING ACTIVITY AREA: The portion of a property within which development
activity, including grading, excavation, storage of materials, construction
access and construction of both main buildings and unattached structures.
CANOPY: The upper portion of a tree sometimes called the crown. This section of
the tree usually contains branches and leaves.
CRITICAL ROOT ZONE: An area on the ground extending out from the trunk of the
tree in all directions a distance of at least one foot for every inch DBH.
CUTTING:
   A.   Felling or removal of a tree, or any procedure that results in the
death or substantial destruction of a tree.
   B.   Cutting that does not include normal pruning or trimming of trees
consistent with good forestry practices.
DAMAGE: Impact or loss of function to any tree including, but not limited to,
removal, root compaction, root removal, girdling, soil contamination, topping,
pruning more than 20% of the trees, canopy removal, bark removal, poisoning
and/or actions resulting in the decline or death of a tree.
DECIDUOUS TREE: A deciduous tree is one that loses most or all of its leaves
for part of the year.
DEVELOPMENT: Any proposed change in the use or character of land, including,
but not limited to, the replacement of any structure or site improvements,
e.g., irrigation installation, driveway replacement, installation of a
retaining wall among others. When appropriate to the context, development may
refer to the receipt or necessity of any building, tree or site work permit.
(See the Landscape Ordinance for more information.)
DIAMETER AT BREAST HEIGHT (DBH): The diameter of the trunk of the tree measured
in inches at a point four and one-half feet (4.5') above ground line. This
forestry standard measurement is used for established and mature trees and is
referred to as “DBH”. All reference to diameter size shall be to the DBH.
EVERGREEN TREE: A tree that retains most of its leaves for most of the year.
URBAN FOREST MANAGEMENT PLAN: A detailed plan developed and approved by the
city under the direction of a certified arborist or forester which protects
this valuable infrastructure and outlines thoughtful strategies for tree
planting, selection, care and preservation for the city and complies with
recognized national standards.
INFRASTRUCTURE: The basic underlying framework or features that provide
collective services, including, but not limited to, roads, waterlines, storm
sewers, bioswales and trees.
INVASIVE SPECIES: An introduced or exotic species that significantly modifies
or disrupts the ecosystem in which it colonizes (e.g., buckthorn).
LANDSCAPE CONTRACTOR: A company or individual contracted to perform landscape
services.
LANDSCAPE PLAN: A plan approved by the city defining the location and species
of plants and associated hardscape including grading.
LANDSCAPE MANAGEMENT PLAN: A plan approved by the city outlining the strategies
for care and management of a specific type of landscape.
LANDSCAPING PROFESSIONAL: A registered landscape architect, horticulturalist or
other similarly degreed, experienced and/or licensed plant professional.
LEGACY TREE: A tree identified on the legacy tree list and which has been
recorded as such by the city. Legacy trees are provided special protection as
outlined in the legacy tree program.
NATURAL AMENITY EXCEPTION: A landscape and preservation plan intended as a
substitute for the replacement requirements of this section.
NUISANCE TREES: Nuisance trees are trees that may provide potential impacts to
other trees, people or structures. This would include, but not be limited to,
diseased, infested, structurally unsound trees or known invasive species.
PARCEL: A single parcel shall mean any lot of record, zoning lot or any
grouping of adjacent lots under single ownership, serving a principal structure
or use.
PREFERRED TREE LIST: A listing of tree species, identified in the city urban
forest management plan.
PROPERTY OWNER: An individual or organization who owns property located within
the corporate limits of the city.
SIGNIFICANT TREE REMOVAL: Removal of a legacy tree or grouping/stand of trees.
SIMPLE TREE REMOVAL: Removal of a tree without other associated site impacts or
other site improvements.
SITE: That parcel of land for which a permit for landscaping or tree removal is
sought.
STREET TREE: Any tree located on or within the public right-of-way or right-of-
way easement.
TRANSPLANTING TREE: The removal of any tree for replanting elsewhere. Any self-
supporting woody plant, together with its root system, trunk and canopy;
growing upon the earth usually with one trunk, or a multi-stemmed trunk system,
supporting a definitely formed crown.
TREE BANK: A bank account established to receive and hold deposits for trees
which were damaged and/or removed. These funds, if not returned to the
applicant, may be used to purchase and care for trees throughout the city.
TREE PERMIT: A written authorization from the city authorizing the applicant to
conduct work which may or may not impact a tree.
TREE PRESERVATION PLAN: A document required by a permit which identifies, by
common name and/or scientific name, certain species of trees of a specified DBH
within a particular area. The plan shall list all existing and proposed trees
and shall specifically state how each tree is proposed to be destroyed,
relocated, replaced, preserved at its present location, introduced into the
site from an off-site source, and whether the tree is to receive remediated
actions due to construction impacts, e.g. root pruning. The city may provide
that the tree preservation plan excludes those portions of the site which it
determines will not be affected by the activity. Any tree preservation plan
required by this section must be dated within thirty six (36) months of the
start date of the proposed activity.
TREE REMOVAL: The cutting down, destruction, removal or relocation of any tree,
including damaging by poison or other direct or indirect action.
VIABLE: A tree, which in the judgment of the city, is capable of sustaining its
own life processes, unaided by man, for a reasonable period of time.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-3: PRESERVATION:
   A.   The city shall consult with at least one certified arborist. Any urban
forestry work completed by a contractor within the city shall be under the
direction of a certified arborist. These individuals are responsible for
enforcement and compliance of the urban forest management plan.
   B.   The city shall have an urban forest inventory of publicly owned trees.
This inventory shall be maintained in a current state. Re-inventory may be
required every five (5) to seven (7) years unless the inventory is updated with
the pruning cycle or is updated as part of routine tree maintenance.
   C.   1.   The city shall have an approved urban forest management plan. This
plan shall be the framework for the protection, management and planting of
trees within the city and shall support and clearly define regulations
identified in the tree preservation ordinance.
      2.   This plan shall include the following:
         a.   A defined ten (10) year urban forestry strategy with clearly
identified one (1), five (5) and ten (10) years goals;
         b.   Community canopy mapping identifying existing tree canopy and
priority locations for planting;
         c.   A strategy for completion and maintenance of a tree inventory on
public;
         d.   Clear guidelines on tree species and age diversity;
         e.   Clear identification of replacement value and requirements for
tree removal or damage;
         f.   A preferred tree list;
         g.   Clearly defined specifications for tree planting, pruning and
impact reduction;
         h.   A risk assessment and management program;
         i.   A legacy tree preservation and protection program including a
legacy tree list;
         j.   A strategy for administration and implementation of a volunteer
program;
         k.   Clear identification of staff qualifications, training, support
and needs;
         l.   Specifications for contracted labor and consulting;
         m.   Clear identification of forestry equipment and resource needs;
and
         n.   A forestry budget with one (1), five (5) and ten (10) year
commitments.
   D.   The city shall require that any contractor, working for the city who
may interact or have impact on the city public property urban forest attain a
tree permit to perform all work pertaining to trees, including, but not limited
to, removal, pruning and planting activities.
   E.   Legacy trees are provided special protection by the city. (See the
urban forest management plan for legacy trees program.)
   F.   All tree planting, selection and management shall be in compliance with
the urban forest management plan.
   G.   It is recognized that diverse species and age structure of urban trees
throughout city are critical to the health of the forest structure and protects
the city from catastrophic loss and improved longevity. Specifications for
species and age diversity, planting and management are contained in the urban
forest management plan.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-4: PLANTING:
   A.   As outlined in the urban forest management plan, the city shall plant,
and recommend to private landowners, diverse species with the ratio of not more
than twenty percent (20%) of any one family, ten percent (10%) of any one genus
or five percent (5%) of any one species, with the exception of naturalized
areas where species selections are based on the natural species assemblages as
defined in the urban forest management plan. Diverse species composition
protects the city from catastrophic loss.
   B.   All trees planted by the city or its agent shall be planted in
accordance with the urban forest management plan.
   C.   Trees purchased by the city shall meet the specifications required in
the urban forest management plan.
   D.   It shall be unlawful to plant any tree or shrub in the public right-of-
way, or on other publicly owned property, without prior written approval from
the city.
   E.   It shall be unlawful to plant any tree under utility wires that is
anticipated to grow to a height that will interfere with the wires.
   F.   The city shall implement a growing program. This program will allow for
stable pricing and broader species diversity to improve the overall diversity
of the urban forest.
   G.   The city shall provide education and outreach to private landowners on
the need for species and age diversity, proper selection and planting
practices, and how to select species for particular sites.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-5: TREE CARE:
Tree care on public lands within the city shall comply with requirements
identified in the urban forest management plan. It is recommended that tree
care on private property meet these same requirements. Tree pruning shall
follow industry standards as listed in the UFMP. Tree topping is prohibited.
Refer to the tree pruning standards section of the UFMP.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-6: TREE PROTECTION:
This section applies to any work or activity which may impact public property
trees.
   A.   Unless otherwise authorized by this section, it shall be unlawful for
any person to remove, injure or undertake any procedure which will cause death,
substantial damage, or create a hazard, to any public property tree without
first obtaining a tree permit from the city. In the case of tree management
practices, these practices shall comply with the requirements identified in the
urban forest management plan.
   B.   In the event of any site improvement which may impact public property
trees, a tree preservation plan is required, must be approved, and implemented
prior to the start of any work or delivery of any materials to the building
activity area. The approved tree preservation plan shall be available on the
site throughout the entire construction period until final approvals for all
site work shall be received in writing. (See urban forest management plan.)
   C.   In instances where the activity requires the use of heavy equipment and
where that activity may impact trees on public or private property, all
appropriate tree protection measures must be taken and identified in the tree
preservation plan. In addition, all tree protection measures shall be in
compliance with the urban forest management plan.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-7: LEGACY TREE PROTECTION:
   A.   Legacy Trees: The Princeton tree board shall determine the location,
selection and identification of any public tree(s) or private tree(s) which
qualify as “legacy trees”. The owner may contest the designation of a legacy
tree status on private property by formal application in writing to the
Princeton tree board. A tree may qualify as a legacy tree if it meets one or
more of the following specifics: species rarity, old age, association with an
historical event or person, abnormality, scenic enhancement or other
qualification as determined by the Princeton tree board.
   B.   If a tree has been awarded “legacy” status by the Princeton tree board
it will be unlawful to:
      1.   Affix any sign to the tree.
      2.   Construct anything in the tree.
      3.   Attach a fence.
      4.   Place anything in such a manner as to obstruct the growth of the
tree.
      5.   Affix any bolts, nails, screws or hardware of any nature unless it
is in the best interest or necessary to the well-being of the tree.
      6.   Remove or trim any legacy tree without prior written notification to
the Princeton tree board thirty (30) days prior to such action except when
emergency situations prevent proper notice. If a legacy tree must be removed or
trimmed during an emergency situation, notice of that emergency action must
still be filed with the Princeton tree board, within 72 hours of that action.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-8: TREE REMOVAL:
Tree removals are considered an impact to the entire city, whether on public or
private land. It is clearly documented that larger trees provide larger
benefits and as such, tree removal fees and fines are based on species and
diameter. (See fee and fine schedule of the code.) It is recognized that the
planting of smaller trees does not replace the value of larger trees that are
lost. It will take tens of years for that value to be replaced and for that
reason efforts should be made to preserve and protect trees where they are
growing.
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any individual to remove or cause damage to
any tree located on public property without first receiving a tree permit from
the city.
   B.   No live, dead or dying tree, or grouping of trees, equal to six inches
(6") or greater on public property may be removed without first obtaining a
permit from the city.
   C.   A nuisance tree is a tree that has already died, is in a state of
irrevocable decline, has the capacity to damage a person or thing or is an
invasive species. In the event of an emergency, and access to the city is not
possible, a nuisance tree may be removed without a permit, however, the
individual removing the tree shall take photographs and memorialize the
nuisance situation prior to removal and shall follow up with a request for a
tree permit from the city on the next business day.
   D.   Any tree removed from a parcel or transplanted offsite must be replaced
according to the regulations outlined in the urban forest management plan.
   E.   All stump removals shall require underground utility locations prior to
any action.
   F.   If a tree is removed or damaged which is not on the tree permit it must
be replaced or bonded as set forth in this section.
   G.   Removal of invasive woody plants such as buckthorn does not require a
permit and is encouraged. These invasive plants can quickly colonize an area
reducing the health and vitality of non-invasive plants. A list of invasive
woody plants is provided in the urban forest management plan.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-9: TREE REPLACEMENT;
   A.   It is required that tree replacement species come from the preferred
species list. The preferred species list is provided in the urban forest
management plan.
   B.   Any tree which is required to be removed or which has been damaged
shall require a bond to be posted until adequate replacements or remediation
can be made. The bond amount is identified in the fee section of the code.
Determination of extent of damage is at the sole discretion of the city.
   C.   Any tree species removed, six inch (6") DBH or six inch (6") group of
trees, which is not identified on the invasive species list, but is identified
on the preferred species list, is required for replacement by this section.
These trees shall be replaced based on the calculation provided on the
preferred species list with a species identified on that list. All replacements
shall be located appropriately as confirmed by a certified arborist and as
approved by the city.
   D.   When a tree removal is required as a result of any project, tree
replacement shall occur within the landscape season. In the event of weather
conditions or species-specific needs, which prohibit proper replacement of a
tree, the city may issue written notice of an extension of up to one hundred
eighty (180) days upon written request by the applicant. If an extension is
awarded to the applicant, the applicant shall notify the city when replacement
is complete. If, after the thirty (30) day or awarded one hundred eighty (180)
day extension, the tree is not replaced or the applicant has not notified the
city that installation is complete, all bonds shall be forfeited and the bond
money shall be placed in the tree bank. Tree removal requirements, associated
with a development project, can be found in the development section of the
code.
   E.   All tree replacement plantings shall require an underground utility
location prior to planting.
   F.   If the property where a removal has taken place does not have adequate
space to plant a replacement tree, then the applicant shall be required to pay
the city a dollar amount as identified in the fee section of the code. Funds
shall be placed in the tree bank for tree replacement or tree care in another
area of the city.
   G.   It shall be encouraged that any species identified on the invasive
species list be removed. There is no replacement requirement for these
removals.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-10: TREE PRESERVATION AND/OR REMOVAL PLAN FOR SIGNIFICANT REMOVALS:
An applicant seeking a permit for significant tree removals or tree removal
and/or planting related to construction and/or development shall comply with
all requirements of this section and the urban forest management plan.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-11: NUISANCE TREES:
A tree which is determined to be a nuisance tree is one which is dead or
declining and has the potential to damage other trees, people or structures.
These trees may be located on public or private property.
   A.   It shall be the duty of the property owner on any parcel to promptly
remove any trees which pose a risk.
   B.   Should the city notify the property owner, in writing, of a tree which
is a potential risk, the property owner shall have thirty (30) days to remove
the tree. If after thirty (30) days the property owner has not removed the tree
then the city shall take action to have the tree removed and shall provide to
the property owner a written invoice outlining all costs associated with the
removal, including but not limited to staff time, materials and oversight of
said removal. Should the property owner not reimburse the city within thirty
(30) days of issuance of a written invoice, the city shall place a lien on the
property until all expenses related to the removal and subsequent lien are
paid.
   C.   Infected, Infested Trees Due to a Pest or Pathogen Are Defined as a
Nuisance:
      1.   Any tree which is in a state of irreparable or untreatable decline
due to heavy infestation or disease is included in the definition of a
nuisance. Infested or infected trees, which are identified by federal or state
departments of agriculture to be in quarantine or can potentially infect or
infest other trees are defined as a nuisance. This would include, but not be
limited to, ash (fraxinus) trees infested with emerald ash borer which are not
being treated or whose treatment is ineffectual, or elm trees (ulmus) infected
with Dutch elm disease.
         a.   The city shall enforce state and federal regulations governing
quarantine zone boundaries, and regulated articles.
         b.   For the purposes of this section, “regulated articles” are hereby
defined as any insects at any living state of development, any quarantines
materials such as wood products including, but not limited to chips, limbs,
lumber, firewood or any other product or means of conveyance which may be
determined by federal or state departments of agriculture to pose a risk of
spread of any infestation or infection.
         c.   It shall be illegal to move out of established quarantine zone(s)
regulated articles unless those articles have met all requirements of the
local, federal and state regulatory agencies.
         d.   It shall be illegal for any person or entity to transfer from a
quarantine zone into a non-quarantine zone including the city any regulated
articles.
         e.   Any person or entity found to be in violation of any local, state
or federal regulations related to tree infestations or infections shall be
prosecuted to the full extent of the law.
         f.   All contractors working within and near any quarantine zone(s)
are required to comply with the quarantine regulations and supply records that
may be required for inspection to the city, county, state or federal agencies
upon request.
      2.   Trees in Decline or Dead Are Defined as a Nuisance:
         a.   Any tree or part of a tree which is dead which could potentially
fall on a person or structure is defined as a nuisance.
         b.   It shall be unlawful for any owner of any lot or land in the city
to permit or maintain on any such lot or land, any tree which is dead, or
declining to the state where it may create a potential risk for structures or
people. It shall be the duty of any such owner to promptly cause the removal of
any such tree.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-12: INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL:
   A.   Invasive plants cause ecological disruption to natural ecosystems. The
type of impact varies based on the species and the traits of that species. The
woody invasive species list is included in the urban forest management plan.
   B.   These species shall not be planted and should be removed and controlled
to reduce impacts to other vegetation.
      1.   Typical impacts include:
         a.   Chemical disturbance to the soil limiting development of other
species; and
         b.   Dense plant growth limiting light to soil surface resulting in
exposed soil allowing erosion.
      2.   Displacement of naturally occurring species resulting in a
monoculture of invasive species and aggressive tendencies.
      3.   Private Property Owner Outreach: The city shall have implementation
and outreach plan to educate property owners of the potential impacts and
remediation strategies, including a suggested planting list of alternative
species to assist property owners in dealing with the problem. This plan is
located in the Urban Forest Management Plan.
   C.   Invasive Diseases And Insects:
      1.   Impacts to Trees: Invasive diseases and insects can create
significant stress to trees and in some instances kill trees. The city has
developed a list of invasive diseases and insects that pose significant threats
to trees from information identified by state and federal departments of
agriculture. This list is included in the urban forest management plan.
      2.   Invasive Species Management Plan: Management of invasive diseases
and insects is included in the urban forest management plan.
      3.   Private Property Owner Outreach: The city shall have an
implementation and outreach plan to educate property owners of the potential
impacts and remediation strategies to help property tree owners in dealing with
pests or pathogens. This plan is located in the urban forest management plan.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-13: TREE BOARD:
   A.   Establishment: The city hereby establishes a tree board which shall be
a recommending body to provide assistance, direction and expertise to the city
regarding the preservation, planting, management and protection of trees. The
tree board shall develop and recommend implementation of an urban forest
management plan for guidance on urban forestry issues.
   B.   Membership:
      1.   The tree board shall consist of five (5) to seven (7) members
subject to approval of the city board. It is recommended that individuals
within the community who have expertise in horticulture, forestry, planning, or
related fields be sought as members of the tree board. At least one (1) member
of the tree board shall be a certified arborist. The mayor shall designate one
(1) of the members to act as chairperson of the tree board, subject to the
approval of the city council. A member of the city streets and city electrical
departments shall be assigned to be ex officio members of said tree board
without the power to vote.
      2.   The appointed members shall serve for a period of three (3) years.
If a vacancy shall occur in the full membership, a replacement will be
appointed by the tree board to fill the remainder of the term. The tree board
members shall serve without compensation.
   C.   Procedures: The tree board shall meet and adopt, change or alter, rules
and regulations of organization and procedure consistent with city ordinances
and Illinois state laws. The tree board shall keep written records of its
proceedings which shall be open at all times to public inspection. The tree
board shall file an annual report to the city board setting forth its past year
activities and recommendations for future action by the city.
   D.   Powers and Duties: The tree board shall have the following powers and
duties subject to the approval of the city board:
      1.   To provide guidance on the preservation, care, management and
protection of trees within the city in accordance with urban forestry
management plan, regional and local best management practices.
      2.   To prepare and recommend to the city council from time-to-time
recommendations for specific improvements of the preservation, care, management
and protection of trees within the city.
      3.   To recommend rules and regulations to the city council for budget,
plans, projects and schedules regarding the preservation, care, management and
protection of trees within the city.
      4.   To review the city urban forest management plan and provide
recommendations for improvements to the city council.
      5.   To work collaboratively with city staff to support the city
ordinances and urban forest management plan.
      6.   Manage and administer all plans, programs, projects and tasks
delegated to it by the city Council as authorized and directed by the city
council.
      7.   The tree board shall hear any requests for appeal to this code and
make recommendations to be forwarded to the city council for a final decision.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-14: TREE PERMIT PROCEDURE:
   A.   Applicant Submission: An applicant for a simple tree removal or
planting on public property shall fill out a tree removal or tree planting
request online, or in person, and the city arborist shall make an inspection
and render a determination.
   B.   Inventory: If a removal or planting is significant or in conjunction
with any type of development, then a full tree preservation plan and inventory
for the area to be impacted may be required. (See urban forestry management
plan for more information.) The city shall review the application. This review
shall include an inspection of the site and referral of the application for
recommendation to other appropriate administrative departments or agencies. The
city shall render a decision on the application within ten working days of its
receipt of a properly completed application.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-15: PERMIT ISSUANCE:
   A.   It shall be unlawful on public property for any person or commercial
enterprise receiving remuneration to engage in the business of planting,
cutting, trimming, pruning, removing, spraying or otherwise treating trees,
shrubs or other plants on city owned property without first having secured a
permit.
   B.   Issuance: The city shall issue a tree permit upon approval of an
application and payment of a required fee and bond.
   C.   Insurance Requirement: Before any commercial tree care permit shall be
issued, each applicant shall first file evidence of possession of liability
insurance in the minimum amounts of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00)
for bodily injury or death for each occurrence and three hundred thousand
dollars ($300,000.00) property damage for each occurrence indemnifying
Princeton or any person injured or damaged resulting from the pursuit of such
endeavor as herein described and shall abide by all of the provisions in this
chapter.
   D.   Time Limitation:
      1.   A tree permit shall expire and become null and void if work
authorized is not commenced within one year from the date of the permit or if
such work when commenced is suspended or abandoned at any time for a period of
one year.
      2.   If work has commenced and the tree permit becomes null and void or
expires because of a lack of progress or abandonment, a new tree permit for the
proposed tree removal, planting activity shall be obtained before proceeding
with further work.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-16: CASH BONDS:
   A.   If tree replacement is required by this section, then as a condition of
the tree permit, the applicant shall submit a cash bond as identified in the
fee section of this code. The bond shall be held for the purpose of assuring
that the replacement tree(s) are purchased and planted.
   B.   If it is determined that practices which violate any portion of the
city code have resulted in tree damage, then the city may require that a cash
bond, as determined in accordance with the fee section of this code, shall be
submitted at the time the violation occurs. The bond shall be held for the
purpose of assuring that all remedial actions to minimize tree damage are
taken, and/or for the purpose of assuring tree replacement should any damaged
tree die or show noticeable signs of decline as determined by a certified
arborist. If it is determined that residual damage may not be apparent, then
the bond may be held for a period of sixty (60) months or five (5) years. At
the end of which time, if the tree survives and is in good health, as
determined by a certified arborist the bond shall be returned. If the tree does
not survive, and was not further impacted by an act of God, or is in poor
health then replacement shall be required as identified above and according to
the fee section of the code.
   C.   If the bond is posted for a tree and the property owner wishes to
transfer the property, then the bond shall be required to be paid before
transfer of the property or shall be refunded to the original property owner
once the bond requirements have been met.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-17: FINAL INSPECTION:
Final approval shall be issued when all relocation, replacement or remediation
of trees is completed and a final inspection has been conducted by the city.
Should the city determine that the season is inappropriate for planting then
relocation or replacement shall be deferred until the next planting season. All
bonds and fees will remain in the custody of the city until final inspection
and approval has been provided in writing.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-18: COMPLIANCE:
The city shall retain jurisdiction to ensure compliance with this section and
shall have the right to issue a stop work order for noncompliance. No stop work
order issued pursuant to this section shall be removed by the city unless the
applicant has paid a reinspection fee in accordance with the fee schedule of
this code.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-19: PENALTY:
Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this chapter shall be
assessed at a cost as prescribed in the fee section of the code. Each tree cut
down, destroyed, damaged, removed or moved shall constitute a separate offense.
In addition to these penalties, if a tree is removed in violation of this
section, all replacement requirements of this chapter shall be applied.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-20: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Enforcement Right of Entry of City Officers: To carry out the purposes
of this section and to implement its enforcement, the city is authorized and
empowered, upon twenty-four (24) hours notice, to enter upon any lot or parcel
of land in the city at all reasonable hours to inspect any tree or wood and to
remove specimens from any such tree to determine their condition. It shall be
unlawful for any person to interfere with a city officer carrying out the
duties authorized in this section.
   B.   Duty of Property Owner to Abate Nuisance or Potential Risk: If it is
determined that there exists a public nuisance or risk as declared in this
section, the city shall serve or cause to be served upon the owner of the lot
or parcel of land on which such nuisance or risk is located, a written notice
identifying the nuisance or risk and requiring the owner to comply with the
provisions of this section. If the person upon whom such notice is served
fails, neglects or refuses to remove and dispose of the tree or dead wood
within thirty days after service of such notice, the city may proceed to remove
and dispose of such tree or dead wood and the costs shall be paid by the owner
to the city.
   C.   Service of Notice to Property Owner: Service of notice provided for in
this section shall be affected by personal service or by certified mail
addressed to the occupant or to the person to whom, and at the address, to
which the tax bill was sent for the general taxes for the last preceding year
on the lot or parcel on which the nuisance is located.
   D.   City Abatement and Assessment of Costs: Any costs incurred by the city
in the abatement of a public nuisance or hazard as declared in this section
shall be assessed against the record owner of the land involved and the city
shall place a lien upon such property for those costs in the manner provided by
law.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-21: EXCEPTIONS:
If because of emergency weather or other casualty conditions a tree is
endangering health, safety or property and requires immediate removal, verbal
authorization may be given by the city for the tree removal without obtaining a
