written permit. Such verbal authorization shall later be confirmed in writing
by the city.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-22: APPEALS FOR VARIANCE:
   A.   Any person aggrieved by any decision of the city in the enforcement of
any terms or provisions of this section may, within ten working days after the
date of the decision, appeal to the tree board by filing a written notice of
appeal with the city clerk. The notice of appeal shall set forth concisely the
decision and the reasons or grounds for the appeal. The tree board may make a
recommendation to the city board to affirm, modify, or reverse the decision.
The decision of the city board shall be final and no petition for rehearing or
reconsideration shall be available. Reasonable notice of the hearing by the
tree board shall be provided by the city clerk to all affected parties.
   B.   No variances in the strict application of the provisions of this
section shall be recommended for approval by the board unless it finds:
      1.   That there are special circumstances or conditions, fully described
in the written notice of appeal which are peculiar to the property (properties)
and do not apply generally to properties within the city, and that said
circumstances or conditions are such that the strict application of the code
would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of the subject property
(properties).
      2.   That for reasons fully set forth in the written notice of appeal,
the granting of the variance is necessary for the reasonable use of the
property (properties) and that the variance, as recommended for approval by the
Board, is the minimum variance that will accomplish this purpose.
      3.   That the result of granting of the variance will be in harmony with
the general purpose and intent of standards set forth within this code and in
harmony with this section, and will not be injurious to adjacent property or
otherwise detrimental to the public welfare.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
7-2A-23: CIVIL REMEDIES:
In addition to any other remedies provided by this section the city shall have
the following judicial remedies available for violations of this section or any
permit condition promulgated under this section.
   A.   The city may institute a civil action in a court of competent
jurisdiction to establish liability and to recover damages for any injury
caused by the removal or damage of trees in contravention of the terms of this
section.
   B.   The city may institute a civil action in a court of competent
jurisdiction to seek injunctive relief to enforce compliance with this section
to enjoin any violation, and to seek injunctive relief to prevent irreparable
injury to the trees or properties encompassed by the terms of this section.
(Ord. O-22-012, 6-20-2022)
CHAPTER 3: CITY PARKS
Section
7-3-1: Short Title
7-3-2: Definitions
7-3-3: Park Property
7-3-4: Water Pollution; Deposit Of Rubbish And Trash
7-3-5: Traffic Regulations
7-3-6: Recreational Activities
7-3-7: Fires; Materials Causing Fires
7-3-8: Fireworks And Explosives
7-3-9: Animal Control
7-3-10: Sales Of Merchandise; Advertising; Notices
7-3-11: Additional Offenses
7-3-12: Permit Requirements For Group Activities
7-3-13: Park Operating Policy
7-3-14: Enforcement
7-3-15: Penalty
7-3-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the CITY OF PRINCETON ORDINANCE
REGULATING CONDUCT IN PUBLIC PARKS.
7-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
DIRECTOR: A person or board immediately in charge of any park area and its
activities and to whom all park attendants of such area are responsible.
PARK: A park, reservation, playground, beach, recreation center or any other
area in the city owned or used by the city including Darius Miller Park,
Veterans Park and City-County Park.
VEHICLE: Any mode of transporting people or goods, whether motor powered,
animal drawn, or self- propelled. The term shall include any trailer in tow of
any size, kind or description or any camper or snowmobile. Baby strollers and
city vehicles used to service the parks are not included in the definition of
“vehicle”.
7-3-3: PARK PROPERTY:
   A.   Structures, Facilities, Utilities:
      1.   No person in a park shall willfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure,
tamper with, displace or remove any buildings, bridges, tables, benches,
fireplaces, railings, pavings or paving materials, water lines or other public
utilities or parts or appurtenances thereof, signs, notices or placards,
whether temporary or permanent, monuments, stakes, posts, or other boundary
markers, or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property or
appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal.
      2.   No person in a park shall climb any tree or walk, stand or sit upon
monuments, vases, fountains, railings or fences or upon any other property not
designated or customarily used for such purposes.
      3.   All persons who use the restroom or washroom facilities shall
maintain the restrooms and washrooms in a neat and sanitary condition.
      4.   No person shall dig or remove any beach sand, whether submerged or
not, or any soil, rock, stones, trees, shrubs or plants, down timber or other
wood or materials, or make any excavation by tool, equipment, blasting, or
other means or agency from any park.
      5.   No person shall construct or erect any building or structure of
whatever kind, whether permanent or temporary in character, or run or string
any public service utility into, upon, or across such lands in any park, except
on a special written permit issued under this chapter.
   B.   Vegetation:
      1.   No person in a park shall damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove
any tree or plant or injure the bark, or pick the flowers or seeds of any tree
or plant; nor shall any person attach any rope, wire, or other contrivance to
any tree or plant. A person shall not dig in or otherwise disturb grass areas
or in any other way injure or impair the natural beauty or usefulness of any
area.
      2.   No person in a park shall tie or hitch a horse or other animal to
any tree or plant.
   C.   Wildlife:
      1.   No person in a park shall hunt, molest, harm, frighten, kill, trap,
chase, tease, shoot or throw missiles at any animal, reptile or bird; nor shall
he or she remove or have in his or her possession the young of any wild animal,
or the eggs, nest, or young of any reptile or bird; nor shall he or she
collect, remove, have in his or her possession, give away, sell or offer to
sell, or buy or offer to buy, or accept as a gift any specimen, alive or dead,
of any of the group of tree snails. As an exception to this subsection C1,
snakes known to be deadly poisonous, such as rattlesnakes, moccasins, coral
snakes, or other deadly reptiles, may be killed on sight.
      2.   No person in a park shall give or offer, or attempt to give, to any
animal or bird any tobacco, alcohol or other known noxious substances.
7-3-4: WATER POLLUTION; DEPOSIT OF RUBBISH AND TRASH:
   A.   No person in a park shall throw, discharge, or otherwise place or cause
to be placed in the waters of any fountain, pond, lake, stream, bay or other
body of water in or adjacent to any park or any tributary, stream, storm sewer,
or drain flowing into such waters any substance, matter or thing, liquid or
solid, which will or may result in the pollution of such waters.
   B.   No person in a park shall have brought in or shall dump, deposit or
leave any bottles, broken glass, ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish,
waste, garbage, refuse, or other trash. No such refuse or trash shall be placed
in any waters in or contiguous to any park or left anywhere on the grounds
thereof, but shall be placed in the proper receptacles where these are
provided. Where receptacles are not so provided, all such rubbish or waste
shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence
and properly disposed of elsewhere.
7-3-5: TRAFFIC REGULATIONS:
   A.   State Laws Apply: No person in a park shall fail to comply with all
applicable provisions of the state motor vehicle traffic laws in regard to
equipment and the operation of vehicles, together with such regulations as are
contained in this code and other ordinances.
   B.   Obedience To Officials And Signs:
      1.   No person in a park shall fail to obey all traffic officers and park
employees, such persons being hereby authorized and instructed to direct
traffic whenever and wherever needed in the parks and on the highways, streets
or roads immediately adjacent thereto in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter and such supplementary regulations as may be issued subsequently by the
city.
      2.   All persons shall observe and obey all traffic signs indicating
speed, direction, caution, stopping, or parking and all other signs posted for
proper control and to safeguard life and property.
   C.   Speed Limit: No person in a park shall ride or drive a vehicle at a
rate of speed exceeding ten (10) miles an hour, except upon such roads as the
city may designate, by posted signs, for speedier travel.
   D.   Vehicles Restricted To Roadways And Parking Areas: No person in a park
shall drive any vehicle on any area except the paved park roads, parking areas,
or such other areas as may be specifically designated as parking areas by the
city.
   E.   Parking:
      1.   No person in a park shall park a vehicle anywhere other than an
established or designated parking area. Such use shall be in accordance with
posted directions or with the instructions of any attendant who may be present.
      2.   No person shall park on the road or driveway of a park at any time.
      3.   No person shall leave any vehicle anywhere in the park with one or
more wheels chained, or with the motor set in gear and the doors locked, or in
any manner fixed or arranged so that such vehicle cannot readily be moved by
hand.
      4.   No person shall leave a vehicle standing or parked in a park at
night without lights clearly visible for at least two hundred feet (200') from
both the front and rear on any driveway or road area, except for legally
established parking areas.
      5.   No person shall fail to immediately notify a park attendant of an
emergency or the police department in the nature of a breakdown requiring the
assistance of a tow truck, mechanic or other person.
      6.   No person shall double park any vehicle on any road or parkway,
unless directed by a park official.
   F.   Muffler Required: No person in a park shall fail to use a muffler
adequate to deaden the sound of the engine in a motor vehicle.
   G.   Bicycles:
      1.   A bicycle may only be used on a paved vehicular road or path
designated for that purpose. A bicyclist may push a bicycle by hand over any
grassy area, wooded trail, or any paved area reserved for pedestrian use.
      2.   All bicyclists shall abide by the same traffic regulations as
motorized vehicles and shall operate on the right hand side of the road as
conditions permit. Bicycles shall be kept in a single file line when two (2) or
more are operating as a group. Bicyclists shall at all times operate their
machines with reasonable regard to the safety of others.
      3.   Bicycles shall be placed in a bicycle rack when such is provided and
there is a space available.
      4.   Every bicycle, when in use at nighttime, shall be equipped with a
lamp and reflector.
   H.   Snowmobiles: Snowmobiles are prohibited on all park property.
7-3-6: RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES:
   A.   Bathing; Swimming:
      1.   No person shall swim, bathe or wade in any waters or waterways in or
adjacent to any park, except in such waters and at such places as are provided
therefor, and in compliance with such regulations as are set forth in this
chapter or as may be hereafter adopted; nor shall any person frequent any
waters or places customarily designated for the purpose of swimming or bathing,
or congregate thereat, when such activity is prohibited by the director upon a
finding that such use of the water would be dangerous or otherwise inadvisable.
      2.   All persons shall abide by the times of use that are designated by
the city for the purpose of swimming or bathing, or congregation.
      3.   In any beach or bathing area no person shall erect, maintain, use or
occupy any tent, shelter or structure of any kind unless there shall be an
unobstructed view into such tent, shelter or structure from at least two (2)
sides; nor shall any guy wire, rope, extension, exterior brace or support be
connected or fastened from any such structure to any other structure, stake,
rock or other object outside thereof.
      4.   No person in a park shall dress or undress on any beach or in any
vehicle, restroom or other place, except in such bathing houses or structures
as may be provided for that purpose.
   B.   Boating:
      1.   No person shall bring into or operate any boat, raft or other
watercraft, whether motor powered or not, upon any waters, except at places
designated for boating by the city. Such activity shall be in accordance with
applicable city regulations.
      2.   No person shall use the public docks for docking or other purpose
without first making arrangements for such accommodation with the city. The
city shall assign space and collect reasonable rental charges in conformity
with established regulations and rates.
      3.   No person shall navigate, direct or handle any boat in such a manner
as to unjustifiably or unnecessarily annoy, frighten or endanger the occupants
of any other boat.
      4.   No person shall launch, dock or operate any boat of any kind on any
waters after the closing of the park and before the opening of the park. Nor
shall any person be on, or remain on or in, any boat after the park is closed.
   C.   Fishing:
      1.   No person shall engage in commercial fishing or the buying or
selling of fish caught in any waters located in a park.
      2.   No person shall fish in any waters, whether by the use by hook and
line, net, trap, or other device, except in waters designated by the city for
that use and under such regulations and restrictions as have been or may be
prescribed by the city.
   D.   Hunting; Weapons:
      1.   No person shall hunt, trap or pursue wildlife at any time in any
park.
      2.   No person shall use, carry, or possess firearms of any description,
air rifles, spring guns, bow and arrows, slings or any other forms of weapons
that are used to harm wildlife, or are dangerous to human safety, or any
instrument that can fire blank cartridges, or any kind of trapping device.
      3.   No person shall shoot into a park from outside of park boundaries.
The city’s police department and the county sheriff’s department are exempt
from this prohibition in the City-County Park.
   E.   Picnic Areas:
      1.   No person shall picnic or lunch in places other than those
designated for that purpose. City employees working in the park shall have the
authority to regulate the activities in such areas when necessary to prevent
congestion and to secure the maximum use for the comfort and convenience of
all. Visitors shall comply with any directions given by a city employee of the
police department to achieve this end.
      2.   That use of the individual firepits, together with tables and
benches, follows generally the rule of “first come, first serve”, except in the
case of the shelters and cabins located in the City-County Park which may be
reserved by special permit issued by the city or county.
      3.   No person shall use any portion of the picnic areas, or any of the
buildings or structures therein, for the purpose of holding picnics to the
exclusion of other persons, nor shall any person use such area and facilities
for an unreasonable time if the facilities are crowded unless use is pursuant
to a permit issued by the city or county, as specified in subsection E2 of this
section.
      4.   No person shall leave a picnic area before the fire is completely
extinguished and before all trash in the nature of boxes, papers, cans,
bottles, garbage and other refuse is placed in the disposal receptacles where
provided. If no such trash receptacles are available, then refuse and trash
shall be carried away from the park area by the picnicker to be properly
disposed of elsewhere.
   F.   Camping: No person shall camp in or set up tents, shacks or any other
temporary shelter for the purpose of overnight camping, nor shall any person
leave any moveable structure or special vehicle that could be used for such
purpose in a park after closing hours. Special vehicle includes but is not
limited to a house trailer, camp trailer, camp wagon or the like. Special
permits may be issued upon applications to the city. No campers or trailers
shall be allowed in a park at any time.
   G.   Games: No person shall take part in or abet the playing of any games
involving thrown or otherwise propelled objects such as balls, stones, arrows
or javelins, except in areas set apart for such forms of recreation. The
playing of rough or comparatively dangerous games such as football, baseball
and quoits is prohibited, except on the fields and courts or areas provided
therefor.
7-3-7: FIRES; MATERIALS CAUSING FIRES:
   A.   No person shall build or attempt to build a fire, except in such areas
and under such regulations as may be designated by the city.
   B.   No person shall drop, throw, or otherwise scatter lighted matches,
burning cigarettes or cigars, tobacco paper or other flammable materia, within
any park area or on any highway, road or street abutting or contiguous thereto.
7-3-8: FIREWORKS AND EXPLOSIVES:
The setting off or causing to explode, discharging or burning of any
firecracker, torpedo, rocket or other fireworks or explosives of flammable
material is strictly prohibited as is the discharge of them or the throwing of
them into any such area from the land or highway adjacent thereto. This
prohibition includes any substance, compound, mixture or article that, in
conjunction with any other substance or compound, would be dangerous from any
of the foregoing standpoints.
Cross-reference:
   See title 5, chapter 6 of this code for unmanned aircraft (drones)
regulations
 7-3-9: ANIMAL CONTROL:
   A.   Domestic Animals:
      1.   No person shall allow a dog to run at large in any park.
      2.   Any person who possesses a dog in a park shall pick up after the dog
defecates.
   B.   Horseback Riding: Where permitted, horses shall be thoroughly broken,
properly restrained, and ridden with due care and shall not be allowed to graze
or go unattended, nor shall they be hitched to any rock, tree or shrub. Any
person who rides a horse in permitted areas shall be responsible for cleaning
up after said horse defecates
7-3-10: SALES OF MERCHANDISE; ADVERTISING; NOTICES:
   A.   No person shall offer for sale any merchandise or service, nor shall he
or she place any stand, cart, or vehicle for the transportation, advertisement,
sale or display of any such merchandise or service in any park.
   B.   No person in a park shall announce, advertise, or call the public’s
attention in any way to any article or service for sale or hire.
   C.   No person shall paste, glue, tack or otherwise post any sign, placard,
advertisement, or inscription to any city owned property. Nor shall any person
erect or cause to be erected any sign on any public lands or highways or roads
adjacent to a park.
7-3-11: ADDITIONAL OFFENSES:
   A.   Interference With Officers and Employees: No person shall interfere
with or in any manner hinder any officer, employee or agent of the city while
such officer, employee, or agent is engaged in constructing, repairing or
caring for any portion of any park.
   B.   Entering Closed Areas: No person shall enter an area posted as “closed
to the public”, nor shall any person use or encourage another to use any area
in violation of posted notices.
   C.   Going Onto Ice: No person in a park shall go onto the ice on any of the
waters.
   D.   Begging; Soliciting Contributions: No person shall solicit donations or
contributions for any purpose, whether public or private.
   E.   Alcoholic Beverages:
      1.   Consumption: No person shall consume alcoholic beverages or possess
open alcohol in any park, except at certain specifically areas or events
approved by the city and in compliance with title 3, chapter 1 of this code.
      2.   Sales: No person shall sell alcoholic beverages in any park, except
at specifically designated events that are approved by the city.
   F.   Gambling: No person shall gamble or participate in any game of chance
that is unlawful pursuant to state law.
   G.   Loitering; Disorderly Conduct:
      1.   No person shall make use of the park as a place to sleep, whether in
cars, buildings, seats, benches or any area within the park after the park
closes. No person shall swing, occupy or use any hammock in any area except
where designated for such purpose by the city.
      2.   No person in a park shall lounge on the seats, benches or other
areas, or engage in loud, boisterous, threatening, abusive, insulting or
indecent language, or engage in any disorderly conduct or behavior tending to
breach public peace.
7-3-12: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS FOR GROUP ACTIVITIES:
   A.   Permit Required: A permit shall be obtained from the city before
participating in group activities in a park.
   B.   Application For Permit: A person seeking issuance of a permit under
this section shall file an application with the city. The application shall
state:
      1.   The name and address of the applicant.
      2.   The name and address of the person, persons, corporation or
association sponsoring the activity, if any.
      3.   The day and hours for which the permit is desired.
      4.   Proof of insurance if applicable and required by the city.
      5.   The park or portion thereof for which such permit is desired.
      6.   An estimate of the anticipated attendance.
      7.   Any other information which the city shall find reasonably necessary
to a fair determination as to whether a permit should be issued.
   C.   Issuance Of Permit: The city shall issue a permit hereunder when it
finds that:
      1.   The proposed activity or use of the park will not unreasonably
interfere with or detract from the general public’s enjoyment of the park.
      2.   The proposed activity and use will not unreasonably interfere with
or detract from the promotion of public health, welfare, safety and recreation.
      3.   The proposed activity or use is not reasonably anticipated to incite
violence, crime or disorderly conduct.
      4.   The proposed activity will not entail unusual, extraordinary or
burdensome expense on the police department.
      5.   The facilities desired have not been reserved for another use at the
day and hour required in the application.
   D.   Denial Of Permit: Within three (3) days after receipt of an
application, the city shall notify an applicant in writing of the reasons for
denying a permit. The denial of a permit may be appealed in writing within
three (3) days to the city manager, who shall consider the application under
the standards set forth in subsection C of this section, and sustain or
overrule the city’s decision within three (3) days. The decision of the city
manager shall be final.
   E.   Exhibit Permit: Upon request of any person authorized by the city, a
person shall produce and exhibit any city permit he or she claims to have.
Failure to produce such permit upon request may result in the person’s removal
from the park and the forfeiture of any reserved space.
   F.   Responsibility Of Permittee:
      1.   A permittee shall be bound by all park rules and regulations and all
applicable city ordinances.
      2.   The person to whom a permit is issued shall be liable for any loss,
damage or injury sustained by any person by reason of the negligence of the
person to whom such permit shall have been issued. Such person shall also be
liable for damage to any park property and the removal of all garbage.
   G.   Revocation Of Permit: The city, including the police department, shall
have the authority to revoke a permit upon a finding of violation of any rule
or ordinance or upon good cause shown.
   H.   Interference With Permittees Prohibited: No person shall disturb or
interfere unreasonably with any person or party occupying any area or
participating in any activity under the authority of a permit.
7-3-13: PARK OPERATING POLICY:
   A.   Except for unusual and unforeseen emergencies, parks shall be open to
the public on designated days. The days open and the hours of operation for
each individual park shall be posted at the park’s entrance and on the city’s
website.
   B.   Any section or part of any park may be declared closed to the public by
the city at any time and for any interval of time, either temporarily or at
regular and stated intervals (daily or otherwise), and either entirely or
merely to certain uses, as the city finds reasonably necessary.
   C.   The finding of lost articles by the city shall be reported to the city
manager or police department who shall make every reasonable effort to locate
the owners. The city shall make a reasonable effort to find articles reported
as lost. Found articles will be maintained and available to be claimed at the
city hall for thirty (30) days after they have been turned in.
7-3-14: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   The city employees, and the city police department and county sheriff’s
department shall, in connection with their duties imposed by law, diligently
enforce the provisions of this chapter.
   B.   The city employees, city police officers and county sheriff’s deputies
shall have the authority to eject any person from the park acting in violation
of this chapter.
   C.   Any city police officer or other authorized city employee shall have
the authority to seize and confiscate any property in the park, or used in
violation of this chapter.
(1989 Code § 9-59)
7-3-15: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day such violation is committed or
permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be
punishable as such under this section.
(1989 Code § 9-58)
CHAPTER 4: CITY CEMETERIES
Section
7-4-1: Names Of Cemeteries; Interpretation
7-4-2: Maps And Plats Of Cemeteries
7-4-3: Funds
7-4-4: Purchase Of Cemetery Lots
7-4-5: Conveyance Of Lots
7-4-6: Reserved Lots
7-4-7: Care Of Lots
7-4-8: Interments
7-4-9: Disinterments And Reinterments
7-4-10: Mausoleums, Monuments, Headstones And Markers
7-4-10-1: Installation Requirements
7-4-11: General Rules
7-4-12: Disposition Of Proceeds
7-4-13: Penalty
7-4-1: NAMES OF CEMETERIES; INTERPRETATION:
The rules and regulations contained and prescribed in this chapter shall govern
and control the operation, management and use of the Oakland Cemetery and the
Elm Lawn Cemetery which are owned by the city. Wherever the term “cemeteries”
or “any cemetery” is used in this chapter, it means the Oakland Cemetery and
the Elm Lawn Cemetery.
7-4-2: MAPS AND PLATS OF CEMETERIES:
The cemeteries shall be kept sufficiently enclosed, and shall be laid out in
blocks and lots and streets, lanes, alleys and walks, under the direction of
and in a manner to be approved by the cemetery manager, and maps or plats with
the full minutes of the surveys shall be kept in the offices of the cemeteries,
such blocks and lots to be numbered.
7-4-3: FUNDS:
   A.   Perpetual Care Fund:
      1.   Funds To City Clerk: It shall be the duty of the cemetery manager to
pay all monies collected and belonging to the cemeteries fund to the director
of finance, and to take the director’s receipt for the same. The manager shall
make a report to the city council whenever required to do so by the council.
7-4-4: PURCHASE OF CEMETERY LOTS:
   A.   Sale Price:
      1.   All lots in the cemeteries shall be sold at private sale by the
cemetery manager. Lots shall be sold at the prices provided in the city fee
schedule which may be amended from time to time by the city council.
      2.   Money from the sale of lots shall be placed in the city’s general
fund.
   B.   Payment Procedure: In the selling of the lots in the cemeteries, the
manager shall require the purchaser to pay the appraised value thereof in cash
at the time of the purchase, unless the purchaser shall give to the manager his
or her note for the amount of such purchase price, payable to the city, due on
or before six (6) months from the date thereof, with interest from that date at
seven percent (7%) per year. Such note shall be secured satisfactorily to the
manager. No lot in the cemeteries shall be considered sold until all the
purchase money thereof shall have been actually paid to the manager of the
cemeteries. If any corpse or the remains of a human body shall be interred upon
any lot in the cemeteries before all the purchase money for such lot shall have
been or shall be actually paid to the manager, then the manager shall, at the
expiration of six (6) months from the time such lot was purchased or bargained
for, disinter such corpse or remains and reinter such in the Potter’s Field as
specified in section
7-4-6 of this chapter. No foundation for a monument, marker or other structure
shall be placed on a lot until full payment is made.
   C.   Certificate Of Purchase:
      1.   Any person purchasing of any lot from the city shall be entitled to
a certificate of purchase signed by the mayor and attested by the clerk, under
the corporate seal of the city, and countersigned by the manager, which shall
vest the ownership of the lot to the purchaser, subject to the rules,
regulations, ordinances and government of the city council. It shall be the
duty of the city clerk to furnish the manager, whenever requested to do so,
with blank certificates, signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk,
under the corporate seal of the city, and when the manager shall sell and
receive the purchase price in full, he or she shall fill in such certificate of
purchase and countersign the same and record it before delivering it to the
purchaser. No certificate shall be valid unless thus signed, attested,
countersigned and recorded. It shall be the duty of the manager to keep a
record in which he or she shall record all such certificates of purchase of
lots.
      2.   Lots sold with perpetual care attached to the purchase price shall
contain, in addition to the above, the following words printed in the
certificate of purchase:
City of Princeton covenants and agrees to perpetually care for and keep up said
space, by keeping the grass thereon mowed, and shrubbery planted thereon
properly cared for, and the graves thereon properly filled or sodded and level
with the surface of the ground, and any other improvements placed thereon by
the city in proper repair, at the expense of the city.
7-4-5: CONVEYANCE OF LOTS:
   A.   All subsequent conveyances from one person to another of any lot or
part of a lot may be made in a form, and attested by the city clerk, under the
corporate seal of the city and countersigned by the manager.
   B.   On the margin of the conveyance shall be written or printed:
This instrument must be countersigned and recorded by the cemetery manager
within thirty (30) days from its date, and on the failure of the purchaser to
have it so countersigned and recorded, said certificate or instrument shall
become void.
7-4-6: RESERVED LOTS:
   A.   Grave spaces in block no. 11-1/2 (commonly referred to as Potter’s
Field) in the Oakland Cemetery shall be forever held exempt from sale and shall
be reserved for the burial of the poor and transient persons whose deaths shall
occur within the limits of the city.
   B.   Lot nos. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 in block no. 48 in the Oakland Cemetery
shall be forever held exempt from sale and shall be reserved for the burial of
soldiers who have served in the army of the United States or in the army, navy
or militia of the state and shall be known as the “soldiers and sailors lot”.
7-4-7: CARE OF LOTS:
All lots in the cemeteries not cared for by the city shall be, by the owner or
owners thereof, kept in as good condition at all times as are the lots cared
for by the city. Any lot not so kept by the owner or owners shall be cared for
by the city, and for so caring for the same, there shall be assessed against
such lot each year a sum of money specified by the manager. The care given to
such lot by the city shall consist of mowing or burning fallen leaves each
spring and fall, filling and seeding of sunken graves, and any and all other
work that may be deemed necessary to keep the lots in as good condition as the
lots receiving perpetual or annual care. Each lot so cared for (except for
filling and seeding graves) shall be assessed at a rate per one hundred (100)
square feet of surface area thereof per year and, in addition thereto, a charge
for filling and seeding each sunken grave. Hereafter, no grave shall be dug on
any lot, and no foundation constructed for monuments or markers, until all
assessments against such lot are fully paid.
7-4-8: INTERMENTS:
   A.   Charges: The charges for burials in both Oakland Cemetery and Elm Lawn
Cemetery shall be as follows. There shall be no burials on holidays.
 
Weekday adult per full-grave burial $575.00
Weekday infant or any cremation     $175.00
Weekend adult per full-grave burial $1,000.00
Weekend infant pr any cremation     $500.00
 
Overtime hourly labor rates of time and one-half shall be additionally charged
to any burial requests received after eleven o’clock (11:00) a.m. on a Friday
for a burial scheduled on the following Monday.
   B.   Digging Graves:
      1.   All graves shall be dug by persons employed by the city, and it
shall be the duty of the manager to dig and prepare or cause to be dug and
prepared, any grave upon the order of any lot owner, upon the payment by such
lot owner in advance to the city of the amount provided in the city cemetery
fee schedule. Whenever the weather is such that the manager and employees are
unable to prepare a grave, or when the ground is in a condition that a grave
cannot be prepared, the body may be placed in the vault until such time as the
condition will permit a grave to be prepared. The manager and other employees
shall wait for necessarily delayed funerals, provided notice is given.
Otherwise, it shall be assumed that the plans have changed, and the manager and
employees will be dismissed at the usual time. When instructions for opening a
grave are indefinite or for any reason the grave cannot be prepared in the
location specified, the manager will order the grave prepared in the location
that seems best under the circumstances. Such action is necessary to avoid the
delaying of funerals.
      2.   The manager shall refuse to permit the burial or other disposal of a
dead human body, or part thereof, in the cemeteries, unless the funeral
director, or other persons present with the body, or part thereof, shall secure
a legal burial permit issued by the local registrar of the district in which
the death occurred. The manager shall not honor a burial permit unless it is
issued by an Illinois local registrar. If the death occurred outside of
Illinois, the funeral director shall obtain a permit from the local registrar
of the district.
   C.   Cremations:
      1.   Urns shall be limited to a maximum size of twenty four inches (24")
long by twenty inches (20") wide if buried in a cremation space. Urns may be
larger if for a sole burial on a lot.
      2.   The number of cremation burials per lot is limited to two (2)
burials except in the case of a grave space already containing a full size
vault, in which case, no further burials shall be allowed in that space.
   D.   Times For Services: Funeral services shall be set no later than three
o’clock (3:00) p.m. from the funeral home or place of worship, so that ample
time is allowed for the cemetery to complete its work before five o’clock (5:
00) p.m. or darkness, whichever is earlier, unless prior approval of the
cemetery manager has been obtained. The cemetery must have an eight (8) hour
working notice for each funeral to be held.
   E.   Record Of Burials: The cemetery manager shall keep a record wherein he
or she shall enter the name, place of death (city/state), the year, month and
day of death and burial, and the age at death. Such record shall also show the
cemetery, lot and block number where such persons is buried.
(Ord. O-22-001, 1-17-2022)
7-4-9: DISINTERMENTS AND REINTERMENTS:
   A.   No disinterments shall be permitted in the cemeteries without the
necessary permits and the consent of the manager, and under no conditions shall
a disinterment be made by anyone other than cemetery employees or as required
under law.
   B.   Reinterment of a human body shall be accompanied by the necessary
permit and shall be made by cemetery employees and under the direction of the
manager.
   C.   The interment of more than one body in any one lot shall be prohibited
except side by side.
   D.   No interment other than that of a human body or part thereof shall be
permitted in the cemeteries.
7-4-10: MAUSOLEUMS, MONUMENTS, HEADSTONES AND MARKERS:
7-4-10-1: INSTALLATION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Definition: A “monument” shall be defined, for the purposes of this
section, as any memorial structure, other than a marker, erected on a lot,
except a vault or mausoleum.
   B.   Foundations:
      1.   All mausoleums, monuments, headstones and markers erected or placed
in the cemeteries shall be placed upon a solid concrete foundation. All
concrete foundations shall be constructed by the manager and his or her
employees and made to comply with the requirements of this section, or shall be
constructed as directed by the manager by the persons desiring to place the
same upon such lots.
      2.   a.   All foundations for mausoleums and monuments hereafter
constructed shall be not less than five feet (5') in depth at both the top and
the bottom, and for headstones and markers, shall be not less than three feet
(3') in depth, wherever possible. The dimensions of all foundations shall be
four inches (4") greater in length and breadth than the stone or base to be
placed thereon, and shall be finished off level with the surface of the ground
on both sides and the ends.
         b.   Length; Width; Ground Level: All foundations shall be eight
inches (8") greater in length and width than the stone to be set thereon, and
this margin shall be carried to the full depth of the foundation. The
foundation shall be at ground level on both sides and ends.
      3.   The material to be used in the construction of foundations shall be
of concrete. Concrete shall be made of good clean gravel, or other material
equal in quality, and good cement, mixed in proportions of six (6) parts gravel
to not less than one part cement.
      4.   No foundation shall be constructed on any lot until the lot is fully
paid for.
   C.   Dimensions:
      1.   Monuments:
         a.   The minimum requirements for die (the primary body portion of a
monument) and base (the lower part of a multi-sectioned monument) of a monument
to be erected in the cemeteries shall be as follows:
 
Die:  36" x 8" x 24"
Base: 48" x 14" x 8"
 
         b.   No monument shall be higher than six feet six inches (6'6") nor
longer than six feet six inches (6'6"). Exceptions in certain localities are
possible but shall be determined after first checking with the manager.
      2.   Markers, Etc.: No marker shall be higher than twelve inches (12"),
shall not exceed thirty inches (30") in length and shall not be over fifteen
inches (15"). All other stones or structures greater in dimensions than the
above will be construed as monuments.
   D.   Charge For Setting Monuments. The charge for setting monuments in the
cemeteries is as provided in the city fee schedule as established by the city
council. Such charge shall be payable by the monument dealer at the time the
monument is delivered to be set.
   E.   Number Of Monuments Per Lot: No more than one monument shall be allowed
on any lot.
   F.   Location of Monuments: All monuments shall be placed as near to the
center of the lot as possible, unless permission is given by the manager to
place them otherwise. No monuments shall be allowed on lots or blocks where
single graves are sold.
   G.   Location of Markers: All markers must be placed at the end of the grave
which is the greatest distance from the center of the lot, unless permission by
the cemetery manager is given to place the markers in a different position.
   H.   Construction of Foundation: No foundation shall be constructed:
      1.   Until the manager has given his or her approval of the stone to be
placed thereon;
      2.   Without first giving notice to the manager as to the time the work
shall be done; and
      3.   Except during the cemetery working hours so that inspection may be
made as the work is being done. Certain exceptions may be arranged after
consultation with the manager.
   I.   Dimensions Of Markers: No marker shall be over thirty inches (30") in
length, twelve inches (12") in width, nor eight inches (8") in height. The
pitch shall not be over two inches (2"). Duplications shall be excepted. The
markers to be erected where single graves are sold shall not be over twenty
four inches (24") in length, twelve inches (12") in width, and eight inches
(8") at the highest point. The pitch shall not be over two inches (2").
   J.   Debts To Cemeteries: No foundation shall be constructed on any lot, or
at any single grave, if there is any amount of money due the cemetery. Dealers
shall first check at the office of the manager before starting work.
   K.   Corner Posts: No corner posts of any kind shall be allowed.
   L.   Preneed Stones: No preneed stones shall be set unless permission is
first obtained from the manager.
   M.   Hickey Markers: No hickey markers shall be less than six inches (6") in
height or over eight inches (8") in height. Government markers and their
duplications are excepted.
   N.   Width For Die: All monuments shall have a minimum of eight inches (8")
of width for the die.
   O.   Slants: There shall be no slants on the bases.
   P.   Marble: There shall be no marble allowed, except in duplications.
   Q.   Duplicates: There shall be no duplicating of design of a monument,
except when placed at alternating block intervals.
   R.   Removal Of Stones: The manager shall be notified when any stone is to
be removed and taken away.
   S.   Work During Funerals: All work by the city shall cease when a funeral
in progress is within sight or hearing of such work.
   T.   Temporary Memorials: No temporary memorial, i.e., cement, artificial
stone, wood, tin, iron, or composition, shall be allowed.
   U.   Lines: Lines shall be used at all times when setting stones.
   V.   Removal Of Foreign Material And Forms: All foreign material shall be
removed from and around the lot when the work is completed; and later, when the
forms are removed, the dirt shall be filled in around the foundations of all
markers.
   W.   Dirt Leveled: All dirt shall be leveled after dumping so that the
mowers may pass over the graves.
   X.   Trucks; Planking: No trucks shall be allowed on the lots, and planking
shall be used at all times when unloading monuments.
   Y.   Face Of Markers: All markers shall face the nearest roadway.
   Z.   Shrubs: No shrubs shall be removed or planted without first obtaining
permission from the manager.
   AA.   Minimum Size Of Markers: No marker shall be smaller than sixteen
inches (16") in length nor eight inches (8") in width.
   BB.   Blank Markers: No blank markers shall be erected in the cemeteries at
any time.
   CC.   Die Polished Or Waxed: Both sides of the die shall be polished or
waxed.
   DD.   Double Markers: The maximum size for double markers shall be thirty
six inches by twelve inches by eight inches (36"x12"x8"). This size marker
shall be allowed to mark double lots (two (2) grave spaces) only. It shall be
placed at the center of the two (2) spaces.
   EE.   Cremation Markers: All cremation markers shall be at ground level and
shall be made of bronze or granite. The maximum size for a double marker shall
be thirty six inches by twelve inches (36"x12"), and it shall be centered
between the two (2) spaces. The maximum size for a single marker shall be
twenty four inches by twelve inches (24"x12").
   FF.   Markers In Potter’s Field: No markers shall be placed on any graves
located in Potter’s Field until such time as an amount equal to forty three
percent (43%) of the cost of a single grave space has been paid to the cemetery
for the perpetual care required by the placement of said monument.
   GG.   Compliance With Provisions: The cemetery manager is hereby directed to
refuse permission to erect any monuments, markers or headstones which do not
comply with this section.
7-4-11: GENERAL RULES:
The following rules shall be observed by owners of lots and other visitors in
the cemeteries:
   A.   Right Of Access; Exceptions:
      1.   Lot owners and other visitors shall have access to the cemeteries
with vehicles, subject to this chapter. Such access shall be between sunrise
and sunset unless otherwise determined by the manager to be necessary and in
accordance with this chapter.
      2.   The manager is authorized to keep the gates locked to all except
funeral processions when the roads are in a soft, unstable condition, or at
other times when deemed necessary by the manager.
   B.   Vehicle Use:
      1.   Licensed Vehicles Only: Motor vehicles shall be admitted to the
cemeteries only if licensed under the Illinois vehicle code.
      2.   Speed Limit: No vehicles admitted to the cemeteries shall be ridden
or driven faster than ten (10) miles per hour.
      3.   Right Of Way: All vehicles and machinery used in the cemeteries
under the direction of the manager shall have the right of way at all times.
      4.   Drive On Roadways Only: No vehicle shall be driven anywhere except
on the streets or avenues of the cemeteries. Vehicles used in the maintenance
of the cemeteries or allowed by the manager are exempt from this restriction.
      5.   Driveway Restrictions:
         a.   No vehicle shall be turned around in any driveway.
         b.   Vehicles shall not be stopped so as to block any driveway, except
for a funeral procession and vehicles used in any cemetery under the direction
of the manager.
         c.   Authorized vehicles stopped in any driveway shall be removed when
requested to do so by the manager or other city employees or tools of any kind,
or sell or give away soil, sod or other material.
   C.   Supervision Of Funerals: On entering and while within the any cemetery,
funeral processions and services shall be entirely under the direction of the
manager and his or her assistants and must be conducted accordingly.
   D.   Use Of Cemetery Property: Cemetery employees shall not loan city
property of any kind, including tools and other equipment, or sell or give away
soil, sod or other material. Should the cemeteries have excess soil, sod or
other natural material, the cemetery manager may request permission of the city
council to sell, give away or dispose of how the city council sees fit.
   E.   Lots:
      1.   Filling Or Grading: No lot shall be filled or graded above the
natural level without permission from the manager.
      2.   Enclosures Or Posts:
         a.   It shall be unlawful for any person to enclose any lot or lots in
the cemeteries with fence, curbing, wire, rods, trees, shrubbery or any other
material.
         b.   Corner posts shall be permitted on certain lots, but hereafter,
no corner posts shall be set so that the top is above the surface of the
ground. The top of the corner post is to be flat.
   F.   Planting, Trimming, Cutting Vegetation:
      1.   Permission shall be obtained from the manager before planting any
shrubs or trees. No shrubs or trees shall be removed or cut down without
permission.
      2.   No person shall trim, prune or remove any branches from any tree in
any cemetery. On request, the manager shall do any pruning which is deemed
necessary.
      3.   No planting of flowers nor the placing of plants which are planted
or established in pots shall be permitted in the park block except as directed
by the manager.
   G.   Damage To Property:
      1.   No person shall go upon any lot, avenue, street, lane or alley or
public ground within any cemetery to disturb, dig up, remove or carry away any
turf, earth, tree, shrub or plant, or any other material without permission
from the manager.
      2.   Picking of flowers, wild or cultivated, breaking or injuring any
tree or shrub, or injuring any monument, marker, ornament, or other structure
or property within the cemeteries, either on the lots or on the public ground,
is prohibited.
   H.   Deposit Of Rubbish: No person shall deposit or leave on any land,
street, walk or driveway any grass, hay, earth or rubbish of any kind. Rubbish
boxes are placed throughout the cemeteries, and all rubbish shall be placed
within these boxes, unless a person is permitted to do otherwise by the
manager.
   I.   Animals. No person shall be allowed to bring any animal into any
cemetery or permit his or her animal to enter any cemetery.
   J.   Firearms:
      1.   Firearms are prohibited in all cemeteries, except by military
personnel for military funerals, unless allowed by the manager.
      2.   No discharging of firearms within the cemeteries, except at military
funerals by military personnel, shall be allowed.
   K.   Authority Of Cemetery Personnel:
      1.   Removal Of Certain Items:
         a.   If anything shall be placed on a lot or grave which shall be
deemed offensive, improper, or injurious to the lot or other lots, or which
violates any of the rules, the manager shall remove the same without notice.
         b.   Funeral designs, floral pieces, etc., shall be removed as soon as
they become unsightly. The manager and employees shall decline to attempt to
find the same after the removal thereof.
(1989 Code § 5-7)
      2.   Removal Of Vegetation: If any tree, shrub, plant or vine situated on
any lot becomes unsightly, dangerous or detrimental to the adjacent lot,
streets, or alleys or inconvenient to passersby, the manager may remove such
tree, plant or vine, or such parts thereof, as he or she deems necessary, or if
any lot or structure thereon becomes unsightly or dangerous, the manager may
put the same in proper order at the cost of the lot owners, which shall be
collected in the same manner as fines for the violations of these provisions or
rules are recovered and enforced. In case the lot owners cannot be located or
found and collection enforced, the manager shall remove any structure that is
unsightly or dangerous.
   L.   Nonliability Of City:
      1.   The city council shall take reasonable precaution to protect all
private property of lot owners, properly in the cemeteries, from loss or
damage, but it distinctly disclaims all responsibility for loss or damage from
causes beyond its reasonable control, and especially from the acts of thieves,
vandals, rioters and malicious mischief makers and from all acts of providence
including winds, tornadoes, cyclones, hail, snow or frost, whether the damage
is direct or collateral.
      2.   The city shall use care in examining trees on the public ground and
removing these apparently in unsound and dangerous condition or unsound and
dangerous limbs and branches, but it expressly disclaims all responsibility for
damage either to person or property resulting from falling trees or parts of
trees.
      3.   The city may take such action as may be necessary, though not
expressly authorized by the rules, to protect the property of lot owners or of
the cemeteries from injury, to preserve peace and good order, or to prevent
injury to the appearance of the lots and graves, grounds and buildings.
(1989 Code § 5-7)
   M.   Soliciting: No soliciting shall be allowed in the cemeteries.
7-4-12: DISPOSITION OF PROCEEDS:
The proceeds from the sale of lots and other monies which may be collected for
work done from the sale of material or property shall be exclusively used for
the upkeep and improvement of the cemeteries and in preserving the public and
private properties therein, building and repairing enclosures, offices and
other buildings, purchasing tools and other supplies and material, and the
payment of salaries and wages as may be necessary to keep the cemeteries in a
good condition.
(1989 Code § 5-6)
7-4-13: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined as
provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this code, and all such fines recovered for
violations of this chapter shall be paid into and become a part of the general
fund.
(1989 Code § 5-1)
CHAPTER 5: SMALL WIRELESS FACILITIES
Section
7-5-1: Purpose And Scope
7-5-2: Definitions
7-5-3: Regulations Of Small Wireless Facilities
7-5-4: Dispute Resolution
7-5-5: Indemnification
7-5-6: Insurance
7-5-1: PURPOSE AND SCOPE:
   A.   Purpose: The purpose of this chapter is to establish regulations,
standards and procedures for the siting and collocation of small wireless
facilities on rights-of-way within the city’s jurisdiction, or outside the
rights-of-way on property zoned by the city exclusively for commercial or
industrial use, in a manner that is consistent with the small wireless
facilities deployment act (Public Act 1000585).
   B.   Conflicts With Other Ordinances: This chapter supersedes all ordinances
or parts of ordinances adopted prior hereto that are in conflict herewith, to
the extent of such conflict.
   C.   Conflicts With State and Federal Laws: In the event that applicable
federal or state laws or regulations conflict with the requirements of this
chapter, the wireless provider shall comply with the requirements of this
chapter to the maximum extent possible without violating federal or state laws
or regulations.
(Ord. O-18-021, 7-16-2018)
7-5-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the following
meanings:
ANTENNA: Communications equipment that transmits or receives electromagnetic
radio frequency signals used in the provision of wireless services.
APPLICABLE CODES: Uniform building, fire, electrical, plumbing, or mechanical
codes adopted by a recognized national code organization or local amendments to
those codes, including the national electric safety code.
APPLICANT: Any person who submits an application and is a wireless provider.
APPLICATION: A request submitted by an applicant to the city for a permit to
collocate small wireless facilities, and a request that includes the
installation of a new utility pole for such collocation, as well as any
applicable fee for the review of such application.
COLLOCATE OR COLLOCATION: To install, mount, maintain, modify, operate or
replace wireless facilities on or adjacent to a wireless support structure or
utility pole.
COMMUNICATIONS SERVICE: Cable service, as defined in 47 U.S.C. 522(6), as
amended; information service, as defined in 47 U.S.C. 153(24), as amended;
telecommunications service, as defined in 47 U.S.C. 153(53), as amended; mobile
service, as defined in 47 U.S.C. 153(53), as amended; or wireless service other
than mobile service.
COMMUNICATIONS SERVICE PROVIDER: A cable operator, as defined in 47 U.S.C. 522
(5), as amended; a provider of information service, as defined in 47 U.S.C. 153
(24), as amended; a telecommunications carrier, as defined in 47 U.S.C. 153
(51), as amended; or a wireless provider.
FCC: The federal communications commission of the United States.
FEE: A one-time charge.
HISTORIC DISTRICT OR HISTORIC LANDMARK: A building, property or site, or group
of buildings, properties or sites that are either:
   A.   Listed in the national register of historic places or formally
determined eligible for listing by the keeper of the national register, the
individual who has been delegated the authority by the federal agency to list
properties and determine their eligibility for the national register, in
accordance with Section VI.D.1.a.i through Section VI.D.1.a.v of the nationwide
programmatic agreement codified at 47 C.F.R. part 1, appendix C; or
   B.   Designated as a locally landmarked building, property, site, or
historic district by an ordinance adopted by the city pursuant to a
preservation program that meets the requirements of the certified local
government program of the Illinois state historic preservation office or where
such certification of the preservation program by the Illinois state historic
preservation office is pending.
LAW: A federal or state statute, common law, code, rule, regulation, order, or
local ordinance or resolution.
MICRO WIRELESS FACILITY: A small wireless facility that is not larger in
dimension than twenty four inches (24") in length, fifteen inches (15") in
width, and twelve inches (12") in height and that has an exterior antenna, if
any, no longer than eleven inches (11").
MUNICIPAL UTILITY POLE: A utility pole owned or operated by the city in public
rights-of-way.
PERMIT: A written authorization required by the city to perform an action or
initiate, continue, or complete a project.
PERSON: An individual, corporation, limited liability company, partnership,
association, trust, or other entity or organization.
PUBLIC SAFETY AGENCY: The functional division of the federal government, the
state, a unit of local government, or a special purpose district located in
whole or in part within this state, that provides or has authority to provide
firefighting, police, ambulance, medical or other emergency services to respond
to and manage emergency incidents.
RATE: A recurring charge.
RIGHT-OF-WAY: The area on, below, or above a public roadway, highway, street,
public sidewalk, alley, or utility easement dedicated for compatible use.
Right-of-way does not include city-owned aerial lines.
SMALL WIRELESS FACILITY: A wireless facility that meets both of the following
qualifications:
   A.   Each antenna is located inside an enclosure of no more than six (6)
cubic feet in volume or, in the case of an antenna that has exposed elements,
the antenna and all of its exposed elements could fit within an imaginary
enclosure of no more than six (6) cubic feet; and
   B.   All other wireless equipment attached directly to a utility pole
associated with the facility is cumulatively no more than twenty-five (25)
cubic feet in volume. The following types of associated ancillary equipment are
not included in the calculation of equipment volume: electric meter,
concealment elements, telecommunications demarcation box, ground-based
enclosures, grounding equipment, power transfer switch, cut-off switch and
vertical cable runs for the connection of power and other services.
UTILITY POLE: A pole or similar structure that is used in whole or in part by a
communications service provider or for electric distribution, lighting, traffic
control or a similar function.
WIRELESS FACILITY:
   A.   Equipment at a fixed location that enables wireless communications
between user equipment and a communications network, including:
      1.   Equipment associated with wireless communications; and
      2.   Radio transceivers, antennas, coaxial or fiber-optic cable, regular
and backup power supplies, and comparable equipment, regardless of
technological configuration. Wireless facility includes small wireless
facilities.
   B.   Wireless facility does not include:
      1.   The structure or improvements on, under, or within which the
equipment is collocated; or
      2.   Wireline backhaul facilities, coaxial or fiber optic cable that is
between wireless support structures or utility poles or coaxial, or fiber optic
cable that is otherwise not immediately adjacent to or directly associated with
an antenna.
WIRELESS INFRASTRUCTURE PROVIDER: Any person authorized to provide
telecommunications service in the state that builds or installs wireless
communication transmission equipment, wireless facilities, wireless support
structures, or utility poles and that is not a wireless services provider but
is acting as an agent or a contractor for a wireless services provider for the
application submitted to the city.
WIRELESS PROVIDER: A wireless infrastructure provider or a wireless services
provider.
WIRELESS SERVICES: Any services provided to the general public, including a
particular class of customers, and made available on a nondiscriminatory basis
using licensed or unlicensed spectrum, whether at a fixed location or mobile,
provided using wireless facilities.
WIRELESS SERVICES PROVIDER: A person who provides wireless services.
WIRELESS SUPPORT STRUCTURE: A freestanding structure, such as a monopole;
tower, either guyed or self-supporting; billboard; or other existing or
proposed structure designed to support or capable of supporting wireless
facilities. Wireless support structure does not include a utility pole.
(Ord. O-18-021, 7-16-2018)
7-5-3: REGULATIONS OF SMALL WIRELESS FACILITIES:
   A.   Permitted Use: Small wireless facilities shall be classified as
permitted uses and subject to administrative review, except as provided in
subsection C9 of this section regarding height exceptions or variances, but not
subject to zoning review or approval if they are collocated:
      1.   In rights-of-way in any zoning district; or
      2.   Outside rights-of-way in property zoned exclusively for commercial
or industrial use.
   B.   Permit Required: An applicant shall obtain one or more permits from the
city to collocate a small wireless facility. An application shall be received
and processed, and permits issued shall be subject to the following conditions
and requirements:
      1.   Application Requirements: A wireless provider shall provide the
following information to the city, together with the city’s small cell
facilities permit application, as a condition of any permit application to
collocate small wireless facilities on a utility pole or wireless support
structure:
         a.   Site specific structural integrity and, for a municipal utility
pole, make-ready analysis prepared by a structural engineer, as that term is
defined in Section 4 of the structural engineering practice act of 1989;
         b.   The location where each proposed small wireless facility or
utility pole would be installed and photographs of the location and its
immediate surroundings depicting the utility poles or structures on which each
proposed small wireless facility would be mounted or location where utility
poles or structures would be installed. This should include a depiction of the
completed facility;
         c.   Specifications and drawings prepared by a structural engineer, as
that term is defined in section 4 of the structural engineering practice act of
1989, for each proposed small wireless facility covered by the application as
it is proposed to be installed;
         d.   The equipment type and model numbers for the antennas and all
other wireless equipment associated with the small wireless facility;
         e.   A proposed schedule for the installation and completion of each
small wireless facility covered by the application, if approved; and
         f.   Certification that the collocation complies with the collocation
requirements and conditions contained herein, to the best of the applicant’s
knowledge.
         g.   In the event that the proposed small wireless facility is to be
attached to an existing pole owned by an entity other than the city, the
wireless provider shall provide legally competent evidence of the consent of
the owner of such pole to the proposed collocation.
      2.   Application Process: The city shall process applications as follows:
         a.   The first completed application shall have priority over
applications received by different applicants for collocation on the same
utility pole or wireless support structure.
         b.   (1)   An application to collocate a small wireless facility on an
existing utility pole or wireless support structure, or replacement of an
existing utility pole or wireless support structure shall be processed on a
nondiscriminatory basis and shall be deemed approved if the city fails to
approve or deny the application within ninety (90) days after the submission of
a completed application.
            (2)   However, if an applicant intends to proceed with the
permitted activity on a deemed approved basis, the applicant shall notify the
city in writing of its intention to invoke the deemed approved remedy no sooner
than seventy five (75) days after the submission of a completed application.
            (3)   The permit shall be deemed approved on the latter of the
ninetieth day after submission of the complete application or the tenth day
after the receipt of the deemed approved notice by the city. The receipt of the
deemed approved notice shall not preclude the city’s denial of the permit
request within the time limits as provided under this chapter.
         c.   (1)   An application to collocate a small wireless facility that
includes the installation of a new utility pole shall be processed on a
nondiscriminatory basis and deemed approved if the city fails to approve or
deny the application within one hundred twenty (120) days after the submission
of a completed application.
            (2)   However, if an applicant intends to proceed with the
permitted activity on a deemed approved basis, the applicant shall notify the
city in writing of its intention to invoke the deemed approved remedy no sooner
than one hundred five (105) days after the submission of a completed
application.
            (3)   The permit shall be deemed approved on the latter of the one
hundred twentieth day after submission of the complete application or the tenth
day after the receipt of the deemed approved notice by the city. The receipt of
the deemed approved notice shall not preclude the city’s denial of the permit
request within the time limits as provided under this chapter.
         d.   (1)   The city shall deny an application which does not meet the
requirements of this chapter.
            (2)   If the city determines that applicable codes, ordinances or
regulations that concern public safety, or the collocation requirements and
conditions contained herein require that the utility pole or wireless support
structure be replaced before the requested collocation, approval shall be
conditioned on the replacement of the utility pole or wireless support
structure at the cost of the provider.
            (3)   The city shall document the basis for a denial, including the
specific code provisions or application conditions on which the denial is
based, and send the documentation to the applicant on or before the day the
city denies an application.
            (4)   The applicant may cure the deficiencies identified by the
city and resubmit the revised application once within thirty (30) days after
notice of denial is sent to the applicant without paying an additional
application fee. The city shall approve or deny the revised application within
thirty (30) days after the applicant resubmits the application or it is deemed
approved. Failure to resubmit the revised application within thirty (30) days
of denial shall require the application to submit a new application with
applicable fees, and recommencement of the city’s review period.
            (5)   The applicant must notify the city in writing of its
intention to proceed with the permitted activity on a deemed approved basis,
which may be submitted with the revised application.
            (6)   Any review of a revised application shall be limited to the
deficiencies cited in the denial. However, this revised application does not
apply if the cure requires the review of a new location, new or different
structure to be collocated upon, new antennas, or other wireless equipment
associated with the small wireless facility.
         e.   Pole Attachment Agreement: Within thirty (30) days after an
approved permit to collocate a small wireless facility on a municipal utility
pole, the city and the applicant shall enter into a master pole attachment
agreement, provided by the city for the initial collocation on a municipal
utility pole by the application. For subsequent approved permits to collocate
on a small wireless facility on a municipal utility pole, the city and the
applicant shall enter into a license supplement of the master pole attachment
agreement.
      3.   a.   Completeness of Application: Within thirty (30) days after
receiving an application, the city shall determine whether the application is
complete and notify the applicant. If an application is incomplete, the city
must specifically identify the missing information. An application shall be
deemed complete if the city fails to provide notification to the applicant
within thirty (30) days after all documents, information and fees specifically
enumerated in the city’s permit application form are submitted by the applicant
to the city.
         b.   Processing deadlines are tolled from the time the city sends the
notice of incompleteness to the time the applicant provides the missing
information.
      4.   Tolling: The time period for applications may be further tolled by:
         a.   An express written agreement by both the applicant and the city;
or
         b.   A local, state or federal disaster declaration or similar
emergency that causes the delay.
      5.   Consolidated Applications:
         a.   An applicant seeking to collocate small wireless facilities
within the jurisdiction of the city shall be allowed, at the applicant’s
discretion, to file a consolidated application and receive a single permit for
the collocation of up to twenty five (25) small wireless facilities if the
collocations each involve substantially the same type of small wireless
facility and substantially the same type of structure.
         b.   If an application includes multiple small wireless facilities,
the city may remove small wireless facility collocations from the application
and treat separately small wireless facility collocations for which incomplete
information has been provided or that do not qualify for consolidated treatment
or that are denied. The city may issue separate permits for each collocation
that is approved in a consolidated application.
      6.   Duration of Permits:
         a.   The duration of a permit shall be for a period of not less than
five (5) years, and the permit shall be renewed for equivalent durations unless
the city makes a finding that the small wireless facilities or the new or
modified utility pole do not comply with the applicable city codes or any
provision, condition or requirement contained in this chapter.
         b.   If the act is repealed as provided in Section 90 therein,
renewals of permits shall be subject to the applicable city code provisions or
regulations in effect at the time of renewal.
      7.   Means of Submitting Applications: Applicants shall submit
applications, supporting information and notices to the city by personal
delivery at the city’s designated place of business, by regular mail postmarked
on the date due or by any other commonly used means, including electronic mail.
   C.   Collocation Requirements and Conditions:
      1.   Public Safety Space Reservation: The city may reserve space on
municipal utility poles for future public safety uses, for the city’s electric
utility uses, or both, but a reservation of space may not preclude the
collocation of a small wireless facility unless the city reasonably determines
that the municipal utility pole cannot accommodate both uses.
      2.   Installation and Maintenance: The wireless provider shall install,
maintain, repair and modify its small wireless facilities in safe condition and
good repair and in compliance with the requirements and conditions of this
chapter. The wireless provider shall ensure that its employees, agents or
contracts that perform work in connection with its small wireless facilities
are adequately trained and skilled in accordance with all applicable industry
and governmental standards and regulations.
      3.   a.   No interference with public safety communication frequencies.
The wireless provider’s operation of the small wireless facilities shall not
interfere with the frequencies used by a public safety agency for public safety
communications.
         b.   A wireless provider shall install small wireless facilities of
the type and frequency that will not cause unacceptable interference with a
public safety agency’s communications equipment.
         c.   Unacceptable interference will be determined by and measured in
accordance with industry standards and the FCC’s regulations addressing
unacceptable interference to public safety spectrum or any other spectrum
licensed by a public safety agency.
         d.   If a small wireless facility causes such interference, and the
wireless provider has been given written notice of the interference by the
public safety agency, the wireless provider, at its own expense, shall remedy
the interference in a manner consistent with the abatement and resolution
procedures for interference with public safety spectrum established by the FCC
including 47 C.F.R. 22.970 through 47 C.F.R. 22.973 and 47 C.F.R. 90.672
through 47 C.F.R. 90.675.
         e.   The city may terminate a permit for a small wireless facility
based on such interference if the wireless provider is not in compliance with
the Code of Federal Regulations cited in subsection C3d. Failure to remedy the
interference as required herein shall constitute a public nuisance.
      4.   a.   The wireless provider shall not collocate small wireless
facilities on city utility poles that are part of an electric distribution or
transmission system within the communication worker safety zone of the pole or
the electric supply zone of the pole.
         b.   However, the antenna and support equipment of the small wireless
facility may be located in the communications space on the city utility pole,
but in no case on the top of the pole.
         c.   For purposes of this subsection, the terms “communications
space”, “communication worker safety zone”, and “electric supply zone” have the
meanings given to those terms in the national electric safety code as published
by the institute of electrical and electronics engineers.
      5.   The wireless provider shall comply with all applicable codes and
local code provisions or regulations that concern public safety.
      6.   The wireless provider shall comply with written design standards
that are generally applicable for decorative utility poles, or reasonable
stealth, concealment and aesthetic requirements that are set forth in a city
ordinance, written policy adopted by the city, a comprehensive plan or other
written design plan that applies to other occupiers of the rights-of-way,
including on a historic landmark or in a historic district.
      7.   Alternate Placements: Except as provided in this collocation
requirements and conditions section, a wireless provider shall not be required
to collocation small wireless facilities on any specific utility pole, or
category of utility poles, or be required to collocate multiple antenna systems
on a single utility pole. However, with respect to an application for the
collocation of a small wireless facility associated with a new utility pole,
the city may propose that the small wireless facility be collocated on an
existing utility pole or existing wireless support structure within one hundred
(100) feet of the proposed collocation, which the applicant shall accept if it
has the right to use the alternate structure on reasonable terms and
conditions, and the alternate location and structure does not impose technical
limits or additional material costs as determined by the applicant. If the
applicant refuses a collocation proposed by the city, the applicant shall
provide written certification describing the property rights, technical limits
or material cost reasons the alternate location does not satisfy the criteria
in this subsection.
      8.   Height Limitations:
         a.   The maximum height of a small wireless facility shall be below
the height of any primary transmission line; no more than ten (10) feet above
the utility pole or wireless support structure on which the small wireless
facility is collocated.
         b.   New or replacement utility poles or wireless support structures
on which small wireless facilities are collocated may not exceed the higher of:
            (1)   Ten feet (10') in height above the tallest existing utility
pole, other than a utility pole supporting only wireless facilities, that is in
place on the date the application is submitted to the city, that is located
within three hundred feet (300') of the new or replacement utility pole or
wireless support structure and that is in the same right of way within the
jurisdictional boundary of the city, provided the city may designate which
intersecting right of way within three hundred feet (300') of the proposed
utility pole or wireless support structures shall control the height limitation
for such facility; or
            (2)   Forty-five feet (45') above ground level.
      9.   Height Exceptions or Variances: If an applicant proposes a height
for a new or replacement pole in excess of the above height limitations on
which the small wireless facility is proposed for collocation, the applicant
shall apply for a variance petition with the Princeton plan commission, in
conformance with procedures, terms and conditions set forth in the land
development code.
      10.   Contractual Design Requirements: The wireless provider shall comply
with requirements that are imposed by a contract between the city and a private
property owner that concern design or construction standards applicable to
utility poles and ground-mounted equipment located in the right-of-way.
      11.   Ground-Mounted Equipment Spacing: The wireless provider shall
comply with applicable spacing requirements in applicable codes and ordinances
concerning the location of ground-mounted equipment located in the right-of-way
if the requirements include a waiver, zoning or other process that addresses
wireless provider requests for exception or variance and do not prohibit
granting of such exceptions or variances.
      12.   Undergrounding Regulations: The wireless provider shall comply with
local code provisions or regulations concerning undergrounding requirements
that prohibit the installation of new or the modification of existing utility
poles in a right-of-way without prior approval if the requirements include a
waiver, zoning or other process that addresses requests to install such new
utility poles or modify such existing utility poles and do not prohibit the
replacement of utility poles.
      13.   Collocation Completion Deadline. Collocation for which a permit is
granted shall be completed within one hundred eighty (180) days after issuance
of the permit, unless the city and the wireless provider agree to extend this
period or a delay is caused by make-ready work for a municipal utility pole or
by the lack of commercial power or backhaul availability at the site, provided
