the wireless provider has made a timely request within sixty (60) days after
the issuance of the permit for commercial power or backhaul services, and the
additional time to complete installation does not exceed three hundred sixty
(360) days after issuance of the permit. Otherwise, the permit shall be void
unless the city grants an extension in writing to the applicant.
   D.   Application Fees. Application fees are imposed as follows:
      1.   Applicant shall pay an application fee of six hundred fifty dollars
($650.00) for an application to collocate a single small wireless facility on
an existing utility pole or wireless support structure, and three hundred fifty
dollars ($350.00) for each small wireless facility addressed in a consolidated
application to collocate more than one small wireless facility on existing
utility poles or wireless support structures.
      2.   Applicant shall pay an application fee of one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) for each small wireless facility addressed in an application that
includes the installation of a new utility pole for such collocation.
      3.   Notwithstanding any contrary provision of state law or local
ordinance, applications pursuant to this section shall be accompanied by the
required application fee. Application fees shall be non-refundable.
      4.   The city shall not require an application, approval or permit, or
require any fees or other charges, from a communications service provider
authorized to occupy the rights of way, for:
         a.   Routine maintenance;
         b.   The replacement of wireless facilities with wireless facilities
that are substantially similar, the same size, or smaller if the wireless
provider notifies the city at least ten (10) days prior to the planned
replacement and includes equipment specifications for the replacement of
equipment consistent with subsection d. under subsection B1d (Application
Requirements); or
         c.   The installation, placement, maintenance, operation or
replacement of micro wireless facilities suspended on cables that are strung
between existing utility poles in compliance with applicable safety codes.
      5.   Wireless providers shall secure a permit from the city to work
within rights of way for activities that affect traffic patterns or require
lane closures.
   E.   Exceptions to Applicability: Nothing in this chapter authorizes a
person to collocate small wireless facilities on:
      1.   Property owned by a private party or property owned or controlled by
the city or another unit of local government that is not located within rights-
of-way, or a privately owned utility pole or wireless support structure without
the consent of the property owner;
      2.   Property owned, leased, or controlled by a park district, forest
preserve district or conservation district for public park, recreation or
conservation purposes without the consent of the affected district, excluding
the placement of facilities on rights-of-way located in an affected district
that are under the jurisdiction and control of a different unit of local
government as provided by the Illinois highway code; or
      3.   a.   Property owned by a rail carrier registered under section 18c-
7201 of the Illinois vehicle code, Metra commuter rail or any other public
commuter rail service, or an electric utility as defined in section 16-102 of
the public utilities act, without the consent of the rail carrier, public
commuter rail service, or electric utility. The provisions of this chapter do
not apply to an electric or gas public utility or such utility’s wireless
facilities if the facilities are being used, developed and maintained
consistent with the provisions of subsection (i) of Section 16-108.5 of the
public utilities act.
         b.   For the purposes of this subsection, “public utility” has the
meaning given to that term in Section 3-105 of the public utilities act.
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to relieve any person from any
requirement:
            (1)   To obtain a franchise or a state-issued authorization to
offer cable service or video service; or
            (2)   To obtain any required permission to install, place, maintain
or operate communications facilities, other than small wireless facilities
subject to this chapter.
   F.   Pre-Existing Agreements:
      1.   Existing agreements between the city and wireless providers that
relate to the collocation of small wireless facilities in the right-of-way,
including the collocation of small wireless facilities on city utility poles,
that are in effect on June 1, 2018, remain in effect for all small wireless
facilities collocated on the city’s utility poles pursuant to applications
submitted to the city before June 1, 2018, subject to applicable termination
provisions contained therein. Agreements entered into after June 1, 2018, shall
comply with this chapter.
      2.   A wireless provider that has an existing agreement with the city on
the effective date of the act may accept the rates, fees and terms that the
city makes available under this chapter for the collocation of small wireless
facilities or the installation of new utility poles for the collocation of
small wireless facilities that are the subject of an application submitted two
or more years after the effective date of the act by notifying the city that it
opts to accept such rates, fees and terms. The existing agreement remains in
effect, subject to applicable termination provisions, for the small wireless
facilities the wireless provider has collocated on the city’s utility poles
pursuant to applications submitted to the city before the wireless provider
provides such notice and exercises its option under this subsection.
   G.   Annual Recurring Rate:
      1.   A wireless provider shall pay to the city an annual recurring rate
to collocate a small wireless facility on a city utility pole located in a
right-of-way that equals:
         a.   Six hundred dollars ($600.00) per year; or
         b.   The actual, direct and reasonable costs related to the wireless
provider’s use of space on the city utility pole.
      2.   If the city has not billed the wireless provider actual and direct
costs, the fee shall be six hundred dollars ($600.00) payable on the first day
after the first annual anniversary of the issuance of the permit or notice of
intent to collocate, and on each annual anniversary date thereafter.
   H.   Abandonment:
      1.   A small wireless facility that is not operated for a continuous
period of twelve (12) months shall be considered abandoned. The owner of the
facility shall remove the small wireless facility within ninety (90) days after
receipt of written notice from the city notifying the wireless provider of the
abandonment.
      2.   The notice shall be sent by certified or registered mail, return
receipt requested, by the city to the owner at the last known address of the
wireless provider. If the small wireless facility is not removed within ninety
(90) days of such notice, the city may remove or cause the removal of such
facility pursuant to the terms of its pole attachment agreement for municipal
utility poles or through whatever actions are provided for abatement of
nuisances or by other law for removal and cost recovery.
      3.   A wireless provider shall provide written notice to the city if it
sells or transfers small wireless facilities within the jurisdiction of the
city. Such notice shall include the name and contact information of the new
wireless provider.
(Ord. O-18-021, 7-16-2018)
7-5-4: DISPUTE RESOLUTION:
The circuit court of Bureau county, Illinois shall have exclusive jurisdiction
to resolve all disputes arising under the small wireless facilities deployment
act. Pending resolution of a dispute concerning rates for collocation of small
wireless facilities on municipal utility poles within the right-of-way, the
city shall allow the collocating person to collocate on its poles at annual
rates of no more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) per year per municipal
utility pole, with rates to be determined upon final resolution of the dispute.
(Ord. O-18-021, 7-16-2018)
7-5-5: INDEMNIFICATION:
A wireless provider shall indemnify and hold the city harmless against any and
all liability or loss from personal injury or property damage resulting from or
arising out of, in whole or in part, the use or occupancy of the city
improvements or right-of-way associated with such improvements by the wireless
provider or its employees, agents or contractors arising out of the rights and
privileges granted under this chapter and the act. A wireless provider has no
obligation to indemnify or hold harmless against any liabilities and losses as
may be due to or caused by the sole negligence of the city or its employees or
agents. A wireless provider shall further waive any claims that they may have
against the city with respect to consequential, incidental, or special damages,
however caused, based on the theory of liability.
(Ord. O-18-021, 7-16-2018)
7-5-6: INSURANCE:
   A.   The wireless provider shall carry, at the wireless provider’s own cost
and expense, the following insurance:
      1.   Property insurance for its property’s replacement cost against all
risks;
      2.   Workers’ compensation insurance, as required by law; or
      3.   Commercial general liability insurance with respect to its
activities on the city improvements or rights-of-way to afford minimum
protection limits consistent with its requirements of other users of city
improvements or rights-of-way, including coverage for bodily injury and
property damage.
   B.   The wireless provider shall include the city as an additional insured
on the commercial general liability policy and provide certification and
documentation of inclusion of the city in a commercial general liability policy
prior to the collocation of any wireless facility.
   C.   A wireless provider may self-insure all or a portion of the insurance
coverage and limit requirement required by the city. A wireless provider that
self-insures is not required, to the extent of the self-insurance, to comply
with the requirement for the name of additional insureds under this section. A
wireless provider that elects to self-insure shall provide to the city evidence
sufficient to demonstrate its financial ability to self-insure the insurance
coverage limits required by the city.
(Ord. O-18-021, 7-16-2018)
TITLE 8: PUBLIC SERVICES
CHAPTER 1: GENERAL PROVISIONS
Section
8-1-1: Application For Service/Termination Of Service
8-1-2: Billing Procedures
8-1-1: APPLICATION FOR SERVICE/TERMINATION OF SERVICE:
   A.   Application: Application for any municipal utility services or uses,
including potable water, sanitary sewer, solid waste collection and disposal
and/or electric (collectively referred to as “municipal utility services”)
requested pursuant to this title shall be made in writing to the finance
department. Every application shall contain a unilateral agreement by the
applicant to abide by and accept all of the provisions of this title as
conditions governing the use of and/or service from the city’s utility
services. The applicant must sign the application and show a picture ID to
verify age.
   B.   Termination: The person in whose name the municipal utility services
are provided must notify the city with the date to terminate services. This
notification can be in person, by phone, email or in writing. A minimum notice
of one business day is required. Customers shall be liable for utility services
used for a minimum of one business day after the date of notice.
   C.   Service Deposits/Activation Fees:
      1.   Amount Of Deposit:
         a.   If the resident is not the owner of public record of a
residential property to which municipal utility services are to be provided,
that resident is required to pay a deposit to obtain services. The deposit
shall be collected at the time of application for service.
         b.   Deposit fees are:
 
For an electric customer with natural gas              $100.00
For all electric (no natural gas)                      $150.00
For water                                              $50.00
For customers that only have sewer or garbage services $25.00
 
         c.   Non-owners of record conducting business in a commercial building
are required to pay a deposit predetermined by the finance department which
would be equivalent to one (1) months’ service.
         d.   All deposits are held and applied to the final bill.
      2.   Return Of Deposit: Customers can receive their deposits back under
the following circumstances:
         a.   After a period of two (2) consecutive years of satisfactory
payment history with no outstanding account balance, any deposit balance shall
be returned to the customer without interest, upon written request by customer.
         b.   Upon termination of all utility services, the deposit will be
applied to the final bill. Any balance shall be returned to the customer
without interest within 30 days. In an instance where real property has been
abandoned and there is an unpaid, delinquent account, the deposit shall be
forfeited to the city as an administrative termination service fee and the
unpaid account balance shall remain due, owing and subject to collection.
         c.   The director of finance may authorize an increased deposit amount
for customers with past poor payment history. The deposit shall not exceed the
average of four (4) months billing.
   D.   Activation Fee: A thirty-five dollar ($35.00) new activation fee will
be added to the first monthly billing for all new tenants and new owners,
pursuant to the application process as identified above.
   E.   Billing Adjustments:
      1.   Customers are responsible for all metered electric and water usage
without exception. In the instance of a large non-sewer water leak, customers
may complete a sewer abatement request form with the finance department.
Adjustments may be granted by the finance director based on the situation and
evidence provided.
      2.   The city is not obligated to provide utility adjustments for
services rendered. If billing errors are made by the city, the city will issue
credits to correct the past six (6) months only.
   F.   Special Sewer Program: This program is available to customers who use
an excessive amount of outside water that is not collected or treated by the
city’s sanitary sewer system. By paying an annual fee of $60 and signing up for
the program, the city will freeze sewer costs from April 1 through November 30
by capping the usage billed based on the customer’s winter average, calculated
per the reading dates from December 1 through March 30. This is an annual
program that customers must sign up and pay for each year.
8-1-2: BILLING PROCEDURES:
   A.   Meter Readings: Meters will be read periodically. For the purposes of
this section, the term “periodic” or “periodically” shall mean the period
between any two (2) consecutive regular meter readings taken, which reading may
occur during intervals of less than, or more than, thirty (30) days. The
customer shall be billed after each meter reading.
   B.   Date Of Billing - Payments: Bills for service or use of the city’s
utilities shall be dated and sent monthly, by mail, electronically or by such
other means which is acceptable to the city and the customer. Bills shall be
due and payable within twenty (20) days after the date of the bill.
      1.   Delinquent Payment: A delinquent payment charge of ten percent (10%)
of the usage and garbage on the bill shall be added to the bill after fifteen
(15) days from the issuance date of the delinquent bill if balance is not paid
in full. One (1) delinquent payment charge may be waived by the director of
finance or designee at the request of the customer. Additional delinquent
payment charges may be waived by the city manager or designee only in
extenuating circumstances at the written request of the customer. The decision
to grant additional waiver of delinquent payment charges rests solely with the
city manager or designee.
      2.   Dishonored Checks/Returned ACH Payments: Any customer who presents a
check or ACH payment to the city which is subsequently returned by the
customer’s bank for any reason shall be subject to charges and fees set forth
in the fee schedule of the city code. After three (3) incidents of returned
payments, customers will be placed on a “cash basis only” status for future
payments. If the returned payment was made pursuant to a shut off notice or was
made to reconnect service after disconnection, the customer will immediately be
subject to a disconnection of services.
   C.   Liability For Payment:
      1.   The owner of the premises being provided municipal utility service,
the occupant thereof and the customer who uses the municipal utilities shall be
jointly and severally liability for payment of any bill rendered by the city
for such service or use.
      2.   Vacating of Premises by Renter: Where a renter has vacated or
abandoned the premises to which municipal utility service is located, and no
new renter has completed the application process, then the municipal utility
service account for the premises shall be transferred to and in the name of the
owner of the premises.
   D.   Discontinuation of Service:
      1.   The city shall have the right to discontinue and/or refuse any
municipal utility services to the customer, with due notice, and to remove the
city property from the customer’s premises whenever the utility bills are in
arrears, or when the customer fails to comply with any of the conditions or
obligations of this title.
         a.   Disconnection And Reconnection Fees: In the event utility bill(s)
in excess of a hundred dollars ($100.00) remains unpaid for a period of thirty
(30) days or, the director of finance shall order the subject utility service
to be disconnected, or limited by a limiting meter (as described in subsection
D3 below). Fifteen (15) days after the due date, a disconnect notice giving
customers five (5) business days to pay the past balance due will be sent by
mail. If payment is not received by the five (5) day extension, the electric
and/or water will be subject to shut off without any further notice. An
administrative fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be paid to the city before
service is reconnected and reinstated to the delinquent customer; however, if
service is reinstated between the hours of three o’clock (3:00) p.m. and seven
o’clock (7:00) a.m. Monday through Friday or anytime on weekends and holidays,
the administrative fee shall be three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00). All
administrative fees shall be paid in addition to all outstanding monies owed by
the delinquent customer, including any current charges or fees before service
is restored.
         b.   City of Princeton municipal electric employees will not accept
any type of payment when performing above mentioned shut offs. Customers will
have to make required payments at city hall before service will be restored.
      2.   Exceptions To Disconnection Of Electrical Utility Service: No
electric service furnished by the city to residential users shall be terminated
for nonpayment of bills:
         a.   On any day when the National Weather Service’s forecast for the
following twenty four (24) hours covering the Princeton, Illinois area includes
a forecast that the temperature will be thirty two degrees Fahrenheit (32°F) or
below; or
         b.   On any day when the National Weather Service’s forecast for the
following twenty four (24) hours covering the Princeton area includes a
forecast that the temperature will be 95 degrees Fahrenheit (95°F) or above.
         c.   While the primary occupant of the residence is a service member
engaged in military service, as defined in 65 ILCS 5/11-117.12-2.
         d.   (1)   Where the customer or his or her family member residing on
the premises has a serious illness, requiring medical electric equipment, in
which case, the customer must produce a certificate from a doctor or from the
health department within five (5) days. The certificate must contain the
following information:
               (A)   Name of the sick person;
               (B)   Verification the sick person is a resident of the address
in question;
               (C)   The name, business address and telephone number of the
certifying party;
               (D)   The nature of the illness and medical equipment requiring
electricity;
               (E)   The period of time during which the lack of electricity
will aggravate the medical condition (i.e. oxygen, electronic treatments, heart
and respiratory monitors, etc.).
            (2)   The certification is good for one month on short-term
illnesses. The certification must be renewed annually for long-term illnesses.
It can also be renewed for one month if the doctor or health department writes
to the director of finance again.
            (3)   If the certification is not renewed and your balance is
delinquent, your utility service will be subject to shut off as outlined in
subsection D1a.
      3.   In reference to subsection D2b and D2c, if the above weather or
medical conditions exist, the city may put a limiting meter on a customer’s
home. If the limiter is installed the customer must continue to pay current
charges to avoid a complete disconnect. Reconnect fees and conditions listed in
D1a of this section apply to the removal of limiting meters.
      4.   Exceptions To Disconnection Of All Municipal Utility Services: The
disconnection of municipal utility service to a customer will not be performed
on the day prior to a city observed holiday or a weekend (Saturday and Sunday).
      5.   Disconnection Of Certain Multi-Family Residences: Pursuant to the
rental property utility service act (765 ILCS 735/0.01 et seq.) the department
manager of electric and/or water for the city shall not terminate any municipal
utility service to buildings with three (3) or more residential apartments
which are served by a common system of water, sewer or electrical services that
goes through a common meter in a single building, until such time as said
director mails, delivers or posts the notice required by 765 ILCS 735/3 at
least ten (10) days prior to the date of termination of said service.
      6.   Collection Of Delinquent Accounts:
         a.   The city attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute
such proceedings, in the name of the city, in any court having jurisdiction
over such matters, and/or the city manager is hereby authorized to file a lien,
against any property as to which the utility bill has remained unpaid for a
period of sixty (60) days after it has been rendered.
         b.   When official bankruptcy paperwork is received by the finance
department, a meter reading will be taken and a final bill prepared. The final
bill will be written off as bad debt after the discharge of debtor paperwork is
received. Using the meter readings collected, a new utility account will be set
up for the customer and billings will resume.
   E.   Turn-On And Turn-Off Charges (Water): Whenever the water supply to a
water connection is shut off at the request of the owner of the premises on any
hour of Saturday or Sunday, or Monday through Friday between the hours of three
o’clock (3:00) p.m. and seven o’clock (7:00) a.m. the city shall charge an
administrative fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for water turn-off. If
reinstatement of the water connection is completed within two (2) hours of the
water turn-off, no fee will be charge for reinstatement. Should a reinstatement
take longer than two (2) hours an additional administrative fee of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) will be assessed. All fees shall be assessed on the first
business day following the reconnection/disconnection.

8-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
CONSUMER: The individual or individuals in whose name an account for electric
utility services is established pursuant to this chapter, which may include but
is not limited to, the owner, occupant, or tenant of the premises to which
services are provided under this chapter.
DEMAND CHARGE: The monthly fee billed to an industrial customer as part of the
cost of maintaining the infrastructure required to deliver electricity to their
location. The demand charge is based on the highest 15-minute interval energy
use during the month measured in kilowatts (kW).
DEPARTMENT: The electric department for the city of Princeton.
POWER COST ADJUSTMENT: The variable rate charged to account for the true cost
of purchased power, based on the actual costs of purchased power used to supply
electricity, without having to continuously change the basic electric rates.
PRIMARY RATE: Rate billed to industrial customers where the metering point is
on the primary, high voltage line. Rate also applies to customers who own their
transformer regardless of metering point.
SECONDARY RATE: Rate billed to industrial customers where the metering point is
on the low voltage side of the transformer.
8-2-2: METERED RATES:
   A.   No city electric current shall be furnished or supplied by the city to
any person, business or agency within or without the city, except by metered
rates, and unless the quantity used shall be ascertained and measured by a good
and sufficient meter as in this chapter provided.
   B.   Electricity metered through one meter shall not be combined with
electricity metered through another meter to get a lower rate than either meter
would separately, unless power is supplied at different voltages, which cannot
be metered on one meter.
8-2-3: RATES AND CHARGES ESTABLISHED:
The rates for electrical service for the Princeton municipal electric utility
shall be set by resolution of the city council. All classifications of electric
service under this section are subject to availability, terms and conditions,
and tax and power cost adjustments clause as specified in this section. Rates
and charges for electric service shall be as follows:
   A.   Residential Rates And Charges:
      1.   Inside Corporate Limits: This subsection applies to electric
services provided to residential customers within the corporate limits of the
city, for all domestic purposes.
         a.   For bills rendered in January 2017, and each year thereafter,
unless waived by the city council at a council meeting prior to January of the
year for which the increase is to take effect, the electric rates shall be
adjusted by an automatic increase based on the prior fiscal year’s increase
received by the Illinois municipal electric agency (IMEA) in an amount not to
exceed five percent (5.00%). If the wholesale increase is expected to result in
increased annual cost to the city (based on a calculation utilizing the most
recently available completed twelve (12) month IMEA cost history for the city)
of less than seventy five thousand dollars ($75,000.00), the wholesale increase
shall be limited to five percent (5.00%). Under circumstances where there is a
net decrease in the wholesale cost from the previous fiscal year, the rate will
increase by five-tenths percent (0.5%). This annual automatic increase can only
be suspended each year by four-fifths (4/5) majority of the city council. If
the wholesale increase is greater than five percent (5.00%), the city council
may, by four-fifths (4/5) majority vote, increase electric rates by the entire
wholesale increase amount, or any portion thereof.
         b.   Electric rate adjustments shall not be limited to adjustments
resulting from increases received from IMEA but may also be adjusted due to
federal or state regulatory mandates, as required for budgetary increases, or
as required to establish and/or maintain reserves in accordance with policy.
Any additional adjustment pursuant to this provision must be approved by a
majority vote of the city council.
         c.   Tax Adjustment: Rates set forth in this subsection are exclusive
of any tax that may be imposed pursuant to state law on the use or consumption
of electricity. Any such taxes shall be billed and collected as directed by
state law.
         d.   Power Cost Adjustment: The energy charges shall be subject to the
power cost adjustment each billing period.
         e.   Residential, inside city:

be suspended each year by four-fifths (4/5) majority of the city council. If
the wholesale increase is greater than five percent (5.00%), the city council
may, by four-fifths (4/5) vote, increase electric rates by the entire wholesale
increase or a portion thereof.
            (2)   Electric rate adjustments shall not be limited to adjustments
resulting from increases received from IMEA but may also be adjusted due to
federal or state regulatory mandates, as required for budgetary increases, or
as required to establish and/or maintain reserves in accordance with policy.
Any additional adjustment pursuant to this provision must be approved by a
majority vote of the city council.
            (3)   Tax Adjustment: Rates set forth in this subsection are
exclusive of any tax that may be imposed pursuant to state law on the use or
consumption of electricity. Any such taxes shall be billed and collected as
directed by state law.
            (4)   Power Cost Adjustment: The energy charges shall be subject to
the power cost adjustment each billing period.

      2.   Industrial Rates And Charges:
         a.   Secondary Rates And Charges:
            (1)   Demand Charge:
               (A)   Governmental Units: Demand charge (per kilowatt) of eight
dollars seventy five cents ($8.75).
               (B)   Nongovernmental Units: Demand charge (per kilowatt) of
nine dollars seventy five cents ($9.75).
            (2)   Energy Charge:
               (A)   For bills rendered in January 2017, and each year
thereafter, unless waived by the city council at a council meeting prior to
January of the year for which the increase is to take effect, the electric
rates shall be adjusted by an automatic increase based on the prior fiscal
year’s increase received by the Illinois municipal electric agency (IMEA) in an
amount not to exceed five percent (5.00%). If the wholesale increase is
expected to result in increased annual cost to the city (based on a calculation
utilizing the most recently available completed twelve (12) month IMEA cost
history for the city) of less than seventy five thousand dollars ($75,000.00),
the wholesale increase shall be limited to five percent (5.00%). Under
circumstances where there is a net decrease in the wholesale cost from the
previous fiscal year, the rate will increase by five-tenths percent (0.5%).
This annual automatic increase can only be suspended each year by four-fifths
(4/5) majority of the city council. If the wholesale increase is greater than
five percent (5.00%), the city council may, by four-fifths (4/5) vote, increase
electric rates by the entire wholesale increase or a portion thereof.
               (B)   Electric rate adjustments shall not be limited to
adjustments resulting from increases received from IMEA but may also be
adjusted due to federal or state regulatory mandates, as required for budgetary
increases, or as required to establish and/or maintain reserves in accordance
with policy. Any additional adjustment pursuant to this provision must be
approved by a majority vote of the city council.
               (C)   Tax Adjustment: Rates set forth in this subsection are
exclusive of any tax that may be imposed pursuant to state law on the use or
consumption of electricity. Any such taxes shall be billed and collected as
directed by state law.
               (D)   Power Cost Adjustment: The energy charges shall be subject
to the power cost adjustment each billing period.

            (2)   Energy Charge:
               (A)   For bills rendered in January 2017, and each year
thereafter, unless waived by the city council at a council meeting prior to
January of the year for which the increase is to take effect, the electric
rates shall be adjusted by an automatic increase based on the prior fiscal

expected to result in increased annual cost to the city (based on a calculation
utilizing the most recently available completed twelve (12) month IMEA cost

the wholesale increase shall be limited to five percent (5.00%). Under
circumstances where there is a net decrease in the wholesale cost from the
previous fiscal year, the rate will increase by five-tenths percent (0.5%).
This annual automatic increase can only be suspended each year by four-fifths
(4/5) majority of the city council. If the wholesale increase is greater than
five percent (5.00%), the city council may, by four-fifths (4/5) vote, increase
electric rates by the entire wholesale increase or a portion thereof.
               (B)   Electric rate adjustments shall not be limited to

increases. or as required to establish and/or maintain reserves in accordance

               (F)   A customer service charge of one hundred twenty three
dollars ($123.00) per month shall be charged for each account within the
corporate limits and one hundred twenty eight dollars ($128.00) per month shall
be charged for each account outside the corporate limits.
               (G)   Billing Period: Monthly.
               (H)   Application: All customers with over two hundred (200) amp
service and whose connected load is greater than seventy five (75) kilowatts.
               (I)   Conditions Of Service: Service will be delivered to the
customer at not more than one (1) of the two (2) following standard delivery
voltages:
                  i.   3-phase service 3-wire 120/208 or 277/480 volts (Y
connected), 480/277 volts (delta connected).
                  ii.   Combined single- and 3-phase 120/208 or 277/480 volt Y
connected, 120/240 volt single-phase.
                  iii.   PMU will provide and maintain all facilities necessary
to deliver and meter one (1) of the above delivery voltages at one (1)
specified location.
               (J)   Demand look back period: The demand charge will be based
on the higher of the current demand reading or seventy percent (70%) of any of
the previous eleven (11) months demand reading.
      3.   Large Economic Discount B6 Rate:
         a.   New or expanding businesses who were neither an end user of
another participating Illinois municipal electric agency member nor an end use
customer of a nonparticipating member immediately prior to locating within a
participating IMEA member’s service territory whose place of business is within
the corporate limits of the city and who meet the following criteria:
         b.   Service will be delivered under the same voltage levels allowed
in rate 110. The business must reach and maintain a peak load of at least one
thousand (1,000) kilowatts, or will be adding a new load of at least one
thousand (1,000) kilowatts;
         c.   The business has not been in business at the same location or
another location within the participating IMEA member’s service territory for
more than sixty (60) days at the time service commences under this rate, or the
business is adding a load of one thousand (1,000) kilowatts or more, which must
be metered separately, at its existing location at the time service commences
under such rate and the customer has taken service from the participating IMEA
member at the location for the previous twelve (12) months.
         d.   This rate will be available for a period of five (5) years if,
and only if, the IMEA B6 rate is available to the city.
         e.   If the business has not reached the threshold of one thousand
(1,000) kilowatts within twelve (12) months of the date service is first
provided, service shall thereafter continue under rates otherwise applicable to
said business.
         f.   Rates shall be calculated as follows:
            (1)   Demand charge shall be that charged to the city per kilowatt
under the IMEA B6 rate, plus fifteen percent (15%).
            (2)   Energy charge shall be that charged to the city per kilowatt
hour under IMEA B6 rate, plus fifteen percent (15%).
            (3)   The energy charge shall be subject to the IMEA power cost
adjustment each billing period.
            (4)   In lieu of this rate, the city may, at the city’s sole
option, install backup generation facilities on the customer’s property at the
city’s expense if approved by the Illinois environmental protection agency. A
customer service charge will be assessed the same as other primary or secondary
industrial customers.
   C.   Operating And Reserve Accounts: The city’s electric utility shall
maintain a cash balance in the operating account of at least one month’s
operating revenue. The city shall also set aside in a separate reserve account
a minimum of three (3) months’ operating revenue. These minimum balances shall
be met no later than July 1, 2014. The city council may use reserve funds in
excess of five (5) months’ operating revenue for intergovernmental loans, as
long as the funds are returned dollar for dollar. Reserves may only be used in
emergency situations in the electric department for natural or unnatural
disasters not covered by insurance. Reserves may also be used for capital
improvements in the electric department mandated by the state or federal
government. In either case, use of these funds shall be approved by at least a
four-fifths (4/5) majority of the city council. In the event these reserve
funds are needed, the city manager shall review and determine an appropriate
plan to replenish the funds.
(Ord. O-16-016, 9-19-2016; O-18-008, 5-7-2018)
8-2-4: PAYMENT OF BILLS; DELINQUENCIES:
   A.   Billing and payment for electric services provided pursuant to this
chapter shall follow the billing procedures set forth in section
8-1-2 of this title. All bills for electric service shall be paid in the city
clerk’s office at the city hall or at a city designated location.
   B.   Bill Information: All bills shall state appropriate meter information;
kilowatt hours consumed; the amount of demand kilowatt hours if applicable; the
amount of the current bill; the amount of the balance unpaid; and the present
amount due.
   C.   Disconnection Of Service Or Limiting Meter Installation:
      1.   Residential and commercial bills not paid within fifteen (15) days
after the due date become delinquent, and the city may disconnect services as
provided in section
8-1-2D of this title. The city may, in lieu of disconnecting service, install a
current limiting meter for the purpose of reducing electric consumption, as set
forth in section
8-1-2 or this chapter.
      2.   The notice to disconnect service shall be served by personal service
or by certified or registered mail, and shall contain the following:
         a.   The name, address and account number of the customer.
         b.   The date of the notice.
         c.   The city’s policy to disconnect five (5) days after the mailing
of notice, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays, and the earliest
date upon which disconnection may occur.
         d.   The total amount required by the disconnection date in order to
bring the account current.
         e.   A statement that service will not be terminated if:
            (1)   Prior to the disconnect date, the customer submits to the
electric department a written request for a hearing as provided in section
8-2-5 of this chapter.
            (2)   Any of the exceptions set forth in section
8-1-2D2 of this title applies.
         f.   A statement that if the customer has not contacted the city clerk
to avail himself or herself of the rights stated above within the five (5) day
disconnection period, the disconnection of service will proceed on or after the
date in subsection C2c of this section.
      3.   Any customer whose service has been scheduled for disconnection and
proper prior notice given will have his or her electric service disconnected
without any additional notification. City municipal electric employees will not
accept any type of payment when performing the above mentioned disconnections.
Customers will have to make required payments at city hall before service will
be restored.
(1989 Code § 13-28)
   D.   Reconnection Of Service: Any customer whose service has been
disconnected or had a limiting meter installed on account of nonpayment may
have the service turned on again or the limiting meter removed, as the case may
be, by paying the account in full, required deposits, if any, and a fee as
provided in the city fee schedule.
(1989 Code § 13-28)
8-2-5: DISPUTE HEARINGS:
   A.   Hearing Request:
      1.   At any time prior to the earliest date on which disconnection may
occur, as set forth in the disconnect notice provided pursuant to section
8-2-3C, a customer may request a hearing before an administrative hearing
officer appointed pursuant to section
1-4A-6 of this code. Requests for hearing must be submitted in writing to the
electric department.
      2.   No disconnection of electric service will occur during the pendency
of the hearing or prior to issuance of a final decision.
   B.   Hearings under to this section shall be conducted pursuant to the
procedures set forth in article 4A of title 1 of this code.
   C.   No Request For Hearing: If a written request for a hearing has not been
tendered prior to the earliest date for disconnection set forth in the
disconnect notice provided pursuant to subsection
8-2-3C of this chapter, then the electric department may disconnect service on
any day thereafter pursuant to this chapter, and no further hearing shall be
required. However, an extension of time in which to file a request for a
hearing may be granted in the discretion of the city manager upon the showing
of good cause by the person requesting the extension.
   D.   Order And Decision:
      1.   Within ten (10) days after a hearing, the administrative hearing
officer shall issue a written order and decision. The decision shall be based
exclusively upon evidence produced at the hearing, set forth all findings of
fact, reasons for the decision and, in the event of a finding in favor of the
city, the earliest possible date on which electric services may be
disconnected.
      2.   The written order and decision shall be sent by registered or
certified mail to the person requesting the hearing, or his or her counsel, and
no disconnection of electric service shall occur until ten (10) days after
depositing the order and decision for mailing.
      3.   A written determination issued pursuant to this section shall
constitute a final determination for purposes of judicial review and is subject
to review under the Illinois administrative review law.
8-2-6: NEGOTIATION FOR PARTIAL PAYMENTS:
   A.   The city may, for good cause shown, refuse to accept a partial payment
from any customer subsequent to the service of a disconnect notice pursuant to
section
8-2-3C. However, it is the policy of the department, upon request of a
customer, to seek to negotiate a partial payment schedule with the customer if
the request is received prior to the issuance of a disconnect notice. The
amount of the partial payment required shall be determined pursuant to
negotiation between the electric department or its designee and the customer.
   B.   After a payment schedule has been arranged, the city shall include a
notation on subsequent monthly bills indicating the amount of the arrearage
due.
   C.   At the discretion of the city manager or his or her designee, a current
limiting meter may be installed on the customer’s premises for the specific
purpose of reducing electric usage until such time as the account is paid in
full.
(1989 Code § 13-31)
8-2-7: RULES:
This section
8-2-6 shall govern the supply of electric current and electric service to
consumers.
(1989 Code § 13-33)
8-2-7-1: CONNECTION, DISCONNECTION AND MISCELLANEOUS CHARGES:
Connection, disconnection and miscellaneous charges shall be as provided in the
city fee schedule or elsewhere in this chapter.
(1989 Code § 13-33; amd. 2017 Code)
8-2-7-2: SERVICES:
The service outlet for electric services shall be installed by the customer and
should be brought out of the building at the nearest point accessible to the
pole lines from which the service is to be supplied by the department, but the
location of such outlet shall in all cases be subject to the approval of the
electric department.
8-2-7-3: METERS:
   A.   The city shall install meters at the site to which electric services
are to be provided, subject to terms and conditions and determined by the
electric department. Consumers shall accept as a standard of measurement the
meter installed by the electric department.
   B.   In case the meter becomes defective or fails to register correctly, the
quantity of electricity used shall be determined by a test of the meter, by
registration of a meter set in its place during the next period following or by
an amount charged during a corresponding period the preceding year. Any or all
of these methods may be used in determining the proper amount to be charged for
electricity used during such time.
   C.   The department shall, on the request of a residential consumer, make a
test of the accuracy of the meter; provided, that such meter has not been
tested within twelve (12) months prior to the date of making such request for a
test. If the meter has been tested within a period of twelve (12) months prior
to the date of the request for a test, the department shall make such a test,
provided the residential consumer makes a deposit to cover the cost of such
test. If the test shows the meter to be over four percent (4%) fast, the
deposit shall be refunded to the residential consumer, but if the test shows
the meter to be not over four percent (4%) fast, the deposit shall be retained
by the department. On any meter which tests more than four percent (4%) fast,
the residential consumer shall be refunded for the actual percentage of error
shown, and such refund shall apply to all bills paid for a period of six (6)
months prior to the date of such test.
   D.   The consumer shall provide a suitable place for the department to set
its meter accessible to the outside and shall provide and install a suitable
meter board for its installation. The consumer shall be responsible for and
reimburse the department for any damage to the meter while it is on the
consumer’s premises.
   E.   In wiring in meter loops on 2-wire installations, both lines and both
load wires shall be brought out to the meter board. For 3-wire installations,
the three (3) lines and the three (3) load wires shall be brought out to the
meter board.
   F.   1.   The department reserves the right to refuse to set meters or to
turn on the electricity unless the consumer’s wiring is installed in accordance
with its rules.
      2.   The department reserves the right to discontinue service and remove
its meters without notice in case the consumer fails to comply with the
department’s rules and regulations, other than for nonpayment of service
charges or electric rates established herein.
      3.   The department shall have the right, through its authorized
employees, at all times to access the premises of the consumer for the purpose
of reading, examination, testing, repairing or removing the meter.
(1989 Code § 13-33)
8-2-7-4: EXTENSION, RELOCATIONS AND REPLACEMENTS:
   A.   The department shall extend its pole lines a distance of one city block
of average length for a consumer. Consumers requiring extensions of unusual
length, or for special service, or for temporary use shall pay in advance the
cost of the labor and materials to be used in making such extensions.
   B.   Consumers requiring removal, relocation or replacement of an existing
pole line shall pay in advance the cost of the labor and materials used in
making such removal, relocation or replacement.
   C.   Customers requiring a reconnect of electric service on overtime shall
be charged for the overtime at the rates set forth by the city in advance of
said reconnection.
   D.   Consumers requesting a line crew for an outage that is determined to be
on the consumer end shall be charged the overtime rate for said line crew.
(1989 Code § 13-33)
8-2-7-5: FLUCTUATION OR DISTURBANCE OF SYSTEM BY CONSUMER:
Electric service must not be used in such a manner as to cause unusual
fluctuations or disturbances to the city’s distribution system. If necessary,
the consumer causing such disturbances will be required to install suitable
equipment to reasonably limit such disturbances at the consumer’s expense. The
consumer will be required to provide and pay for the installation of any
equipment necessary to provide nonstandard voltage or above normal voltage
regulation or above normal continuity of service. Failure to comply can result
in the disconnection of service or the installation of a limiting meter until
such action to correct such fluctuations or disturbances are completed.
(1989 Code § 13-33)
8-2-7-6: TAMPERING WITH SYSTEM; DAMAGE RECONNECT/INSPECTION FEE:
   A.   If any electric service is disconnected or any electric meter removed
or tampered with without the authorization of the city electric department, the
customer will be charged a reconnect and/or inspection fee as provided in the
city fee schedule or this chapter. The inspection will only cover the first
point of electrical disconnect.
   B.   Any person who causes damage to any meter, electric line, pole line or
pole, or any other equipment or property of the city electric department, by
any means whatsoever, will be responsible for the cost to the city to repair or
replace the damaged equipment or property.
8-2-8: SERVICE OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS:
Electric service may be furnished and sold by the city to consumers outside the
corporate limits of the city where permitted by 65 ILCS 5/11-117-6.
8-2-9: OVERHEAD AND UNDERGROUND SERVICE:
   A.   Overhead Service: The city shall furnish electrical service for all
residential customers, except subdivisions, as provided in this chapter, on an
overhead construction basis. Overhead residential electric service shall be
installed by the city to the city connection point nearest the premises to be
served.
(1989 Code § 13-51)
   B.   Underground Service:
      1.   Residential Customers: Residential customers shall be responsible
for the installation of and payment for underground electrical service from the
city connection point nearest the premises to be served. Underground electrical
service to residential customers shall include, but shall not be limited to,
secondary services such as two hundred forty (240) volt service.
      2.   Subdivisions: Any developer, subdivider or builder hereafter
desiring the installation of electrical services underground within a platted
subdivision shall pay to the city, in advance, a nonrefundable payment equal to
the excess difference in cost to the city between an underground installation
and an overhead installation.
      3.   The installation of underground electrical services shall be subject
to the following conditions:
            (1)   The granting of easements to the city to allow access by the
city for installation, repair and maintenance of underground electrical lines
and equipment.
            (2)   That all obstructions be removed from the easements.
            (3)   That lot lines and finished grades be appropriately marked at
suitable intervals.
            (4)   That where abnormal ground conditions are believed to exist,
it shall be determined by test that ground conditions in the easement are
acceptable.
            (5)   That the city shall be provided with a detailed map or plat
of the subdivision, showing the lots to be served, identified by number, lot
dimensions, and easement locations.
            (6)   A refundable deposit equivalent to the estimated cost of
overhead facilities (in addition to a nonrefundable charge equal to the
difference in cost in overhead and underground facilities) shall be invoked
where appropriate. The refundable deposit shall be invoked at the option of the
electric department.
(1989 Code § 13-52)
8-2-10: FACILITIES CONNECTION REQUIREMENTS:
The city will allow city electric utility customers to undertake behind the
meter renewable generation and make associated connections to the city’s
electric system when said customer has made appropriate application to the city
and complied with the city facilities connection requirements. The city
application for proposed behind the meter renewable generation and the
facilities connection requirements shall be available in the office of the city
clerk. The facilities connection application and requirements shall be as
promulgated by the city electric utility department staff, with the assistance
of the city’s consulting engineers in that regard. The facilities connection
application requirement may be amended from time to time by the city electric
utility staff, with the assistance of the city's consulting engineer.
(1989 Code § 13-36)
8-2-11: ELECTRIC UTILITY PAYMENT IN LIEU OF TAX:
The Princeton municipal electric utility will pay to the city of Princeton
general fund a monthly payment in lieu of tax for all kilowatt hours of
electricity sold at a rate as provided in the city fee schedule.
(1989 Code § 13-37)
ARTICLE 2A: RENEWABLE RESOURCES, INTERCONNECTIONS AND NET METERING
Section
8-2A-1: Interconnection
8-2A-2: Net Metering Policy
8-2A-1: INTERCONNECTION:
   A.   City of Princeton electric utility shall make available, upon request,
interconnection services to any customer that meets the required guidelines.
Interconnection services refers to on-site generating facilities connected to
the city’s electric utility electric distribution system in a manner that will
allow excess electricity generated by the eligible on-site generating facility
to be safely delivered onto the city’s electric utility’s electric distribution
system.
   B.   Guidelines for interconnecting to the utility system:
      1.   Only generating facilities that have been approved by the
superintendent of electric generation shall be interconnected with the city’s
electric utility’s electric distribution system.
      2.   Interconnection services shall only be available to premises with
aggregated total generation at a single customer site of less than two percent
(2%) or 600 kW, whichever is smaller.
      3.   All interconnections shall comply with the institute of electrical
and electronics engineers (“IEEE”) Standard 1547 for interconnecting
distributed resources with electric power systems (IEEE 1547) as they may be
amended from time to time.
      4.   The city electric utility is under no obligation to purchase energy
supplied to the utility under this standard. This does not preclude the
customer meeting applicable standards that would allow the customer to supply
power onto the utility’s system and receive credit for such energy under
section
8-2A-2 below.
      5.   If the customer qualified under the interconnection standard but
does not qualify under section
8-2A-2, then any energy delivered to the utility system shall be surrendered to
the utility with no value. The city’s electric utility will install a meter
that will not provide any credit for energy delivered to the utility system and
the customer will pay for any costs associated with the meter change.
      6.   Customers will comply with all other applicable utility standards
for interconnection.
      7.   Capacity Of 10 kW: Systems of 10kW or less and interconnected to the
utility system shall comply with IEEE 1547 section 5.5, periodic
interconnection tests. All interconnection related protective functions and
associated batteries shall be periodically tested at intervals specified by the
manufacturer system integrator, or the authority that has jurisdiction over the
distributed resources interconnection, or all tests shall be performed at a
minimum of every three (3) years. Periodic test reports shall be maintained and
submitted to the city’s electric utility.
      8.   Capability Greater Than 10 kW: Systems of greater than 10 kW shall
perform all interconnection-related protective functions and associated battery
testing on a yearly basis. All test reports shall be submitted to the city’s
electric utility after completion of the yearly testing.
      9.   Reports required under subsection B7 and B8 must be submitted within
thirty (30) days of the anniversary date of the energizing of the interconnect
generating. If the required reports are not received within the period, the
generation must be disconnected until such time as the reports are submitted.
   C.   The city’s electric utility shall develop such documents as needed to
implement interconnection.
8-2A-2: NET METERING POLICY:
   A.   The city’s electric utility shall make available, upon request, net
metering service to any customer taking service from the city’s electric
utility and who meets the requirements set forth herein. For purposes of this
chapter, “net metering” means service to an electric customer under which
electric energy generated by that electric customer from an eligible on-site
generating facility owned by the customer and, under some circumstances,
delivered to the local distribution facilities may be used to offset electric
energy provided by the electric utility to the electric customer as provided
for herein.
   B.   Eligible On-Site Generating Facility: An eligible on-site generating
facility shall be defined as a renewable generating facility such as a
photovoltaic facility and small wind turbines. Other forms of renewable
generation, such as sources fueled by landfill methane, fuel cells, or micro
turbines fueled by renewable fuels shall be considered on a case by case basis.
In all cases, facilities interconnected must be deemed to be renewable to
qualify for net metering.
   C.   The electric generating facility must also abide by the city’s electric
utility interconnection standards set forth in section
8-2A-1 above.
   D.   Subject to the limitations set forth herein, the city’s electric
utility shall make net metering service available upon request to any city
electric utility electric customer with a qualifying generating facility of 10
kW capacity or less.
   E.   Any generating facility greater than 10 kW but less than 600 kW shall
be considered on a case by case basis. The decision with respect to such
facilities shall be made by the superintendent of electric generation.
   F.   Total net metered capacity interconnected under this chapter for the
city’s electric utility system shall not exceed two percent (2%) of the
system’s peak as it existed in the prior calendar year. In the event that the
system peak is reduced such that the existing net capacity exceeds the two
percent (2%) level, those existing net metered customers shall be allowed to
continue under this policy. However, no new interconnections will be allowed
until such time as the system peak grows such that net metered capacity is
again no greater than two percent (2%) of the system’s peak.
   G.   Energy generated by the customer-owned generator will offset the energy
required by the customer’s load during the billing period. For any energy
generated by the customer in excess of the energy required by the customer’s
loads for a given billing period a credit shall be carried forward to the
customer’s next billing period. In no case shall credits for excess energy be
carried forward for a period greater than three billing periods. In the event
of termination of an account qualifying for net metering under this section,
any outstanding credits are surrendered. Under no circumstances will be there
by payments, or credit transfers for excess energy.
   H.   In as much as the generating facility that is net metered by the city
under this section generates renewable energy credits (RECs) under state or
federal law, the city shall retain the value of such credits.
   I.   Any costs the city electric utility incurs associated with the net
metering program, including, but not limited to, changes in metering, other
physical facilities or billing-related costs, shall be borne by the
participants in the net metering program provided however that such costs shall
be capped at one thousand dollars ($1,500.00) to each qualifying customer
interconnecting facilities of 10 kW or less. For those facilities greater than
10 kW that are deemed to qualify under this policy, all costs associated with
the program shall be borne by the participant.
   J.   The city’s electric utility shall develop such documents as needed to
implement this section.
CHAPTER 3: WATER SYSTEM

8-3-2: Charges Established
