8-3-3: PAYMENT OF BILLS; DELINQUENCIES:
   A.   Billing and payment for water services provided pursuant to this
chapter shall follow the billing procedures set forth in section
8-1-2 of this title. All bills for water service shall be paid in the city
clerk’s office at the city hall.
   B.   Bill Information: All bills shall state appropriate meter information,
gallons or cubic feet consumed, the amount of the current bill, the amount of
the balance unpaid and the present amount due.
   C.   Disconnection Of Service:
      1.   Bills not paid within thirty (30) days after the due date shall
become delinquent, and the city may disconnect services as provided in section
8-1-2D of this title.
      2.   The notice to disconnect service sent pursuant to section
8-1-2D1a of this title shall contain the following information:
         a.   The name, address and account number of the customer and the name
and address of the property owner, if it is not the same as the customer.
         b.   The date of the notice.
         c.   The city’s policy to disconnect five (5) business days after the
receipt of notice, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays, and also
the earliest date upon which disconnection may occur.
         d.   The total amount required by the disconnection date in order to
bring the account current.
         e.   A clear, concise statement of the reason for disconnection,
including the period of consumption for which there has been no payment if
notice of disconnection is for nonpayment.
         f.   A statement that service shall not be disconnected if:
            (1)   Prior to the termination date, the customer or property owner
submits to the water department a written request for a hearing as provided in
this section.
            (2)   Any of the exceptions set forth in section
8-1-2D of this title applies.
         g.   A statement that if the customer or user has not contacted the
city clerk to avail himself or herself of the rights stated in subsection C2f
of this section within the five (5) day disconnection period, the disconnection
of service will proceed on or after the date in subsection C2c of this section.
(1989 Code § 13-79)
   D.   Reconnection Of Service: Any customer or user whose service has been
disconnected for nonpayment may have the service reconnected by paying the
account in full, required deposits, if any, and a fee as provided in the city
fee schedule.
(1989 Code § 13-79)
8-3-4: RULES:
This section
8-3-4 shall govern the supply of water and water service to consumers from the
city.
(1989 Code § 13-77)
8-3-4-1: APPLICATION FOR SERVICE; DEPOSIT REQUIREMENTS:
All persons desiring water service shall make a written application to the
water department for such service on forms provided by the department, and
shall pay all application fees, connection fees, security deposits, or other
fees required pursuant to chapter t of this title.
8-3-4-2: SERVICES:
   A.   Water Taps:
      1.   The city shall make all taps to any city water main and extend
service from any such water main to the property line of any owner requesting
extension of water service to the property line. The cost of the tap and
extension of service shall be paid by the owner to the city based upon the cost
of the time and materials expended by the city for the tap and extension of
service.
      2.   Owners of all properties shall pay a hookup fee to the city upon
connection of their service line to the city water main. The charge for the
hookup shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) for service lines less than two
inches (2") and four hundred dollars ($400.00) for service lines two inches
(2") and greater in diameter. Further, the owner of the property shall
reimburse the city for the time and materials expended by the city in regard to
said hookup.
      3.   All mains or distributing pipes shall be tapped in the body, and in
no case nearer than two feet (2') of either end of the pipe. No pipe shall be
tapped on the hub or the bell, and no tap shall be made within fifteen inches
(15") of each other. No tap shall be larger than three-quarters of an inch (3/
4") in diameter, unless by special permission of the superintendent of
waterworks.
   B.   Installation Of Service Pipes And Appurtenances:
      1.   Every property being furnished with water shall have at least one
service pipe running from the city water main to such property.
      2.   All service pipes shall be of type K copper, not less than three-
fourths inch (3/4") in diameter, or plastic pipe approved for high pressure
water service use and approved by the American Water Works Association (AWWA)
and the department manager unless, in the judgement of the department manager,
an owner proposes a service size inadequate for proper pressure and flow
velocities. In that case, the department manager may require a service line and
meter of adequate size to be installed at the owner’s expense.
      3.   Where a service pipe of one and one-fourth inch (1-1/4") or larger
in size is required, copper, brass or cast iron pipe may be used by special
permission of the department manager.
      4.   On all services of two inches (2") or less in size, a curb box
approved by the department shall be installed.
      5.   Where cast iron pipe is used for services, an approved valve and
valve box shall be used in place of a curb box.
      6.   An approved stop and waste valve shall also be installed in an
accessible location between the curb box and the meter.
      7.   On a written request for service, the department shall install that
part of the service pipe extending from the mains to a point approximately one
foot (1') outside the outside line of the sidewalk, install a curb box and tap
the main. Such installation shall be at the expense of the owner or tenant of
the property or premises supplied with service, and such owner or tenant shall
be charged, at cost, for the labor and material used, but in all cases, the
length of the service charged for will be considered as the measured distance
from the curb box to the center of the street. As a condition of service,
applicants whose overall distance from an existing fire hydrant is greater than
two hundred fifty feet (250') may be required to install, at the applicant’s
expense, a fire hydrant or similar device suitable for sustaining high velocity
flows for the flushing of service lines.
   C.   Turning Water On Or Off: No person who is not an employee of the
department shall open a curb box within the jurisdiction of the department, or
turn off or turn on the water by means of the valve located in such curb box,
under any circumstances, except by special permission, which special permission
may be given by the department manager at his or her option. In cases of
emergency and the department head is not available, such permission may be
obtained from the city manager at his or her option. Any violation of this
subsection shall result in a five hundred dollar ($500.00) reconnection and/or
inspection fee.
   D.   Replacement Of Service Pipes And Appurtenances:
      1.   Whenever the department finds it necessary to replace that part of a
wrought iron pipe service extending from the main to the curb box, the owner or
owners of the property served shall replace that part of the service, if it is
iron pipe, extending from the curb box to the meter at their expense.
      2.   Whenever it shall be necessary to replace the valve between the curb
box and the meter in any service pipe, it shall be replaced by a standard ball
valve approved by the water department.
   E.   Curb Boxes Not To Be Impeded: No curb box in the city shall be covered
up by any sidewalk, crosswalk or driveway. In cases where it is necessary to
build sidewalks, crosswalks or driveways over existing curb boxes, the
department shall be notified prior to installation of such walk, etc., so that
such curb box can be either adjusted so that its top is flush with the top
surface of the walk or driveway, or moved, as the case may be.
   F.   Water Leaks:
      1.   Whenever it shall be discovered that there is a leak in any service
pipe, it shall be repaired at once. If the leak is between the curb box and the
meter, it shall be repaired by the owner or owners of the property or premises
served at their expense. If the service discovered to be leaking is a wrought
iron or lead pipe service, it shall not be repaired but shall be replaced with
materials in compliance with the Illinois plumbing code (77 Ill. Admin. Code
Part 890).
      2.   If the owner or owners of the property whose service is found to be
leaking between the curb box and the mater fail to have the leak repaired or
the service renewed, as the case may be, within thirty (30) days after
receiving written notice to do so, the department shall disconnect the water
service to the property until repairs are made.
8-3-5: WATER METERS:
   A.   All water furnished through any water service tap, plug or other
connection which is connected to the mains and distribution system of the city
shall be metered through a water meter of a size and type approved by the
department and shall be tested and installed under the supervision of the
department manager or his or her designee.
   B.   Customers shall accept as a standard of measurement the meter installed
by the department. In case the meter becomes defective or fails to register
correctly, the quantity of water used shall be determined by a test of the
meter by registration of a meter set in its place during the next period
following or by an amount charged during a corresponding period the preceding
year. Any or all of these methods may be used in determining the proper amount
to be charged for water used during such time.
   C.   In all cases where a meter is required for a new installation, the
department shall furnish, at cost, a meter for measuring the water used, and
such meter shall be paid for, prior to installation, by the owner or owners of
the property or premises where the water is used. Such meter remains the
property of the city and shall be installed so as to be accessible from the
outside.
   D.   The department reserves the right to refuse to set meters or to turn on
the water unless the customer’s piping is installed in accordance with its
rules.
   E.   The department shall have jurisdiction over and make all necessary
repairs and tests on all meters connected to its distribution system.
   F.   Customers or owners of the premises served shall be responsible for and
reimburse the department for the cost of repairs on any meter which may be
damaged by freezing, hot water or other preventable causes while in use on the
customer’s or owner’s premises.
   G.   The department shall, on the request of a customer, make a test of the
accuracy of the water meter; provided, that such meter has not been tested
within a period of twelve (12) months prior to the date of making such request
for test. If the water meter has been tested within a period of twelve (12)
months prior to the date of request, the department shall make a test, provided
the customer makes a deposit to cover the cost of such test. If the test shows
the meter to be over four percent (4%) fast, the deposit shall be refunded to
the customer, but if the test shows the meter to be not over four percent (4%)
fast, the deposit shall be retained by the department. On any meter which tests
more than four percent (4%) fast, the customer shall be refunded for the actual
percent of error shown and such refund shall apply to all bills paid for a
period of six (6) months prior to the date of such test.
   H.   When a customer desires to close his or her premises temporarily or the
same are vacated by a tenant, it shall be the duty of the customer or the owner
of such premises to notify the department of such fact and request that the
water be shut off at the curb box and, if in freezing weather, have the meter
removed. Where service is shut off for the above reason, a minimum bill shall
be charged during the period the service is shut off. Reconnection fees as set
for the in chapter 1 of this title shall apply for turning the water on again.
The customer shall be responsible for draining the pipes on the customer’s side
of the meter.
8-3-6: SERVICE OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS:
City water services may be furnished and sold to customers in specified areas
outside the city limits when, in the judgment and discretion of the city
council, it is practicable to be done, provided that a majority of the owners
of record of the real property in the specified area petition the city council
for such service, and upon such terms and conditions as shall be prescribed by
the city council.
(1989 Code § 13-83)
8-3-7: EXTENSION OF MAINS:
The city shall extend its water mains along any public highway within its
service area on the following terms and conditions:
   A.   Estimated And Actual Costs:
      1.   Upon application being made for an extension of water main, the city
engineer shall make an estimate of the cost of the proposed extension including
pipe, valves, fittings, all other materials and all other costs such as labor,
supervision, engineering, insurance, tools and equipment and other overhead
expenses.
      2.   If the city engineer’s estimated cost of the proposed extension
exceeds three and one-half (3-1/2) times the city’s estimate of annual revenue
to be received from customers or users who will immediately attach to the
extension, the city will finance and make the extension without the requirement
of any payment.
      3.   If the city engineer’s estimated cost of the proposed extension
exceeds three and one-half (3-1/2) times the city’s estimate of immediate
annual revenue, the applicant or the applicant’s authorized agent shall
contract for such extension and shall pay in advance to the city the estimated
cost of the extension less three and one-half (3-1/2) times the estimated
annual revenue.
      4.   Should the actual cost of the extension be less than the estimated
cost, the city shall refund the difference as soon as the actual cost has been
ascertained.
   B.   Eligible Customers Or Users: Original prospective customers or users to
be considered under this section shall be those who have buildings under
contract or construction. An estimate of annual revenue shall be made by the
city and shall be based on the experience of the city regarding the use of
water by other customers or users similarly situated.
   C.   Refunds:
      1.   The city shall make refunds during the first five (5) years after
the date upon which the extension contract has been entered into, and only to
the person who has contracted and paid for an extension as follows:
         a.   Each new additional customer or user to be connected to this main
shall pay his or her prorated share to the city based on a per foot unit cost
of such extension required to reach the end of the property of the original
applicant, plus the usual service charge.
         b.   Unit costs shall be based on actual construction costs of the
extension, divided by the total front footage of all undeveloped property
facing this extension.
         c.   The prorated share shall be the front footage of the lot times
the per foot unit cost.
         d.   This regulation shall apply only on such extensions as may be
made where more than one owner of property facing this extension is concerned.
      2.   The sum of the refunds shall in no event exceed in the aggregate the
amount paid to the city for extension.
      3.   No interest shall be paid by the city on the applicant’s payment or
on any unrefunded balances.
      4.   At the expiration of the five (5) year period, the refund account
shall be closed and no further refund shall be made.
   D.   Extensions Are City Property: Extensions made under this section shall
be and remain the property of the city.
   E.   Additional Extensions: The city reserves the right to further extend
its water mains from and beyond the terminus of each water main extension made
under this section. The applicant or applicant’s agent paying for an extension
shall not be entitled to any refund for the attaching of customers or users to
any further extension.
   F.   Size Of Mains: Extensions made under this section shall be on the basis
of a main size adequate to serve the customer or user but no less than six
inches (6") in diameter or as otherwise required by the Illinois plumbing code.
If the city desires to make the extension of the main with a pipe larger than
the required size, then the additional cost of the larger pipe shall be borne
by the city.
   G.   Contract For Extensions: All water main extensions shall be made by
contract with the applicant in accordance with the conditions of this section.
(1989 Code § 13-84)
ARTICLE 3A: CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL
Section
8-3A-1: Purpose
8-3A-2: Scope
8-3A-3: City Policy
8-3A-4: Definitions
8-3A-5: Water System
8-3A-6: Cross Connections Restricted
8-3A-7: Surveys And Investigations
8-3A-8: Backflow Prevention Required; Testing And Records
8-3A-9: Where Protection Required
8-3A-10: Type Of Protection Required
8-3A-11: Backflow Prevention Devices
8-3A-12: Entry Powers; Information Supplied By Consumer
8-3A-13: Inspections, Tests And Maintenance
8-3A-14: Booster Pumps
8-3A-15: Additional Regulations
8-3A-16: Violations; Discontinuance Of Water Service
8-3A-17: Responsibility For Cleanup Costs
8-3A-18: Provisions Cumulative; Conflicts
8-3A-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this article is:
   A.   To protect the public water supply system from contamination or
pollution by isolating within the customer’s water system contaminants or
pollutants which could backflow through the service connection into the public
water supply system.
   B.   To promote the elimination or control of existing cross connections,
actual or potential, between the public or consumer’s potable water system and
nonpotable water systems, plumbing fixtures and sources or systems containing
substances of unknown or questionable safety.
   C.   To provide for the maintenance of a continuing program of cross
connection control which will prevent the contamination or pollution of the
public and consumer’s potable water systems.
(1989 Code § 13-105)
8-3A-2: SCOPE:
This article shall apply to all premises served by the public potable water
supply system of the city.
(1989 Code § 13-105)
8-3A-3: CITY POLICY:
The city council shall be responsible for protection of the public water supply
system from contamination due to backflow or back siphonage of contaminants
through the customer’s water service connection. If, in the judgment of the
department manager or his or her authorized representative, an approved
backflow prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water
supply system, the utility manager shall give notice to the consumer to install
such approved backflow prevention device at each service connection to the
premises. The consumer shall immediately install such approved device at his or
her own expense. The failure, refusal or inability on the part of the consumer
to install such device immediately shall constitute grounds for discontinuing
water service to the premises until such device has been installed. The
consumer shall retain records of installation, maintenance, testing and repair
as required in subsection
8-3A-8 of this article for a period of at least five (5) years.
(1989 Code § 13-105)
8-3A-4: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
AGENCY: The Illinois environmental protection agency.
APPROVED BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE: Backflow prevention devices or methods
approved by the Research Foundation for Cross-Connection Control of the
Association of State Sanitary Engineers, University of Southern California,
American Water Works Association, American National Standards Institute or
certified by the National Sanitation Foundation.
AUXILIARY WATER SYSTEM: Any water source or system on or available to the
premises other than the public water supply system and includes the water
supplied by the system. These auxiliary waters may include water from another
purveyor’s public water supply system; or water from a source such as wells,
lakes, or streams; or process fluids; or used water. These waters may be
polluted or contaminated or objectionable or constitute a water source or
system over which the water purveyor does not have control.
BACKFLOW: The flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances into the
distribution pipes of a potable water system from any source other than the
intended source of the potable water supply.
BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE: Any device, method or type of construction intended
to prevent backflow into a potable water system. All devices used for backflow
prevention in the city shall meet the standards of the Illinois plumbing code
(77 Ill. Admin. Code Part 890) and the Illinois environmental protection agency
(35 Illinois administrative code part 653).
CONSUMER OR CUSTOMER: The owner, official custodian or person in control of any
premises supplied by or in any manner connected to the city water system, which
may include, but is not limited to, an owner, tenant or occupant.
CONSUMER’S WATER SYSTEM: Any water system located on the customer’s premises. A
building plumbing system is considered to be a customer’s water system.
CONTAMINATION: An impairment of the quality of the water by entrance of any
substance to a degree which could create a health hazard.
CROSS CONNECTION: Any physical connection or arrangement between two (2)
otherwise separate piping systems, one of which contains potable water and the
other a substance of unknown or questionable safety or quality, whereby there
may be a flow from one system into the other.
CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL DEVICE: A tested and approved plumbing appurtenance,
complete with shut off valves, installed in a potable water line to prevent
potable water from being mixed with any substance from a piping system
containing non-potable substances, connected in any manner to the potable water
supply.
DEPARTMENT: The water department of the city of Princeton.
DIRECT CROSS CONNECTION: A cross connection formed when a water system is
physically joined to a source of unknown or unsafe substance.
DOUBLE CHECK VALVE ASSEMBLY: An assembly composed of single, independently
acting check valves approved under ASSE standard 1015. A “double check valve
assembly” shall include tight shutoff valves located at each end of the
assembly and suitable connections for testing the water tightness of each check
valve.
FIXED PROPER AIR GAP: The unobstructed vertical distance through the free
atmosphere between the water discharge point and the flood level rim of the
receptacle.
HEALTH HAZARD: Any condition, device or practice in a water system or its
operation resulting from a real or potential danger to the health and well
being of consumers. The word “severe”, as used to qualify “health hazard”,
means a hazard to the health of the user that could be expected to result in
death or significant reduction in the quality of life.
INDIRECT CROSS CONNECTION: A cross connection through which an unknown
substance can be forced, drawn by vacuum or otherwise introduced into a safe
potable water system.
INSPECTION: A plumbing inspection to examine carefully and critically all
materials, fixtures, piping and appurtenances, appliances and installations of
a plumbing system for compliance with the requirements of the Illinois plumbing
code, 77 Illinois administrative code 890.
NONPOTABLE WATER: Water generally not fit for human consumption in accordance
with accepted water supply principles and practices.
PLUMBING: The actual installation, repair, maintenance, alteration or extension
of a plumbing system by any person. “Plumbing” includes all piping, fixtures,
appurtenances and appliances for a supply of water for all purposes including,
without limitation, lawn sprinkler systems, from the source of a private water
supply on the premises or from the main in the street, alley or at the curb to,
within and about any building or buildings where a person or persons live, work
or assemble. “Plumbing” includes all piping from discharge or pumping units to
and including pressure tanks in water supply systems. “Plumbing” includes all
piping, fixtures, appurtenances and appliances for a building drain and a
sanitary drainage and related ventilation system of any building or buildings
where a person or persons live, work or assemble from the point of connection
of such building drain to the building sewer or private sewage disposal system
five feet (5') beyond the foundation walls.
POLLUTION: The presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic,
radiological, or biological) in water that tends to degrade its quality so as
to constitute a hazard or impair the usefulness of the water.
POTABLE WATER: Water generally fit for human consumption in accordance with
accepted water supply principles and practices.
POTENTIAL CROSS CONNECTION: A fixture or appurtenance with threaded hose
connection, tapered spout or other connection which would facilitate extension
of the water supply line beyond its legal termination point.
PROCESS FLUID: Any fluid or solution which may be chemically, biologically or
otherwise contaminated or polluted in a form or concentration such as would
constitute a health, pollution or system hazard if introduced into the public
or a consumer’s potable water system. This includes, but is not limited to:
   A.   Polluted or contaminated waters.
   B.   Process waters.
   C.   Used waters originating from the public water supply system which may
have deteriorated in sanitary quality.
   D.   Cooling waters.
   E.   Questionable or contaminated natural waters taken from wells, lakes,
streams or irrigation systems.
   F.   Chemicals in solution or suspension.
   G.   Oils, gases, acids, alkalis and other liquid and gaseous fluids used in
industrial or other processes, or for firefighting purposes.
PUBLIC WATER SUPPLY: All mains, pipes and structures through which water is
obtained and distributed to the public, including wells and well structures,
intakes and cribs, pumping stations, treatment plants, reservoirs, storage
tanks and appurtenances, collectively or severally, actually used or intended
for use for the purpose of furnishing water for drinking or general domestic
use and which serve at least fifteen (15) service connections or which
regularly serve at least twenty five (25) persons at least sixty (60) days per
year.
REDUCED PRESSURE PRINCIPLE ZONE BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE: A device containing
a minimum of two (2) independently acting check valves, together with an
automatically operated pressure differential relief valve located between the
two (2) check valves and approved under ASSE standard 1013. During normal flow
and at the cessation of normal flow, the pressure between these two (2) checks
shall be less than the supply pressure. In case of leakage of either check
valve, the differential relief valve, by discharging to the atmosphere, shall
operate to maintain the pressure between the check valves at less than the
supply pressure. The unit shall include tightly closing shutoff valves located
at each end of the device, and each device shall be fitted with properly
located test cocks.
SERVICE CONNECTION: The opening, including all fittings and appurtenances, at
the water main through which water is supplied to the customer.
SURVEY: The collection of information pertaining to a customer’s piping system
regarding the location of all connections to the public water supply system and
shall include the location, type and most recent inspection and testing date of
all cross connection control devices and methods located within that customer’s
piping system. The survey shall be in written form, and should not be an actual
plumbing inspection.
SYSTEM HAZARD: A condition through which an aesthetically objectionable or
degrading material not dangerous to health may enter the public water supply
system or a consumer’s potable water system.
USED WATER: Any water supplied by the city water system to a consumer’s water
system after it has passed through the service connection and is no longer
under the control of the city water department.
8-3A-5: WATER SYSTEM:
   A.   Components Of Water System: The water system shall be considered as
made up of two (2) parts: the public water supply system and the consumer’s
water system.
   B.   Public Water Supply:
      1.   The public water supply system shall consist of the source
facilities and the distribution system, and shall include all those facilities
of the potable water system under the control of the department up to the point
where the consumer’s water system begins.
      2.   The source shall include all components of the facilities utilized
in the production, treatment, storage and delivery of water to the public water
supply distribution system.
      3.   The public water supply distribution system shall include the
network of conduits used to deliver water from the source to the consumer’s
water system.
   C.   Consumer’s Water System: The consumer’s water system shall include all
parts of the facilities beyond the service connection used to convey water from
the public water supply distribution system to points of use.
(1989 Code § 13-106)
8-3A-6: CROSS CONNECTIONS RESTRICTED:
   A.   No person shall establish or permit to be established or maintain or
permit to be maintained any connection whereby a private, auxiliary or
emergency water supply other than the regular public water supply of the city
enters the supply or distribution system of the city, unless such private,
auxiliary or emergency water supply and the method of connection and use of
such supply shall have been approved by the department manager and the Illinois
environmental protection agency.
(1989 Code § 13-113)
   B.   Connections between potable water systems and other systems or
equipment containing water or other substances of unknown or questionable
quality are prohibited except when and where approved cross connection control
devices or methods are installed, tested and maintained to ensure proper
operation on a continuing basis.
   C.   No physical connection shall be permitted between the potable portion
of the public water supply and any other water supply not of equal or better
bacteriological and chemical quality as determined by inspection and analysis
by the department and the agency.
   D.   There shall be no arrangement or connection by which an unsafe
substance may enter the public water supply.
   E.   There shall be no direct connection between potable water lines and
sewage lines or equipment and vessels containing sewage.
8-3A-7: SURVEYS AND INVESTIGATIONS:
   A.   The department manager shall cause surveys and investigations to be
made of industrial and other properties served by the public water supply to
determine whether actual or potential hazards to the public water supply may
exist and to compile and update an inventory of backflow prevention and cross
connection control devices. Such surveys and investigations shall be made a
matter of public record and shall be repeated as often as the department
manager shall deem necessary, but in no case less frequently than once every
two (2) years. Records of such surveys shall be maintained by the city and
available for review for a period of at least five (5) years.
(1989 Code § 13-114)
   B.   It shall be the responsibility of the water consumer to arrange
periodic surveys of water use practices on his or her premises to determine
whether there are actual or potential cross connections to his or her water
system through which contaminants or pollutants could backflow into his, her or
the public potable water system. All cross connection control or other plumbing
repairs, maintenance, and installations shall be conducted in accordance with
section 3 of the Illinois plumbing license law, being 225 ILCS 320/3.
(1989 Code § 13-109)
8-3A-8: BACKFLOW PREVENTION REQUIRED; TESTING AND RECORDS:
It is the responsibility of the water consumer to prevent backflow into the
public water system by ensuring that:
   A.   All cross connections are removed or approved backflow prevention
devices are installed for control of backflow and back siphonage.
   B.   Cross connection control and/or backflow prevention devices are
installed in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions, the Illinois
plumbing code and the requirements of this chapter.
   C.   Records submitted to the department shall be available for inspection
by agency personnel in accordance with applicable law.
8-3A-9: WHERE PROTECTION REQUIRED:
   A.   An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on all
connections to the public water supply as described in the plumbing code, 77
Illinois administrative code part 890, and the agency’s regulations, 35
Illinois administrative code part 653, subpart H. In addition, an approved
backflow prevention device shall be installed on each service line to a
consumer’s water system serving premises, where in the judgment of the
department manager, actual or potential hazards to the public water supply
system exist.
   B.   An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on each
service line to a consumer’s water system serving premises where the following
conditions exist:
      1.   Premises having an auxiliary water supply, unless such auxiliary
supply is accepted as an additional source by the department manager, and the
source is approved by the Illinois environmental protection agency.
      2.   Premises on which any substance is handled which can create an
actual or potential hazard to the public water supply system. This shall
include premises having sources or systems containing process fluids or waters
originating from the public water supply system which are no longer under the
sanitary control of the department manager.
      3.   Premises having internal cross connections that, in the judgment of
the department manager, are not correctable or intricate plumbing arrangements
which make it impractical to determine whether or not cross connections exist.
      4.   Premises where, because of security requirements or other
prohibitions or restrictions, it is impossible or impractical to make a
complete cross connection survey.
      5.   Premises having a repeated history of cross connections being
established or reestablished.
   C.   An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on all
connections to the public water supply as described in the plumbing code, 77
Illinois administrative code 890, and the agency’s regulations, 35 Illinois
administrative code part 653, subpart H. In addition, an approved backflow
prevention device shall be installed on each service line to a consumer’s water
system serving, but not necessarily limited to, the following types of
facilities, unless the utility manager determines that no actual or potential
hazard to the public water supply system exists:
      1.   Salons and restaurants.
      2.   Car washes.
      3.   Chemical plants.
      4.   Food or beverage processing plants.
      5.   Healthcare facilities and mortuaries.
      6.   Laboratories.
      7.   Metal plating industries.
      8.   Petroleum processing or storage plants.
      9.   Piers, docks, waterfront facilities.
      10.   Radioactive material processing plants or nuclear reactors.
      11.   Sewage treatment plants, sewage pumping stations or stormwater
pumping stations.
(1989 Code § 13-110)
8-3A-10: TYPE OF PROTECTION REQUIRED:
   A.   The type of protection required under subsection
8-3A-9C of this article shall depend on the degree of hazard which exists as
follows:
      1.   An approved fixed proper air gap separation or an approved reduced
pressure principle backflow prevention device shall be installed when the
public water supply system may be contaminated with substances that could cause
a severe health hazard. The approved fixed proper air gap separation should
always be used where technically feasible.
      2.   An approved fixed proper air gap separation or an approved reduced
pressure principle backflow prevention device shall be installed where the
public water supply system may be contaminated with a substance that could
cause a system or health hazard.
      3.   An approved fixed proper air gap separation or an approved reduced
pressure principle backflow prevention device shall be installed where the
public water supply system may be polluted with substances that could cause a
pollution hazard not dangerous to health.
   B.   The type of protection required under subsection
8-3A-9C of this article shall be an approved fixed proper air gap separation or
an approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device.
   C.   Where a public water supply or an auxiliary water supply is used for a
fire protection system, reduced pressure principle zone backflow preventers
shall be installed on fire sprinkler systems connected to the public water
supply when:
      1.   The fire safety system contains antifreeze, fire retardant or other
chemicals;
      2.   Water is pumped into the fire safety system from another source;
      3.   Water flows into the fire safety system by gravity from a nonpotable
source; or
      4.   There is a connection whereby water can be pumped into the fire
safety system from any other source.
(1989 Code § 13-111)
8-3A-11: BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICES:
   A.   Only backflow prevention devices which are approved by the Research
Foundation for Cross- Connection Control of the University of Southern
California, American Water Works Association, American Society of Sanitary
Engineering or American National Standards Institute or certified by the
National Sanitation Foundation to be in compliance with applicable industry
specifications shall be used.
   B.   If, in accordance with the Illinois plumbing code or in the judgment of
the city, an approved backflow prevention device is necessary for the safety of
the public water supply system, the department manager shall give notice to the
water customer to install such a device immediately. The water customer shall,
at his or her own expense, install such a device at a location and in a manner
in accordance with the Illinois plumbing code and all applicable local
regulations and shall have inspections and tests made of such approved devices
as required by the Illinois plumbing code and local regulations.
8-3A-12: ENTRY POWERS; INFORMATION SUPPLIED BY CONSUMER:
   A.   The approved CCCDI shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time
any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution
system of the city for the purpose of verifying the presence or absence of
cross connections.
   B.   The department manager or his or her authorized agent shall have the
right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to
the public water supply or distribution system of the city for the purpose of
verifying information submitted by the customer regarding the required cross
connection control inspection.
   C.   On demand, the owner, lessees or occupants of any property so served
shall furnish to the department manager any information which he or she may
request regarding the piping system or systems or water use on such property.
The refusal to provide such information, when demanded, shall, with the
discretion of the department manager, be deemed evidence by the presence of
improper connections as provided in this article.
(1989 Code § 13-115)
8-3A-13: INSPECTIONS, TESTS AND MAINTENANCE:
   A.   The consumer at any premises on which backflow prevention devices
required by this article are installed shall have inspection, tests,
maintenance and repair made in accordance with the following schedule or more
often where inspections indicate a need or are specified in the manufacturer’s
instructions:
      1.   Backflow prevention and cross connection control devices shall be
inspected at the time of installation and at least annually thereafter.
      2.   Fixed proper air gap separations shall be inspected at the time of
installation and at least annually thereafter.
      3.   Double check valve assemblies shall be inspected and tested at the
time of installation and at least annually thereafter. Required service shall
be performed within fifteen (15) days.
      4.   Reduced pressure principle zone backflow prevention devices shall be
tested at the time of installation and at least annually or more frequently if
recommended by the manufacturer. Required service shall be performed within
five (5) days.
   B.   Testing shall be performed by a person who has been approved by the
agency as competent to service the device. Proof of approval shall be in
writing.
   C.   Each device shall have a tag attached listing the date of the most
recent test or visual inspection, the name of the tester, and the type and date
of repairs.
   D.   A maintenance log shall be maintained and include:
      1.   The date of each test or visual inspection.
      2.   The name and approval number of the person performing the test or
visual inspection.
      3.   The test results.
      4.   The repairs or servicing required.
      5.   The repairs and date completed.
      6.   The servicing performed and the date completed.
   E.   Whenever backflow prevention devices required by this article are found
to be defective, they shall be repaired or replaced at the expense of the
consumer without delay.
   F.   Backflow prevention devices shall not be bypassed, made inoperative,
removed or otherwise made ineffective without specific authorization by the
utility manager.
(1989 Code § 13-116)
8-3A-14: BOOSTER PUMPS:
   A.   Where a booster pump, except those used for fire protection, has been
installed on the service line to or within any premises, such pump shall be
equipped with a low pressure cutoff device designed to shut off the booster
pump when the pressure in the service line on the suction side of the pump
drops to twenty (20) pounds per square inch or less.
   B.   The water consumer shall maintain the low pressure cutoff device in
proper working order and shall certify to the utility manager, at least once a
year, that the device is operable.
(1989 Code § 13-117)
8-3A-15: ADDITIONAL REGULATIONS:
The city council shall adopt such regulations as it shall deem necessary to
promote the elimination or control of existing cross connections in furtherance
of this article.
(1989 Code § 13-103)
8-3A-16: VIOLATIONS; DISCONTINUANCE OF WATER SERVICE:
   A.   The department manager is authorized and directed to deny or
discontinue, after ten (10) days’ written notice to the occupant thereof, the
water service to any property wherein any connection in violation of the
provisions of this article is known to exist including, but not limited to, the
following. Any backflow prevention device required by this article is not
installed, tested, maintained and repaired in a manner acceptable to the
utility manager, or if it is found that the backflow prevention device has been
removed or bypassed, or if an unprotected cross connection exists on the
premises, or if a low pressure cutoff required by this article is not installed
and maintained in working order.
   B.   The department manager shall take such other precautionary measures as
he or she may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the
public water supply distribution mains.
(1989 Code § 13-102)
   C.   Water service to such property shall not be restored until such
conditions have been eliminated or corrected in compliance with the provisions
of this article, and to the satisfaction of the department manager, and until a
reconnection fee as provided in the city fee schedule is paid to the city.
(1989 Code § 13-102)
   D.   Immediate disconnection with verbal notice can be effected when the
department manager reasonably believes that imminent danger of harmful
contamination of the public water supply exists. Such action shall be allowed
by written notification of the cause of disconnection.
   E.   Any person found to be in violation of any provision of this chapter is
subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) per offense. Each day the violation
continues shall be considered a separate offense.
(1989 Code § 13-102)
8-3A-17: RESPONSIBILITY FOR CLEANUP COSTS:
The consumer responsible for backsiphoned material or contamination through
backflow, if contamination of the potable water supply system occurs through an
illegal cross connection or an improperly installed, maintained or repaired
backflow prevention or cross connection control device, or a device which has
been bypassed, must bear the cost of cleanup of the potable water supply
system.
(1989 Code § 13-108)
8-3A-18: PROVISIONS CUMULATIVE; CONFLICTS:
This article is in addition to all other ordinance provisions and shall be
construed therewith except as to that part in direct conflict with any other
ordinance provisions. In the event of such conflict, the provisions of this
article shall govern.
(1989 Code § 13-104)
CHAPTER 4: SEWER SYSTEM
ARTICLE 4A: SEWER USE AND SERVICE
Section
8-4A-1: Definitions
8-4A-2: Use Of Public Sewers Required
8-4A-3: Private Sewage Disposal Systems
8-4A-4: City Sewer Mains
8-4A-5: Buildings Sewers And Connections
8-4A-6: Use Of The Sanitary Sewer System
8-4A-6-1: Discharges Into System
8-4A-6-2: Interceptors
