8-4C1-6: PAYMENT OF BILLS; DELINQUENCIES:
   A.   Billing and payment for sewer services provided pursuant to this
article shall follow the billing procedures set forth in section
8-1-2 of this title. All bills for sewer service shall be paid in the city
clerk’s office at the city hall.
   B.   Bill Information: All bills shall state the following: appropriate
meter information; gallons or cubic feet of water metered; the amount of the
current bill; the amount of the balance unpaid; and the present amount due.
   C.   Disconnection Of Service: Bills not paid within thirty (30) days after
the due date become delinquent, and the city may disconnect water services as
provided in section
8-1-2D of this title. The notice to disconnect service shall be served by
personal service or by certified or registered mail, and shall contain:
      1.   The name, address and account number of the customer and the name
and address of the user if it is not the same as the customer, insofar as is
known.
      2.   The date of the notice.
      3.   The department’s policy to disconnect five (5) days after the
receipt of notice, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays , and
also the earliest date upon which disconnection may occur.
      4.   The total amount required by the disconnection date in order to
bring the account current.
      5.   A clear, concise statement of the reason for disconnection,
including the period of consumption for which there has been no payment, if
notice of disconnection is for nonpayment.
      6.   A statement that service will not be terminated if:
         a.   Prior to the disconnect date, the customer or use submits to the
water department a written request for a hearing as provided in section
8-3-3 of this title.
         b.   A statement that if the customer has not contacted the city clerk
to avail himself or herself of the rights stated in this subsection within the
five (5) day disconnection period, the disconnection of service shall proceed
on or after the date in subsection C3 of this section.
(1989 Code § 11-138)
   D.   Reconnection Of Service: Any consumer whose service has been
disconnected for nonpayment may have the service turned on again by paying all
arrears and a fee as provided in the city fee schedule.
(1989 Code § 11-138; amd. 2017 Code)
8-4C1-7: REVIEW AND REVISION OF WASTEWATER SERVICE CHARGE:
The wastewater service charge shall be revised periodically to reflect a change
in debt service or a change in operation and maintenance costs, including
replacement costs.
(1989 Code § 11-137)
8-4C1-8: NOTICE OF RATES:
A copy of this article, properly certified by the city treasurer, shall be
filed in the office of the county recorder of deeds and shall be deemed notice
to all owners of real estate of the charges of the sewerage system of the city
on their properties.
(1989 Code § 11-145)
8-4C1-9: REVENUES:
All revenues and monies derived from the operation of the sewerage system shall
be deposited in an account designated as the “sewerage fund of the city.” All
such revenues and monies shall be held by the city treasurer separate and apart
from his or her private funds and separate and apart from all other funds of
the city. All of such sum, without any deductions whatever, shall be delivered
to the city treasurer not more than ten (10) days after receipt of the same or
at such more frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by the
city council. The treasurer shall administer such fund in every respect in the
manner provided by statute.
(1989 Code § 11-143)
8-4C1-10: ACCOUNTING:
   A.   The city treasurer shall establish a proper system of accounts and
shall keep proper books, records and accounts in which complete and correct
entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the sewerage system, and
at regular annual intervals he or she shall cause to be made an audit by an
independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and
disbursements of the sewerage system.
   B.   In addition to the customary operating statements, the annual audit
report shall also reflect the revenues and operating expenses of the wastewater
facilities, including a replacement cost, to indicate that sewer service
charges under the waste cost recovery system and capital amounts required to be
recovered under the industrial cost recovery system do in fact meet these
regulations. In this regard, the financial information to be shown in the audit
report shall include the following:
      1.   Flow data showing total gallons received at the wastewater plant for
the current fiscal year.
      2.   Billing data to show the total number of gallons billed.
      3.   Debt service for the next succeeding fiscal year.
      4.   The number of users connected to the system.
      5.   The number of nonmetered users.
      6.   A list of users discharging nondomestic wastes (industrial users)
and the volume of waste discharged.
(1989 Code § 11-144)
8-4C1-11: ACCESS TO RECORDS:
The state environmental protection agency or its authorized representative
shall have access to any books, documents, papers and records of the city which
are applicable to the city system of user charges or industrial cost recovery
for the purpose of making audit, examination, excerpts and transcriptions
thereof to ensure compliance with the terms of the special and general
conditions to any state grant.
(1989 Code § 11-146)
DIVISION C2: INDUSTRIAL COST RECOVERY
Section
8-4C2-1: Industrial Cost Recovery Required
8-4C2-2: Determination Of Industrial Population Equivalent
8-4C2-3: Determination Of Costs
8-4C2-4: Charge For Recovery
8-4C2-5: Recovery Period
8-4C2-6: Payments And Billing; Delinquencies
8-4C2-7: Initial Payment
8-4C2-8: Adjustments Of Charges
8-4C2-9: No Charge For Unused Or Reserved Capacity
8-4C2-10: Commitment For Increased Use
8-4C2-11: Disposition And Investment Of Revenues
8-4C2-12: Responsibilities Of City Officials
8-4C2-13: Monitoring User Discharges Required
Cross-reference:
   Definitions, see section
8-4A-1 of this chapter
   Penalty, see section
8-4A-9 of this chapter
8-4C2-1: INDUSTRIAL COST RECOVER REQUIRED:
Each industrial user shall pay that portion of any state grant which has been
obtained by the city for the financing of the construction of wastewater
treatment works allocable to the treatment of the wastewater from such user.
Such users shall not include an interest component.
(1989 Code § 11-137)
8-4C2-2: DETERMINATION OF INDUSTRIAL POPULATION EQUIVALENT:
An industrial user’s portion of any state grant shall be based on the
population equivalents attributable to wastewater of such user tributary to the
wastewater treatment works of the city. The population equivalents shall be
determined as follows:
   A.   Volume Population Equivalent: The volume population equivalent equals
the average daily rate of water consumption as determined by the consumption
records of the past year, divided by one hundred (100) gallons per day (the
average domestic water consumption).
   B.   BOD Population Equivalent: The BOD population equivalent equals the
average daily pounds of BOD in the wastewater as determined by the city,
divided by one hundred fifty six (156) pounds of BOD per day (the average per
capita BOD of nonindustrial discharges).
   C.   SS Population Equivalent: The SS population equivalent equals the
average daily pounds of suspended solids in the wastewater from such user as
determined by the city, divided by one hundred thirty three (133) pounds of
suspended solids per day (the average per capita SS of nonindustrial
discharges).
(1989 Code § 11-137)
8-4C2-3: DETERMINATION OF COSTS:
   A.   Cost Per Capita: The dollar cost per capita shall be determined as
follows: total amount of grant, divided by total population, equals cost per
capita.
   B.   Cost For Industrial User: The cost to be recovered from an industrial
user shall be determined as follows: volume population equivalent, plus BOD
population equivalent, plus SS population equivalent, equals population
equivalent. Cost per capita, multiplied times population equivalent, equals
cost for industrial user.
(1989 Code § 11-137)
8-4C2-4: CHARGE FOR COST RECOVERY:
Each year during the industrial cost recovery period, each industrial user of
the treatment works shall pay the cost recovery amount determined by subsection
8-4C2-3B of this article for such industry, divided by the recovery period.
Where an industry is connected to a public sewer after the startup of the
facilities constructed under a state grant, the industry shall pay its portion
of the state grant for each quarter remaining in the recovery period. The
industry will not be required to pay for those quarters of the recovery period
prior to connection to a public sewer.
(1989 Code § 11-137)
8-4C2-5: RECOVERY PERIOD:
The industrial cost recovery period shall be equal to the useful life of the
treatment works which shall be twenty (20) years from 1978, not to exceed
thirty (30) years.
(1989 Code § 11-137)
8-4C2-6: PAYMENT OF BILLS; DELINQUENCIES:
   A.   Due Date; Late Payment Penalty: For the purpose of industrial cost
recovery, the year shall be divided into quarterly periods, to begin on July 1,
October 1, January 1 and March 1. All industrial users of the city shall pay
the cost as determined by section 8-4C2-4 of this article for industrial cost
recovery. Such payments shall be made quarterly on the fifteenth day of the
month immediately following the expiration of the quarterly period for which
service has been supplied, and such charge shall be payable within thirty (30)
days after rendition thereof. If such bills are not paid within such thirty
(30) days, a service charge of ten percent (10%) shall be added thereto.
   B.   Lien Provisions; Disconnection Of Service: If the charges for
industrial cost recovery are not paid within sixty (60) days after the
rendition of that bill, then such service charges shall be deemed and are
hereby declared to be delinquent, and thereafter, such delinquent charge shall
constitute a lien upon real estate for which such sewer services were supplied.
The city clerk is hereby authorized and directed each quarter to file sworn
statements showing such delinquencies in the office of the county recorder of
deeds, and the filing of such statements shall be deemed notice of a lien for
the payment of such charges for sewer service. If the delinquency in the
payment of the recovery cost continues for a period of more than thirty (30)
days, the sewer service shall be discontinued.
(1989 Code § 11-137)
8-4C2-7: INITIAL PAYMENT:
The initial payment made by an industrial user which is connected to a public
sewer after the startup of the treatment works constructed with a state grant
shall be made by the next scheduled due date as defined in subsection 8-4C2-6A
of this article and shall be equal to one-fourth (1/4) of the amount as
determined by section 8-4C2-4 of this article.
(1989 Code § 11-137)
8-4C2-8: ADJUSTMENTS OF CHARGES:
   A.   Strength Of Volume Changes: If there is a change in the strength and/or
volume introduced into the treatment works by an industrial user, as determined
by the previous year’s records, the city shall adjust the user’s portion of any
state grant accordingly.
   B.   Plant Improvement Utilizing State Grant Funds: If there is an expansion
or upgrading of the treatment works utilizing a state grant, each existing
industrial user’s share shall be adjusted accordingly.
(1989 Code § 11-137)
8-4C2-9: NO CHARGE FOR UNUSED OR RESERVED CAPACITY:
An industrial user’s portion of any state grant shall not include any portion
of the grant amount allocable to unused or reserved capacity.
(1989 Code § 11-137)
8-4C2-10: COMMITMENT FOR INCREASED USE:
An industrial user’s portion of any state grant shall include allowance for the
cost of any firm commitment to the city for an increased use by such user.
(1989 Code § 11-137)
8-4C2-11: DISPOSITION AND INVESTMENT OF REVENUES:
   A.   The city shall retain fifty percent (50%) of the amounts recovered from
industrial users. The remainder, together with any interest earned thereon,
shall be returned to the state antipollution fund on an annual basis.
   B.   Eighty percent (80%) of the retained amounts, together with interest
earned thereon, shall be used solely for the eligible costs of the expansion or
reconstruction of treatment works associated with the project and necessary to
meet the requirements of the act and the state. The city, prior to commitment
of the retained amounts, shall obtain written approval of the state
environmental protection agency for any expansion or reconstruction. The
remainder of the retained amounts may be used for such expenditures as the city
deems appropriate.
   C.   Pending use, the grantee shall invest the retained amounts for
reconstruction and expansion in:
      1.   Obligations of the United States government; or
      2.   Obligations guaranteed as to principal and interest by the United
States government or any agency thereof; or
      3.   Shall deposit such amounts in accounts fully collateralized by
obligations of the United States government or by obligations fully guaranteed
as to principal and interest by the United States government or any agency
thereof.
(1989 Code § 11-137)
Cross-reference:
   See definition of “the act” in section
8-4A-1 of this chapter
8-4C2-12: RESPONSIBILITIES OF CITY OFFICIALS:
   A.   City Clerk: The city clerk shall maintain the necessary records for
determination of the user share of the cost and shall provide the billing and
collection services as required by section 8-4C1-2 of this article and
subsection 8-4C2-6A of this article.
   B.   City Treasurer: The city treasurer shall be responsible for the
investment and expenditure of all monies collected for industrial cost recovery
in accordance with section 8-4C2-11 of this article.
(1989 Code § 11-137)
8-4C2-13: MONITORING USER DISCHARGES REQUIRED:
The city shall maintain a program of monitoring industrial user discharges as
the city deems necessary, and as prescribed in article B of this chapter.
Additionally, industrial users shall be monitored at such frequency as deemed
necessary by the city for determination of the population equivalent of the
industrial user. The monitoring data collected shall be used to determine the
population equivalent in accordance with section 8-4C2-2 of this division.
(1989 Code § 11-137)
CHAPTER 5: SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL
Section
8-5-1: Definitions
8-5-2: Nuisance Declared
8-5-3: Accumulation And Storage Of Litter
8-5-4: Collection And Disposal Services; Charges
8-5-5: Container Requirements
8-5-6: Collection Charges
8-5-7: Disposal Of Litter
8-5-8: Landscape Waste
8-5-9: Prohibited Acts
8-5-10: Enforcement
8-5-11: Penalty; Prima Facie Proof
8-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words shall have the following meanings:
DUMPSTER: A metal container of one cubic yard or more in volume with an
attached lid for handling by mechanical means.
GARBAGE: The handling, preparation, cooking, consumption and storage of food
and any other matter of any nature whatsoever subject to decay which may
putrefy or generate noxious or offensive odors, be a food source for rodents,
or may serve as a breeding or feeding place for insects or vermin.
LITTER: Includes garbage and rubbish.
OWNER: Any agent, firm, corporation or person who, alone or jointly or
severally with others, has a legal or equitable interest in the property.
PERSON: Any individual, corporation, firm or any other group acting as a unit.
PUBLIC PLACE OR PUBLIC WAY: Any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys,
public grounds or public buildings.
RECYCLABLES: Newspapers, magazines, catalogues, corrugated cardboard, green/
brown clear glass bottles, tin and aluminum cans, plastic milk bottles and
water jugs, plastic pop bottles, and plastic detergent bottles.
ROADWAY: That portion of a street or highway improved, designed or ordinarily
used for vehicular traffic.
RUBBISH: Nonputrescible solid waste consisting of both combustible and
noncombustible waste, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, metal
cans, yard clippings, dead trees, tree limbs, wood, glass, discarded furniture,
concrete, bricks, crockery, and similar materials. However, “rubbish” shall not
include wood and other materials that are stored and commonly used for fuel.
STRUCTURE: A building or portion of a building of any type.
(1989 Code § 11-196)
8-5-2: NUISANCE DECLARED:
All litter which has been stored, dumped or accumulated in any structure or in
any public way or on any real property, improved or vacant, other than as
provided in this chapter, is hereby declared to constitute a nuisance.
(1989 Code § 11-198)
8-5-3: ACCUMULATION OR STORAGE OF LITTER:
   A.   No person shall store or permit the accumulation of any litter in any
structure, other than in one designed for that purpose, upon any improved or
vacant property or upon any public place or public way in the city, unless
necessary for the operation of a business enterprise lawfully conducted
thereon.
   B.   The owner or occupant of any single-family structure shall have the
responsibility to maintain the private premises free from litter.
   C.   This section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in private
containers.
(1989 Code § 11-199)
8-5-4: COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL SERVICES; CHARGES:
   A.   Residential properties shall be eligible for solid waste collection and
disposal services as set forth in this chapter.
   B.   Duplexes, multi-family dwellings of four (4) units or more and
apartments in conjunction with a business will be deemed commercial and will
not be provided solid waste collection and disposal services under this
chapter.
(1989 Code § 11-201)
8-5-5: CONTAINER REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Number And Capacity: Every structure must have sealable litter
containers in sufficient number and capacity to accommodate and contain all
litter generated and accumulated by occupants of the structure. A container,
other than a dumpster, shall have a capacity of not more than forty five (45)
gallons. No container shall weigh in excess of fifty (50) pounds.
(1989 Code § 11-200)
   B.   Responsibility To Provide Containers:
      1.   Single-Family Dwellings: The occupants of any single-family dwelling
must provide, maintain and keep tightly covered or sealed watertight containers
for all litter; provided that rubbish may be stored in other types of
containers, provided it is not mixed with garbage.
      2.   Multi-Family Dwellings Of Less Than Four Units: The owner of a
multi-family dwelling of less than four (4) units must provide, maintain and
keep tightly covered or sealed watertight containers for all litter; provided
that rubbish may be stored in other types of containers, provided it is not
mixed with garbage.
      3.   a.   Duplexes, Multi-Family Dwellings Of More Than Four Units And
Apartments: The owners of duplexes, multi-family dwellings of four (4) units or
more and owners of apartments must provide and maintain a watertight and
tightly sealed covered or sealed dumpster for all litter.
         b.   The owners of duplexes, multi-family dwellings of four (4) units
or more and apartments must register with the street department office the
number of dwelling units within said structure.
(1989 Code § 11-201)
   C.   Placement Of Containers:
      1.   Single-Family Dwellings: It shall be the duty of all persons
occupying or controlling any single-family dwelling to place containers for
litter either on the alley lot line or on the curb line of the premises on the
day of garbage pick up. However, in no instance shall the placement of litter
at said location be made more than twenty four (24) hours prior to the time of
garbage pick up.
      2.   Multi-Family Dwellings Of Less Than Four Units: In multifamily
dwellings of less than four (4) units, it shall be the duty of the owner to
assure placement of containers for litter either on the alley lot line or on a
curb line of the premises on the day of garbage pick up. However, in no
instance shall litter be placed at said location more than twenty four (24)
hours prior to the scheduled pick up.
      3.   Multi-Family Dwellings Of Four or More Units And Businesses: The
owner or occupant of a multi-family dwelling of four(4) or more units or any
business shall not locate a dumpster or any other container for garbage or
rubbish nearer than one hundred feet (100') to any single-family residential
building unless an application is made to and is granted by the city
superintendent of streets to otherwise place the same on the property.
(1989 Code § 11-202)
   D.   Disturbing Containers Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person,
other than the owner, occupant or members of the family, the owner’s agent,
employees of the city, agents of the city, or garbage contractor employed by
the city to deposit, remove, deface, destroy or disturb litter containers.
(1989 Code § 11-206)
8-5-6: COLLECTION CHARGES:
   A.   Owners will be charged a fee of sixteen dollars ($16.00) per month for
in-city residential collection of garbage, recycling, and landscape wastes, and
thirty two dollars ($32.00) per month for outside-city collection of same, or
must contract privately to have commercial haulers remove said litter.
(1989 Code § 11-203; amd. 2017 Code)
   B.   Bills For Service; Due Date: The fee shall be billed in accordance with
the billing procedures set forth in section
8-1-2 of this title. Payment of this fee, except as otherwise set forth
previously herein, will permit the placement of one litter container for
collection on the day of garbage pick up. Containers bearing recycled items are
not subject to this limitation.
   C.   Garbage Disposal Stickers:
      1.   The third litter container, and all those thereafter, shall be
required to bear a garbage disposal sticker issued by the city (hereinafter
“sticker”) upon that container. If a container is presented for disposal which
requires a sticker and the container does not bear the same, it will not be
accepted for disposal.
(1989 Code § 11-203)
      2.   Stickers for garbage disposal may be obtained at the city clerk’s
office, during normal business hours, and through various businesses located
within the city. The fee for each sticker shall be as provided in the city fee
schedule.
      3.   Any business desiring to provide the retail sale of said stickers
may purchase the same from the city clerk at the cost as provided in the city
fee schedule. Each wholesale purchase shall be in groups of one hundred (100)
stickers or more. The retail sale of stickers shall be as provided in the city
fee schedule.
(1989 Code § 11-203; amd. 2017 Code)
   D.   Waiver Of Charges: Charges for collection may be waived when the owner
or occupant of a residential dwelling unit advises the city street department
that they will not be in residence at the dwelling for a period of at least
three (3) consecutive full calendar months. Charges will be waived for only
those full calendar months the dwelling unit is unoccupied during that time.
(1989 Code § 11-203)
   E.   Disputed Charges: Any garbage and refuse collection customer disputing
any charges or services rendered may have an opportunity to be heard and
present evidence before the city administrative hearing officer if such
customer files a written notice with the city clerk as provided in this title.
(1989 Code § 11-204) (O-21-006, 3-15-2021; O-22-005, 3-21-2022)
8-5-7: DISPOSAL OF LITTER:
   A.   No person shall throw, deposit or dump litter, or hire or cause another
to throw, deposit or dump litter, on any property except in a public landfill.
   B.   The owner of any litter shall be liable for its placement on the
property of others. Proof of ownership of any litter found on any property of
another shall be prima facie evidence at the trial of a violation of this
section. Evidence that the owner of the litter reasonably relied upon his or
her agent to deposit litter in a public landfill shall be an affirmative
defense in any ordinance prosecution.
(1989 Code § 11-205)
8-5-8: LANDSCAPE WASTE:
   A.   Residential Curb Pick Up: The fees for residential curb pick up shall
be as provided in the city fee schedule. Fees will be exempted for major storm
events, as determined by the superintendent of streets.
   B.   Routine Yard Waste:
      1.   Bagged Or Bundled: For routine yard waste, bagged or bundled, the
bags cannot be heavier than fifty (50) pounds. There are no added fees.
      2.   Not Bagged Or Bundled: For routine yard waste unable to be bagged or
bundled, the fees shall be as provided in the city fee schedule.
      3.   Tree Stumps Or Logs: No tree stumps or logs shall be accepted in
excess of eighteen inches (18") in diameter.
      4.   Fees may be declared exempted after major storm events.
(Ord. O-16-002, 4-18-2016; amd. 2017 Code; Ord. O-17-011, 6-5-2017)
   C.   Residential Preparation For Disposal:
      1.   Branches are to be neatly placed and parallel to the curb.
      2.   Unorganized or tangled brush piles will not be collected, and the
resident will be asked to restack the pile.
      3.   Only branches from trees and bushes (up to eight (8) inches in
diameter at the cut end) will be eligible for pick up.
      4.   Branches may be any length, though the ends must be cleanly cut with
no attached root systems.
      5.   Items larger than eight inches (8") in diameter, materials such as
construction wood, branches with nails or spikes, wooden fence pieces/doors,
firewood logs, rose bushes, poison ivy, small hedge/evergreen trimmings, and
yard rakings cannot be mulched and must be disposed of by the resident through
other means.
      6.   Brush pick up at any one residence will be limited to approximately
one hundred (100) square feet of front area along the parkway (approximately
six feet (6') high by seventeen feet (17') long).
      7.   Contractor generated brush will not be collected.
   D.   Disposal Requirements:
      1.   Yard waste is collected from April 1 to December 15 only. A special
two-week collection period for Christmas trees and greenery will be the first
two full weeks in January.
      2.   Smaller brush and yard waste can be placed into biodegradable yard
waste paper bags not to exceed 30 gallons in capacity or 50 pounds in weight.
      3.   Larger brush piles must be bundled using garden string or twine, no
metal wire or plastic ties. The bundle size is restricted to four feet (4') in
length, two feet (2') diameter, and no heavier than fifty (50) pounds. Branches
cannot exceed three inches (3") in diameter.
      4.   Branches or stumps larger than three inches (3") in diameter cannot
be placed in the landscape waste bags; they must be handled with regular
refuse. Weight is limited to a maximum of fifty (50) pounds. Excessive amounts
will incur a charge or require an alternative disposal method.
(Ord. O-16-002, 4-18-2016)
   E.   Contractor Disposal:
      1.   Permit Fees: The permit fees for contractor disposal shall be as
provided in the city fee schedule.
      2.   Logs: Logs must be separated from brush. Logs with any diameter
along their lengths exceeding twenty four inches (24") are prohibited.
      3.   Use Of City Brush Pit:
         a.   Once a permit is issued, contractors will only be able to use the
brush pit during regular hours (eight o’clock (8:00) a.m. to two thirty o’clock
(2:30) p.m., Monday through Friday). The brush pit will be closed on city
observed holidays.
         b.   In addition, contractors are not allowed to use the city’s brush
drop-off on Euclid Avenue.
(Ord. O-17-011, 6-5-2017)
8-5-9: PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   Abandoned Containers: No person shall have on any lot any abandoned or
unattended refrigerator or other similar appliance with a capacity greater than
one and one-half (1-1/2) cubic feet, and which has an airtight door or lid
which may be opened or fastened shut by means of an attached latch, and which
may not be released from the inside.
(1989 Code § 11-208)
   B.   Depositing Litter Onto Public Ways And Property: No person shall sweep
or deposit any litter onto any public place or public way except in public
containers. Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk and
any right of way on their property free of litter.
(1989 Code § 11-209)
   C.   Throwing Litter From Vehicles: No person shall throw or deposit litter
from a vehicle upon any public way or public place.
(1989 Code § 11-210)
   D.   Spilling Loads; Deposits From Tires: No person shall drive or move any
vehicle unless such vehicle is constructed or loaded to prevent any litter or
material from being blown or deposited upon any public way or public place; nor
shall any person drive or move any vehicle whose wheels or tires deposit dirt,
mud, sticky substances, or similar material on a public way or public place.
(1989 Code § 11-211)
Cross-reference:
   Certain nuisances enumerated, see subsection
4-1-3B of this code
   Depositing refuse onto public ways, see section
7-1-3 of this code
8-5-10: ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty of the city police department to enforce the provisions of
this chapter.
(1989 Code § 11-197)
8-5-11: PENALTY; PRIMA FACIE PROOF:
   A.   Penalty: Any person found to have violated any provision of this
chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense, and a separate offense shall
be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues.
   B.   Prima Facie Proof: The fact that litter remains on any premises in the
city in violation of this chapter shall be prima facie evidence that the
occupant of such premises is responsible for the occurring violation. However,
in the event that the property on which the litter is located is vacant, it
shall be prima facie evidence that the owner of such property is responsible
for the violation of this chapter.
(1989 Code § 11-212)
Cross-reference:
   See chapter 1-4A of this code for prepayment fine in lieu of court
appearance
TITLE 9: BUILDING REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1: ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
Section
9-1-1: Permit Requirements
9-1-2: Fees
9-1-3: Enforcement Official
9-1-4: Penalty And Other Remedies
9-1-1: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required: A building permit shall be secured before:
      1.   Work is commenced to erect, enlarge or structurally alter any
building or structure of any kind whatsoever, or before any excavation is dug
for any such purpose.
      2.   Sidewalks, curbings, parkways, streets or any other property of the
city are obstructed, broken, repaired or in any way altered.
   B.   Application For Permit:
      1.   An application for the issuance of a building permit shall be made
to the zoning administrator on such forms as he or she shall prescribe, which
application, among other things, shall contain an accurate and complete
description of the location, extent and dimensions of any proposed work.
      2.   When the application is for the erection, enlargement or alteration
of any building, the application shall contain or there shall be attached
thereto a drawing or plat showing the lot plan and the location of existing
buildings, if any, on such lot, and the location, extent and dimensions of the
proposed construction or alteration. However, nothing contained in this
subsection B2 shall be construed as requiring the employment of an architect to
prepare the application or plans required by this subsection. The application
shall be kept in the office of the zoning administrator.
   C.   Issuance Of Permit: Within a reasonable time after such application has
been made, the zoning administrator shall issue a building permit if the
application and the proposed construction or work complies with the provisions
of this title and with any zoning regulations and all other building and health
laws and provisions of this code, which are now or shall be hereafter in force.
   D.   Copy On Site: The job copy of the building permit shall be kept at the
place of construction at all times until the work is completed.
Cross-reference:
   See section
10-11-19 of this code
9-1-2: FEES:
The fees for this title shall be as provided in the city fee schedule.
9-1-3: ENFORCEMENT OFFICIAL:
It shall be the duty of the zoning administrator to enforce this title.
9-1-4: PENALTY AND OTHER REMEDIES:
   A.   Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply
with, or who resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this title
shall be fined as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this code.
   B.   In case any building or structure is erected, constructed,
reconstructed, altered, repaired, converted or maintained, or any building,
structure or land is used in violation of this title, or if any sidewalk,
parkway, curbing or street is obstructed, broken, repaired or altered in
violation of this title, the proper authorities of the city, in addition to
other remedies, may institute any appropriate action or proceeding to prevent
such unlawful erection, alteration, repair, conversion, maintenance or use to
restrain, correct or abate such violation, to prevent the occupancy of such
building, structure or land, or to prevent any illegal act, conduct, business
or use in or about such premises.
Cross-reference:
   See chapter 1-4A of this code for prepayment fine in lieu of court
appearance

9-5-1 of this chapter shall be amended as follows:
Section A101.1, insert city of Princeton.
9-6-3: POLLINATOR GARDENS:
Pollinator gardens shall be allowed to cover a maximum area of 50 square feet
in front yards, and may occupy up to 50% of a rear yard area. Pollinator
gardens must be 4'-0" linear distance from public properly. Pollinator gardens
shall only be deemed as compliant if all plants in the dedicated area arc of
the approved pollinator species for the State of Illinois as defined by the
Department of Natural Resources. Pollinator gardens shall be maintained
annually in order to prevent unwanted and non-native species from inhabiting
the dedicated pollinator garden area as defined by this ordinance. Code
enforcement officers have the ability and right to deem a pollinator garden as
compliant or non-compliant, and can enforce property maintenance code in the
instance that a planting area does not meet the standards of pollinator gardens
as outlined by this ordinance.
(Ord. O-25-003, 1-20-2025)

CHAPTER 9: BUILDING AND LOT NUMBERS
Section
9-9-1: Numbers Required
9-9-2: Method Of Numbering
9-9-3: Fractional Lots
9-9-4: Violations; Penalties
9-9-1: NUMBERS REQUIRED:
All lots and parts of lots and buildings lying and being within the corporate
limits of the city shall be designated by street numbers in the following
manner: All lots, fractional lots and buildings abutting on the south and east
sides of the streets and avenues of the city shall be numbered with odd
numbers; and all lots and parts of lots and buildings abutting on the north and
west sides of the streets and avenues shall be numbered with even numbers.
(1989 Code § 11-112)
9-9-2: METHOD OF NUMBERING:
   A.   On all streets and avenues north of North Street, and which run north
and south, the numbering of the lots, fractional lots, and buildings abutting
on such streets and avenues shall commence at the points where such streets and
avenues intersect North Street, with the numbers one hundred (100) on the west
sides, and one hundred one (101) on the east sides thereof, and shall be
continued thence northerly, giving numbers consecutively, in each block, to
each twenty feet (20') of frontage in such block, except as stated in this
chapter. The lots, fractional lots and buildings in each block, continuing
northward to the city limits, shall be numbered in like manner, commencing in
each block with the first even and odd numbers of the next succeeding hundred.
   B.   On all streets and avenues south of North Street, and which run north
and south, the numbering of the lots, fractional lots and buildings abutting on
such streets and avenues shall commence at the points where such streets and
avenues intersect North Street, with the numbers one hundred (100) on the west
sides, and one hundred one (101) on the east sides thereof, and shall be
continued thence southerly, giving numbers consecutively, in each block, to
each twenty feet (20') of frontage in such block, except as stated in this
chapter. The lots, fractional lots, and buildings in each block, continuing
southward to the city limits, shall be numbered in like manner, commencing in
each block with the first even and odd numbers of the next succeeding hundred.
   C.   On all streets and avenues east of Main Street, and which run east and
west, the numbering of the lots and fractional lots and buildings abutting on
such streets and avenues shall commence at the points where such streets and
avenues intersect Main Street, with the numbers one hundred (100) on the north
sides, and one hundred one (101) on the south sides thereof, and shall be
continued thence easterly, giving numbers consecutively in each block to each
twenty feet (20') of frontage in such block, except as stated in this chapter.
The lots, fractional lots and buildings in each block, continuing eastward to
the city limits, shall be numbered in like manner, commencing in each block
with the first even and odd numbers of the next succeeding hundred.
   D.   On all streets and avenues west of Main Street, and which run east and
west, the numbering of the lots, fractional lots and buildings abutting on such
streets and avenues shall commence at the points where such streets and avenues
intersect Main Street, with the numbers one hundred (100) on the north sides,
and one hundred one (101) on the south sides thereof, and shall be continued
thence westerly, giving numbers consecutively in each block, to each twenty
feet (20') of frontage in such block, except as stated in this chapter. The
lots, fractional lots and buildings in each block, continuing westward to the
city limits, shall be numbered in like manner, commencing in each block with
the first even and odd numbers of the next succeeding hundred.
(1989 Code § 11-113)
9-9-3: FRACTIONAL LOTS:
The provisions of section
9-9-2 of this chapter requiring each twenty feet (20') of frontage to be given
a number mean that such twenty feet (20') shall include or exclude small
fractions more or less than twenty feet (20'), if such fractions do not exceed
ten feet (10'); but if any fraction over twenty feet (20') shall be ten feet
(10') or more, then such fraction shall be given a one-half (1/2) number
between the numbers of the lots, fractional lots or buildings, on either side
thereof, such fractions to be determined by ownership; if the entire frontage
of any owner or owners shall be ten feet (10') or less, such lots, fractional
lots, or buildings on such frontage shall be given a one-half (1/2) number in
like manner; provided, that if any owner has a frontage which shall require
more than one number, the smallest of such numbers so required which would be
properly applicable to the building or buildings already on such frontage shall
be used, and the remaining numbers shall not be used until other buildings
shall be erected on such frontage.
(1989 Code § 11-114)
9-9-4: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
   A.   Any person who shall, by posting a number or numbers on any lot,
fractional lot or building in the city, attempt to designate such lot,
fractional lot, or building by any other number than that which is in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter, shall be subject to a penalty
as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this code.
   B.   Any person who shall, in any manner, maliciously mar, deface, injure or
remove any number or numbers properly placed on any lot, fractional lot, or
building in the city in accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall be
subject to penalty as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this code.
(1989 Code § 11-111)
TITLE 10: LAND DEVELOPMENT CODE
CHAPTER 1: INTRODUCTORY PROVISIONS
Section
10-1-1: Title
10-1-2: Effective Date
10-1-3: Authority
10-1-4: Applicability And Jurisdiction
10-1-5: Minimum Requirements
10-1-6: Purpose And Intent
10-1-7: Flood Warning And Disclaimer Of Liability
10-1-8: Zoning Map
10-1-9: Interpretation Of Zoning District Boundaries
10-1-10: Word Usage And Construction Of Language
10-1-11: Conflicting Provisions
10-1-12: Transitional Provisions
10-1-13: Severability
10-1-1: TITLE:
This title will be known and cited as the LAND DEVELOPMENT CODE OF PRINCETON,
ILLINOIS. References herein to “this title” will be interpreted as referring to
the land development code.
(Ord. O-65-06-08-07, 8-7-2006 as revised 3-2016)
10-1-2: EFFECTIVE DATE:
The provisions of this title become effective on October 1, 2006.
(Ord. O-65-06-08-07, 8-7-2006 as revised 3-2016)
10-1-3: AUTHORITY:
This title is adopted under the statutory authority conferred by 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11.
(Ord. O-65-06-08-07, 8-7-2006 as revised 3-2016)
10-1-4: APPLICABILITY AND JURISDICTION:
This title applies to all lands and waters within the corporate limits of the
city. All structures and land uses constructed or commenced and all
enlargements of, additions to, changes in and relocations of existing
structures and uses are subject to the requirements of this title.
(Ord. O-65-06-08-07, 8-7-2006 as revised 3-2016)
10-1-5: MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS:
The standards in this title are minimum requirements. Other local, state and
federal regulations may also apply. The issuance of any permit, certificate or
approval in accordance with the standards and requirements of this title does
not relieve the recipient of such permit, certificate or approval from the
responsibility of complying with all other applicable requirements.
(Ord. O-65-06-08-07, 8-7-2006 as revised 3-2016)
10-1-6: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
The purpose of this title is to promote the public health, safety and general
welfare of existing and future residents of the city by:
   A.   Implementing the comprehensive plan;
   B.   Classifying land within the city into zoning districts;
   C.   Regulating the location and use of all structures, lands and waters;
   D.   Regulating the intensity of uses and structures through building
coverage, density and dimensional standards;
   E.   Ensuring protection from fire, flood and other dangers;
   F.   Lessening congestion and promoting the safety and efficiency of streets
and highways;
   G.   Improving pedestrian safety;
   H.   Providing adequate privacy, light, air, sanitation, and drainage;
   I.   Preventing overcrowding and avoiding undue population concentration;
   J.   Facilitating the adequate provision of public facilities and utilities;
   K.   Providing adequate and aesthetically pleasing stormwater management
facilities;
   L.   Stabilizing and protecting property values;
   M.   Furthering the appropriate use of land and conservation of natural
resources;
   N.   Maintaining and enhancing the aesthetic appearance and physical design
of the city;
   O.   Encouraging the effective use of signs as a means of communication for
businesses, organizations and individuals, and minimizing the possible adverse
effects of signs on nearby public and private property;
   P.   Ensuring sound development and community growth by establishing minimum
standards for subdivision design;
   Q.   Promoting aesthetically pleasing development by establishing minimum
standards for installation of landscaping and screening materials;
   R.   Minimizing the adverse impacts of noise, dust, glare and other
objectionable activities or impacts;
   S.   Promoting the development of land for the highest possible use and
protecting against deterioration and obsolescence that would adversely affect
the living environment or tax base;
   T.   Providing common grounds of understanding and a sound working
relationship between the city and developers and to safeguard the interests of
the homeowner, the subdivider, the investor and the city;
   U.   Managing growth within the city by concentrating development within the
effective operating range of existing public utilities and improvements;
   V.   Causing the cost of design and installation of improvements in new,
platted subdivisions to be borne by the persons purchasing the lots rather than
by any direct or indirect burden upon existing property owners beyond the
limits of the subdivision;
   W.   Coordinating new subdivision design with the design of the city as a
whole to allow for the proper capacity of all types of improvements on the
basis of an orderly sequence of subdivisions as a part of neighborhoods and
neighborhoods as a part of the community;
   X.   Securing the rights of the public with respect to public lands and
waters;
   Y.   Improving land records by establishing standards for surveys and plats;
and
   Z.   Providing for the administration and enforcement of this title and
providing penalties for its violation.
(Ord. O-65-06-08-07, 8-7-2006 as revised 3-2016)
10-1-7: FLOOD WARNING AND DISCLAIMER OF LIABILITY:
The degree of flood protection required by this title is considered reasonable
for regulatory purposes and is based on engineering and scientific methods of
study. Larger floods may occur on rare occasions or the flood height may be
increased by manmade or natural causes. This title does not imply that
development either inside or outside of floodplain areas will be free from
flooding or flood damage. This title does not create liability on the part of
the city or any officer or employee thereof, or the federal emergency
management agency, for any flood damage that may result from reliance on this
title or any administrative decision made lawfully thereunder.
(Ord. O-65-06-08-07, 8-7-2006 as revised 3-2016)
10-1-8: ZONING MAP:
   A.   Adoption: The location and boundaries of the zoning districts
established by this title are shown on the map entitled “Zoning Map Of The City
Of Princeton, Illinois”. That map, together with all notations, references,
data and other information shown on the map, is hereby adopted as part of this
title. The map must remain on file and available to the public in the office of
the city zoning administrator.
   B.   Annual Revision: The city council will publish a revised zoning map no
later than March 31 of each year clearly showing the zoning district
classifications of the city for the preceding calendar year. If in any calendar
year no changes are made to zoning classifications or city boundaries, the city
is not required to publish a zoning map for that calendar year.
(Ord. O-65-06-08-07, 8-7-2006 as revised 3-2016)
10-1-9: INTERPRETATION OF ZONING DISTRICT BOUNDARIES:
Rules for the interpretation of zoning district boundaries are as follows:
   A.   Zoning district boundaries will be construed to follow:
      1.   Corporate limits;
      2.   United States public land survey lines;
      3.   Property lines;
      4.   Centerlines of streets, highways, alleys, easements, railroad rights
of way or extensions of such lines;
      5.   Soil mapping unit lines.
   B.   Vacation of public streets and alleys will cause the vacated land to be
automatically placed in the same district as the abutting side to which the
vacated land reverts.
   C.   Annexations to or consolidations with the city subsequent to the
effective date specified in section
10-1-2 of this chapter will be classified in the most restrictive zoning
district of contiguous property within the city. However, parcels consisting of
twenty (20) or more acres, and presently used for agricultural purposes, may,
at the petitioner’s election, be zoned agricultural district upon annexation.
(Ord. O-65-06-08-07, 8-7-2006 as revised 3-2016)
10-1-10: WORD USAGE AND CONSTRUCTION OF LANGUAGE:
   A.   Meanings And Intent: All provisions, terms, phrases and expressions
used in this title will be construed according to the purpose and intent set
out in section
10-1-6 of this chapter.
   B.   Headings, Illustrations And Text: In case of any difference of meaning
or implication between the text of this title and any heading, drawing, table,
figure, or illustration, the text controls.
   C.   Lists And Examples: Unless otherwise specifically indicated, lists of
items or examples that use terms such as “including”, “such as”, or similar
language are intended to provide examples; not to be exhaustive lists of all
possibilities.
   D.   Computation Of Time: The time in which an act is to be done will be
computed by excluding the first day and including the last day. If the last day
is a Saturday, Sunday, or holiday observed by the city, that day will be
excluded.
   E.   References To Other Regulations, Publications And Documents: Whenever
reference is made to a resolution, ordinance, statute, regulation, or document,
that reference will be construed as referring to the most recent edition of
such resolution, ordinance, statute, regulation, or document or to the relevant
successor document, unless otherwise expressly stated.
   F.   Delegation Of Authority: Whenever a provision appears requiring the
head of a department or another officer or employee of the city to perform an
act or duty, that provision will be construed as authorizing the department
head or officer to delegate that responsibility to others over whom they have
authority.
   G.   Technical And Nontechnical Terms: Words and phrases will be construed
according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words
and phrases that may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law
will be construed and understood according to such meaning. (See also chapter
14, “Terminology”, of this title.)
   H.   Public Officials And Agencies: All public officials, bodies, and
agencies to which references are made are those of the city, unless otherwise
expressly provided.
   I.   Mandatory And Discretionary Terms: The words “shall”, “will” and “must”
are mandatory. The words “may” and “should” are discretionary and advisory
terms.
   J.   Conjunctions: Unless the context clearly suggests the contrary,
conjunctions will be interpreted as follows:
      1.   “And” indicates that all connected items, conditions, provisions or
events apply; and
      2.   “Or” indicates that one or more of the connected items, conditions,
provisions or events may apply.
   K.   Tenses And Plurals: Words used in one tense (past, present or future)
include all other tenses, unless the context clearly indicates the contrary.
The singular includes the plural, and the plural includes the singular.
(Ord. O-65-06-08-07, 8-7-2006 as revised 3-2016)
10-1-11: CONFLICTING PROVISIONS:
   A.   Conflict With State Or Federal Regulations: If the provisions of this
title are inconsistent with those of the state or federal government, the more
restrictive provision will control, to the extent permitted by law.
   B.   Conflict With Other City Regulations: If the provisions of this title
are inconsistent with one another, or if they conflict with provisions found in
other adopted city ordinances, the more restrictive provision will control. No
text amendment, variance or condition on a special use permit or any other
development approval under this title may diminish the provisions of any other
more restrictive city ordinance.
   C.   Conflict With Private Easements, Agreements, Covenants Or Restrictions:
This title is not intended to annul or interfere with any private easement,
agreement, covenant, restriction or other private legal relationship. The city
is responsible for enforcing this title; it does not enforce private
agreements, easements, covenants or restrictions except those specifically
required for the administration and enforcement of this title, even where the
private agreements are more restrictive than the provisions of this title.
(Ord. O-65-06-08-07, 8-7-2006 as revised 3-2016)
10-1-12: TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   Violations Continue: Any violation of the previous zoning or
subdivision regulations of the city will continue to be a violation under this
title and will be subject to penalties and enforcement under chapter 13 of this
title, unless the use, development, construction or other activity is
consistent with the express terms of this title, in which case, enforcement
action will cease, except to the extent of collecting penalties for violations
that occurred before the effective date specified in section
10-1-2 of this chapter.
   B.   Completion Of Development:
      1.   Permits Issued Before Effective Date: Any building, development or
sign for which a permit was lawfully issued before the effective date specified
in section
10-1-2 of this chapter may be completed in conformance with the issued permit.
If the building, development or sign is not completed within the time allowed
under the original permit, then the building, development or sign may be
constructed, completed or occupied only in strict compliance with this title.
      2.   Preliminary Plats Approved Before Effective Date: If a preliminary
plat was approved before the effective date specified in section
10-1-2 of this chapter, final plat approval may be granted in accordance with
the preliminary plat. If a final plat is not approved within the time
requirements specified by prior ordinance or a schedule included with the
preliminary plat approval, the plan commission may grant one or more
extensions. The total time of all extensions may not exceed one year. If a
final plat is not approved within the time required, including any extensions,
then the completion of the subdivision and construction of buildings may only
occur if the final plat complies with all requirements of this title. If the
final plat is not in compliance with this title, then a modified final plat
must be submitted and approved pursuant to the procedures of chapter 11 of this
title.
   C.   Special (Conditional) Uses:
      1.   Any use that was legally established before the effective date
specified in section
10-1-2 of this chapter without a conditional use permit and which after the
effective date is located within a zoning district that requires a special use
permit for the subject use under this title, will be issued a special use
permit without following the procedures of section
10-11-5 of this title. Any use that was legally established prior to the
special use permit requirement of this title for the subject use in the zoning
district in question will similarly be issued a special use permit without
following the procedures of section
10-11-5 of this title. Expansions and modifications of such uses will be
subject to section
10-11-5 of this title. Even if a special use permit is issued pursuant to this
section, those uses or structures that do not comply with applicable standards
of this title, including the use regulations of chapter 3 of this title, will
be deemed nonconforming and be subject to the regulations of chapter 12 of this
title.
      2.   Any use that was legally established before the effective date
specified in section
10-1-2 of this chapter with a conditional use permit and which after the
effective date is located within a zoning district that requires a special use
permit for the subject use, may continue to be operated under the terms of the
original conditional use permit and will hereby be referred to as a special
use. The use will be subject to all applicable standards of this title,
including the use standards of chapter 3 of this title and the nonconformity
regulations of chapter 12 of this title. Expansions and modifications of such
uses will be subject to section
10-11-5 of this title.
      3.   Any use that was legally established before the effective date
specified in section
10-1-2 of this chapter with a conditional use permit and which after the
effective date is located within a zoning district that does not require a
special use permit for the subject use, will continue to be subject to all
applicable standards of this title, including the use standards of chapter 3 of
this title and the nonconformity regulations of chapter 12 of this title.
(Ord. O-65-06-08-07, 8-7-2006 as revised 3-2016)
10-1-13: SEVERABILITY:
If any court of competent jurisdiction rules any provision of this title
invalid, that ruling will not affect any provision of this title not
specifically included in the judgment. If any court of competent jurisdiction
rules invalid the application of any provision of this title to a particular
property, building other structure, or use, that ruling will not affect the
application of this title to any property, building other structure, or use not
specifically included in the judgment.
(Ord. O-65-06-08-07, 8-7-2006 as revised 3-2016)
CHAPTER 2: ZONING DISTRICTS
Section
10-2-1: Residential Districts
10-2-2: Commercial Districts
